HEADLINE: Medicine Promotes Itself, With Professional Help

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
"WE'RE on the phone 40 hours a week for him; we mail out videos, press kits, action photos; we give him an angle, a special hook," exults Lilly Lipton, a public relations consultant in Studio City, Calif. "He is a celebrity. He is!"
Is her client an actor? A rock star? Maybe a rising politician? No. He is Dr. Ian R. Brown, a surgeon. Thanks to Ms. Lipton's aggressive promotion, Dr. Brown says, he has appeared on dozens of television programs from the news to "Entertainment Tonight" to "Geraldo." As a result, his cosmetic surgery practice is thriving. 
 "They tell me there's a recession now, but I'm not feeling it," he said. "Because of public relations I've gotten a lot of new patients, and also some hostility from other doctors."
Once shunned by doctors as crass and unprofessional, marketing and public relations have now been increasingly accepted as a cornerstone of a successful practice. In an era of economic hard times, as hospitals and doctors compete for paying patients, more and more are promoting themselves to prospective customers.
Critics worry that it encourages unnecessary procedures, driving up the nation's health costs and may sometimes be dangerous when it leads patients to doctors whose marketing budgets outweigh their professional skills.
While few doctors and hospitals rely on outright advertising, many embrace public relations. The P.R. trend is most pronounced in the West, South and Southwest but is noticeable around the country.
Ms. Lipton estimates that 60 percent of doctors in the Los Angeles area do P.R. In New York, "virtually 100 percent" of hospitals have taken on full-time public relations staff members, including the most staid ivory tower institutions, said Howard J. Rubenstein, president of the huge public relations firm that bears his name.
Rubenstein Associates, known for representing celebrities like Donald Trump, now writes news releases and handles news media coverage for about 20 hospitals in the New York area, including New York University Medical Center and the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. While Mr. Rubenstein said he had represented hospitals from time to time in the last two decades, the volume has sharply increased in the last three to five years.
"It used to be just plastic surgeons and dermatologists, but now all sorts of specialists and every little community hospital is jumping in," said Dr. Arnold J. Relman, editor emeritus of The New England Journal of Medicine. "I think it's unfortunate, but medicine has come to be regarded as a business where the name of the game is to sell."
Health-care experts say that promoting medical services in the same spirit as promoting running shoes or laundry detergent poses hazards for patients. The glossy brochures and hard-sell phone calls can become the basis of magazine articles or news segments that seem objective but contain subtle biases. When a public relations agency surveyed 2,500 editors and reporters around the country, it found that 90 percent of ideas for health articles had originated with a public relations person, far higher than the 75 percent of entertainment articles and programs that the survey said were suggested by public relations firms.
While a public relations agency obviously has a vested interest in showing the effectiveness of P.R., experts say the trend is real and troublesome.
"The public should know that most of what they see on the evening news is there because a publicist has pushed it, not necessarily because it is the best treatment," said Dr. Harold Ravins, a Los Angeles dentist who is one of Ms. Lipton's clients. "Marketing is about money, and some treatments that should be promoted in terms of health are not."
Worse still, experts say, materials released by public relations agents often promote marginal or unnecessary care and may be misleading.
For example, when a community hospital publicizes its new mammography equipment, it "suggests that the facility is offering something special or of higher quality, which it isn't," Dr. Relman said. "And promotion often plays on the fears of patients: 'How do you know you don't have prostate cancer? Come to our clinic and be checked out.' "
 
Ethics of Marketing
 Many doctors insist that marketing medicine can be done ethically. Dr. Neil Baum, a New Orleans urologist, quietly began promoting his fledgling practice in the mid-1980's and says he reluctantly went public in 1988, when the American Medical Association newspaper asked him to write a monthly marketing column.
"Not long ago you would get kicked out of the medical societies for doing this and I was worried about losing the respect of my colleagues," Dr. Baum said. He has since become something of a marketing guru and is now booked to speak at medical meetings seven months in advance.
Trying to carve out a niche at a hospital with 13 other urologists, Dr. Baum found business inspiration in H. Ross Perot's formula for success: find unmet needs in the market; learn the industry cold; fill those needs.
Realizing that 5 million American men suffer from impotence that could be treated with surgery and knowing that only about 50,000 had been operated on, Dr. Baum began promoting his expertise in this field. He took on another taboo medical problem, incontinence, as well. He spoke before Rotary clubs, called local television stations and wrote articles for magazines and bulletins for the elderly. One such article generated 50 referrals and 5 operations, for an immediate added income of more than $10,000.
"I see my practice as a shopping cart," Dr. Baum said. "The patients in the practice area are like items in the cart. The goal of marketing is to let those outside know what you do and how to get to you, and I think that can be done ethically."
 
A Once-Unthinkable Idea
 Twenty years ago, a debate about medical marketing would have been unthinkable; both the American Medical Association and the American Dental Association strictly forbade advertising and promotional activities.
But in 1975, the Supreme Court ruled that antitrust law prohibited the American Bar Association from regulating the business practices of lawyers. Fearing lawsuits from entrepreneurial doctors and dentists, the medical societies dropped their stand.
"I'm sure the major medical organization are very unhappy with the trend, but they are too timid to do anything," Dr. Relman said.
In fact, attitudes as well as laws have changed.
"When I used to tell doctors that I could get them in tabloids, they'd say 'Oh no,' " said Ms. Lipton, who is the director of a company called the Public Information Network. "Now they're thrilled."
Dr. Robert Kotler, a Los Angeles plastic surgeon, has used four or five different public relations agencies to promote various parts of his practice. "Sure there can be too much hype," he said, "but people have to have a little bit of reserve about what they're going to obtain, whether in dishwashers or in health care."
For many doctors, particularly in places with a surplus of doctors in a given specialty, the impetus is primarily financial.
As a result, the recession has been a boon for medical public relations. "As doctors and institutions are squeezed economically, they find that P.R. is more and more important," Mr. Rubenstein said. "They have to be more creative in telling their story."
But if money is the motive for some doctors, others who market their practices describe themselves as educators who use public relations to inform patients about new techniques.
Still others clearly enjoy the spotlight. "In the long run I hope it will have an impact on my practice, and I would like more name recognition with the general public," said Dr. Marvin Karp, who specializes in musculoskeletal injuries in Los Angeles. "But also I though it would be fun to dabble in the media, maybe even have my own talk show someday."
The procedures and tests most heavily promoted are elective. Also, experts say that doctors who invest heavily in promotion are more likely to have unusual practices or training, so that they fall outside of traditional referral patterns.
For example, both Dr. Kotler and Dr. Brown are head and neck surgeons who subsequently specialized in facial cosmetic surgery and now limit their practices to this field; they are not plastic surgeons. Although they can legitimately perform a wide variety of cosmetic operations from nose jobs to face lifts, they would not be recommended by groups like the American Society for Plastic and Reconstructive Surgeons.
"The societies are so cliquish," Ms. Lipton said.
But today, even the most established, mainstream medical institutions frequently hire layer upon layer of public relations help, with hospitals represented by one firm and departments or individual doctors by another.
For such institutions, the goal is often to attract insured customers to prestigious practices and hospitals that are nonetheless in financial distress because of a heavy load of Medicaid and nonpaying patients. Also, academic medical centers are increasingly dependent on donations, which in a tight economy are felt to be closely tied to a strong public image.
Public relations consultants offer their clients a wide variety of services, for fees ranging from $1,500 to $5,000 a month. Mr. Rubenstein said his firm had been asked at various times to promote a new wing, to advise on a fund raiser, to write employee manuals or to prepare releases to news organizations. Such releases often appear on the hospital's own stationery, to disguise the involvement of a paid public relations firm.
"P.R. was such anathema in the medical world for so many years that a lot is still done very quietly," said Anthony Mora, who heads Anthony Mora Associates, a medical public relations firm in Los Angeles.
For individual doctors, public relations agents will often arrange for television or radio appearances and provide training to make sure they are up to the task. Ms. Lipton said she frequently started her clients on local radio talk shows or a cable show she produces to help them gain confidence.
In contrast, Dr. Baum advises a do-it-yourself strategy. "I don't want anyone going out saying I am the best urologist or making unrealistic promises," he says. "After all, you are not marketing Donald Trump. This is much more delicate."
His office has adopted what he calls "the Disney approach." He puts out a newsletter, receptionists use prospective patients' names twice during phone calls and banners carrying motivational statements have supplanted medical degrees on the walls.
When Time magazine described a new screening test for prostate cancer last spring, Dr. Baum photocopied the article and sent it out to his patients with the next billing cycle, with a note saying, "We offer this!" Dr. Baum acknowledges that urologists are divided about the utility of the test for general screening, but he believes that every man over 50 should have it.
"There isn't a doctor in America who can't market himself if he uses a little common sense and makes some observations from industry," Dr. Baum said. And displaying promotional flair, he added that his new book, "Marketing Your Clinical Practice" (Aspen Publishers, 1991), could show them how.

HEADLINE: The Recession, as Seen From 1993

 BODY:
Excerpts from news conference in June 1993 with Thomas Foley, Democrat and Speaker of the House, and Newt Gingrich, House Republican whip.
Reporter: Back in December 1991 the economy was sagging and threatening to get much worse. The number of people working fell an astonishing 250,000 in one month. Now, 18 months later, the economy's still stagnating. Looking back, Mr. Gingrich, why did you propose tax subsidies on retirement savings of the rich? 
 Gingrich: Because saving spurs growth.
Reporter: But wouldn't your plan have lowered consumer spending, meaning lower sales and more layoffs during the recession?
Gingrich: Well, Republicans believe tax cuts stimulate growth.
Reporter: But could a tax cut like that stimulate growth anywhere near fast enough to fight recession?
Gingrich: Oh, I'm sure there must be some economist who thinks it could have done so.
Reporter: Well, you also proposed a cut in the tax rate on capital gains. I can understand the benefit of making new investment more profitable. But you also would have cut taxes on sales of everything old. Instead of lining rich people's pockets, why didn't you limit the cut to future investment?
Gingrich: Well, you have a point, but even so, the tax code is unfair to investors.
Reporter: Is that why many of your Republican colleagues favored indexing capital gains -- so that only price increases above inflation would be taxed?
Gingrich: Of course, That's only fair.
Reporter: But it sounds as though that would distort investment. Unless you also indexed interest payments and depreciation allowances, people would be driven to invest where taxes are low, not where productivity is high.
Gingrich: Let me get back to you about that.
Reporter: Mr. Foley, Looking back again to December 1991, weren't Democrats embarrassed by pushing so hard for permanent tax cuts for middle-class families?
Foley: No. They pushed hard because they wanted to fight the recession.
Reporter: But why raise the long-term deficit by fighting a temporary recession with permanent tax cuts?
Foley: Maybe that's not such a hot idea. But some Democrats proposed offsetting middle-class tax cuts by raising taxes on the rich.
Reporter: But those proposed tax cuts were tiny, and had to be. There aren't enough rich people.
Foley: Yes, but there were also proposals to offset the tax cuts with delayed cuts in defense. That would have meant instant tax relief and no long-term rise in the deficit. Nifty, no?
Reporter: I don't follow you. Congress is already required to make huge spending cuts under the budget law. If next year's defense cuts had been pledged to pay for previous middle-class tax cuts, wouldn't Congress have to make massive cuts in education, research and every other public investment?
Foley and Gingrich: You forget that the middle class had suffered stagnant incomes for more than a decade and deserved a break.
Reporter: But that wasn't because of taxes. It was because of low productivity growth, no? In the end, did Congress do anything to solve either need, to fight the recession or spur long-run investment and growth?
Foley and Gingrich: Well, no, not really.
Reporter: Can either of you guess why the economy is stagnant 18 months later?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

LENGTH: 246 words

HEADLINE: Russian Farms Need More Than Privatization;
Women Keep It Going

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"No Matryoshkas Need Apply" by Yelena Khanga (Op-Ed, Nov. 25) presents Soviet women as either pretty, young and dreaming of becoming "high-class call girls" or ugly, old and doomed to do boring, dirty jobs. 
 There are a lot of women in between. It is thanks to Soviet women that what used to be the Soviet Union is still functioning -- despite a 1,000 percent annual inflation and empty store shelves. It is women who stand for hours in lines, keep their houses tidy, their children healthy and the families surviving. Men have given up. All they can do with the country in tailspin is watch political debates on television and contemplate the fate of Mother Russia. About the only lines men stand in are lines for vodka. Their response to the everyday struggle for survival is swearing and retreat to the nearest couch.
It is true that Soviet society is very sexist, has no feminist movement, its "social behavior is 100 years behind" American behavior, and the majority of Soviet leaders and politicians you see on television are men. But television and some opinion polls of teen-agers do not represent the society.
Women and men in my country are both in dire straits -- but under the surface it is women who make the survival of the society possible, though they might talk about it less than men do.
 
ANYA YERMOLENKO
Denver, Dec. 3, 1991
 
The writer, a Soviet journalist working in the United States, reports for KCNC-TV, Denver.

LENGTH: 406 words

HEADLINE: If They Remember How to Be Democrats

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Tom Wicker's right-to-the-point Dec. 1 column, "Where the Ducks Are" -- a reference to the need for the Democrats in 1992 to seek votes in states like California, Michigan and Illinois, rather than the South, to "go hunting where the ducks are" -- gives a sound analysis of what the results might have been if the Democrats had adopted a different number strategy in the 1988 election. Surprisingly, however, Mr. Wicker omits any mention of another vital element in the Presidential election fortunes of the Democrats. 
 The failure of the Democratic Party to win back the Presidency lies both in the mistaken numbers approach, the Southern strategy, and in the message adopted by recent candidates. Democrats will not reoccupy the White House until they begin to talk and act like Democrats instead of warmed-over Republicans.
That message should now be abundantly clear from the results of the special Senate election in Pennsylvania. Harris Wofford's campaign message was a clarion call to do something about the condition of society. In that electoral case, the emphasis was on the dismal state of the nation's health care.
The other issues that concern Americans can convey electoral messages just as potent if delivered ringingly and without equivocation:
Too many Americans are functionally illiterate. The condition of our schools and the ability of teachers to teach has declined to dangerous levels, while Washington talks about the schools but withdraws financial support for them.
Too many Americans are unemployed and dependent for bare survival on unemployment insurance (and that will run out, even as extended, if the recession continues much longer) and welfare. Too many Americans are homeless, a condition that has worsened as the Federal Government has withdrawn from the housing business.
Too many Americans are breathing tainted air, drinking chancy water and eating food that was grown on questionable soil. Too many Americans live in cities that struggle to survive as the Federal Government has turned away from urban blight.
Too many Americans are disheartened and look for racial, ethnic, gender or other scapegoats because no one has addressed, and given hope for solving, the real problems that are facing the nation.
The Democrats can win if they know where the ducks are -- and if they begin to talk and lead like Democrats.
 
RICHARD C. SACHS
New York, Dec. 2, 1991

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Mostly Unchanged

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved erratically but ended mostly unchanged yesterday, as credit market participants struggled to sort out remarks made in Washington by David Mullins, vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.
In a speech delivered at the National Economists Club, Mr. Mullins gave an essentially upbeat economics assessment, saying that the Fed's persistent reductions in short-term interest rates since mid-1990 should produce a pickup in economic activity by the middle of next year. 
 Echoing a theme that was embraced last week by the Treasury, Secretary, Nicholas F. Brady, Mr. Mullins said the idea of shifting Treasury borrowings toward shorter maturities and away from long-term bonds was worth further study.
Discussion about that subject has circulated through the market for the last six weeks or more. With the spread, or difference, between long-term bond yields and rates on short-term bills and notes at record levels, some economists have suggested that the Treasury cut its issuance of 30-year bonds as a way to lower long-term interest rates and stimulate the economy.
 
An Upset to Traders
 The possibility that Washington might tinker with the way it borrows money upset traders of short-term bills and notes. So, too, did Mr. Mullins's comments about an improving economy, which some market participants took to mean that the Fed had finished its easing policy.
Short-term rates, which had been moving lower during the morning, went back up after Mr. Mullins's comments moved across trading screens.
"Mr. Mullins said all the right things to get people nervous," one Treasury-bill trader said. "For today at least, he broke the back of the rally" in short-term rates.
But some analysts said too much was made of what the Fed official said.
"He implied that easing is over for this cycle, but I don't think that is the case," said James Fralick, a principal and senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. "To say Fed easing is over is not consistent with the kind of economic data we have been seeing."
 
Disproven Optimism
 Mr. Fralick and others recalled that over the last year, various Fed officials had provided optimistic assessments about the economy's prospects, forecasts that have subsequently proved wrong.
"We have been told by people at the Fed that recovery was coming in the spring of 1991," said Raymond W. Stone, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., research firm. "Then it was supposed to happen during the summer, then in the fall. I tend to think the Fed will react to the data as it comes in. And despite what Mr. Mullins said, I would not rule out a cut in the discount rate."
Mr. Mullins's speech attracted so much attention because there was little else to focus on yesterday, traders said. Despite some movement during the day, prices of most issues were little changed.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 102 1/2 late yesterday, to yield 7.78 percent, unchanged from late Monday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7.50 percent 10-year notes were offered at 102 2/32, up 2/32, to yield 7.20 percent. And the 5.50 percent two-year notes were also unchanged, at an offered price of 100 27/32, to yield 5.04 percent.
Early in the session, the two-year notes traded at a price to yield 4.99 percent, a low level many traders said they had never seen.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were narrowly mixed. Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 4.16 percent late yesterday, down three basis points, or three one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by one basis point, to a late offered rate of 4.17 percent. But one-year bill rates rose by three basis points, to a late offered rate of 4.22 percent.
Low interest rates and the approach of the year's end prompted a flood of new investment-grade corporate bonds to be priced yesterday, as eight companies offered some $1.8 billion worth of new securities.
Among the issuers was GPA Delaware, a subsidiary of GPA Group P.L.C., the big British conglomerate. The unit sold $500 million worth of seven-year notes guaranteed by its parent through an underwriting group led by Merrill Lynch & Company.
The 8 3/8 percent securities, which mature on Dec. 15, 1998, were priced at $99.635 to yield 8.821 percent, 2.125 percentage points more than the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 1/8 percent seven-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities, which are noncallable for life, are rated Baa-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the tax-exempt bond market, the State of New Jersey sold a total of $451 million in bonds at competitive bid. A group led by Lehman Brothers won the $425.89 million worth of tax-exempt securities.
The bonds were reoffered to investors at yields ranging from 4.20 percent on securities maturing in 1993, to 6.45 percent on bonds that mature in 2012.
Graph: "Treasury Yield Curve" shows yields of selected Treasury securities, in percent. (Source: Technical Data)

CORRECTION-DATE: December 12, 1991, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A chart on the Credit Markets page of Business Day yesterday, headed "Treasury Yield Curve," mislabeled the two yield curves for Treasury securities. The black line represented the current yields, which are lower than the yields a month ago, shown on the white line.

HEADLINE: Friars Who Tend the Forgotten, Helped by the Neediest Cases Fund

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
A tall, bearded man wearing a monk's coarse black robe and sandals strode along the streets of the South Bronx -- past the rubble lots, the garbage, the gutted cars, the buildings burned down or bricked up.
A group of homeless men around a bench sized him up him warily. The eyes of four teen-age boys followed him down the sidewalk. The night before, he recalled, a woman cackled hysterically as he walked by. 
 "They're still startled to see us," he said, turning to climb an apartment building's worn steps. "To them we look like something out of the Middle Ages. I've been called Ninja, Buddhist. One woman asked me if I was Ku Klux Klan."
At the top of the stairs, though, he was no stranger. "Brother John! Brother John!" a boy squealed as the monk entered a fourth-floor apartment carrying a bag of rolls and oranges. The boy, Jeremy, ran at a full waddle down the long hallway and up and into his arms.
 
Helping Young and Old
 For 15 years, the San Damiano friars have lived according to their vows of poverty in Morrisania, one of New York City's poorest neighborhoods. The five Franciscan brothers in the boxy, red-brick friary distribute clothing and food, including vegetables they grow in plots around the friary. They operate a senior center on Wednesdays and a youth center on Saturdays. They visit addicts in Bronx-Lebanon Hospital and the homes of elderly people who, because of age or illness, are shut in. In a fearful area of dreadful needs, they offer what help they can.
Each brother lives in a small room that is bare except for a mattress and table. The principal decoration is replicas of the San Damiano crucifix that spoke to St. Francis. But their ascetic existence has not shielded them from the effect of the recession that has increased the burden on charities around the New York region. Until this year, the friary received a yearly contribution from the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, one the seven charities aided by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
But overwhelmed by increasing demands and declining revenues, Catholic Charities has had to trim a number of their grants, including the $10,000 the friars received for their work with the elderly -- one third of their total budget. The money that used to be spent on such grants now goes to programs that deal with immediate food and rent emergencies.
"We had to cut anything that was not essential," Nora Murphy, a spokeswoman for the Catholic Charities, said in an interview yesterday. "That's not to say their work isn't essential. We're simply facing increasing demands for services, and more acute needs have come into the office."
The loss of the grant has begun to be felt. The brothers have begun spending more of their time and energy on the simple things they do to raise money -- bake sales, for example -- and less on the simple things they do to help their neighbors.
"We have to pick up the slack," said Brother Walt Hund, who heads the household, "and that takes away from our other ministries."
 
Left Teaching Posts
 The friary was founded in 1976 by Brother Walt and Brother Giles Naedler, two Franciscans who left positions teaching in Pennsylvania when they decided to adhere more closely to the example of St. Francis of Assisi. The pastor at St. Augustine's Church on Franklin Avenue, the Rev. Robert Jeffers, offered to let them keep an eye on the friary, which had just been vacated by the Christian Brothers. "We've been watching the house ever since," Brother John Kerr said.
The daily life is regulated -- or "contained," as another brother, David Leidl, described it -- by four daily prayer sessions in the friary's Spartan chapel, as well as evening Mass across the street.
"There are some people in the neighborhood who have more luxuries: a TV, a VCR," said Brother David, who joined the friary out of college in 1982. "We chose not to have those things, because that forces us to deal with each other and with God."
They subsist on donations and money they make selling bread, muffins and cookies they make in a donated pizza oven in the friary's basement.
Brother Gabriel Amato, who comes from a family of bakers, makes the bread for the sales. Brother Randy Hunt makes jellies and rosaries. Brother David makes their habits. Brother Walt makes their sandals. They all tend gardens around the friary, growing beans, eggplants, zucchini, peppers, tomatoes that they eat and give away in the neighborhood.
Father Jeffers, the pastor at St. Augustine for 22 years, said the friars are a "very visible" part of the church's work -- one that, unlike others, is there all day, every day. "They are the contact for the people who tend to be forgotten in the world -- the elderly, the shut-ins, the people who are invisible."
Brother John said it is difficult for people to understand why the friars would choose to live where they do. He said people sometimes describe them as somehow Messianic -- a notion he dismisses.
 
Offering Hope
 He describes the work more simply. "Hope is in such short supply," he said. "If that is something we can offer to people, then we have done our job."
Before joining the monastery, Brother John held a string of jobs editing trade magazines, the last one, Pest Control, based in Manhattan. He was a devout Catholic but felt no sense of calling. His sister, a nun, had once introduced him to the brothers of San Damiano, but it was not until after he took a long trip through Africa, where he was moved by a deep sense of love and community, that he felt a calling to join.
"I realized I wanted to change my lifestyle to be simpler and more loving," he said.
One day Brother John visits elderly people in their homes. Another day he delivers furniture or food to families. His work finds him as often as he finds it.
Jeremy's family, for example, found him, he said. Jeremy is one of Jose and Yolanda Diaz's 10 children. Mr. and Mrs. Diaz, known in the neighborhood as Bobby and Yogi, live with their children, three grandchildren and often "a couple of strays," as Brother John put it, in a four-bedroom apartment on Boston Road near the friary.
Brother John became a sort of confidant and friend to the family last year after a couple of the children tagged after him. Then one day, he said, one of the daughters, 6-year-old Christie, came to the friary and told him that her mother had sent her for milk for the baby. He sent her away, telling her that her mother should ask him.
Later, he learned that it was the girl's idea, not Mrs. Diaz's, to ask for the milk. "That really touched me," Brother John said.
"Wherever you could find a problem -- my landlord, my kids, my husband, food in the house -- I'll go to Brother John," Mrs. Diaz, who is 43, said Monday afternoon after Brother John's latest visit. "And he'll do that for me."
A few blocks down Boston Road, Brother John stopped to visit Mae Chapman, who is 88. ("I may be old," she said, "but I'm not cold.") "How are you?" he asked as he leaned way over to kiss her cheek.
"I'm aching," she said. She led him to a neat living room, where she talked about her ailments and her visit to the doctor's office for an X-ray. "The table was this wide," she explained, holding her hands apart and then spreading them further, "and I'm this wide."
Mrs. Chapman, who worked for years at St. Augustine's rectory, has lived in her city-owned apartment since 1943. She recalled how the neighborhood has changed, how the apartment has been robbed four times, how a man died of a gunshot wound on the stoop last year.
"Whatever has happened," she said, "I won't leave."
After about 20 minutes, Brother John and Mrs. Chapman bent their heads for prayer. Brother John opened his Bible to Isaiah, Chapter 35, and read:
"The desert and the parched land will exult. The steppe will rejoice and bloom. They will bloom with abundant flowers and rejoice with joyful song."

A headline yesterday about the San Damiano friary in the Bronx and The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund misstated the relationship between the friary and the fund. The friary no longer receives money from the Neediest Cases appeal. A drawing on Wednesday with an article about The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund carried an erroneous credit. The artist was Lloyd Stevens.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
Some Small Signs of Optimism for Denver's Office Market

BYLINE: By Dyan Zaslowsky

DATELINE: DENVER

 BODY:
IN this city, where too many office buildings have been attracting too few tenants since the mid-80's, the Resolution Trust Corporation has given the market a lift by proposing to lease 148,000 square feet for its regional headquarters in Republic Plaza, a 56-story downtown building.
"I didn't know anybody could find happiness in having the R.T.C. around," said Kevin Shields, a Resolution Trust spokesman. The Federal agency was created to manage and dispose of the assets of failed savings and loan associations, many of which lent heavily to builders of the office space that is now in oversupply in much of the nation. 
 Once it consolidates in Republic Plaza, Resolution Trust will be occupying more total space than in the three scattered sites it now has in Denver. That, along with the expansion of the Federal Deposit and Insurance Corporation offices in the Denver Bank Building and an influx of small companies, is helping create a slow but steady recovery in the Denver office market.
Republic Plaza has 1.2 million square feet of space and is in the heart of the downtown financial district. When it opened in the summer of 1984 less than 20 percent of it was leased, according to Robert Sumner, general manager for the Canadian-based Brookfield Development Company, which owns and manages the property.
"The Denver economy had just crashed," Mr. Sumner said. Many of the oil and natural gas companies that Republic Plaza's owners hoped would rent space never signed leases. To encourage tenants, Brookfield Development and other Denver landlords offered attractive concessions to prospective tenants.
Over the last two or three years the building has maintained a 70 percent occupancy rate, slightly below average for downtown Denver. The Resolution Trust lease would raise occupancy to 82 percent in the rectangular white granite structure.
Mr. Sumner said space at Republic Plaza rents for $12 to $16 a square foot. When the building was planned, the developer expected rents would be twice that. Resolution Trust's five-year lease would gross Brookfield $8.8 million. The lease is still subject to approval from Washington.
Denver's office centers are principally in the downtown area and at the Denver Tech Center, a mirrored-glass office park jutting out of the plains southeast of the central business district. The Tech Center's vacancy rate for prime office space was 11.3 percent last June, according to data compiled by the Frederick Ross Company, a real estate concern; that compares with a 17.7 percent rate in downtown Denver. Space in the Tech Center leases for some $16 a square foot a year.
But Denver's overall vacancy rate, including less-than-prime buildings, is put at 23.7 percent. This is a drop from 30 percent in the mid-80's. The period of free rents to induce tenants to newly built prime buildings is past, brokers say, but vacancies are still high in the older buildings.
"Twenty-three percent when it is heading down looks a whole lot different from 23 percent when it is heading up," said Tucker Hart Adams, chief economist for the Central Banks of Denver.
Rick Pederson, senior vice president of Fredrick Ross, noted that Denver had no single dominant industry but was attracting a variety of smaller companies. One big company, United Airlines, announced last summer that it was basing 2,000 new reservations jobs in Denver, but most of the businesses moving in employ fewer than 100, he said.
In addition, more than 200,000 square feet in Denver have been leased in the last year or so by state agencies and the University of Colorado.
"At $13 a square foot, downtown Denver is a deal right now," said Sherman Miller, a senior vice president with Coldwell Banker, the real-estate brokerage firm.
Among the small companies that have opened offices in the city recently is the San Francisco-based American President Lines, with a staff of 40 at the Tech Center. Ivan Joens, service director, said that the container-vessel company decided to lease 12,000 square feet in the Denver area primarily because management liked the "education and motivation of the local work force."
Another small company that relocated to the area from out of state is Outrigger Hotels, a Hawaiian company that bought a 35,000-square-foot office building for $24 a square foot, according to Mr. Miller. Outrigger will occupy a third of the building and lease the rest.
"The healing process has manifested itself very slowly," said Mr. Pederson of Frederick Ross. "Office real estate alone is not a significant barometer of overall economic health," he maintained, but even on that score he said that he felt generally optimistic. The low cost of Denver housing and the existence of an educated labor force are major strengths, he said.

HEADLINE: NEW YORK FAILING TO USE $600 MILLION FOR WATER SYSTEM

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
New York City's program to upgrade its long-neglected water mains, sewers and tunnels has fallen sharply behind schedule in the last year because the city's Environmental Protection Department has failed to let more than $600 million in contracts for the repair work -- almost half of the money budgeted for the purpose.
While the city authorized $1.34 billion for water and waste projects for the fiscal year that ended in July, the Environmental Protection Department spent only $711 million, according to figures obtained from the city's Office of Management and Budget. 
 The shortfall in capital spending, the largest ever recorded by a city agency, comes as water main breaks and sewer backups have become routine in New York City, disrupting traffic and subway service and leaving residents without water for days.
 
'Unfortunate' Events
 Dinkins administration officials have been embarrassed and angered by the delays and have sought to focus the criticism on Albert F. Appleton, their Environmental Protection Commissioner.
Mr. Appleton, in turn, linked the delays to a number of "unfortunate" events, ranging from cuts in the crews that do street reconstruction work to the confusion caused by the relocation of his agency's offices.
But First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel recently demanded, in a sharply worded letter to Mr. Appleton, a more detailed accounting for the delay. Water and waste projects were given high priority in the budget while other city services and capital rebuilding programs were being cut to help offset gaps in operating budgets.
The delay, city officials say, will cost the city hundreds of millions of dollars for emergency repairs as aging pipes that should have been replaced burst. Scores of weakened water mains and sewers due for rehabilitation over the next five years are not expected to be replaced until sometime after 1995 and many pipes where work is being put off are expected to rupture during the delay.
The officials said the environmental agency's inability to let its contracts on time will have a high cost in another sense: the city is missing a prime opportunity to save money on construction costs, which are now extremely low because of the weak economy.
Finally, the failure to spend capital funds at a time of high unemployment has outraged contractors and disappointed officials who see such public works as a way to stimulate the sluggish city economy. Economists at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said the $600 million involved could have created 8,000 jobs.
The city is in the midst of one of the largest reconstruction plans ever undertaken. Since late in the Koch administration, billions have been budgeted to shore up the city's deteriorating infrastructure, from highway repaving to completion of the decades-old third-water-tunnel project.
While other city agencies have failed to meet their capital spending targets, none are as far behind as the Department of Environmental Protection. "We are very concerned that D.E.P. is as far behind as it is in capital spending, given the need for construction jobs in the region and the need to fix our water mains," said Rudolph J. Rinaldi, the city's Buildings Commissioner, who oversees all city construction projects.
Mr. Appleton said in an interview that the environmental agency has been delayed in letting contracts for the work because of a chain of "unfortunate" events, including moving the agency to new office space in Queens, changes in the city's procurement procedures that require more paper work, and a blueprint company that recently went out of business.
 
Perhaps 'Too Ambitious'
 The capital program, Mr. Appleton observed, was perhaps "too ambitious" from the start.
He said the rebuilding effort was also hurt by severe cuts in the Transportation Department's street reconstruction program. In the past, the environmental agency has scheduled its water main and sewer replacement to coincide with street reconstruction, but doing that in the wake of Transportation Department budget cuts has proved difficult, he said.
The environmental agency fell farthest behind in its spending on sewers and water mains. It was authorized to spend $209.3 million on sewers but let contracts for $76.7 million in the 1991 fiscal year. It was authorized to spend $315 million on water mains but let contracts for $56.8 million. On water control projects, the agency was budgeted to spend $700 million but spent $498 million, and for equipment it spent $28 million of the $58.4 million it was authorized to spend.
 
Dilapidated and Leaky
 The environmental department is also falling behind on construction of the city's third water tunnel, a 20-foot-wide shaft being built to carry water from the Kensico Reservoir in Valhalla, N.Y., to points throughout the city. The tunnel is to supplement the city two aging tunnels, which are now dilapidated and leaky.
Contractors, desperately seeking work in these hard economic times, expressed outrage that the environmental department has been sitting on hundreds of millions of dollars in contracts.
"When an agency as large as D.E.P. underruns its capital budget, especially in times like these, we get very upset because it's money that could be used to help stimulate the economy and create jobs," said Frank McArdle, managing director of the General Contractors Association, a trade association for the heavy construction industry.
Mr. McArdle, who served as the city's Environmental Protection Commissioner from 1978 to 1981, said that in the future the city might be less willing to allocate such substantial sums to an agency that has shown itself unable to spend them.
In fact, some officials at the city's Office of Management and Budget said there were plans to reduce substantially the environmental department's capital spending over the next five years because budget officials were convinced that the agency was not capable of doing the work on time.
Mr. Rinaldi, the Buildings Commissioner, said the administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins currently had no plans to transfer the environmental department's unspent capital funds to other agencies that can spend them faster, but he noted that, given the city's fiscal crisis, the administration's priorities were constantly changing.
But Mr. Appleton said that his department had resolved most of its logistical problems in letting contracts and that the agency was moving quickly to get bids on contracts to take advantage of discount prices by contractors.
Mr. Appleton said, as he has in the past, that the department was doing more repair work than it has ever done before. He also said age was only one factor that contributed to the stress that can cause a water-main break. Congestion, vibrations from subways and street traffic and corrosive soil conditions are also factors.
But Samuel I. Schwartz, a former city transportation official who now is director of the Infrastructure Institute at Cooper Union, said every day of delay in reconstructing water mains and sewers meant another day of pounding by traffic and subways, further increasing the probability of a major break, like the one that occurred on 42d Street near Grand Central Terminal in October.
"One of these days city officials will realize that you can't ignore our infrastructure," Mr. Schwartz said, "but unfortunately it appears that that day will be too little, too late."

HEADLINE: THE EUROPEAN SUMMIT: Europe at Crossroads;
Leaders Return From Meetings Confident That Region Will Move Onward to Union

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands, Dec. 11

 BODY:
After the deadlocks, squabbles and veto threats that frequently marred their negotiations, European Community leaders returned home today confident that their two-day summit meeting here would be remembered as a turning-point in the region's decades-old integration process.
At first sight, it might seem more out of political necessity than outright conviction that all 12 leaders cheerfully asserted early today that they had achieved their main objectives, not least because France and Germany were aiming to speed regional unity while Britain was intent on slowing it. 
 Yet despite Britain's frequent isolation from its partners, despite the compromises needed to prevent a breakdown in the talks, in the end they agreed on a treaty that commits the 12 member countries to monetary union by the end of the century and for the first time gives the community a clear political profile.
 
Mitterrand Praises Accord
 The French President, Francois Mitterrand, tonight described the agreement as the most important in Europe since the 1957 Treaty of Rome created a common market. "A great power is being born," he said, "one at least as strong commercially, industrially and financially as the United States and Japan."
The German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, a convinced "Europhile" who played a central role in building a consensus here, said he was sure "a federally structured Europe" was in the making. "If I weren't satisfied now, when could I ever be?" he asked. "We have made enormous progress."
The British Prime Minister, John Major, seemed more pleased that he had kept his word to his Conservative Party colleagues by not making concessions in key areas. But he too noted of the treaty: "It advances the interests of Europe as a whole. It opens up new ways of cooperating in Europe."
The new treaty is of course still only a blueprint, yet it represents an approach that has worked before: with Britain ever-reticent, France and Germany persuaded the community to set itself ambitious goals and even target dates with the hope that, in time, Britain would come around to accepting them.
Certainly, this is what happened after the community's last "great leap forward" in 1985. Only at the last moment did Margaret Thatcher, who was then British Prime Minister, endorse the decision to form a single regional market after 1992. Today, Britain is enthusiastically building what will become the world's largest trading bloc.
Indeed, it was confidence in well-advanced plans for the single market -- and the need to compete with the United States and Japan -- that led many community governments to support still greater economic unity by committing themselves this week to create a single currency and a regional central bank no later than 1999.
Britain was again the odd man out, insisting on an "opt-out" protocol that allows its Parliament to decide at a later date whether to replace the pound with what will become known as the ECU, or European Currency Unit. Yet many experts believe Britain will eventually accept the plan.
More important, though, is that Germany agreed in principle to abandon the mark, which is Europe's dominant currency, if a series of strict economic performance targets are met by community members. And German participation in a single currency will irrevocably transform Europe's financial scene.
 
On German Unification
 Germany's commitment to European unity is doubly important to France and other Western European countries that had initial misgivings about German unification last year. France in particular sought to accelerate the region's timetable for economic and political integration as a way of establishing new rules that would firmly "anchor" a powerful single Germany within the community. Many governments have been reassured by Mr. Kohl's own support for this idea.
After the "irreversible" decision to create a single currency, however, moves toward political unity this week were more cautious, disappointing such advocates of a federal Europe as Jacques Delors, the President of the community's powerful Executive Commission based in Brussels. Yet what was long a purely economic bloc has now also assumed political responsibilities.
At Britain's insistence, the 12 leaders dropped a planned reference to the community's "federal" vocation, replacing it with a commitment to "ever closer union." Britain also successfully demanded that, in most new areas of community competence, power will remain in the hands of governments and be exercised through unanimous votes.
On social matters, though, rather than accept a British veto outright, the 11 other governments decided to act without Britain, signing a separate protocol to the treaty that envisages majority voting on a broad chapter of issues relating to workers' rights, working conditions and social security.
Nonetheless, the summit sketched the outlines for closer political cooperation by committing the 12 countries to work toward common foreign and security policies -- to be defined through unanimity -- and to establish the long-term goal of a common defense policy.
 
9-Nation Military Pact
 Community leaders specifically agreed to assign a nine-nation military pact known as the Western European Union the task of elaborating and carrying out decisions on defense questions, albeit stressing that the group will remain closely tied to North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
They further agreed to coordinate their policies on police, judicial and immigration matters and, at the request of Germany, created a new regional security body to be known as Europol and gave modest new decision-making authority to the 518-member European Parliament.
While the community plans to review -- and perhaps expand -- its political competences in 1996, however, its declared aim of "asserting its identity on the international scene" will be increasingly tested in the coming years by the disintegration of the Soviet Union and ethnic unrest in Eastern Europe.
In recent months, for example, its efforts to broker a political settlement to the Yugoslav civil war have been repeatedly frustrated by cease-fire violations and, at times, by disagreements among community governments. At the same time, demands for economic aid from former Soviet bloc countries are increasing.
 
New Applications Considered
 Recognizing that it remains the main pillar of stability in the "new" Europe, the community this week therefore took the crucial decision of acknowledging that its membership will grow significantly in the 1990's. And as a first step, it agreed to take up applications for entry by Austria and Sweden as early as next year.
Watching from the sidelines, Norway's Prime Minister, Gro Harlem Brundtland, described this week's community treaty as "a milestone" in European history. Like Finland and Switzerland, Norway is contemplating seeking membership of the community. Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary have also signaled they hope to join one day.
Until recently, the community itself seemed divided over whether it should be "deepened" through accelerated integration of existing members or "widened" by inclusion of new states. With the new treaty, as Mr. Major put it early today, "the argument has been settled because we will do both."
Having spent some 26 hours around a table shaping the future, community leaders now face the task of persuading their parliaments -- and notably their public opinions -- of the wisdom of their actions. The current plan is for the treaty to be formally signed next February and ratified by all states before the end of 1992.
In this context, Mr. Major is perhaps surprisingly well placed, not only because he can boast that he did not accept a single currency, a social program or majority voting on foreign policy, but also because an intense public debate about Europe has already clarified the battlelines in Britain.
But no one faces a greater challenge than Mr. Kohl because only in the last few days has German public opinion suddenly awakened to the implications of a single currency. And to rub it in, he returned home to Bonn today to a huge headline in the mass circulation daily, Bild, that read: "1999 -- the End of the Mark."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "It advances the interests of Europe as a whole," said Prime Minister John Major of the new European Community treaty. With him in Maastricht, the Netherlands, was Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd.; Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, who said that he was sure "a federally structured Europe" was in the making. (Associated Press) (pg. A18)

HEADLINE: Crash of Private Plane in Georgia Kills 9

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROME, Ga., DEC. 11

 BODY:
A corporate jet carrying five top executives of a supermarket chain crashed into a rugged mountainside near this northwest Georgia city today, killing all nine people aboard.
The twin-engine Beechcraft BE-400 jet crashed into a wooded area of Lavender Mountain, six and a half miles west of Richard B. Russell Airport, from which it had taken off at 9:37 A.M. The crash site is two to three minutes flying time from the airport. 
 The victims included the chairman and vice chairman of Bruno's Inc., based in Birmingham, Ala. The corporation, which had sales of $2.6 billion for the fiscal year ended last June, operates stores in Alabama, Georgia, Tennessee, Mississippi and parts of Florida under the names Piggly Wiggly, Food World, Food Fair, Foodmax, Consumer Warehouse Foods, Bruno's Finer Foods and Bruno's Food and Pharmacy stores.
 
Executives Are Identified
 The executives were being flown by two company pilots on an annual tour of some of the region's stores and were heading for Huntsville, Ala.
Among the plane's passengers were Angelo J. Bruno, the chairman of the company; his brother, Lee J. Bruno, vice chairman; Sam A. Vacarella, senior vice president for merchandising; Edward C. Hyde, vice president for store operations, and R. Randolph Page Jr., vice president for personnel.
Roff Sasser, an investigator with the National Transportation Safety Board, said at news conference this afternoon, that there were no survivors. He said the plane's flight data recorder had been recovered but officials had yet to determine what had caused the crash. Workers were going about the task of removing the bodies of the two crew members and seven passengers from the thickly wooded area of pines and limestone outcroppings.
"It is a very hazardous, steep and rocky area," said Mr. Sasser. "It will take us the rest of today and into tomorrow to remove all of the bodies."
Aerial views of the site indicated that only the plane's tail section was intact.
At 1,700 feet, Lavender Mountain is the highest mountain in the Rome area and much of the thickly wooded area is owned by Berry College, which is at the foot of the mountain.
Sheriff Mike Thornton of Floyd County said that his office was notified by the Federal Aviation Administration and the Air Force at about 11 A.M. that the plane was missing after taking off from the local airport nearly two hours earlier. Mr. Sasser said that area air-traffic controllers had heard no distress calls from the plane and there had been no witnesses to the crash.
But workers at a nearby landfill sighted smoke on the mountain's slope and alerted local fire officials, who had been called in to search for the missing plane. They found it at about noon.
Just six months ago another small plane crashed on Lavender Mountain, said Robert Skelton, director of the Winshape forestry center of Berry College. The vegetation is so thick, he said, that the wreckage and remains of the plane's two passengers was not found for 10 days.
Investigators had little information on weather conditions that might have affected the plane's takeoff, but Ernie Conner, who fuels planes at the Russell airport, described conditions as "marginal" for visual flying, with a cloud ceiling of about 1,300 feet and some fog. But, according to Mr. Sasser, the corporate plane was using instruments to aid its takeoff and flight to Huntsville and should not have been troubled by fog.
Bruno's, the Alabama-based corporation, has grown rapidly as an operator of traditional and large supermarkets and large food and drug stores. It has 241 locations, mainly in Alabama and Georgia, and is also a partner with the K mart Corporation in three hypermarket stores opened since 1989.
The company, which has 21,600 employees, had about $2.5 billion in revenue last year, or more than twice the $1.1 billion it posted in 1987. Bruno's expanded sharply in 1988 when it acquired 76 Piggly Wiggly supermarkets.
Ronald G. Bruno, the company's 39-year-old president and chief executive, issued a statement saying, "We are all deeply saddened by the tragedy that has struck Bruno's Inc."
 
Trading of Stock Halted
 The family of Angelo J. Bruno, the chairman and founder, who was 67 years old, owns 25.8 percent of Bruno's shares, worth roughly $260 million. Trading in the shares, which are listed on the over-the counter market, was halted after the company reported the deaths of the high-ranking officers.
The shares, which reached a record high of $21.625 in March, have weakened as the economy slumped in recent months. They traded on Wednesday at $12.50, off 37.5 cents, before trading was halted.
A food retailing analyst, Lee J. Wilder, of the Robinson Humphrey Company, a brokerage in Atlanta, said Bruno's had a reputation for strong and aggressive management. But like many food retailers, Bruno's had slower sales growth, and fewer new store openings, because of the recession this year, she said.
The deaths of the senior Bruno officers "is a terrible loss, but we don't expect to see any near-term impact on specific local operations," Ms. Wilder said. "Supermarkets are, by and large, locally operated, and the store managers and department managers are still in place."
In addition to the five senior executives, the others who died in the crash were identified as Karl Mollica, produce director; Mary Faust, an advertising consultant; and the two pilots of the company plane, John Tesney and Rob Stamps.

HEADLINE: THE EUROPEAN SUMMIT;
U.S. ENDORSES PACT ON EUROPEAN UNITY

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11

 BODY:
The United States today welcomed the pact by European Community heads of state to seek greater political and economic union, but President Bush warned against limits on American exports.
"The results of the E.C. summit in Maastricht represent a milestone which we celebrate along with our European partners," the President said in a written statement. "The United States has long supported European unity because of our strong conviction that it was good for Europe, good for the Atlantic partnership, and good for the world." 
 But he also urged European leaders not to exclude American exports and alluded to the trans-Atlantic disputes preventing the so-called Uruguay Round of talks from producing an agreement to reduce trade barriers. "This means working with us to bridge our bilateral differences, to expand an open global trading system by successfully concluding the Uruguay Round, and to avoid the dangers of protectionism," he said.
American officials and experts also said that while the agreement would mean closer trans-Atlantic political, military and commercial cooperation, the implications of a planned single European currency were unclear and could undermine the dollar's dominant role in international finance.
 
Trade Accord Blocked
 A conclusion to the multilateral trade talks under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade has been blocked for more than a year by a fight over the European Community's subsidies to agriculture, which the United States wants to reduce or eliminate. Julius L. Katz, a Deputy United States Trade Representative, testified to the House Agriculture Committee on Tuesday that disagreements remain over direct payments to farmers, the method of calculating cuts in export subsidies, a formula for changing farm quotas to tariffs, and the time period for these changes.
American corporations have generally favored continued European integration, although those companies with large factories and other investments in Europe have been more enthusiastic than businesses which rely on exporting from the United States.
American corporations with existing European operations are likely to benefit from the elimination of border controls and national rules that restrict, for example, the long-haul trucking industry, said Willard A. Workman, the vice president for international issues at the United States Chamber of Commerce. "Not having to unload things from a French truck to a German truck at the border represents a significant economy," he added.
All of the European Community member countries except Britain endorsed an agreement in Maastricht to seek a common system of social laws that would cover everything from worker health and safety regulations to "equality between men and women with regard to labor market opportunities and treatment at work."
The prospect of such a system has worried some American exporters, who fear that the European Community may seek to limit imports produced under less restrictive rules, Mr. Workman said. But the European Community, after briefly floating such an idea in the early 1980's, has not expressed any recent interest in doing so.
American environmentalists have sought similar rules barring imports produced by environmentally harmful methods, and European countries have been critical of extraterritorial application of United States laws.
 
Future Role of Central Bank
 American corporations with European subsidiaries have expressed few worries about the proposed system because they are already required to observe the same local laws as European companies.
Less clear, although potentially far-reaching, are the consequences of the European decision to seek a common currency by the end of the century. The structure of the European central bank responsible for issuing this currency will determine whether inflation in Western Europe is lower or higher, and this in turn will affect the ability of the United States to tolerate higher interest rates without suffering a devaluation of the dollar, economists agree.
If foreign central banks abandon large portions of their dollar-denominated assets, the dollar's value and role in international finance could suffer, although the Treasury and most private economists consider this unlikely.
American diplomatic contacts with the community have expanded enormously in the last two years and are likely to intensify as Western European countries seek to coordinate their foreign policies through the community's headquarters in Brussels, said an American official who insisted on anonymity.
Because each member country retains its own foreign policy, Brussels' growing role is likely to pose problems for American diplomats, said Alberta M. Sbragia, an associate professor of political science at the University of Pittsburgh who is writing a book on the subject for the Brookings Institution.
"We're going to have to deal with a system that is much more complicated than any other in world that I know of," she said.

HEADLINE: A Growing Choice: Housing or Food

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE

 BODY:
When Harold Coleman, a 23-year-old chef's assistant, sketches his family's budget, two figures command attention. He brings home $596 a month. He pays about $480 for rent and utilities for an apartment in Charlotte, N.C.
Those figures make the Colemans part of a large and almost certainly growing number of poor Americans who pay more than half their income for rent and utilities in a condition that is changing the way poor people live. 
 Experts dicker over the details, but the housing problems of America's poor have grown so severe that they lie almost beyond the realm of controversy, with virtually everyone agreeing that the problem is vast and that near-term solutions are so expensive as to be politically unimaginable.
"This one is so big and so related to money, it's not controversial because it's not even on the radar screen," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat who is among Congress's foremost housing experts.
 
Official Recognition
 Asked if he agreed that the nation's poor faced a severe problem paying for housing, John Weicher, an Assistant Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, said: "Sure do. We've been saying so for a long time. If you're trying to get a disagreement on that, I'm probably of little help."
A report made public yesterday by two Washington not-for-profit organizations is the latest in an avalanche of recent studies that paint a grim portrait of affordable housing for the poor.
The study, by the Center for Budget and Policy Priorities and the Low Income Housing Information Service, said 56 percent of poor renters, or about 10 million people, pay more than half their income for shelter. It put at 47 percent the proportion of the nation's poor renters who pay more than 70 percent of their income for shelter.
The Government considers housing affordable if it consumes no more than 30 percent of a family's income.
The report contended that the problem, which has its roots in the economy of the 1970's and early '80's, failed to improve in the seven years of economic growth that ended in 1989 and that it could be expected to worsen as the recession drives people out of jobs and slows the construction of housing.
 
'It Drives Up Hunger'
 Indeed, housing affordability looms so large in the lives of low-income Americans that analysts have devised a term to describe the condition of people whose housing costs leave them unable to afford other necessities: shelter poverty.
"It drives up hunger," said Robert Greenstein, the executive director of the budget center, which analyzes policies affecting low-income Americans. "It drives more of the poor into substandard and overcrowded housing and even into homelessness."
One measure of the problem's vastness can be seen in Mr. Schumer's tepid predictions for last year's National Affordable Housing Act, the most significant Congressional housing legislation in more than a decade, and one he helped design. The law creates a variety of programs to help poor people pay for housing.
"It will have a difference at the edge," he said, "but it's not going to change the direction of the statistics."
 
Geographic Diversity
 Since housing problems are caused not just by high rents but also by low incomes, they can be found with dismaying geographic diversity -- in the high-priced Northeast and West as well as in the inexpensive South. They afflict people who work full time, like Mr. Coleman, and those who rely on welfare; they trouble black, white and Hispanic people, young families and old pensioners; the urban and the rural poor.
Mr. Coleman earns $5 an hour making salads at a Radisson hotel in Charlotte, a city that has many empty luxury apartments but not enough inexpensive housing. Of Mr. Coleman's $596 in take-home pay, $415 goes for rent and about $65 for utilities, he said, leaving him a little more than $100 a month. "So once you pay the diapers and bus fare and electricity and the phone bill, there's nothing left," he said.
In the last several years, the Colemans have been evicted twice and arrested once for pirating electricity from a neighbor's outdoor outlet. Mr. Coleman said he ran an extension cord to the outlet to plug in his alarm clock after his own electricity was shut off.
Victoria Coleman, Mr. Coleman's wife, said she is not working because she would only pay for day care what she would expect to earn. Mr. Coleman, who is as earnest as he is poor, feeds the family on $323 a month in food stamps. He has decorated his living room with furniture found beside a nearby trash container.
 
Causes of the Problem
 "You wouldn't believe what people throw out around here," he said.
The problem stems from three main causes: The number of people needing low-rent apartments has grown; the number of those apartments available in the private market has shrunk, and Federal housing assistance has failed to keep pace with the change.
Since 1970, the report said, the number of low-income renters grew 41 percent, to 9.6 million in 1989. The study defined as low-income any household earning less than $10,000 a year in 1989 terms.
But over the same period, the number of inexpensive units available in the private market actually decreased 14 percent, to 5.5 million. They were defined as those costing less than $250 a month.
While in 1970 there were actually 400,000 more units than there were poor renters, the report said, by 1989 the situation had been drastically reversed, with 4.1 million more poor renters than affordable units.
The report cites a variety of reasons for the decline in low-cost units, including the conversion of rental units to condominiums, apartment operating costs that have outstripped inflation and urban renewal programs that have destroyed units.
 
Federal Aid Slackened
 At the same time, Federal aid slackened. From 1977 to 1980, the report said, the housing department added an average of 290,000 families each year to its list of those receiving housing assistance. In the last 10 years, however, the Government has added an average of only 78,000 families each year. Had the expansion of Federal housing assistance continued at the same pace, the report said, there would be an additional 2.3 million American families now getting help.
But even that would only begin to make a dent. While 4.4 million American households currently receive help from the department, an additional 9.6 million qualify. Waiting lists in some cities are years long.
Pointing toward numbers like these, some advocates for the poor have said that the only solution is to make housing assistance an entitlement, like food stamps or Medicare, that is available to anyone who qualifies.
 
Huge Homeowner Subsidy
 Cushing Dolbeare, a co-author of the report, has estimated it would cost $10 billion to $40 billion a year to do that. The study said the Government currently provides $37 billion a year in subsidies to homeowners, by allowing them to deduct from their taxes the interest they pay on their mortgages.
The report's data came from the 1989 American Housing Survey, a Census Bureau study produced every two years. It has been criticized for underestimating the incomes of the poor, but the survey also excludes the homeless, so its biases may balance.
One of the few bright spots, analysts agree, is that housing quality has substantially improved, with far fewer homes lacking amenities like indoor plumbing. But in some cases, neighborhood quality has declined, with many subsidized units located in violent, drug-dominated areas.
Mary Patton found that even in Charlotte -- hardly America's most blighted city -- accepting Government assistance could be risky. After raising nine children of her own, Ms. Patton, 49 years old, is now raising an 11-year-old grandson and a 12-year-old son of a friend.
She was paying $110 a month to live in a subsidized apartment, but after a shot was fired through her front window, she said she could no longer stand the drug trade. "I said I got to get out of here -- God forbid, they shoot one of my kids," she said.
She now pays $375 a month -- about half her average monthly earnings in a clothing factory -- to rent a modest two-bedroom home, where she sleeps on a couch because she cannot afford a third bed.
Ms. Patton was still saving for her gas deposit when the fall's first freeze arrived; she and the two children spent the night huddled together beneath the family's electric blanket.

HEADLINE: 73 Haitians Who Returned Home Were Rapidly Arrested, U.N. Says

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11

 BODY:
A group of 73 Haitian refugees who returned voluntarily to the Haitian capital on Dec. 1 from temporary haven in Venezuela were arrested and interrogated by the police on their arrival, according to officials in the offices of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees here and in Geneva.
The refugees were arrested at the airport in Port-au-Prince despite assurances given to the United Nations by the Haitian Red Cross that there would be no retribution. Initial reports indicate that all were released within 24 hours, but United Nations officials say they have no way of monitoring what happened afterward. 
 A small amount of money that had been given to the Haitians by United Nations officials to help them return to their homes was apparently taken from them during the course of the interrogation.
The fate of Haitians returning to the country they fled is at the heart of a court case that is to resume on Thursday in the Federal Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit in Atlanta. These Haitians are among a group of more than 400 who were moved from United States custody at the Guantanamo Bay naval base to Venezuela, Honduras and Belize.
The Bush Administration is asking the court to lift a temporary stay on forced repatriations of Haitians.
 
Others Seek to Return
 The State Department has maintained that there is no evidence that Haitians returned to the island by the Coast Guard are persecuted. The last forced repatriations took place on Nov. 18 and 19, before a Federal judge in Miami issued the temporary order halting the procedure.
The voluntary return of the 73 Haitians from Venezuela was the first such program undertaken since the judge's order. At least 20 Haitians being held at the Guantanamo base have also asked to return, United Nations officials say, along with some others in temporary shelters in Honduras.
The United Nations warns the Haitians of the risks they run in returning, but cannot prevent them from doing so. A United Nations refugee official had awaited the returning Haitians at the airport at Port-au-Prince, but apparently left when the flight from Venezuela was late. The official had not been advised of the plane's rescheduled time of arrival.
The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and human rights and refugee groups say that it is difficult to monitor the treatment of citizens returning to Haiti because transportation has been severely curtailed by a lack of fuel. The gas shortage results from an embargo imposed against the military leaders who overthrew the elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, on Sept. 30.
Many rights groups have ceased to function in Haiti, and the United States Embassy has been stripped down to essential staff, with no rights observer. Some nongovernmental human rights organizations in Haiti are operating with pared-down staffs and resources.
Haitians forcibly returned from the United States under a 1981 agreement between the two countries have normally been turned over to the Haitian Red Cross, which is now led by a doctor who has served at one of the country's most notorious prisons.
"The Haitian Red Cross is hardly an independent institution," said Kenneth Roth, deputy director of Human Rights Watch in New York. "Everybody is at risk. This regime is as vicious and lawless as any that can be imagined. It murders at will. It is almost preposterous to expect a government of that sort to respect international law."
Anne Fuller, associate director of the National Coalition for Haitian Refugees, returned on Sunday from a trip to Port-au-Prince. She said she felt a "pervasive fear" in the capital that she had not experienced on previous visits over a number of years.
"I felt as though half the country was in hiding," she said. "At least 100,000 people have fled a city of a million-plus. There is no transportation running." She said that Roman Catholic priests were being arrested and rectories searched.
Other refugee, church and rights organizations say that arrests and interrogations are commonplace, and though people are often released within days, many Haitians have nonetheless fled their homes and moved underground or to other parts of the country where they will not be recognized.
 
Food Shortages Worsen
 The 34-nation Organization of American States, which imposed the embargo to put pressure on the military rulers to reinstate President Aristide, recently sent a mission to Haiti to investigate humanitarian needs.
 The mission reported on Tuesday that shortages of medicine and food are apparent and that conditions of near-starvation could develop by January.
 It recommended that the Organization of American States take steps to insure that inoculation doses, essential drugs, and chemicals for purifying water are transported to Haiti before crises deepen. Humanitarian aid is not prohibited by the embargo.

Stations Suspend Reporting
 PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Dec. 11 (Reuters) -- The last two independent Haitian radio stations providing news coverage suspended all reporting today after an attack by gunmen forced a radio station off the air on Tuesday.
 After broadcasting reports of the attack on Radion Galaxie, in which seven plainclothes gunmen fired on studio equipment with automatic weapons and kidnapped the station director, Radio Metropole and Radio Tropic gave no further news.
 The move left the Government-run station with a monopoly on radio news at a time of rising tension over negotiations between the Haitian Parliament and the country's deposed President, Father Aristide.
 Army hard-liners are said to fear that the Parliament, under pressure from the embargo that is strangling the economy, is moving closer to an agreement that could pave the way for Father Aristide's return to power.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

COMPANIES
General Motors signaled investors and employees that deep cutbacks were in the works. Robert Stempel, the chairman, said in a statement that details of the cutbacks, which were endorsed by G.M. directors, would be explained publicly next Wednesday. [D1.] 
 Pfizer has broken through with a cornucopia of winners after seven dry years without important new drugs. [D1.]
A long-awaited autopsy report says Robert Maxwell apparently did not die of drowning but probably had a heart attack. [D1.]
The Maxwell family's private companies may be laboring with far more debt than previously estimated. [D17.]
Representatives of The Daily News management and unions met to begin work on a reorganization. [B6.]
Shearson Lehman is reportedly negotiating to sell its mortgage banking unit for $238 million. [D2.]
Macy's said it had renegotiated an important credit agreement with its lenders. [D2.]
