HEADLINE: Quayle Returns Critics' Fire on Conflict of Interest

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11

 BODY:
Vice President Dan Quayle lashed out today at several committee chairmen in Congress for raising accusations of conflict of interest against him and his staff, and said his Council on Competitiveness would carry on with efforts to reduce regulation of American business.
The barbs from the Vice President, who accused critics of pursuing a "negative agenda" against the American people, were the latest in a feud with Congress that has grown more heated by the day. It began with Congressional criticism last summer of the council, of which Mr. Quayle is chairman, and of its actions in revising Federal regulations after they had been written by the agencies charged with doing so. 
 Because the council's aim is to ease the impact of regulations on business, and because it operates out of the public's view, with no record of who influences its decisions, critics in Congress have called it "a shadow government." They have further asserted that it was created to give businesses another chance to revise regulations after they have already failed to make their case to Federal agencies.
 
Attacks From Several Quarters
 Six Democratic committee chairmen in Congress have begun attacks on the council and on Mr. Quayle: Representatives Henry A. Waxman of California, John D. Dingell and John Conyers Jr. of Michigan, and Ted Weiss of Manhattan, as well as Senators John Glenn of Ohio and Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts. On Tuesday, a former Justice Department official in the Reagan Administration, Cass Sunstein, said the council's operations, while laudable in purpose, were plainly illegal under the Constitution.
Last week Mr. Waxman and Mr. Conyers began to investigate the personal finances of the staff director of the council, Allan B. Hubbard, a wealthy Indiana businessman, and on Tuesday succeeded in getting him to agree to put his financial holdings in a blind trust and to donate to charity some stock holdings that have been questioned by the Congressmen as possibly conflicting with his responsibilities.
Mr. Waxman also held a hearing on Tuesday in which experts in Federal rules governing administrative procedures and conflict of interest said that the council was operating illegally and that Mr. Hubbard might be in violation of criminal laws concerning conflict of interest. Mr. Quayle himself, they asserted, was operating beyond the bounds of conflict of interest rules because he had large financial interests he had not put in trust while he worked on regulations that may affect them.
Today, in a speech before a food and drug industry group, Mr. Quayle attacked the committee chairmen who had criticized him, saying they were pursuing an agenda that risked the finances and even the lives of the American people by seeking more regulation.
He said the criticisms of the council were a purely political argument against what he called needed reforms in the regulations set out by Federal agencies like the Food and Drug Administration and the Environmental Protection Agency.
 
One Disputed Proposal
 One proposal presented by the council that provoked a heated debate would make major changes in the way the F.D.A. approves drugs, allowing private and university groups, along with health agencies in other countries, to try to influence the agency's reviews. The proposal would allow private contractors to review drugs rather than the F.D.A., give data from some foreign studies equal weight with data compiled here in approving a drug, and allow early safety tests on humans to be reviewed by university review boards rather than the F.D.A.
Critics suggest it would simply drop the F.D.A.'s safety standards in order to get drugs on the market faster.
Mr. Hubbard announced Tuesday that he wanted to "put to rest" assertions of conflict of interest, and in a letter to Mr. Waxman said, "Both the Office of Government Ethics the Office of White House Counsel have reviewed my activities pursuant to your request and have concluded that the arrangements I took to avoid conflicts of interest were appropriate."
But, he said, "after careful consideration, I have engaged private counsel to immediately contact the Office of Government Ethics for the purpose of creating a blind trust."
Mr. Waxman said Mr. Hubbard would still need to remove himself from any matters connected with his businesses. He said creating the trust or removing himself from consideration of issues would not affect whether Mr. Hubbard was prosecuted for conflicts that had already occurred.
Also Tuesday, Mr. Conyers, chairman of the House Government Operations Committee, said he had asked the General Accounting Office to look into the matter.

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
Dole, Bush's Point Man in the Senate, Is Considering Life Behind the Lines

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11

 BODY:
Bob Dole did more with less in the last session of Congress, extricating his party from White House-made difficulties on civil rights and unemployment benefits. But the Republican leader of the Senate sounds tired of keeping the increasingly fractious, dwindling Republican minority together.
And if his party lost still more seats, the senior Senator from Kansas said in a recent interview, "about all you could do is frustrate the majority. You couldn't deal with them. You could frustrate them, drag things along, irritate people, which you'd have to do." 
 He added, "You wouldn't have much impact on the results, keep a lot of people awake."
The 68-year-old politician is on the eve of deciding whether to run for a fifth term, and he says he is contemplating what once seemed impossible: retiring from politics. His friends say he may seek the tamer pursuits of practicing law and serving on corporate boards.
 
Is Dole Irreplaceable?
 His Kansas colleague, Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, recently made public a letter urging him to run again. He was nearly irreplaceable, she wrote, both in the "frustrating and difficult" task of conciliation among Senate Republicans and in the role of a leader who "persuaded the White House to listen."
Mr. Dole earned such credentials through dedication to President Bush's interests -- even when other senators suspected that he was not convinced of the political wisdom of a White House position. "There has been no more effective advocate of the President's position nor protector of the President's prerogatives," said Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, who credits Mr. Dole with the President's string of sustained vetoes.
"My job is to reflect the Administration view, get as much of their program as we can," Mr. Dole said. In doing so, he gives the public no hint of the disdain he showed in his own 1988 Presidential campaign and his bitter primary battle with Mr. Bush in New Hampshire. Republican senators say he gives them no hint either.
Generally Dole the legislative leader has much less of a sharp tongue, on almost any subject, than Dole the candidate. It's more responsible, but it may be less fun.
"I don't think he terribly enjoys being minority leader, and he enjoyed it less in the last year or two," said Senator Warren B. Rudman of New Hampshire, Mr. Dole's diehard ally in the 1988 primary there.
Pushing the Administration's view was a more satisfying job for Mr. Dole as majority leader in 1985 and 1986. But the 1986 elections put the Republicans in the minority, and their numbers shrank in 1988 and 1990. After November's election of Harris Wofford in Pennsylvania, the Republicans were stuck on the short end of a 57-to-43 balance in the Senate.
 
A Minority Leader's Dream
 "I'd like to be majority leader," Mr. Dole said. "Obviously you never know around this place, there can be big sweeps, but I don't think that's going to happen in '92, so I wouldn't want to lose any seats."
With still fewer seats, "you'd still have to make the same fights," he said. But the outcome would be obstruction, not influence, and even if this year was frustrating, Mr. Dole had a powerful impact.
On civil rights, one of the few important bills passed, he kept pressing for talks between the White House and Senator John C. Danforth, the Missouri Republican, whose summerlong appeal to his party to abandon the quota issue and work for compromise on the job-discrimination measure kept it within reach of enactment. But Mr. Dole also worked to keep Mr. Danforth from taking enough Republicans publicly committed to him to provide strength to override a veto in the Senate.
The Missourian was tantalizingly close. "You have to choose between supporting the President and Jack Danforth," he recalls Mr. Dole telling a Republican caucus.
Buying time by dragging things out on the floor, using parliamentary stalling tactics, Mr. Dole confronted President Bush and his aides with the uncertainties of the situation in the Senate. He assembled a group of uncommitted Republican senators whom the Administration can usually count on to visit the White House.
When several of the senators all but threatened to vote to override, Mr. Bush sent C. Boyden Gray, the White House counsel, to make a deal.
 
A Tactical Commitment
 Afterward, Mr. Dole loyally and routinely insisted that the votes to sustain a veto had been there all the time. But he does not expend much energy trying to convince people of that. Instead, he defines his function on this bill as beginning with being a bit uncomfortable at opposing the measure in 1989 and sustaining Mr. Bush's veto.
"From a party standpoint, it was not in our interest to get locked in," he said. "We had to bring everybody along fairly slowly; we had a few in our party who thought that would be the great issue, we shouldn't drop it."
On civil rights, Mr. Dole had no legislative ax to grind, though an inventive aide, Dennis Shea, kept peppering both sides with compromise suggestions.
But on unemployment, he had a counterproposal as soon as the first of three efforts to provide extra benefits for people out of work at least half a year came to the floor in July. The final versions passed last month.
Mr. Dole's commitment was tactical, not principled. Indeed, his was the loudest "aye" when the Senate passed the Democratic bill after rejecting his plan on Aug. 1. But the alternative provided cover for Republicans until the White House finally felt the issue's strong political winds and abandoned its arguments that the benefits were not needed because the recession was ending and that extended benefits would deter the jobless from seeking work.
"My view was 'We don't want to give anybody unemployment benefits' was not a winner," he said.
He conceded "it took a while to get it done," from July until November. What was in the final legislative package owed at least as much to Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Senate Finance Committee, and Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who heads the House Ways and Means Committee, as it did to Mr. Dole. And the House minority leader, Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, probably did as much as Mr. Dole to get the White House interested in negotiating.
But Mr. Dole kept the game alive, for the conflicting interests of Mr. Bush and his party. First he persuaded enough Republicans to cast a risky vote with the President to sustain an October veto. Then he kept demanding a compromise to protect Republicans from Democratic accusations that they had killed the benefits.
 
The Flow's the Thing
 But even if Mr. Dole is good at it, there isn't as much joy in influencing legislation as in controlling the flow.
He has been majority and minority leader under Republican presidents, but he envies the Democratic majority leader, saying, "I always thought the strongest position would be the position Mitchell is in -- to be majority leader when the other guy is in charge downtown, and then you can pretty well bring things to a halt around here."
His job is complicated not just by an insufficient number of Republicans in the Senate, but by the divisions among those who are there. Mr. Rudman said Mr. Dole is bothered by their lack of support, especially when other party leaders do not back him.
Some moderates believe that he neglects their interests in backing Mr. Bush. And so do some conservatives; when Senator Malcolm Wallop of Wyoming criticized Mr. Dole's support of last year's budget accord, Mr. Dole said that if Mr. Wallop wanted to be the party leader they could hold an election that minute. Mr. Wallop backed down.
Mr. Dole's sometimes sharp tongue occasionally makes enemies in the Senate. While Mr. Mitchell holds him in high regard for limiting the chaos that Senate rules seem to demand, there are other Democrats who have less sympathy for him as he routinely delays floor consideration of many major Democratic bills.
And if he could work to move the White House on some issues, he did not always succeed. He tried to smooth over the dispute over the rule barring abortion counseling by doctors in Federally financed family planning clinics.
But the White House, at the insistence of John H. Sununu, President Bush's chief of staff who is resigning, would not compromise.
In the end Mr. Dole's decision on seeking another term may well rest on numbers and his sense of how Republican Senate candidates may fare next fall. For now, he insists, "I like my job."
Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, one of the most enthusaistic Dole supporters in the Republicans' conservative wing, said: "I think he's really on the border. If the numbers were closer, I don't think he would quit."

HEADLINE: Legislature Drops Wage Tax by Vote Weicker Can Veto

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Dec. 11

 BODY:
The drive to undo Connecticut's new wage tax suffered a major setback tonight when the Senate passed a repeal bill by a majority too weak to survive a certain veto by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.
The 21-to-15 vote, in a chamber that had been viewed by repeal leaders as the legislature's fortress of anti-income tax sentiment, technically keeps the repeal plan alive and sends it back to the House. But the majority was three short of the 24 votes needed to override a veto. The House of Representatives approved the plan by 86 to 63 on Monday, 15 votes short of the two-thirds needed to override a veto. 
 Repeal leaders had predicted a strong Senate showing of well over two-thirds that would swing some wavering House votes back into the repeal fold for a final attempt later this week to try to override Mr. Weicker and kill a tax that has sparked protest and anger across the state. But the vote tonight short-circuited that momentum, making the success of the override vote now an open if not doubtful proposition in both chambers instead of just one.
 
An Ambiguous Moment
 The final vote, which came just after 11 P.M. after five hours of debate, was an ambiguous moment of victory and defeat. The final speeches -- which were delivered after the outcome had been predicted -- sounded more like elegies than rousing battle cries.
"Connecticut grew and flourished," said the majority leader, Senator Cornelius O'Leary, an anti-income tax Democrat from Windsor Locks, in describing the years of Connecticut's pre-wage-tax innocence. "Connecticut can stand tall and proud and compare its record without an income tax to any state in this union and Connecticut comes out ahead. Let's keep that lead."
The bill, which would cut spending and raise other taxes to replace the wage tax, now goes back to the House because it was amended during the Senate debate. And an attempt to override is still expected, probably later this week. But lawmakers in both chambers said the dynamic of the special session had been changed by the Senate vote. Some Senators blamed the replacement budget itself, which they said they would have liked to vote for but could not.
The proposal would increase state borrowing and cut more than $200 million from this year's budget of $7.6 billion, including a $50 million reduction in the state's contribution to general assistance welfare. A legislative analysis also concluded that that plan could be out of balance by a $1 billion or more in just six months.
"It is not responsible," said Senator Amelia P. Mustone, a Democrat from Meriden who voted against the plan despite expressing distaste for the wage tax. "I can't lie to keep my job."
 
'Has Hurt Our Economy'
 "It's mean," said another lawmaker who voted against the bill, Senator Charles H. Allen 3d, a Democrat from New Haven. "It preys on those who are least able to defend themselves -- it hurts the weakest areas of our state in addition to the weakest people."
Supporters of the proposal conceded that their alternative to taxing wages was not perfect. But for better or worse, they added, it is what the people of the state wanted. And the income tax, they said, has been a blow to an economy already in a severe recession.
"It has hurt our economy, and our families and our future," said one repeal leader, Senator John B. Larson, an East Hartford Democrat and the Senate President pro tem.
The vote, which had originally been set for Tuesday afternoon, then Wednesday afternoon, was postponed again late in the day, as lawmakers scrambled to adjust their strategies about a repeal session that in the last 48 hours has departed significantly from the prepared script.
"The organizing framework fell apart," said Senator George Jepsen, a Democrat from Stamford, in the hours before the debate began. "Nobody knows what to do."
Mr. Jepsen, who opposes repeal and instead supports changing the existing income tax to ease the burden on middle-income taxpayers, said he and several like-minded Senators had planned a push to amend the plan today. But discussions through the afternoon changed that strategy, as lawmakers began to conclude with increasing confidence that repeal had fizzled and that not everything need be staked on one throw of the dice on Wednesday.
The amendment was offered in order to hold up an alternative to the plan being voted upon, then withdrawn. Mr. Jepsen said the income-tax repair plan would be brought to a vote perhaps next week.
Wage tax supporters in the House said that two weak votes in succession on repeal had significantly increased the chances of passing measures like Mr. Jepsen's. Many opponents of the income tax have said they would oppose any effort to change it or ease its burden because that would mean accepting that the tax is valid and permanent enough to consider tinkering with.
"A week ago I would have said we had a 30 percent chance," said Representative Miles S. Rapoport, a Democrat from West Hartford who supports amending but keeping the income tax. "Now I would say 50-50."

HEADLINE: Democrat Sees a Big '92 Budget Gap in Trenton

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Dec. 11

 BODY:
A major Senate Democrat says New Jersey will not have to wait until the next fiscal year for its economic picture to grow truly grim. By his calculations, the state could find itself $700 million in the red before this budget cycle ends.
Senator Laurence S. Weiss of Woodbridge, the Appropriations Committee chairman, who is considered one of Trenton's most astute fiscal analysts, said in an interview today that he expected a lagging economy to cause the state to fall far short of revenue expectations before the fiscal year ends next June 30. 
 "If I said a billion dollars, it would scare the hell out of everybody, so I'm saying about $700 million," Mr. Weiss said, a hint that using the lower figure might be optimistic.
He based his estimate on his scrutiny of tax collections through November and his own belief that the economy is not picking up so quickly as expected.
State Treasurer Douglas C. Berman, although reporting that revenues have generally been up to expectations this year, has also warned of potentially serious problems building as the economy continues to sputter.
Today, Harvey Fisher, spokesman for the Treasury Department, said that "revenues overall have been on target through November, and for sales taxes through October," the last figures available.
Mr. Fisher conceded, however, that "there is some concern about the economic recovery, and that is producing some anxiety about revenues in the months ahead."
Mr. Fisher said he had no direct response to Mr. Weiss's projection of a $700 million shortfall before the fiscal year ends next June.
A shortfall of that magnitude would be extremely serious in a total budget of $14.6 billion that has already been balanced by emergency procedures.
Senator Weiss also had news today about next year's budget, saying that he has the votes to send to the floor a package of bills that would roll back the $2.8 billion tax increase voted by the New Jersey Legislature last year. The package is up for a vote Thursday in his Senate committee.
Companion legislation to end the taxes on June 30, 1992, when the fiscal year ends, is expected to be introduced in the Assembly on Monday. But last Monday a similar attempt to introduce the "sunset" legislation was thwarted when Republicans refused to show up for a quorum call and six Democrats were absent, mostly because of illness, so no quorum was possible. The Republicans have been boycotting all sessions pertaining to tax cuts, and it is unclear whether a quorum can be achieved.
Meanwhile, Gov. Jim Florio, who pushed the new taxes through the Legislature last year, seemed to serve notice to his fellow Democrats that he might veto a tax rollback if Democrats succeed in passing it.
The Governor said on the Cable Television Network's "State of the State" program tonight that he had not prejudged the tax cut proposal and was willing to consider it if it comes to his desk. But he hinted that he would veto it if he decided it would jeopardize property tax relief and educational quality, both of which were the primary objectives of the $2.8 billion increase last year.

HEADLINE: PRETORIA'S AIRLINE HIRES FEW BLACKS

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 6

 BODY:
Among the benefits South Africa reaped from the lifting of American economic sanctions last July was the restoration of landing rights for South African Airways in the United States.
Yet South Africa's state airline, which now flies three times a week between Johannesburg and New York, lags conspicuously behind the Government of President F. W. de Klerk in the dismantling of apartheid. 
 The airline's critics, including black job applicants who say they were rejected on flimsy pretexts, accuse South African Airways of balking at real affirmative action that would elevate blacks in significant numbers above the menial chores of janitors and baggage handlers.
"They are a highly discriminatory company that is putting all sorts of obstacles in the way of employment of blacks," said Papie Moloto, a human services administrator for the African National Congress.
 
11 Professionals Rejected
 The list of rejected job applicants include at least two pilots, five flight engineers and four aircraft maintenance engineers, all of whom returned from exile this year. Some were trained in Ireland and Nigeria and flew or maintained Boeing jetliners for Ethiopian Airlines.
South African Airways rejected all 11 applicants as unqualified, though the International Civil Aviation Organization had certified their competence. Some were promised a chance to start at the bottom as apprentices but have yet to be enrolled in any course.
A.N.C. officials related some of the alleged snubs.
In one case, a former Ethiopian Airlines pilot with 650 hours of flight time was told to log 350 hours more before reapplying, with no assurance of eventual acceptance.
In another, a maintenance engineer who qualified on the Boeing 737 jetliner in Ethiopia failed after being tested on a light aircraft he had never handled before. The Boeing 737 is the smallest airliner flown commercially by South African Airways.
In a third case, the airline took only one of 20 potential black stewardesses recommended by the African National Congress, dismissing most of the others because they did not speak Afrikaans fluently enough.
"If the standards are that high, we're saying, 'Why don't you prepare them for your standards? They are available,' " Mr. Moloto said. "This is what other companies are doing."
 
White Unions Blamed
 He blamed the problem partly on whites-only aviation unions anxious to protect white jobs during a recession. A white union official was allowed to sit in on an examination given blacks applying for jobs as aircraft mechanics.
The state airline said in a statement that "South African Airways has been committed to equal opportunity employment since 1983," after laws reserving good jobs for whites were repealed. The airline said its "ratio of black to white employees was significantly increased" but did not support this with statistics.
South African Airways failed to respond to repeated questions over the last month about the racial breakdown of its staff and professional training and bridging programs for blacks. It said only that 1,222 employees attended courses on "literacy training," "free market principles" and "bridging cultural differences."
Some South Africans, including Tony Leon, a white Member of Parliament, expressed surprise that the United States did not, as the Commonwealth has done, make affirmative action programs a condition of restoring the landing rights taken away from South African Airways.
"It is making no moves to align itself with the new reality in South Africa," said Mr. Leon, a legislator for the liberal Democratic Party. "As the flag carrier of the country, it's a remarkably unprogressive organization."
 
Questions in Parliament
 Mr. Leon asked Dawie de Villiers, the Minister of Public Enterprises, in Parliament what South African Airways was doing to hire more non-whites. Government ministers must answer questions from the opposition benches, so Mr. de Villiers disclosed these statistics in February:
*All but one of 736 pilots employed by South African Airways were white. The exception was of Indian origin.
*All but 50 of 1,443 flight attendants were white.
*All but 32 of 271 apprentices enrolled in aviation maintenance programs were white.
Mr. de Villiers gave no breakdown for other jobs at South African Airways. According to Zelda Roux, a spokeswoman for the airline, the number of black flight attendants increased from 38 to 60 between March 1990 and March 1991 and 64 other people of color were given administrative jobs.
"I certainly know of no programs or schemes -- and that's really what's required -- to make a positive contribution to employment opportunities specifically for blacks," Mr. Leon said. "They have that obligation and they're not fulfilling it."
Returning exiles with airline experience spoke on condition of anonymity for fear of losing any hope of eventual employment with South African Airways. One confessed that he questioned his own competence after his rejection.
"I'm very much discouraged about this," he said. "It's maybe better to take a course in computer programming or teaching."

HEADLINE: Republicans in Albany Propose Cuts in Medicaid

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 11

 BODY:
The Republican-controlled State Senate released a plan today that it said would slash $1.6 billion in spending on Medicaid and welfare over the next 15 months, largely by cutting services and changing eligibility levels for program recipients.
But in a vivid illustration of the philosophical gulf that has helped stall budget negotiations here, the Democratic-led State Assembly dismissed many of the ideas tonight as an assault on the poor and, in the case of one proposal to cap emergency housing grants, a means of "sentencing people to instant homelessness." 
 The Senate proposal was released as Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the legislative leaders continued to debate a plan that would simultaneously close more than $4 billion in combined deficits in the state's current $30 billion budget and its next budget.
John E. McArdle, a spokesman for the Senate Majority Leader, Ralph J. Marino, said the Senate plan would essentially freeze state spending on Medicaid and welfare at current levels, a combined total of roughly $7.3 billion annually.
 
A 'Day of Reckoning'?
 Mr. Marino hailed the proposals as a much-needed fundamental restructuring of social-service spending that could finally bring New York's budget problems under control.
"The day of reckoning is upon us," he said. But many advocates for the poor predicted that they would have the opposite effect, throwing the state's economy into further disarray and aggravating the fiscal problems.
"This is not a day of reckoning," said Russell Sykes, a senior policy associate with the State Communities Aid Association, a nonprofit group. "This is a day of wrecking."
It has long been clear that crucial to any successful resolution of the budget would be an agreement to halt Medicaid spending, now running more than 17 percent ahead of 1990 levels. But Medicaid remains one of the most politically polarized issues in the Legislature, with the Republicans seeking to protect health-care providers and the Democrats resistant to any reduction in services for the nearly 3 million poor and elderly who rely on the program.
Still, despite the differences, negotiators indicated today that there was a hint of progress in reaching agreement on general targets for spending reductions.
The Assembly, while falling far short of the $1.6 billion goal set by the Senate, has expressed a willingess to shoot for at least $1 billion in Medicaid and welfare cuts, some of which will affect recipients.
"We've come a long way in what we're prepared to do," said James R. Tallon Jr. of Binghamton, the Assembly's Majority Leader. "For the Assembly to talk about a billion dollars in Medicaid cuts is a big change."
But Senate aides said they were not convinced that the Assembly was ready to deal seriously with the issue. Unlike the Senate, the Assembly has published only a vague description of the cuts it would accept. "When we see anything from the Assembly that resembles real reform, it will be progress," said Mr. McArdle, the Senate spokesman.
Even if negotiators could agree on the outline of large-scale cuts in Medicaid, they would still face wide and bitter resistance.
"To think that we can just cut a billion dollars out of our health-care system and not have a tremendously negative impact on quality of life is insane," said Dennis Rivera, president of Local 1199 of the Drug, Hospital and Health Care Employees Union, one of the most powerful unions in New York City.
Here are some of the most significant cost-cutting measures backed by the Senate:
*Reducing grants to recipients of home relief, a welfare program for those who do not qualify for Aid to Families with Dependent Children, by 20 percent.
*Eliminating Medicaid coverage for sick-room supplies, ranging from aspirin to crutches, and limiting transportation costs for many Medicaid recipients.
*Requiring fingerprinting and photo identification cards for Medicaid recipients.
*Capping Medicaid reimbursement for personal-care services like the use of private attendants for those unable to care for themselves, at 120 hours a week.
The disputes over what to cut left little hope today of a quick solution to the budget talks.
For Governor Cuomo, events are compelling him to make up his mind about a Presidential campaign, which he has yet, formally anyway, to enter: the filing deadline for the New Hampshire is Dec. 20, with deadlines for a number of larger states coming just days after that. He has insisted that he could not run without some resolution of the budget morass.

HEADLINE: Foundations Bolster Fund For Neediest

BYLINE: By J. PEDER ZANE

 BODY:
Although most donors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are individuals who contribute $100 or less, many foundations provide larger sums in joining the effort to help the city's sick, poor and disabled.
Like many individuals and families, these organizations have made donating to the fund a holiday season ritual. The Starr Foundation in Manhattan, for example, has given money every year since 1983. This year the foundation, founded in 1955 by the insurance executive Cornelius Vander Starr, gave $150,000. 
 And like many of the people who have written to say why they felt it was particularly important to give this year, several foundation representatives said the prolonged recession has made them feel an even greater urgency to contribute.
It was that sense that prompted two foundations started by descendants of Robert Wood Johnson, a founder of Johnson & Johnson, the health-care products company, to make donations of $78,500 this week.
 
'Dig a Little Deeper'
 "It is a difficult time for many people who normally give, so we feel there is an even greater responsibility for those who can to dig a little deeper," a spokesman for the foundations, who declined to be named, said in a telephone interview.
Since it was founded in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, who was then publisher of The New York Times, the Neediest Cases Fund has raised money for New York's sick, poor and disabled. What began as the "Hundred Neediest Cases" has expanded to meet the needs of thousands of people.
As in the past, The New York Times is covering the campaign's overhead costs so that every dollar collected can be passed on directly to seven charities. The money provided many forms of relief, including food for the hungry, shelter for the homeless and clothing for those without.
The broad array of services that the seven charities provide led the Mary J. Hutchins Foundation of Manhattan to contribute $55,000. In a note accompanying the gift, the organization's vice-president, Richard J. Mirabella, observed that the fund provided programs "regardless of race, creed or nationality."
The Starr Foundation's $150,000 donation this year was the second installment of its three-year $450,000 grant. Its president, T. C. Hsu, said one reason his organization continues to support the Neediest Cases was the fund's efficiency. "We know that every penny will go to those who really need it, and in these tough times that's where it has to go," he said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
G.M. Hints Deep Cuts Are Ahead

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 11

 BODY:
Leading the latest round of corporate shrinkage, the General Motors Corporation signaled investors and employees today that deep cutbacks were in the works.
Also today, Xerox and TRW announced that they would make substantial trims. [Page D3.] 
 The Xerox Corporation said it would eliminate 2,500 white-collar jobs, or more than 20 percent of the total, by the middle of next year and take a $175 million pretax charge against earnings.
TRW Inc. said it would sell businesses worth $400 million to $500 million; cut capital spending by more than $100 million next year, or more than 16 percent, and cut 2,500 jobs.
At G.M., which has been bleeding huge sums from its North American operations, Robert C. Stempel, the chairman, said in a terse three-paragraph statement said that details of the cutbacks, which were endorsed by G.M. directors at a board meeting on Monday in Washington, would be explained publicly next Wednesday.
Mr. Stempel's announcement came in reaction to rumors sweeping Detroit and Wall Street, a spokesman said, which depressed the price of G.M. stock in the last week to a four-year low. G.M. closed today at $27.875, down 62.5 cents.
Analysts have been speculating that G.M. will be forced to close several assembly plants, dismiss thousands of white-collar workers and, perhaps, reshuffle its executive suite. They have also been predicting a dividend cut in February.
 
Paring Excess Capacity
 The latest move would be intended to pare excess capacity and thus improve operating efficiency. The excess capacity has resulted from the prolonged automotive recession, as well as G.M.'s failure to gain back any of the market share the auto maker lost in the 1980's. Personnel costs would also be lowered.
Most analysts estimate that G.M. is losing at least $500 million a month in North America. The deficits have been partly balanced by a strong performance by G.M.'s non-automotive subsidiaries and big profits in Germany, where the Adam Opel subsidiary is having a record year. Even so, G.M. posted a net loss of $2.2 billion in the first nine months of 1991.
Although G.M. remains financially strong, it cannot continue to lose such sums. Credit analysts say they are considering a downgrading of G.M.'s bonds and commercial paper.
After the G.M. announcement, the Standard & Poor's Corporation said it would "evaluate management's strategies for restoring the company's creditworthiness. S.& P. expects to conclude its review by early March."
Mr. Stempel's credibility with Wall Street could be endangered if he fails to deliver on his promise to increase capacity utilization to 100 percent by 1993. He has been in office about 18 months, during which time he has kept a low public profile compared with his predecessor, Roger B. Smith.
Until now, Mr. Stempel's style has been to improve efficiency slowly and methodically, but the recent erosion of G.M.'s standing in the credit markets may have prompted a move to bolder action.
"We've never been told how Stempel's going to do it," said John Casesa, an analyst for Wertheim Schroder & Company. "All the speculation without detail creates uncertainty, and the market doesn't like that."
Mr. Stempel, in his statement, said "the magnitude and timing" of an expected charge against earnings from plant closings and personnel reductions "have not yet been determined and will require further management consideration and board review." But he said he expects that charge to be less than the $3.3 billion pretax charge taken during the third quarter of last year to close up to eight plants.
Frank Joyce, a spokesman for the United Automobile Workers, said he would not speculate about details to be released next Wednesday; he was also not aware of any contact between G.M. and the union, which represents G.M.'s 300,000 hourly workers in this country. Union workers are largely protected from lost wages resulting from layoffs or plant closings.
Shutting plants now will be more expensive and complicated for G.M. than in the past. During the 1980's, G.M. closed and wrote off several assembly plants that were idled because the models they produced had been discontinued or were scheduled to be discontinued.
Today, the gap between G.M.'s actual production and capacity is spread among many of G.M.'s 32 North American assembly lines. Thus, said Mr. Casesa of Wortheim Schroder, G.M. must devise a plan to close plants and then move the tooling for some vehicles to other plants, where several models would be produced simultaneously.
Among factories analysts said might be vulnerable are G.M.'s Arlington, Tex., plant, which builds large rear-wheel-drive cars and operates below capacity. G.M.'s Willow Run, Mich., plant builds many of the same models as Arlington and could accommodate extra production.
 
Consolidating Midsize Cars
 Midsize cars built in the plants at Doraville, Ga.; Fairfax, Kan., and Oshawa, Ontario, which have been operating below capacity, could also be consolidated. And G.M.'s Orion Township plant near Detroit could be vulnerable if it is true, as has been rumored, that the new Cadillac Deville will be built at G.M.'s Hamtramck, Mich., factory.
Many G.M. salaried workers may receive financial incentives to leave, analysts said. The number of salaried workers dropped about 30 percent, to 100,000, in the 1980's, but the number is still too high given G.M.'s share of the domestic automotive market. Mr. Casesa estimated that the salaried staff could face an additional 20 percent reduction.
The most sensitive issue for Mr. Stempel may be that of G.M.'s top management. A G.M. spokesman said no top management changes would be announced Wednesday. But changes could occur as plant closings are announced. Historically, G.M. executives, unlike those of the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation, have retained perks, benefits and job titles through good times and bad.
Until Mr. Smith retired, the supposition among auto analysts was that once he was gone, the succeeding generation -- Mr. Stempel and his "team" -- would be free to boldly cure G.M.'s ills.
To break with tradition and to dismiss or demote top fellow team members could be wrenching for Mr. Stempel. If it happened, it would most likely be done in consultation with G.M.'s non-employee directors, who have been taking a sterner, more active stance in recent years. In Mr. Smith's era and earlier, top management changes were normally influenced by the chairman exclusively.
Mr. Stempel has been invited to accompany President Bush to Japan in early January to discuss trade matters, but he is understood to be considering not making the trip.
At Ford today, the company's president, Philip E. Benton Jr., said his company did not plan any major cost-cutting moves in 1992 but would continue to cut its salaried work force and seek greater efficiencies, Bloomberg Business News reported.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Dividend Cut in Half By Caterpillar Board

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill., Dec. 11

 BODY:
The board of Caterpillar Inc. today halved the company's quarterly cash dividend and announced the "probable closing" of a manufacturing plant in York, Pa.
The company, based in Peoria, also said it would consolidate its operations in Brazil, where soaring inflation has hurt the company's earnings. The cost of the plant closings would result in a fourth-quarter charge of $220 million, the company said. 
 Caterpillar said the board had decided to slash the dividend to 15 cents, from 30 cents.
The company has forecast a significant loss for 1991, with uncertainties for next year, because of a worldwide recession and a collapse in demand for construction equipment.
The possible York closing hinges on whether the United Automobile Workers union will agree to contract concessions to reduce costs at the plant. About 9,000 of the union's 16,000 members are idled by a strike, lockout and layoffs. The strike began on Nov. 4 after contract talks broke down.
About 1,900 jobs are at stake at the York plant, including about 1,450 union workers.
"If Caterpillar is unable to make sufficient reductions in the cost structure to make the business unit competitive, including the negotiation of an appropriate agreement with the United Auto Workers union, the business unit will be closed," the company said in the statement.
Caterpillar said the plant was inefficient and too expensive to operate under present conditions.
Another 300 union members work in the York parts distribution center.
If the York operation is closed, Caterpillar would phase it out by 1994.
The shares of Caterpillar fell 37.5 cents each today, to $39, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Xerox Plans to Trim 2,500 From White-Collar Staff

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that it would eliminate 2,500 white-collar jobs, or more than 20 percent of the total, by the middle of next year and take a $175 million pretax charge against earnings in the current quarter to cover the cost.
Xerox said the reductions in managerial and support staff would cut its costs by $150 million next year and $200 million in 1993. 
 All the reductions will come from Xerox's document-processing business, which employs 101,000; production workers, engineers, direct sales and customer service staff will not be affected. The reduction will be most strongly felt in the Rochester region, which will lose up to 800 jobs.
Paul A. Allaire, the company's chairman and chief executive, described the reductions as part of "our ongoing process to create a more efficient, flatter, customer-responsive organization."
He said Xerox, which is based in Stamford, Conn., had decided to accelerate its restructuring because of the uncertainty caused by the weak economy.
"We would have done this over the next two years anyway," he said. "We think we have changed other parts of the company enough that we can do without some of this supervision."
Xerox's stock lost $1.75 a share on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at $61.125.
Some Wall Street analysts viewed the plan as overdue and overly cautious. "It's a first step in the right direction, but the company is still too fat," said Curt Rohrman, of First Boston.
Mr. Rohrman estimated that the reductions would cut Xerox's sales and administration costs to 32 percent of revenue from 33 percent. "Less than 30 percent is a lean company," he said.
Mr. Allaire agreed that Xerox needed to lower its expense ratio further but he said that there were limits to how much could be accomplished by slicing white-collar employees.
Xerox said about 500 jobs would disappear through attrition. The company said it was still uncertain how much of the remainder could come through voluntary programs, but some layoffs would occur before the end of the year.

HEADLINE: Big Bargains In Air Fares Grow Scarce

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
A year ago the nation's airlines, desperate to increase their winter business, were widely advertising bargains like two tickets for the price of one. Couples were flying coast to coast for just $214 a person.
This year has been different. Air fares this winter will probably be higher than a year ago, analysts say. A couple flying coast to coast today would pay at least $468 a person, or $378 after Jan. 15. One reason is that three carriers -- including Midway Airlines, which helped begin the two-for-one fare war last year -- have since gone out of business. And the surviving airlines, which are still losing money, feel more able to resist price cuts now that some competitors are gone. 
 Not only are carriers not reducing fares sharply at this point, but some are also even raising the base rates. The most recent fare increase was announced two days ago by Continental Airlines, which will raise fares $20 round trip on restricted fares as of next Thursday, those requiring Saturday stays, and on vacation fares purchased in advance. The carrier will also eliminate some one-way advance-purchase ticket categories that offered 15 percent discounts off full-price travel.
But if offers like the two-for-one fares are a thing of the past, industry analysts say bargains can still be had, although generally they are not as good as last year's rock-bottom fares, and they require more persistence in finding.
"The major airlines aren't advertising most of their bargains as widely as in the past, because they don't want to set off an industrywide fare war," said Tom Parsons, editor of Best Fares magazine in Arlington, Tex., which lists current travel discounts. "But they are offering more promotional discounts than ever in history."
Like its rivals, Continental is running numerous promotions aimed at customers of supermarket chains, credit-card users, even buyers of deodorants and shampoo. While these fares can save 25 percent or more on any ticket, in most cases they still are not as low as last winter's best prices.
 
Chapter 11 Airlines
 America West Airlines, which like Continental is operating under Chapter 11, offers a $298 round-trip fare between New York and Los Angeles or San Francisco. America West is also honoring a Continental coupon worth $50 that can be found in the magazine Entertainment Publication, for a $248 round-trip fare.
Customers of Furr's Supermarkets, a large chain in the Southwest, can buy certificates offering 25 percent off any Continental flight of $199 or more within the continental United States. Customers of Stop and Shop, a supermarket chain in New England, can save a like amount on USAir. And those who buy a "Home Alone" video can receive a certificate offering discounts up to $100 on American Airlines flights to Europe.
In addition, a Southwest Airlines promotion enables passengers to take a companion for free, while America West offers a free companion ticket or 50 percent off the passenger's own ticket to Hawaii. All those offers are freighted with restrictions, usually including advance purchase, a Saturday night stay and many dates when they are not valid for travel.
"A few years ago there were few such promotions," Mr. Parsons said. "Now we're seeing 20 to 25 new ones a month."
The reason is that they allow airlines to cut fares on a limited basis. Contrast that with November 1990, when American Airlines offered its frequent flier holders a chance to buy a second ticket on certain routes for $50. Midway Airlines quickly extended the offer to the general public, and before long most other airlines were giving the second ticket free.
In fact, the airline industry lost a record $4 billion last year, not only because of these offers but also from a doubling of the cost of fuel during the Persian Gulf crisis. This year, a year in which Eastern Airlines, Midway and Pan American went out of business, officials say the industry will lose almost $2 billion.
 
Strong Financial Pressures
 "We see air fares increasing next year because of financial pressures on the carriers," said Robert Harrell, a vice president of American Express Travel Related Services. Business travelers, he said, should expect about a 10 percent fare increase.
Even at that, the airline industry contends that it still has a lot of catching up to do. USTravel, a nationwide travel agency based in Rockville, Md., has calculated that 1990 fares adjusted for inflation were 18 percent below those of 1978, before deregulation.
One exception to the low-key approach to bargain fares is American Airlines' recently announced discount fares to Europe, during the slow travel season of Jan. 12 through April 7. The fares -- with the usual restrictions, and subject to availability -- are $318 round trip to Europe from Boston, $338 from New York, $358 from other East Coast cities and $478 from the West Coast, as well as Dallas/Fort Worth and Chicago.
Most of American's competitors announced similar deals, and Virgin Atlantic said it would charge $1 less than American from its five gateways in the United States.

HEADLINE: Japan Trade Surplus Grows

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 11

 BODY:
Japan's trade surplus nearly tripled in November, the Government said today, and economic analysts predicted international pressure on Tokyo would increase.
Japan's trade balance widened to a $6.56 billion surplus before seasonal adjustment, from $2.24 billion in November 1990. Japan's surplus with the United States edged slightly higher in November to $3.59 billion from $3.56 billion a year earlier. 
 "It shows a continuing reversal of the trade adjustment process and is bound to increase trade friction with the U.S.," said Marshall Gittler, an economist at UBS Phillips and Drew International.
Seasonally adjusted, the surplus widened to $7.45 billion against $6.44 billion in October, which was revised downward from the figure initially reported.
"It's likely to put more pressure on Japan to open up its rice market in the Uruguay Round of GATT negotiations," Mr. Gittler said, referring to the current round of negotiations under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Tax-Free Fund Yields Fall After Increase in Demand

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields on tax-exempt money market funds began to retreat in the week ended yesterday, after rising in the previous seven-day period, according to the latest figures from IBC/Donoghue's, which monitors the funds and publishes The Money Fund Report. Taxable funds continued their long decline.
"Recent rising yields of the tax exempts attracted investor attention, and the law of supply and demand helps explain the declining yields of the past week," said Walter S. Frank, chief economist at IBC/Donoghue's. 
 The total assets of the tax-exempt funds rose $1.9 billion, to $93.4 billion. The average days to maturity of the tax-free funds was unchanged at 58 days.
The seven-day compound average yield for the tax-exempt funds was 3.75 percent, down 5 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, from the previous week's 3.80 percent. The seven-day simple yield declined to 3.68 percent, also down 5 basis points.
The 30-day compound yield dropped t0 3.77 percent, down 2 basis points from the previous week, while the 30-day simple yield was also down 2 basis points, to 3.70.
 
Single-State Funds
 Among tax-exempt funds investing in individual state securities, the top New York fund was again the Salomon Brothers New York Municipal Money Market Fund, which reported a seven-day compound yield of 4.47 percent, up from 4.44 percent the previous week.
In Connecticut, the top-yielding fund again was the Prudential Connecticut Municipal Money Market Series with a seven-day compound yield of 4.04 percent, down from 4.16 percent the previous week.
New Jersey's leading fund for yields was again the Calvert Tax Free Reserve New Jersey fund, with a seven-day compound yield of 4.24 percent, down 11 basis points from 4.35 percent.
Among the funds nationwide with $100 million or more in assets, the highest yield performance was again turned in by the Strong Municipal Money Market Fund, with a seven-day compound yield of 4.74 percent, down 9 basis points from 4.83 percent.
 
Big Rise in Taxable-Fund Assets
 Mr. Frank said the total assets of the taxable funds rose a sharp $5.6 billion, to $478.1 billion, with $4.7 billion coming from institutional investors.
"This is a direct consequence of the recent Federal Reserve's easing of the Federal funds rate," he said. "This left money funds as the highest yielding alternaitve for cash assets."
The average days to maturity of the portfolio holdings were unchanged from a week earlier at 62 days.
The seven-day compound yield on the taxable funds was 4.73, down from 4.77 percent a week earlier, while the seven-day simple yield was 4.63, down from 4.66.
The average compound 30-day yield was 4.81 percent, down from 4.86, and the 30-day simple yield was also off 5 basis points, to 4.70 percent. Among the taxable funds, the top- yielding fund for the week was the Riverside Capital Fund of Columbus, Ohio, with a surprisingly high seven-day compound yield of 13.96 percent versus 5.96 percent a week earlier, attributable to its taking capital gains. Bank money market accounts, a main competitor of money funds, dropped to a yield of 4.59 percent from 4.65 percent the previous week, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index.

HEADLINE: S.& L. Industry Posts Profit For 3d Consecutive Quarter

BYLINE: By Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11

 BODY:
The nation's savings and loans not under Government control were profitable in the third quarter, the third period in a row in the black and the first time since 1986 that the industry has posted earnings in three consecutive periods.
"We are cautiously optimistic that this will be the first year in a number of years the thrift industry will have a profit," Timothy Ryan, the director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, told reporters today. 
 The savings associations earned $271.8 million in the third quarter, compared with a loss of $773.6 million in the comparable period of 1990, the thrift office said.
The improvement, which was attributed in part to falling interest rates, excludes the insolvent savings institutions that are being operated by the Government under a huge Federal program to close and sell failed institutions. There are 87 such savings and loans, out of some 640 that have failed since the cleanup began in August 1989.
The thrift office said that of the 2,148 savings institutions still in private hands, 86 percent were profitable in the quarter that ended Sept. 30, with a net after-tax income of about $1.4 billion. That was offset by losses of some $1.2 billion incurred by the remaining 14 percent.
Interest rates have been falling all year, largely because of the Federal Reserve's policy to make credit more easily available in an effort to stimulate the moribund economy.
As a result, savings and loans were able to charge, on average, a record 2.4 percentage points more for loans than they paid out on deposits, the thrift office said.
But those profits were largely offset by new reserves that the institutions had to set aside to cover potential losses on loans and by assets like real estate that are not earning interest.
Without Government assistance, the industry would not have been profitable at all. The industry's profits included $421.6 million in Government assistance provided under deals negotiated before the current bailout program was put in place.
Before the program is finished, taxpayers are expected to have to pay some $500 billion over 40 years, including interest. The Office of Thrift Supervision said second-quarter profits of the industry were revised to $275.4 million from the $386.8 million originally reported. Officials said the revision reflected amended reports submitted by the industry.

HEADLINE: Incinerators: Unwanted and Politically Dangerous

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TINTON FALLS, N.J., Dec. 7

 BODY:
This is where the voters of Monmouth County decided to save the earth.
After months of watching mothers in gas masks and riot gear predict apocalypse for their tranquil community, residents here last month rejected an incinerator that had been planned -- and approved -- for nearly a decade. It was the first referendum of its kind in the state, and it will soon leave this rapidly growing county with nowhere to put its garbage. 
 "The whole thing was a case study in hysteria," said Robert Collins, the County Administrator, who has supported both the plant and the county's aggressive recycling program. "We had the best technology and a perfect location. It didn't matter. It never does. What happened here will happen all over the country."
It already has. Opponents of a proposed incinerator at the Brooklyn Navy Yard have promised to block it with their bodies if they have to. From Baltimore to Nashville and Boston to San Diego, any politician who supports the burning of garbage risks political death. It has become Long Island's most powerful single issue. Last month, Assemblyman Lewis J. Yevoli ran for Oyster Bay Supervisor with a solid promise: no new incinerators. A Democrat in a Republican fortress, he won handily.
The Tinton Falls decision was typical of the opposition that confronts virtually every proposed incinerator in America. Yet even their most vigorous detractors acknowledge that, as the population grows and landfills rapidly close, incinerators have become critical, particularly in crowded cities with little land. Recycling has frequently been embraced as an ecologically sensitive alternative -- but even where it succeeds, recycling offers only partial solutions. Despite the controversy they cause, waste managment officials agree, incinerators have never been more essential.
"We can run from this some more, and we will," said Steven M. Polan, who recently announced his resignation as New York City Santitation Commissioner, in part out of frustration over his inability to enhance recycling or build incinerators. "But in this city we have more garbage and less land than anyone in America. We can spend every tax dollar we have to find a home for our garbage in the Midwest at the expense of police, teachers and hospitals if that's what we really want. It isn't a question of recycle or burn. We have to do both."
Incinerators are easy to hate. They are ugly, expensive and, with their smoke belching into the skies, present a convenient symbol for the degradation of the environment. But each American generates nearly four pounds of garbage every day -- in New York City, the figure is nearly twice that -- and as the country's population grows, its options have begun to vanish. Although environmental groups constantly warn that incinerators will bring increased health risks to nearby residents, most scientific studies contradict their assertions.
"There is absolutely no serious data to support the view that proper burning is dangerous," said Richard Magee, executive director of the Hazardous Substance Research Center in Newark, which is financed by New Jersey universities, businesses and government agencies. "They are regulated far more stringently than wood-burning stoves or cars."
 
The Advent of NIMTOO
 The issue has left municipalities across the nation flailing in political quicksand. Because incinerators have become so unpopular, few politicians will propose them. A new acronym, NIMTOO -- for Not In My Term Of Office -- has emerged to describe the paralysis. As long as someone comes to pick up the garbage, most civic leaders find other things to worry about. But by putting off inevitable decisions, most solid-waste experts agree, places from Monmouth County to Los Angeles end up spending millions in additional fees for landfills, incinerators or recycling plants.
Irrational agreements between neighboring towns have become common. On Long Island, Hempstead burns 200 tons of Huntington's waste every day. But North Hempstead ships its trash to Ohio for half of what it would cost to burn it in Hempstead.
In Tinton Falls, the $240 million plant would have extended the life of the local landfill by at least 30 years, according to county studies. Without the new plant, the landfill will run out of space by the end of the decade. The 1,700-ton-a-day plant would have become part of a comprehensive waste plan -- it includes a recycling center at the same location -- that has been in place since 1985, a year before the state began to require recycling. The plant would have generated enough energy to provide electricity to at least 40,000 dwellings.
In New York, Mr. Polan, the Sanitation Commissioner, has said that the city will have to burn at least 10,000 tons of garbage each day in several new or refurbished plants. The city produces nearly 27,000 tons of refuse daily, and has not built a new garbage-burning plant in 30 years.
The city exports much of its commercial waste to dumps from Pennsylvania to Montana. Of the 15 million tons of garbage sent across state lines in the United States in 1989, 53 percent came from New York and New Jersey. Congress may soon allow states to prevent such commerce, however, and that would hasten the arrival of a garbage crisis for the region. Currently residential recycling accounts for less than 6 percent of New York's waste.
 
Dinkins Changes His Mind
 During his campaign for mayor in 1989, David N. Dinkins thrilled incinerator opponents by calling for an absolute moratorium on any new construction. But with the city's recycling program struggling, he has recently changed his mind. Advocates of new incinerators, particularly the one at the Brooklyn Navy Yard that has been under study for years, consider his endorsement tepid. They say the city will need several such plants in coming years, and it will take a committed mayor to convince residents to support them.
Opponents, however, see the administration's change of heart as a treacherous retreat from its stated goal, recycling at least 25 percent of its garbage by the end of the century.
"The city has never even tried to use its marketing muscle to make recycling work," said John F. Ruston, an economic analyst at the Environmental Defense Fund.
It has become impossible to discuss recycling or incineration without discussing both. For incinerators to work properly -- at high enough temperatures -- they must use large amounts of trash. Often, however, the trash that burns best, particularly plastics and paper, also makes the most sense to recycle.
Advocates of a stronger recycling program say that if New York and nearby cities and counties paid more attention to developing markets for their recycled waste, they would have considerably less need to burn. Without a commitment to increase recycling, few paper-pulping or glass-grinding companies -- the companies that are needed to make it work -- are willing to invest.
As a result, none of the major environmental groups in New York will say publicly that they support new incinerators until the city greatly increases a recycling program that costs far more than initial projections and has struggled to attain its most modest goals.
"Incineration should be the last resort, not the first," said Eric A. Goldstein, a senior attorney with the National Resources Defense Council. "Only after we have implemented comprehensive regionwide recycling programs can we begin to think about it as an alternative." Communities that have relied solely on incinerators have been unable even to consider reasonable recycling programs.
Recycling has often been seen as a "green" approach to managing waste. But even when it succeeds, it can create problems.
Seattle and Newark have often been presented as models of appropriate trash reduction. Newark recycles more than half its waste and burns the rest in a modern incinerator that converts heat to energy. In Seattle, the American mecca of waste reduction, recycling officials cannot begin to unload all the glass, paper and plastic they collect. Paper that costs the city more than $100 a ton to collect, sort and process sells for about $10 a ton on the open market. If Seattle gets any better at recycling, it may be forced to truck recycled waste to out of state landfills.
"If you did this on economics alone," said Mr. Polan, "burning would be the only answer."
Yet disruptions from truck traffic and the high cost of incinerators -- as much as $500 million for a major plant -- scare many municipalities. Health questions persist as well.
But the risks of incineration, despite the often angry protests, are small. Estimates of the chances of developing cancer are often based on exaggerated assumptions. With incinerators, those assumptions often include breathing heavily 24 hours a day for 70 years at the spot where the greatest emissions fall.
With modern pollution control equipment, such tests predict that the chances are less than one in a million that the most heavily exposed person would develop cancer as a result of a nearby incinerator. A chest X-ray, by comparison, carries a risk of about six cancers in a million.
Burning what cannot be recycled reduces its volume by nearly 90 percent. The heat in new plants is converted to steam for electricity. Ash produced by combustion can contain unhealthy levels of heavy metals and other pollutants, but when deposited properly in a lined landfill they pose little danger.
"It is one thing to have legitimate objections, as many do," said Paul Casowitz, a former Deputy Sanitiation Commissioner under Mayor Koch who is now at Sieve, Paget and Riesel, a law firm. "But there are also those that take advantage of the fear. They have a political stake in creating hysteria. These are the guys who in the Middle Ages said, 'There are witches here, and I can find them.' As long as they have clout, this is a problem without a solution."


GRAPHIC: Cross section of the proposed plant at the old Brooklyn Navy Yard
 
1. Garbage arrives along the East River in barges.
 
2. A crane lifts garbage into a chute that drops to a furnace.
 
3. Furnace temperature is kept at a minimum of 1,800 degrees, burning barbage in about 30 minutes. Ash is taken to a landfill.
 
4. Gases produced in the furnace rise past pipes carrying water; the water is turned to steam taht is sent to a Con Edison plant nearby to help produce electricity.
 
5. Gases also pass through a scrubber that neutralizes acids, and then through tight mesh fiberglass filters that catch small particles.
 
6. Cleansed gasses rise through a 500-foot-high smokestack. (Sourc: New York City Sanitation Department)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Fedders Layoffs

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: EFFINGHAM, Ill., Dec. 11

 BODY:
Seven hundred workers of the Fedders Corporation have been temporarily laid off while production at an Illinois air-conditioner plant is shut down. The layoffs were prompted by a seasonal reduction in demand for air-conditioners and slumping sales caused by the weak economy, said Barbara VanBlarcum, a Fedders spokeswoman. The workers are expected to be recalled on Jan. 6, she said. The plant, which makes room air-conditioners, was on a restricted production schedule because of slack demand. The plant, which closed last weekend, was also shut down at the same time last year. Fedders is based in Peapack, N.J.

HEADLINE: Court Setback to ZZZZ Best

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11

 BODY:
The Supreme Court, in a case stemming from the financial collapse of the ZZZZ Best Company, today ruled in favor of creditors who make long-term loans to businesses on the verge of bankruptcy.
By a 9-to-0 vote, the Justices said Federal law does not automatically give financially distressed companies the power to recover interest they paid on long-term loans shortly before declaring bankruptcy. 
 The High Court said lower courts must decide whether such loans had been made "in the ordinary course of business." If that is so, the Justices said, the bankrupt businesses then may not be entitled to recover the interest payments.
The ruling is at least a preliminary victory for Union Bank in California, which is seeking interest payments that ZZZZ Best paid the bank on a $7 million loan before the company's collapse.
The carpet-cleaning concern was founded by Barry Minkow as a teenager in his parents' garage. He was sentenced to 25 years in prison for Federal securities, credit card and mail fraud violations in a scheme to bilk investors and banks of more than $100 million.
ZZZZ Best used a scheme in which money from later investors was used to pay early debts while nearly no work was actually performed by the company.
Union Bank, owned by the Bank of Tokyo, agreed to provide the company in December 1986 with an eight-month, $7 million line of credit.
ZZZZ Best made monthly interest payments totaling more than $270,000 until it filed for bankruptcy in July 1987 under the Chapter 11 provision
Herbert Wolas, a court-appointed trustee for the bankrupt company, sought to recover the interest payments to Union Bank and use the money to pay off other ZZZZ Best creditors.
The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled in Mr. Wolas's favor in 1990.
But today the High Court said Federal bankruptcy law does not distinguish between short-term and long-term debt.

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Islanders Are Staying Home, but Will Get a New Look

BYLINE: By ROBIN FINN

 BODY:
It isn't the sale to end all sales, but it has, at least for the foreseeable future, ended speculation that Long Island was on the verge of losing its only professional sports team, the New York Islanders.
The Islanders will remain on the Island, and their absentee owner, John O. Pickett Jr., will continue to hold the majority interest in the club. But starting in January, the full operating control of the franchise will be ceded to two local investment firms that have joined forces to purchase up to 50 percent of the team. 
 The buyers, Walsh, Greenwood, & Company of New Hyde Park and First Long Island Investors Inc., of Jericho, said Pickett's agreement to give them full managerial power was pivotal to the completion of the deal. Stephen Walsh, a managing partner in Walsh, Greenwood, and Robert Rosenthal, president of First Long Island Investors, will assume key directorial roles within the franchise if the sale is approved, as expected, next month by the National Hockey League.
 
Control Was Important
 "Operational control of the team will be vested in our two groups; to make the investment we'll ultimately have to make, we had to have that control," said Rosenthal, whose consortium has the option of acquiring a 50 percent share of the club within the next five years. "It's an investment that can make sense economically, philanthropically, and it's going to be exciting, we hope. But we had to try and separate the two things, being hockey fans but being businessmen, when we pursued the investment."
Their aim, said Walsh, is to first resuscitate the team's image and standing both on the ice and in the community, and then bring a fifth Stanley Cup to Long Island.
"We're not interested in financial leverage, we're interested in operating leverage," said Walsh. "The team has a tremendous history and tradition, and what we're interested in doing is coming in to turn something around: the model here is not that dissimilar to the Dallas Cowboys, a great tradition, and a great franchise that had kind of lost their way."
 
A Hockey Merger
 Although both firms had separately investigated the possibility of purchasing the franchise since Pickett announced last spring his intention to sell it, it was not until midsummer, when a conversation between Walsh and Rosenthal turned to business after a day on the golf course, that they combined resources and pooled their bid.
Pickett initially hoped to sell the team in its entirety for $70 to 90 million, but when no offers approached that figure, he grew more receptive to the notion of retaining his investment in the franchise while severing his responsibility for its daily operation. Pickett refused to disclose his selling price, which sources estimated at $25 to 35 million.
Walsh and Rosenthal said they were in full support of the Oct. 25 trade that was a face lift for the franchise, removing the malcontent superstar, Pat LaFontaine, and the Stanley Cup veteran Brent Sutter and replacing them with an array of younger prospects like Pierre Turgeon, Adam Creighton, Steve Thomas, and Benoit Hogue.
While a major renovation of the team's corporate and community marketing stance appears imminent, Walsh and Rosenthal said they did not expect to make wholesale changes on the ice. They implied that the jobs of Bill Torrey, the general manager, and Coach Al Arbour, both 20-year veterans of the franchise, were not in jeopardy.
"We are businessmen, and I don't see us getting involved with the on-ice side of things in the direct sense, except of course we'd like to win a Stanley Cup," said Walsh. "I have the utmost respect for Bill Torrey and Al Arbour: they've already done it four times and I assume they know how to do it again."
