HEADLINE: Through Loophole In Tax Law, Art Gifts Pour Into Museums

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN

 BODY:
The San Diego Historical Society already knows what it's getting for Christmas: a set of vintage Lionel trains. A museum in Rhode Island has asked for an exotic 17th-century Turkish towel. And the Whitney Museum of American Art has its heart set on a self-portrait by Chuck Close. At the Metropolitan Museum, it's been Christmas all year. Over the last 11 months, the Met has been given $28.3 million worth of art by donors, almost six times more than it received in 1990, including important works by Degas and Pissaro, and an outstanding collection of pre-Columbian gold.
The reason for this gift-giving bonanza is a loophole in the Federal tax law that permits donors of valuable objects to deduct their full market value on income-tax returns. The one-year "window" was due to expire at the end of this year -- thus, the last-minute rush of giving -- but has now been extended by Congress for the first six months of 1992. 
 The window was adopted last year as an experiment after congressional leaders decided that the 1986 Tax Reform Act might have gone too far by eliminating such deductions and leading to a precipitate drop in donations. The extension was passed late last month after a vigorous lobbying campaign in Congress spearheaded by the American Association of Museums. "Our victory was probably a result of being swept along with the tide of several anti-recession measures," said Edward Able, the association's executive director. But he said he expected "a terrific battle" in Congress in the spring.
 
Revenue Loser a Target
 "Many members of Congress now understand how valuable this tax break has been for museums," Mr. Able said, "but they also have to contend with the Federal deficit, and consequently any revenue loser is going to have an uphill battle."
In the meantime, museums throughout the country, which have been buffeted by cuts in government and private aid, are pleased about the opportunity the tax window offers. The Los Angeles County Museum of Art, for instance, has received more than twice as many gifts as it did in any year since the 1986 tax law took effect.
But the important thing, said Earl A. Powell 3d, the museum's director, is not the number of gifts "but the fact that many of them this year have been great masterpieces, including works by Giacometti, Rodin, Frank Stella, Clyfford Still and others: they range across all of our collections."
At the Whitney and the National Gallery of Art in Washington, the effect of the tax window has been accentuated by long-planned donation drives.
David Ross, director of the Whitney, said: "There's a rumor that Carter Brown convinced Congress to create the tax window to help with the celebration of the National Gallery's 50th anniversary. I don't know if that's true, but certainly the combination of the tax window and our own 60th anniversary has been extremely helpful." Mr. Brown is the head of the National Gallery. The Whitney has received so many gifts recently that it has had to postpone its new-acquisitions exhibition until May.
 
Gifts Galore
 Ruth Kaplan, a spokeswoman for the National Gallery, said that "while we'd love to take credit for the tax-window legislation, the fact is that Carter Brown, as a Federal employee, is not permitted to lobby Congress."
She said gifts to the National Gallery had soared this year, from an average of 280 a year between 1987 and 1990, to 1,514 in just the first 10 months of 1991. "Obviously," she said, "both the tax window and our 50th anniversary activities have had an impact."
Anne d'Harnoncourt, director of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, said that an unusually large number of substantial gifts were still being negotiated, and that many artworks already willed to the museum were instead being donated because of the loophole. "It's been a splendid year," she said. "It was a spurring of generosity that was already there."
Smaller institutions have also benefited from the loophole. The Museum of Art at the Rhode Island School of Design in Providence, for instance, has received more than 2,000 gifts, an almost sixfold increase from last year.
"We're receiving a very important collection of textiles, including an outstanding 17th-century Turkish towel, pre-Columbian pieces, and a remarkable Italian velvet," said Frank Robinson, director of the museum. "The collection had been on loan here for three years, but when the tax window opened, we got it."
 
A Rise at the Getty, Too
 And the San Diego Historical Society received a multi-million-dollar donation of vintage toys, including a virtually complete set of everything produced by Lionel Trains and Buddy 'L' toys from the turn of the century to the early 1940's.
The country's wealthiest museum, the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., has received only 15 or 16 donations this year, said Lori Starr, head of public information at the institution. But even that relatively small number, she said, is an increase over the "handful" of gifts received over the last couple of years.
Some museum directors have vigorously publicized the tax window. Lin Nelson-Mayson, curator of the collections of the Columbia Museum of Art in Columbia, S.C., sent letters to people who had lent artworks to the museum pointedly informing them about the loophole. "We enclosed a pamphlet explaining the law so that our approach wouldn't be a scary process," said Ms. Nelson-Mayson.
As a result, the museum was given a fifth-century B.C. Phoenician amphora that had been on loan since 1972, a collection of fourth-century B.C. Greek funerary objects, on loan since 1974, and many other works.
There is a dark side to all of this public largess, however, one that museum officials are reluctant to discuss for fear of discouraging potential donors. Many proffered gifts are not as choice as their would-be donors believe them to be, and so must be rejected. The museum director who looks a gift horse in the mouth, no matter how graciously, may live to regret having offended a wealthy patron.
Moreover, the process of acquisition -- which may involve authentication, cataloguing, conservation and storage -- gobbles up staff hours. Mr. Powell of the Los Angeles County Museum chuckled over the matter, and remarked, "That's a problem we look forward to dealing with!" But the fact is that many museums, severely pinched by recession-driven budget and staff cuts, are at a loss to find qualified people to handle the influx.
 
The Risk of Overvaluing
 Furthermore, even in ordinary times museums run the risk of being seen as giving lavish tax deductions to the rich by overvaluing their gifts. In one dramatic example, Jiri Frel, curator of antiquities at the Getty Museum, was relieved of his post in 1984 after an investigation revealed that he had encouraged donations by overvaluing more than 6,000 artworks received by the museum.
Still, museum officials believe that the practice of overvaluation, while rampant in years past, was sharply curtailed by the tax law of 1984, which requires that appraisals be made by experts with no connection to the recipient institution, and also subjects appraisers to stiff fines if they overvalue a donation by 150 percent or more.
"Some people will still try anything," said Ashton Hawkins, executive vice president and counsel to the trustees of the Metropolitan Museum, "but I think the problem of overvaluation has been effectively dealt with. Appraisers are on notice that if they go way out of line, they're risking their careers."

LENGTH: 515 words

HEADLINE: Leap to Unity in Europe

 BODY:
A generation from now when schoolchildren study Europe's resurgence after World War II, they may well focus on this week's summit meeting in the Dutch city of Maastricht as a decisive event. Members of the European Community approved treaties that will forge common economic, foreign and defense policies. The idea is to propel Europe into the 21st century as a cohesive power able to meet economic and political challenges from North America and Asia.
Agreement didn't come easily. Bitter disputes, especially between Britain and the rest of the E.C., were only overcome by hard bargaining and compromise. That allowed each country to leave Maastricht a victor, and Europe to claim the biggest prize of all: enhanced unity. 
 The most important economic decision was to adopt a single currency, controlled by a central bank, before the end of the century. By eliminating separate currencies, the E.C. will strip away layers of unnecessary cost in doing business across the Continent. The only holdout was Britain, which hasn't decided whether it wants to discard its own currency, and therefore its own monetary policy, for the sake of monetary cohesion. Although Britain retained the right to keep the pound, few experts believe it will choose monetary isolation.
Also dividing Britain from its neighbors was the issue of a social charter -- adoption by majority vote of communitywide rules on, for example, minimum wages, vacation time, working conditions and labor-management relations. The Tory Government saw this as an imposition of expensive government mandates that would force British employers to lay off low-skilled workers. Britain insisted that such rules be adopted only by consensus.
Here, too, the solution was to let Britain opt out. That could be troubling; the E.C. fears that employers might flock to the country offering the least onerous regulations.
The U.S. will be pleased by the Maastricht treaties because they unify Europe in a way that virtually rules out a repetition of internal rivalries that led to two World Wars. And a unified economy should prove to be a prosperous economy, assuring the U.S. high-quality imports and a vibrant market for its exports.
Americans could have been threatened if the Maastricht conference had turned protectionist, passing rules that would have locked out U.S. goods and investors. But that didn't happen. Indeed, the E.C. decided that aid to specific industries will have to be approved unanimously. That's good protection against protectionists.
The treaties also outline sensible rudiments of a common defense policy, emphasizing that it will remain closely tied to NATO. And they commit E.C. members to coordinating foreign, judicial, immigration and police policies.
The language of the treaties is general, making their institution uncertain. But they are a grand foundation on which to build Europe's future. If European Community members proceed in the same spirit of constructive compromise, the next generation's schoolchildren will read about Maastricht as the prelude to glorious prosperity.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Gorby Invites the Deluge

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

 BODY:
Revealing the true colors of a tyrant, Mikhail Gorbachev now seeks to thwart the democratic will of the independent republics of his former empire by bidding for the support of the veteran Red Army generals.
He is responding to the declaration of independence and formation of a commonwealth by Russia, Ukraine and Byelorussia by encouraging what amounts to a military coup. 
 That puts the truth nakedly, but even his remaining apologists in the West cannot escape this fact: He seeks to enlist the power of arms to overrule the decision of elected representatives of the freed peoples.
The new line of our discredited stay-in-the-union set is that Mr. Gorbachev is seeking only to control the nuclear weaponry in four of the newly independent states, and that it is in the interest of world safety that the West discreetly support his struggle to maintain central Kremlin control.
The opposite is true. The danger to order in the former internal empire comes from entrenched apparatchiks seducing the troubled military. The resistance of the unelectable old guard to ineluctable change is the main source of instability.
What is causing the U.S. Ambassador, Robert Strauss, to bewail the "wild card" of the Red Army, and inducing our new Director of Central Intelligence to send solons to dictionaries with his predictions of "xenophobic atavism"?
Not the responsible and orderly transfer of power undertaken by Boris Yeltsin, until recently the object of scorn as a "buffoon" by Brent Scowcroft, Mr. Bush's much-touted strategic aide. Not the historic referendum for freedom by Ukraine, instructed not to indulge in "suicidal nationalism" by President Bush in his infamous "Chicken Kiev" speech.
On the contrary; the fears of upheaval and chaos being fanned by so many union-minded Gorbachevites are caused by the clique trying to exaggerate those fears to cling to power. In the French proverb quoted by Madame de Pompadour to Louis XV: Apres nous le deluge.
Consider what Mr. Gorbachev, reformer without a cause, has done in response to this week's swift but peaceable replacement of the Soviet Union with a commonwealth of the core republics.
He marched to the old Defense Ministry, reminded the generals that he still held the title of Commander in Chief and admonished Marshal Shaposhnikov for having prematurely welcomed the commonwealth's proposal of a sharing of "strategic military space."
If the Defense Minister had been Gen. Mikhail Moiseyev, Mr. Gorbachev's first choice to replace the faithless Marshal Yazov after the August coup, few doubt that the Red Army chief would have saluted and obeyed Gorbachev orders to assert the Kremlin center's military control over the republics.
But Marshal Shaposhnikov was a Yeltsin choice, and is torn between protecting his sponsor and saving his officer corps from the hardships of demobilization. He temporized.
In the face of this threat from the old union's Defense Ministry, Mr. Yeltsin did what he did during the August coup: went publicly to the Russian regional commanders (and privately to the arm of the K.G.B. in Moscow now under his control). He promised "to make the life of servicemen better" to counter the Gorbachev bribes.
Thus has Mr. Gorbachev's appeal to military leaders increased the potential for civil war, even as he hints at its dire consequences. More likely, however, the Gorbachev military move has started a different kind of war -- a bidding war between politicians for the support of the military.
The first thing the new republic's economies need is a drastic reduction in military spending; the last thing needed is pressure to maintain expensive forces. But if you were a general, with your lifelong colleagues facing unemployment, wouldn't you play one politician off against the other?
Postponing demobilization takes food off civilian tables and prevents recovery. That is the terrible consequence of Mr. Gorbachev's latest grab for power.
Our diplomatists should stop wistfully dreaming of him as a source of stability and see him for what he has become in his final throes: a tinhorn despot reaching for military mastery; a source not of nuclear control but of civil upheaval; and a man trying to arrange a deluge to follow his certain downfall.

HEADLINE: Business, Like the Voters, Is Worrying About the Economy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
If there was one clear message from this year's election results, in New York State and across the country, it is that voters are worried about the sick state of the economy. 
 Just glance to New Jersey, where Democrats lost control of the Legislature, or look at local officials in New York who will be out of work come January. Look to the attention President Bush and Congress are now paying to the economy.
The business community is worried too. Our concerns only deepened with the news that New York State's potential budget gap for next year may be twice as large as earlier believed. Business leaders agree that state government needs major structural reform if New York is ever going to regain its fiscal health. And we agree that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the Legislature need to make those changes now.
We also couldn't agree more with what the voters said on Election Day -- that raising taxes isn't the answer. After three years of crisis budgets, quick fixes and multibillion-dollar tax increases on everything from income to linoleum, New York's budget is still out of balance.
Look at the first seven months of this fiscal year. According to the most recent figures from the state comptroller, overall revenues from state sources are up 9 percent -- some $1.6 billion -- from last year. That's a nice boost in the pocketbook.
Though revenues have grown at nearly twice the inflation rate, the state is still broke because New York is outspending its income. Social services spending alone, driven largely by explosive increases in Medicaid costs, is rising some 16 percent over last year, or $1.4 billion.
More people are out of work and more people are sick and needing health care. While that's a sad and unfortunate reality of a poor economy, it's an understandable side effect. What's more difficult to comprehend is that our Medicaid costs had been growing at a horrendous pace even before the economy dipped.
The economy isn't getting any better and may be getting worse. New York State budgets for the last few years have been made on the assumption that recovery was just around the corner. The problem is that nobody quite knows where the corner is.
Clearly, elected officials in Albany and in local governments need a new approach. They need to break away from short-term, patchwork responses and to make major structural reforms for long-term solutions.
And they have to realize that voters aren't going to be happy with further taxes on businesses when they see those increases result in more job losses.
 
DANIEL B. WALSH
President
Business Council of New York State
Albany, Nov. 25, 1991

HEADLINE: SKIING;
Reading for the Best Line on Slopes

BYLINE: By JANET NELSON

 BODY:
By almost any measure, skiing cannot be called a user-friendly sport. Going up and down a mountain is simple compared with the logistics of getting there, tending equipment, taking lessons, eating, sleeping and snatching a bit of nightlife.
That's probably the reason so many books are written about skiing and so many skiers read them. They are keys to basic survival, or at least a reduction of hassles, and they represent a minimalist route to pleasure. 
 Recent book offerings bear this out with hardly any of the coffee-table variety, but plenty of how-to, what-it's-like and getting-the-best-deal books published in soft cover. As gifts, these books are appropriate for skiers from beginners to experts.
Two books, published annually, which promise to keep traveling skiers up to date are "Skiing America" and "Ski Europe" (World Leisure, $14.95 each) by Charles Leocha and a group of contributing writers. Both books are loaded with facts, prices and names to help skiers cope at practically all the major ski resorts in North America and the Alps. They also provide advice on choosing a ski package, getting around Europe and finding friends to ski with.
 
Resorts Around the World
 In "The Traveling Skier" (Doubleday, $13), Andrew Slough covers a selection of ski resorts around the world, telling of his adventures with style and refreshing frankness. Also, numerous boxes with practical information about lodging, transportation and other facets of travel are scattered through the text.
"The Insider's Guide to the Best Skiing in New England" (Western Eye Press, $11.95) by Peter Oliver has a more limited scope, but provides an insider's view -- warts and all. Besides essential facts, the Starter's Kit segments about each of the 22 areas offers advice and caveats for newcomers. Lots of opinion and even wit make this worth reading for Eastern skiers.
All of Vermont's areas are covered alphabetically and more or less equally in "Ski Vermont!" (Chelsea Green Publishing Co., $16.95) by Jules Older. The straightforward presentation includes history as well as facts and figures, plus some advice. The author knows his subject.
 
Focusing on the Lodging
 Marge Lamy has made the selections carefully in "Cross Country Ski Inns" (Snow Vacations, $16.95), so the author has few complaints about the inns in the Northeast and Quebec that she describes. Despite the lack of criticism, there are differences in charm and amenities at the inns as well as in the extent of the cross-country trails and facilities. After reading Lamy, readers will know what to expect. Color pictures enhance the descriptions.
"The Cross Country Primer" (Lyons & Burford, $14.95) by Laurie Gullion is described as a beginner's guide, but for anyone who aspires to mastery of cross-country skiing, this book offers clear and concise explanations of the sport. Beyond the most basic maneuvers, the author gives no-nonsense descriptions and exercises for advanced skills like skating and downhill skiing while wearing cross-country equipment. It's a useful self-teaching guide.
Another book that is appropriate for beginners, or at least those less familiar with skiing, is "The Snow Skier's Bible" (Doubleday, $12) by Peter Shelton. Practically every aspect of downhill and cross-country skiing -- instruction, equipment, weather, snow grooming, safety, mental attitudes, competition and exercises -- is touched upon, with some topics described in more detail. Photographs relieve the rather dry text.
Hal O'Leary, who has been a leader in teaching disabled people to ski, has written "Bold Tracks" (Cordillera Press, $16.95) to explain teaching techniques as much as to show handicapped people that skiing is within their reach. Approaches to skiing are described and illustrated for amputees, the visually impaired, paraplegics and people with practically every other handicap, with information about equipment and resources available.
Two books that take off-beat looks at the sport are "The Art of Skiing, 1856-1936" (Wood River Publishing, $19.95), by Gary H. Schwartz, and "Vermont People" (Vermont People Project, $35) by Peter Miller.
"The Art of Skiing" is a visual history of magazine illustrations and covers, advertising artwork and postcards over this 80-year-period, before skiing became a popular sport.
"Vermont People" is not about skiing, but about people displaced by skiing. Miller has composed a series of two-page essays, each with a handsome black and white photograph. They are stark portraits, revealing changes that have taken place in people's lives as recreation has grown to dominate Vermont's economy.

HEADLINE: KOREAS SIGN PACT RENOUNCING FORCE IN A STEP TO UNITY

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Friday, Dec. 13

 BODY:
Leaders of North and South Korea signed a treaty of reconciliation and nonaggression this morning, renouncing armed force against each other and saying that they would formally bring the Korean War to an end 38 years after the fighting ceased.
The agreement would also re-establish some measure of regular communication between the two countries, including telephone lines, mail, some economic exchanges and the reunion of some families who have been separated since war broke out in 1950. It would also commit the countries to rebuilding railway and road links across the heavily guarded border, known as the Demilitarized Zone, which has been the symbol of the armed division of the country for almost four decades. 
 Officials on both sides described the accord as the first step toward what they term the inevitable reunification of the Korean peninsula, but they conceded that it failed to deal with some of the most potentially dangerous issues dividing North and South, including Pyongyang's race to develop an arsenal of nuclear weapons.
 
'Milestone and an Evolution'
 At a briefing for reporters Thursday night at a hotel on the outskirts of Seoul, where the two sides have been meeting since Tuesday in their fifth set of high-level talks in 15 months, Lee Dong Bok, South Korea's chief spokesman, termed the agreement "a historical milestone and an evolution in inter-Korean relations."
In the accord, the two sides agreed to forswear all acts of terrorism or any efforts to overthrow the government of the other. They stopped short, however, of calling the agreement a peace treaty, saying that the armistice agreement signed in 1953 between the American-led United Nations forces and the army of North Korean President Kim Il Sung would remain in effect until it can be transformed into a formal peace.
For the United States, which lost 54,000 men and suffered 103,000 casualties before signing the truce with North Korea on July 27, 1953, the new reconciliation and nonaggression pact raises a host of new questions.
The most critical is whether the new North-South relationship will undercut the rationale for keeping 40,000 American troops stationed here, formally serving under the United Nations Command that directed combat operations during the war. In recent years, the United States has slowly been turning command of those forces over to South Koreans, but last month American troop reductions here were halted by Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney until North Korea allows international inspection of its nuclear complexes and dismantles a fuel reprocessing plant that could produce weapons-grade plutonium.
North and South Korea announced later today that they would conduct a separate set of negotiations over nuclear issues later this month, but North Korea did not indicate how it would respond to a proposal for mutual inspection of suspected nuclear sites on both sides of the border, including American military bases. In recent weeks the United States has been removing the nuclear weapons it has stored here for decades to deter a North Korean attack.
In Washington on Thursday, a spokesman for the State Department, Bob Hall, said that the United States had not yet received a copy of the accord. "In terms of what it means for our posture in Korea," he said, "I think it's at this point premature to say."
 
Caution Despite Toasts
 This morning, as negotiators for the two sides began to read aloud their accord in a meeting that was broadcast throughout South Korea, both sides said they would exchange radio and television broadcasts, newspapers and other publications, breaking their nearly four-decade wall of silence. But there were no guarantees that North Korea would allow that news to be disseminated in its tightly controlled society. Two days ago, at the start of the talks, North Korea's Prime Minister, Yon Hyung Muk, said he had to protect his "clean society against pollution by stinking, corrupt cultures."
While Prime MinisterYon and his South Korean counterpart, Chung Won Shik, toasted a new era of reconciliation at an elaborate Korean-style banquet Thursday night, others were far more cautious about whether the treaty would have much practical effect in reducing tensions. Past communiques and agreements -- though none as sweeping as this one -- have often collapsed amid charges of duplicity, treachery and provocation on both sides.
"It will not put most of the problems between the North and the South to rest," an American diplomat here said on Thursday. "But it might make people feel better. And it is something that they can point to as progress, after a year of serious talks."
Seoul was alive with speculation Thursday night about why North Korea suddenly seemed so eager for a peace agreement.
Many speculated that it signaled the increasing desperation of North Korea's Government, which is facing shortages of food and fuel, a disastrous harvest, an economy on the brink of collapse, virtual abandonment by its Soviet allies, and increasing international pressure to abandon its nuclear plans.
"The key here is that they want to buy time," said Yang Sung Chul, a professor of political science at Kyung Hee University. "The North's leaders need to show some evidence of positive action so that they can ease the pressure on the nuclear project, and so that they can make some progress with Japan and the United States." Japan is viewed as North Korea's best hope for aid and basic industry, although it has said that it will provide neither until Pyongyang allows inspection of its nuclear plants, which experts say could produce a weapon in one to three years.
North and South Korea have argued over nonaggression pacts on and off for almost four decades, with the North demanding -- until Thursday morning -- that it also negotiate directly with the United States, which signed the 1953 armistice. American officials have always refused, viewing the North Korean insistence as a transparent effort to cast the South as an American lackey. South Korea has harbored its own fears about a nonaggression pact, worrying that it would pave the way for North Korea to demand the removal of American forces stationed here.
As part of the accord, the two Koreas agreed to replace the armistice with what the South Korean press termed a "peace regime," with a North-South liaison office set up at the village of Panmunjom, along the armed and mined demilitarized zone. Tens of thousands of troops are still massed on either side of the zone, which over the years has been the site of periodic violence, including ambushes, infiltration attempts and the ax murders of two United States Army officers in 1976.
South Korea, too, is under some pressure to make progress in its relations with the North, though much of the pressure is internal. President Roh Tae Woo, the former Army general who was elected president four years ago and has slowly edged the country away from ironclad rule, is eager to arrange the first summit between a South Korean president and Mr. Kim, the North's aging leader. Within Mr. Roh's Democratic Liberal Party, there is also considerable maneuvering among those who hope to succeed him as President, and the talks with the North are something that each contender wants to leave his fingerprints on.
 
Talks Very Personal
 News of the accord bolted through Seoul at rush hour Thursday night, as commuters and shoppers gathered around department-store television sets. For millions of South Koreans the negotiations are very personal: Many middle-aged and elderly people here were born in the North but have been unable to return.
"I want so much to go back and see if any of my brothers are alive," a middle-aged Korean woman visiting here from her home in Hawaii said the day the talks began. "But," she added, with the caution that usually follows such conversations here, "I don't really have much hope that it will be possible." The country has been divided since 1945.
In a few ways, the negotiations are trailing the everyday realities of life on the Korean peninsula. Several prominent South Korean businessmen visited the North recently -- a delegation from the giant Samsung conglomerate is there now -- to discuss the opening of trade, something the two sides have virtually prohibited. Seoul's stock market soared on Thursday as word that the talks were making progress spread from the conference room.
The talks have also been a chance for South Korea to show off its wealth to its impoverished relative, and the country was not about to lose the opportunity.
Visiting North Korean journalists were given a tour of the Seoul subway. Dignitaries wandered through the Samsung production lines, watching VCR's under construction. There was a musical at the National Theater -- Mr. Chung and Mr. Yon sat together -- and Thursday afternoon Mr. Yon walked through a crowded department store, a symbol of South Korea's phenomenal growth and rampant consumerism.
But beneath the veneers of civility lies a deep distrust. Older residents still remember the bitter battles that left Seoul in ruins -- the capital changed hands four times -- and more recent acts of terrorism, like the North Korean effort to kill the South's cabinet during a visit to Burma, now Myanmar, in 1983. Seventeen South Koreans, incuding four cabinet members, were killed in the attack. North Korean agents were also responsible for blowing up a Korean Airlines jet in 1983, killing all aboard.
The accord, formally named the "Agreement on Reconciliation, Nonaggression, Exchange and Cooperation," makes no mention of whether mutual force reductions will occur along the DMZ. However, it does call for talks over "phased reductions in armaments, including the elimination of weapons of mass destruction and surprise attack capabilities."
North Korea made no public response on Thursday to a proposal by South Korea and the United States that the North open its doors to nuclear inspection, in return for rights to visit military and civilian sites in the South. The inspections are part of an effort to demonstrate that South Korea is now approaching "nuclear free" status. The proposal also would require both sides to abandon any effort to reprocess nuclear fuel, a commitment the South has already made.
In the agreement signed this morning, the two sides said that from this point forward, "differences of opinion and disputes arising between the two parties shall be peacefully resolved through dialogue and negotiations." They also agreed to create a joint military committee within three months. They also said they would install an emergency telephone line "to prevent accidental armed clashes."
The vaguest sections of the agreement commit the two sides to carry out scientific, cultural and sports exchanges, and to permit ordinary Koreans on both sides of the border to correspond and visit with their families. Until now, South Korea has sharply limited visits to the North and harshly punished students and others who have traveled there without permission.

Toasting the agreement yesterday in Seoul were, from left, Prime Minister Yon Hyong Muk of North Korea; his South Korean counterpart, Chung Won Shik; and Kim Dae Jung, South Korean opposition leader. Chart: "The Two Koreas: Four Decades of Division"
 
Aug. 15, 1945: Korea is liberated from 35 years of Japanese colonial rule. It is divided along the 38th parallel, with Soviet troops in the North and United States troops in the South.
 
1948: North Korea establishes a Communist dictatorship led by Kim Il Sung. South Korea holds elections and establishes a U.S.-supported Government headed by Syngman Rhee.
 
1950: North Korea invades South Korea, setting off a three-year war. The United States and other Western nations fight for South Korea; Chinese troops aid the North. An estimated 2.4 million soldiers and 4.4 million civilians are killed or wounded.
 
1953: The Korean War ends with an armistice and a 2 1/2-mile-wide demilitarized zone dividing the peninsula. A peace treaty is never signed.
 
1968: North Korean commandos try to assassinate President Park Chung Hee of South Korea. The Pueblo, an American reconnaissance ship, is captured by North Korea; the crew is held 11 months.
 
1972: The two Koreas issue a joint statement renouncing hostilities and pledging peaceful reunification, but follow-up talks collapse.
 
1974: South Korea discovers the first of four tunnels dug by North Korea under the demilitarized zone and accuses the North of planning an invasion. North Korea denies digging them.
 
1983: North Korean commandos bomb a cemetery in Rangoon, Burma, killing 17 South Korean officials, including four Cabinet ministers accompanying President Chun Doo Hwan.
 
1987: Terrorists bomb a South Korean airliner over the Andaman Sea near Burma, killing all 115 people aboard. South Korea accuses the North of responsibility.
 
1988: The Summer Olympic Games are held in Seoul, with 160 nations attending. North Korea boycotts the games.
 
1990: The Prime Ministers of the two Koreas hold three rounds of talks, the highest-level contact ever between the two Governments. Soccer teams from both Koreas meet in the first sports exchange between the two nations.
 
Feb. 12, 1991: Joint Korean sports teams are formed for international matches in table tennis and youth soccer.
 
Sept. 17, 1991: The Koreas join the United Nations as separate members.
 
Oct. 22, 1991: The Prime Ministers resume talks and agree to work toward an accord on reconciliation.
 
Dec. 13, 1991: The two Koreas sign a comprehensive accord calling for reconciliation, non-aggression and cooperation in communications and transportation. (Source: Associated Press) (pg. A16)

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: SOVIET DISARRY;
Baker Presents Steps to Aid Transition by Soviets

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d laid out an American plan today for dealing with the collapse of the Soviet Union, including a call for an international conference in Washington in January to divide responsibilities between different nations to deal with the needs of a "disoriented and confused" Soviet people.
In a 50-minute address at Princeton University, Mr. Baker outlined a series of steps that Washington would take to help dismantle Soviet nuclear weapons, stabilize the economy, establish democratic institutions and overcome food and medical shortages. But there was no call for a significant increase in United States funds for the former Soviet Union. 
 The first new concrete step, starting next week, will be an airlift by the United States Air Force of food to Moscow, St. Petersburg and other hard-hit cities, using military ration packets left over from the Persian Gulf war.
"If during the cold war we faced each other as two scorpions in a bottle, now the Western nations and the former Soviet republics stand as awkward climbers on a steep mountain," Mr. Baker said. "Held together by a single rope, a fall toward fascism or anarchy in the former Soviet Union will pull the West down, too. Yet, a strong a steady pull by the West now can help them to gain their footing." [Excerpts, page A24.]
Nevertheless, the specific steps that Mr. Baker outlined, while wide-ranging, seemed small compared with the huge problems in the Soviet Union, and the goals he set for the United States. He stressed that no nation alone had the resources to recast the wreckage of the Soviet empire.
 
Destroying Atomic Weapons
 While his speech combined some new proposals with some longstanding initiatives, few involved new outlays of American money, and even those were relatively small sums. The speech was primarily meant, it appears, to give more coherence to American policy toward events in the Soviet Union at this time of rapid transition.
Besides the international conference, among the other proposals made by Mr. Baker was an announcement that the Administration would draw on the $400 million appropriated by Congress to assist the Soviets in destroying their nuclear weapons, and would be sending teams of experts to brief leaders of each republic on the sorts of controls that the international community will expect to insure that the loosened central controls do not lead to a spread of weapons abroad. Washington will also ask Congress for $100 million more next year to stimulate private capitalist businesses in the republics.
President Bush today appointed Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger to coordinate all of the assistance programs for the Soviet Union, as he has been doing for Eastern Europe.
Mr. Baker's speech, which included some ideas that the Democrats have been pressing for months, marked the first time that any Administration official had argued that chaos among the Soviet republics could drag the West down as well. This appeared to be intended in part to explain to the American public why at a time of economic hardship at home Washington is spending any money at all trying to help its former Communist enemies.
Administration officials admit that helping the Soviet republics now is much more complicated than before. It involves getting into factories and changing their production, distributing food on local levels, keeping track of mobile missiles despite disintegration in the Soviet Army and giving birth to capitalist enterprises -- not simply cutting a deal with one man in the Kremlin.
Mr. Baker said the $100 million for new technical assistance to promote capitalism in the republics, which seemed to represent the biggest new outlay in his speech, "will, of course, not come from domestic accounts but from assistance to other foreign nations." He added, "Given the gravity of the situation, there is no other choice."
This is an important point, because what Mr. Baker was signaling for the first time was that the former Soviet republics -- for whom American foreign aid would have been unthinkable five years ago -- will now be competing for a shrinking American foreign aid budget, and one of the traditional big recipients, like the Philippines, the African bloc, Israel or Egypt, is probably going to have to pay.
 
Referring to Kennan
 Mr. Baker opened the speech, titled "America and the Collapse of the Soviet Empire: What Has to Be Done," by referring to George F. Kennan, who was in the audience and whose 1947 call for containing the Communist Soviet Union until it crumbled from within set the parameters of American foreign policy for the last four decades.
In evoking Mr. Kennan, Mr. Baker suggested that this speech marked an effort by the Administration to form a new approach for dealing with the emerging countries and territories that once formed the Soviet Union.
"What I present to you today is not a fixed blueprint," said Mr. Baker. "Rather, it is the principles and approaches which together define an agenda for action in a revolutionary, unpredictable situation -- a situation in which the West can play an important supporting role."
The Secretary, who leaves for a tour of Soviet republics on Saturday, maintained the Administration's hands-off approach to the current internal power struggle between the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and the Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin.
"We will work with those republics and any common entity which commit to responsible security policies, democratic political practices and free market economics," he said. "Fortunately, new leaders are emerging who are committed to these principles."
Those republican governments taking an undemocratic course -- and Mr. Baker singled out Georgia -- will not receive Western support.
In terms of economic aid, Mr. Baker argued that the "wreckage of Communism" was too large for any one nation to alone repair, so Mr. Bush "proposes that we begin by holding a coordinating conference to better divide our labor and responsibilities to help meet immediate and drastically increasing Soviet humanitarian needs."
He said the United States would invite the advanced industrial democracies, the Central and Eastern European countries, the members of the Persian Gulf war coalition, like Saudi Arabia, and the international financial institutions to come together in Washington in early January "to discuss how best to meet ongoing humanitarian needs over the course of the next year."
 
Shape of Conference
 This proposal is still in its infancy and it is not clear whether this conference would be at the head of state, foreign ministers or experts level, let alone whether the Europeans would be prepared to take part.
On its own, Mr. Baker said, the Administration will work with Congress to expand the Peace Corps program so that by next winter 250 American volunteers will be on the ground in at least four different republics, and will expand the Commerce Department's Business Training Program to accommodate 150 Soviets in the coming year. This is in addition to various humanitarian aid programs totaling about $4 billion in the last two years.
In the arms control field, Mr. Baker said the United States did not want to see any "new nuclear weapons states" emerge from the transformed Soviet Union. That means those republics in which Soviet nuclear weapons are now deployed, must either destroy them in place or band together with other nuclear republics in a program that would insure a single, unified command and control of such weapons.
 
Sending U.S. Experts
 To help in this regard the Administration will not only draw on the $400 million appropriated by Congress to help the republics destroy their nuclear weapons, but will also "send a team of experts to brief republic leaders" on how to establish "strict export control policies and to put in place strict internal mechanisms" to insure that weapons are not sent abroad or that "the talents of Soviet scientists and engineers are not diverted to dangerous military programs elsewhere in the world."
In the area of institution building, Mr. Baker argued that "unless republic governments respond by complementing their independence with democracy and the equal treatment of persons belonging to minorities, they will soon find themselves suffering the very same crises of legitimacy, cohesion and effectiveness that has caused the centrifugal devolution of power."
To prod the republican leaders to move down a democratic path, Mr. Baker said the United States would begin discussing with fellow members of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe ways to let newly independent republics join the organization, if they carry out the basic human rights principles of the Helsinki Final Act.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Soviet Response
 MOSCOW, Dec. 12 (AP) -- A Soviet spokesman welcomed Washington's proposal today for an international conference next month on coordinating humanitarian aid to the Soviet Union, but urged the West to move quickly.
The Soviets have urgently requested help for their country, which faces severe shortages of food, heating fuel and basic consumer goods.
The Foreign Ministry spokesman, Vitaly Churkin, said Mr. Bush's plan was "very positive." But he added, "We have seen in the past many rounds of discussion, and I would not want another conference to slow down any efforts which might be forthcoming in terms of humanitarian to our country, because it is something which is indeed very necessary."
Mr. Churkin stressed that he was expressing his own opinion rather than an official reaction to Mr. Bush's plan.

HEADLINE: For Fortunate Few, Tribal Casino Promises Jobs

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LEDYARD, Conn.

 BODY:
The shell of the first casino in New England is rising from the rock-strewn earth at the edge of the Mashantucket Pequot reservation here. Already one can see where the poker room, the blackjack tables and what management calls "three different restaurant experiences" will be when the yet-unnamed casino opens for business in February.
These days Joe Bonmer, a bespectacled Atlantic City veteran, teaches the fine points of the game of craps in a community-college gymnasium in nearby Norwich to a crowd of wide-eyed students. 
"What's he gonna do?" Mr. Bonmer asked in his best dealer's drawl as his audience stared at the numbers and boxes on the game table sprinkled with plastic gambling chips. "Your odds are off. Coming out, ma'am. Sir? Something's gotta give here."
 
Little Contact With Casinos
 His words rang true in more ways than one for the students, all of whom had signed up for a free course in how to run casino games like craps, blackjack and poker. Although many of the students had little or no contact with casinos or the Mashantucket Pequots before the 250-member tribe announced plans to open a casino, they rushed forward when advertisements for the course said dealers could make as much as $30,000 a year in wages and tips.
Most of the 650 people chosen to enroll in the course (more than 2,000 had applied) said they had lost their jobs in the last few months. Putting aside concerns about the possible negative aspects of standing between people and their money, they signed on for casino training because they saw no better prospects.
There are certainly drawbacks. The students are not guaranteed jobs; first they have to pass an audition in front of casino management. Dealers will be paid $3.75 an hour, meaning they would have to rely on tips for much of their livelihood. In an area where people are not well versed in casino etiquette, it is unclear whether tips will roll in at a high enough rate. And then there are the uniforms, Indian-style blouses trimmed with beads for men and skimpy pseudosuede tunics for cocktail waitresses.
 
Laid Off After 20 Years
 Still, the course has drawn people like Gary Workman of Norwich, who was laid off by UNC Naval Products after 20 years at the company. About 1,000 people in his research division were let go, he said, and several signed up for casino school.
"There are four of us in craps and six or seven who just started learning blackjack and poker," he said. "Everybody was a little bit hesitant to come here, because you depend a lot on tips. But it's going to be the only game in town."
At another craps table was Pam Cruh of nearby Mystic. Laid off in June as a program supervisor in the State Department of Mental Retardation, she was busy practicing her new skill: stacking and dividing piles of chips. "I never thought I'd be laid off," she said. "That's why I went to work for the state, for the security. And look what happens."
There is no doubt in most people's minds that legalized gambling, arriving amid a deep economic decline, will alter this part of Connecticut, which is still largely rural and has long depended on industries like military contracting that show little likelihood of returning to their former strength.
 
'A Stepping Stone'
 Despite some fears that gambling might worsen traffic and lead to an increase in crime, many people welcome the venture. "Things are drying up in this area," said Norman Barrett, a cable-television contractor who is not officially unemployed but notes that there is so little work now that he may as well be. "This is 10 miles from my house, and it might be a stepping stone to the restaurant part of it or the motel part of it."
Under an agreement between the state and the tribe, state agencies will regulate the casino. All profits will remain with the tribe, after it reimburses the state for the money spent on regulation, said Avice Meehan, a spokeswoman for Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.
The Mashantucket Pequots, who have run a high-stakes bingo parlor on the site for years, won the right to open their casino last year after a long legal battle that was finally decided by the United States Supreme Court. Lawyers for the tribe argued that because Connecticut allowed nonprofit groups to run fund-raising "Las Vegas nights," the state could not block the Indians from opening a casino on their reservation. The legislature approved the casino in a vote requested by Mr. Weicker this year.
 
A Different Influence
 The 45,000-square-foot casino is expected to help support services like health care and job training. It will also include features quite apart from the usual Atlantic City experience -- an exhibition hall for Indian artifacts and, eventually, a museum of the Indian experience.
The Indians' involvement has affected the design in other ways. The casino president and chief executive, Alfred J. Luciani, whose last two jobs were with the Golden Nugget and Resorts casino hotels in Atlantic City, said the tribe was "very sensitive about its image" and had early on rejected the "glitz and bordello red" that characterize many casinos.
A gray fox beneath a barren oak tree, the symbol of the Mashantucket Pequots, who are known as the fox people, dominates the facade.
Until the casino is given a name, marketing it will be inhibited, Mr. Luciani said. But perhaps not as much as it would be if the tribe's name were used. "The word Mashantucket has been butchered in so many ways since I've been here," he said. "It's certainly not a marketable name." People seem to have difficulty remembering the name or pronouncing mash-an-TUCK-ette.
 
Quarters vs. Millennium
 Mr. Luciani and the team he brought with him from New Jersey are also trying to adjust to the way their new partners think about business. "I think in terms of quarterly profits and annual results, and they really think in terms of the millennium," he said. "There's something more to this than just a blackjack game. Every tree on the construction site is personally tagged by a member of the tribe. We have to get permission before we do anything."
About 40 members of the tribe will work at the casino, filling some of the 2,300 jobs that the casino is expected to generate.
"We just can't make people Pequots," a spokeswoman for the tribe, Terry D. Bell, said. "We're a small tribe and we will always depend on outside people working for us."
That means opportunity for people like Holly Greene of Groton. She was laid off in October as a financial analyst at Electric Boat, the submarine builder, which cut 700 jobs.
"I thought it would be fun," Miss Green said, plopping piles of chips across the felt-covered table. "I told my mother I was going to craps school. And she said, 'Oh, crafts school? What are you making?' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: The casino the Mashantucket Pequot Indians are building on their reservation in Ledyard, Conn., has attracted hundreds of job applicants. Robin Francis, left, and Angela Dobbins practiced at the craps table. (Gale Zucker for The New York Times) (pg. B10)

HEADLINE: Data Show Poor Start For Sales

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12

 BODY:
Reflecting a desultory start to the holiday shopping season, retail sales rose three-tenths of 1 percent in November, to $153.1 billion, the Commerce Department reported today.
Such transactions cover a wide variety of outlets from department stores to fast-food restaurants and account for half of all consumer spending and a third of all economic activity 
 While the percentage gain was a bit more than most analysts expected, this was partly attributed to a downward revision for October, for which sales are now put at $152.7 billion, or $200 million less than initially reported a month ago.
"The November retail sales figures confirm that the holiday shopping season was slow getting out of the blocks," said John M. Albertine, a Washington economics consultant. "Even a late buying surge won't be enough to make it a good Christmas for many retailers. The big discounters, like Wal-Mart and K Mart, will still do well, but the upscale department stores are likely to have a blue Christmas."
 
Tame Inflation Report
 A separate report today by the Labor Department showed that prices received by American producers of finished goods rose a modest two-tenths of 1 percent last month, with about half of this the result of jumps in tobacco and car prices that appear unsustainable in the current economic climate. [Page D2.]
Analysts said the tame inflation news improved the chances of another prompt move by the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates in hopes of reviving an economy that nobody believes is growing much and that many believe is heading into a second contraction. Just last Friday the Federal Reserve nudged a key short-term rate lower in response to a larger-than-expected drop in corporate payrolls in November.
The bad news about the inflation results, said Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis, "is that it is a reflection of the lousy economy."
Most economists believe the recession that began in July 1990 ended during the spring -- recessions technically end when the upturn starts and not when the lost ground is recovered -- but the modest recovery that followed has all but disappeared.
Today's report came just before a crucial, long-scheduled Federal Reserve policy meeting next Tuesday and amid a flurry of tax-cut and other ideas to revive growth that will be considered by Congress early next year. President Bush, acknowledging the need for action, had planned to disclose his proposal in the State of the Union Message Jan. 28 but Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said this week that some elements could be presented earlier.
A second Labor Department report showed that first-time claims for state unemployment insurance dropped a hefty 61,000 in the week ended Nov. 30, to 414,000, but analysts largely dismissed this as yet another aberration in this highly erratic series. This claims period included Thanksgiving, when unemployment offices were closed.
The retail figures showed that sales of clothes, fuel and other nondurables climbed four-tenths of 1 percent in November after falling three-tenths of 1 percent in October. Turnover rose 1.9 percent at apparel and accessory stores, 1.1 percent at gasoline stations, five-tenths of 1 percent at restaurants and bars and three-tenths of 1 percent in general merchandise stores. Food stores and drug and proprietary stores, however, posted declines of three-tenths of 1 percent.
Durable goods were unchanged over all, with a six-tenths of 1 percent advance for automotive dealers and a one-tenth of 1 percent rise for furniture, home furnishings and equipment offset by a 2.2 percent drop for dealers in building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes.
While some analysts found some solace in relatively brisk sales for such deferrable purchases as apparel and furniture, others stressed the heavy promotion and price-cutting many stores found necessary to entice customers.
"A lot of what is being moved is a little or no profit," said Lacy H. Hunt, chief economist in this country for the Hongkong Bank. He added that the large number of unfilled retailing jobs this season was "particularly troubling" because temporary workers often spend much of their earnings on gifts.
October's sales, though lower than first reported, are now calculated to have been unchanged instead of edging down one-tenth of 1 percent. This is because September's figures were also revised to show $152.7 billion of sales now, up three-tenths of 1 percent instead of six-tenths of 1 percent as previously reported.
Excluding the automotive sector, November's retail sales gain was two-tenths of 1 percent, the first increase since July.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Maxwell Weekly Ceases Publication

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Dec. 12

 BODY:
The European, the 19-month-old pan-European newspaper, closed its offices today and laid off its 145 employees -- a casualty of the collapse of the Maxwell publishing empire.
Although there appear to be some possible buyers for The European, unless a deal is struck quickly the issue that comes out on Friday will be the last. 
 The apparent end of the weekly that Robert Maxwell promoted as "Europe's first national newspaper" came only a day after European Community leaders agreed to start on the road to greater economic and political union.
 
Waiting for a New Era
 "The paper's archetypal target audience was the European traveling business executive who wanted to know what was going on in German politics as much as he wanted to know what was going on in French sports," said David W. Byles, the London-based media director of the J. Walter Thompson ad agency.
But he noted that the era of pan-European products and marketing, while on the way, was still not here, and that the paper was struggling to find the right editorial mix.
"It was a great idea but it was not a storming success in terms of advertising revenues," Mr. Byles said. "It may have been a bit ahead of its time."
After the closing, about 60 to 70 employees of The European marched across the street to the Mirror building to demand that Mirror Group Newspapers P.L.C. give them jobs. Many employees of The European came from the Mirror Group, which Mr. Maxwell controlled, and are still covered by Mirror Group union contracts. So they contend that they are entitled to jobs with the group.
 
Losses Versus Vision
 Editors of The European argue that since the paper no longer has to cater to Robert Maxwell's demands, its costs could be slashed and it could be made profitable in a year or so.
But court-appointed administrators for the bankrupt holding companies at the heart of the Maxwell empire have been more concerned with the English-language paper's losses than the correctness of its vision. One administrator, Martin Fishman, said the prospect of heavy losses led him to close the three-section color newspaper, which has a circulation of about 250,000. More than 100,000 copies are sold in Britain, about 130,000 in the rest of Europe and the remainder in the United States.
Charles Garside, deputy editor of The European, said the paper was losing nearly 200,000 a week, or more than $360,000, at the time of Robert Maxwell's death on Nov. 5.
Mr. Maxwell invested an estimated $108 million to $145 million in The European.
With The European's closure, many employees of The Daily News in New York may be happy that their money-losing paper has sought protection from creditors -- and the British administrators -- in United States Bankruptcy Court.
 
Owner of the Newspapers
 The Daily News and The European share the same parent, Robert Maxwell Group P.L.C. That private company and another, Headington Investments Ltd., are the main holding companies for the empire. Both filed for bankruptcy a week ago, leading to The Daily News's action.
The filings came just days after Coopers & Lybrand Deloitte, auditors of the Maxwell empire, discovered that Mr. Maxwell had taken more than $1 billion from employee pension funds and his two flagship public companies, the Mirror Group and the Maxwell Communication Corporation. He is believed to have made these transfers in a desperate bid to prop up his private companies. Some money is believed to have gone to The European and The Daily News.
"The real person who should be taking the blame" for the paper's closure "is lying under the ground at the Mount of Olives, " said John Bryant, editor of The European, referring to Mr. Maxwell, who is buried in Israel.
"I told my staff that it is awful and that people will be shocked, but there is no point in bitterness and despair," Mr. Bryant was quoted as saying today by The Evening Standard.
 
Clinging to Hope
 The European's staff, which includes about 70 journalists, is clinging to the hope that someone will buy the paper within a few days so it will not have to skip an issue. The employees fear that if the paper does not come out next week, reader and advertiser loyalty will be severely damaged and the paper will be unsaleable. "You can't afford to go off the street," Mr. Garside said.
Bankers Trust International P.L.C., the London-based unit of the American bank, estimated the paper might fetch as much as 27 million, or nearly $49 million. That estimate was in a report presented last month to bankers with loans to the private Maxwell companies, but it assumed there would be no fire sale of The European.
Asked whether he might get that kind of price, Mr. Fishman, a partner at Arthur Andersen & Company, laughed. Still, he said the potential buyers are British or continental Europeans and their interest seemed genuine. That, along with the offer by the staff to work without pay, were the only reasons he allowed this week's issue to be published.
 
Friends on the Payroll
 Mr. Garside said Mr. Maxwell forced the paper to put friends and acquaintances on the payroll. These people, he said, were employed as "senior advisers" to Mr. Maxwell or as contract writers, who submitted articles that were inappropriate or poorly written. He said Mr. Maxwell also insisted the paper be printed at five sites when one or two would have made sense.
In an interview published in the issue of The European that goes on sale on Friday, Ian Maxwell, who became the paper's publisher after his father's death, said he was "shocked about these revelations" about his father. But he also defended his father, saying he had created large businesses and employment for thousands. To forget the good his father did, he said, "is wrong."
"It is a tough and unforgiving world," Ian Maxwell said. "Robert Maxwell was my father and I love him."

HEADLINE: 3 Democrats Lay Out School Agendas

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12

 BODY:
Seeking the endorsement of a national teachers' union, three Democratic Presidential candidates today unveiled education plans in an effort to seize the mantle of "education president" that President Bush has been claimed but struggled to own.
The candidates -- Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, and former Senator Paul Tsongas of Massachusetts -- spoke in separate 15 minute segments at the National Education Association and used the opportunity to talk about their domestic agendas as well. The audience of about 400 included the 100-member board of directors of the National Education Association, and the organization's 50 state presidents. 
 Mr. Kerrey, who spoke first, said that unless the nation's economic ills were addressed immediately, the high school graduates of the year 2000 would inherit a debt-ridden, second-rate nation.
"The graduates of 2000 will say to us like the children of Robert Maxwell, 'Dad, we thought you were rich,' " Mr. Kerrey said.
Along with the standard Democratic promise to make Head Start, the pre-school program for low-income children, available to all those eligible, Mr. Kerrey said he would sponsor legislation to provide national health insurance and to consolidate a number of Federal departments, including folding the Department of Education into the Health and Human Services, in an effort to streamline delivery of Federal services.
"When you come to Washington and you're concerned about children you have to go to 22 different agencies," Mr. Kerrey said. "We don't even coordinate Head Start with our schools."
Mr. Clinton, who has been an advocate of educational reform in his state as well as nationally, presented his education proposals in a larger context, decrying what he called the Bush Administration's "us vs. them" approach to the nation's economic stagnation, an approach he said has pitted woman workers against men and minorities against working-class whites. He said the nation needed a national economic policy as well as national health care and national education plans.
"We better make up our mind whether we're going up or down together," Mr. Clinton said.
Mr. Clinton's education plan was the most detailed and in presenting it he was interrupted with frequent applause. Among other things, he said he would institute a national program for adult literacy, start a national apprenticeship system for young people not going to college, and scrap the current student aid program in favor of a national trust that would make college loans to students who would then pay them back in small amounts over years through Federal income tax payments.
He also promised the audience that he would involve them in education decisions if he was elected President. "If you elect me President, you'll be a full partner in the greatest education Presidency the U.S. has ever said Mr. Clinton said.
Mr. Tsongas's message was of the interaction between a country's economic health and its educational health. "Education equals economics equals education," he said, interlocking his fingers.
Mr. Tsongas told about his experiences in the Peace Corps as a teacher in Ethiopia where, he said, teachers are accorded a high status they do not enjoy in the United States. He said he wanted to change that.
 
'All Part of a Team'
 He also echoed the theme that the fortunes of all citizens of the country were tied to one another.
"We're all part of a team and we are all linked together," Mr. Tsongas said. Mr. Tsongas also proposed a student loan program that would be paid back through the Federal income tax system, with those who make more money paying back more.
An endorsement by the National Education Association, the nation's largest teacher's union with more than two million members, would mean that a candidate could count on campaign support from the group's 50 state affiliates. The association endorsed the Democratic Presidential candidates, Michael S. Dukakis, in 1988, and Jimmy Carter, in both his races. The association will announce its endorsement after April 30.
"We're looking for the best Democratic candidate to beat the incumbent President," said Keith Geiger, president of the N.E.A.
Mr. Geiger is a member of a Bush Administration's education advisory panel, but the N.E.A. is opposed to Mr. Bush's education package, "America 2000," because of its emphasis on school choice. The Bush Administration's version of school choice would allow parents to use public funds to send children to any school, public, private or parochial.
All three of the Democratic candidates at today's forum oppose any school choice plan that would include private and parochial schools.

HEADLINE: In Perpetual Candidacy, Duke Raises the Stakes

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Dec. 9

 BODY:
Like a traveling road show that folds its tent in one town and opens it in the next, the David Duke campaign is back, this time as an aside to Presidential politics.
The question is whether Mr. Duke, whose disaffected blue-collar base is made up more of traditional Democrats than Republicans, can make much of an impact in primaries where the constituency and the rules may work against him. 
 Mr. Duke, who announced last week that he would challenge President Bush in next year's Republican primaries, is concentrating on the South, on states in which Democrats can vote in Republican primaries and on states in which candidates can pick up a share of delegates without finishing first in the primary. He has identified about 20 states as potential places to campaign.
But with party rules that make it difficult for also-rans to pick up stray delegates and with overwhelming hostility from the Republican Party leadership, Mr. Duke is in the odd position of needing support from Democratic voters to do well in Republican primaries. Experts say his biggest impact could come if he mounted a third-party candidacy in the general election in November in the manner of the George Wallace campaigns of 1968 and 1972.
 
'A Media Creation'
 To some critics, particularly Republicans seeking to disown him, Mr. Duke, a Louisiana State Representative who is also a former Ku Klux Klan leader and Nazi sympathizer, remains little more than an exotic bloom that lives only in the exaggerated glow of the media.
"He's nothing but a media creation," said David Shafer, executive director of the Georgia Republican Party. "There is no other state representative in the country who could run twice for office, be beaten by increasingly larger margins and then be taken seriously by the media as a candidate for President. It's totally ridiculous. It boggles me that he's taken seriously at all."
But after Mr. Duke won more than half of the white vote in Louisiana in racially divisive campaigns for senator last year and governor last month, others see the real possibility that he could play a political role wildly disproportionate to his modest hopes of gaining many delegates.
"The real question is whether he will run as an independent," said Larry Sabato, a professor of government at the University of Virginia, "because that's where he could do real damage, not just to Bush but also to the public discourse on race.
"He's a terribly divisive individual, I think more than the equivalent of George Wallace in 1968. Wallace certainly helped to tear the social fabric, and I fear Duke will do the same and perhaps more so."
 
Potential for a Reprise
 Few doubt that the slumping economy and the frustrations of disaffected whites, particularly in the South, provide the potential for a reprise of Mr. Wallace's angry outsider's campaigns.
"Southern turnout peaked in 1968, and it's been down ever since," said Merle Black, a professor of politics and government at Emory University. "And a large part of that is because Wallace got out of the business. Those people have never had a champion since, and Duke is the closest incarnation of that."
The trouble for Mr. Duke is that those voters are not necessarily going to vote in Republican primaries, which usually attract upscale Republican regulars rather than members of his blue-collar base.
"When you look at his supporters, the Republican primaries are his worst possible constituency," Mr. Black said.
In Florida, where primary voting is limited to registered Republicans and where party leaders decide who is on the ballot, Mr. Duke may not even get on the ballot or choose to run. In other important states, like Texas, the other top prize in the 12 states scheduled to take part in the Super Tuesday primary on March 10, most analysts expect him to struggle to break out of single digits.
 
Buchanan Complication
 His troubles will be compounded, too, by the Presidential candidacy of Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative columnist who is expected to split the anti-Bush protest vote.
"Zip, zero, nada, zilch," said Carl Rove, a Republican consultant in Austin who was vice president of the 1988 George Bush campaign in Texas. "There just aren't enough unreconstructed Nazi sympathizers and Ku Klux Klansmen in the Republican Party for him to have a measurable impact on the primary. He will have zero delegates in Texas."
Mr. Duke is likely to focus on open primary states, those where all voters can vote in either the Democratic or Republican primary, and states in which runners-up can get a share of delegates rather than those where the first-place finisher gets all the delegates.
Early primaries where he has the potential to get a healthy slice of the vote include Georgia and Mississippi, which have open primaries. Tennessee, with an open primary and no winner-take-all system, could be his best bet for picking up both votes and delegates to the Republican National Convention in Houston.
Mr. Duke is also likely to run in states outside the South like New York, California, Maryland and Michigan. But some states are contemplating changing the threshold for acquiring delegates as a way to thwart him. Michigan's State Republican Committee voted last weekend to increase the threshold for winning delegates to 33 percent from 5 percent.
Skeptics, like Mr. Rove of Texas, say Mr. Duke runs the risk of doing so poorly in the primaries that he will be discredited as a serious threat.
 
'Nothing But a Fraud'
 "Getting into these primaries is going to just marginalize this guy," Mr. Rove said. "This whole thing is nothing but a fraud, an attempt to keep raising campaign money."
Those who have followed Mr. Duke's political career in Louisiana are less quick to discount him.
"I think what's driving it are some very fundamental discontents and anxieties," said Lawrence Powell, a history professor at Tulane University. "I don't know if he could do as well as Wallace, but there's a lot of deep cynicism that he's tapping into."

HEADLINE: New Capital Rules Proposed For Investments of Insurers

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG

 BODY:
Top state insurance regulators released a rough draft of a proposal yesterday that would require insurers that take above-average risks to have capital, or cushion against loss, commensurate with those risks.
The proposal, which is similar to a regulation already in place for banks, could benefit policyholders who are concerned about their insurers' financial positions. 
 Specifically, once insurers face a risk-adjusted capital requirement, any insurer that fell short of the necessary capital would be highlighted.
"What that would do is give regulators a chance to better zero in on companies in trouble," explained Gloria Vogel, an analyst who follows insurance stocks for Shearson Lehman Brothers in New York.
 
Trial Period Ahead
 The proposal, which will now be tried out in a handful of states, was made by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, a group of state insurance regulators that ended its regular winter meeting yesterday in Houston.
If all goes according to the association's plan, the test phase will last roughly from next March to December 1992. There will then be an additional comment period before a final version of the capital requirement goes into effect, presumably for financial statements covering 1994.
Regardless of the ultimate details, the intention is to tie the amount of capital an insurer must keep on hand to the riskiness of its business. There is a broad consensus in the industry that the current system, under which an insurer's required capital is fixed by state law, makes little sense given the large variety of policies being written today and insurers' different approaches to investing.
Under the capital requirement to be tested, state insurance regulators would measure four different risks at each insurer: the risk from declines in asset values, risks of unexpectedly high claims, interest-rate risk and business risks, such as from lawsuits.
Tallying up these risks would then permit state insurance regulators to set an appropriate level of capital for each insurer. So, for instance, an insurer writing health insurance, for which claims often run unexpectedly high, would need more capital than a company selling auto policies, for which claims are very predictable.
The N.A.I.C. is using the term "threshold capital" to describe how much capital each insurer would need. Insurers that failed to maintain their capital at the threshold would be subject to regulatory action.
 
Incentive of Regulators>
 Faced with growing pressure from consumers incensed that regulators did not move more quickly to correct problems at three giant life insurers that failed this year -- Executive Life, Mutual Benefit Life and First Capital Life -- regulators are eager to appear to be on top of the problem, particularly in states where insurance commissioners are elected.
Executive Life had a sizable portfolio of high-risk junk bonds, and many other life insurers have invested heavily in commercial real estate, which could result in large losses in the current real estate recession.
