HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Disney Picks California Theme Park Site

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 12

 BODY:
The Walt Disney Company said today that it had chosen a site adjacent to Disneyland in Anaheim, Calif., for its next theme park, ending consideration of a competing site in Long Beach, Calif.
Disney executives stopped short of guaranteeing that the project would be built. They said the company must still deal with a number of environmental, regulatory and economic issues related to building in an increasingly congested urban area. 
 The company built Disneyland in Anaheim 36 years ago, when Orange County, south of Los Angeles, was largely strawberry fields and orange groves. The area is now heavily developed and choked with traffic.
Today Disney executives seemed to be dangling the prospect of a huge influx of jobs and tax dollars into Southern California's battered economy if state and local governments would cooperate on plans for the $3 billion, 470-acre Anaheim project.
The project, called the Disneyland Resort, would open at the end of the decade and would include a new theme park known as Westcot Center, as well as hotels, a huge lake and a shopping mall.
If completed, Disney said, the new project would create nearly 28,000 new jobs, and would generate $55 million a year in additional taxes and fees for the city of Anaheim and Orange County, and $70 million a year in new tax revenue for the state.
"We've never built a mega-project like this in an existing urban environment," said Peter Rummell, president of Disney Development, the subsidiary in charge of the project. "The economic feasibility of the project still has to be proven."
Disney is now putting the final touches on Euro Disneyland, outside Paris, and it also operates Disney World in Florida. The company licenses its name to Tokyo Disneyland in Japan.
The centerpiece of the new project is the Westcot Center, a complex inspired by the highly sucessful Epcot Center at Disney World. it would contain themed pavilions about foreign countries, the human body and other subjects. The project would also include an elaborate system of parking lots and people movers to cope with the traffic it would create.
Disney has long been interested in a second theme park in Southern California. For the last several years, it has been openly considering both Long Beach and Anaheim. Some analysts said the company had been playing the two cities off against each other to get the best possible deal for itself and to minimize regualatory objections.
In ruling out Long Beach today, the company said that the time and expense of winning the necessary approvals for that site made the project unfeasible. The Long Beach project would have been built partly on landfill along the city's harbor, and that plan raised questions among state and regional agencies about its effect on the harbor and the Pacific Ocean.
 
Delighted and Excited
 Officials in Anaheim said they were optimistic the project would be built. "The City of Anaheim is delighted, excited and enthusiastic about the decision to build a second attraction here," Anaheim's City Manager, Jim Ruth, told The Associated Press. "We think we have arrived at a plan that is environmentally and economically sound."
Still, Disney must make a final decision about the Anaheim project at a time when its theme parks are suffering from the economic downturn and a decline in tourism.

HEADLINE: Changes Begun in Water Works Projects, Dinkins Says

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
Acknowledging that the New York City Department of Environmental Protection was remiss in not letting $600 million in contracts for water mains and sewers last year, Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that the city had begun making changes to insure that the agency's rebuilding projects were not delayed.
While Mr. Dinkins said he was disappointed, he declined to criticize Albert F. Appleton, the Environmental Protection Commissioner. 
 But the Mayor has assigned Rudolph J. Rinaldi, the city's Building Commissioner, to personally oversee the environmental department's rebuilding program, which Mr. Appleton said yesterday he welcomed.
The Mayor maintained that his administration had identified the problems several months ago and that steps had been taken to resolve them. The problems, which recently prompted a sharply worded letter to Mr. Appleton from First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel, had not been made public before they were reported yesterday in The New York Times.
 
Leaky Pipes Unrepaired
 Mr. Appleton and other administration officials said environmental department capital spending was delayed last year because the department moved, its contracting officials did not understand changes in the city procurement procedures, and other city agencies were delayed in performing support services for bids.
The department's shortfall in capital spending has meant that dozens of deteriorating water and sewer pipes have gone unrepaired. It has cost the city 8,000 jobs that would have resulted from the constrution, city officials and local economists say.
Mr. Appleton said in an interview yesterday that the agency is moving quickly to increase its capital spending and that in the last three months it has let $219 million in contracts. He said he is optimistic that the department will meet its $1.51 billion spending target for the 1992 fiscal year.
But Mr. Appleton said the agency's capital budget will probably drop to about $1.1 billion because of design delays at the Newtown Creek sewage treatment plant, cuts in the Transportation Department's street rebuilding program and lower construction costs.
The City Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman, issued a report yesterday that criticized the city's method of setting water and sewer fees, which have risen sharply in recent years.
Ms. Holtzman said that the department's capital and operating budgets are proposed by the administration and approved by the City Council, but that an independent body, the Water Board, sets water and sewer rates at levels needed to pay for the spending. The process has resulted in millions of dollars in waste and ovespending, she said.

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
It's Pay-for-Play: When Cost Equals Privilege

BYLINE: By ANDREW H. MALCOLM

DATELINE: RIDGEFIELD, Conn.

 BODY:
WHEN the girls' basketball team warms up here tomorrow noon against the dread Danbury Hatters, the Ridgefield Tigers will have one invisible distinction: they'll be the only players in the gym who have paid for the privilege of representing their school in athletic competition.
The infiltration of high school sports by user fees is spreading, especially in the Northeast. To compete against another school, every Ridgefield athlete must pay $75 a sport, considerably more than the spectators pay. 
 The principal, Joseph Ellis, doesn't like it. "The question is," he said, "should public school students have to pay to participate in a public school activity? From my point of view, no."
The superintendent, Jerry Marcus, doesn't like it. "I thought I was making progress to kill the fees," he said. "But given today's budget problems, I don't see that happening."
Even the Ridgefield Board of Education, which approved the policy in 1989, doesn't like it. "It's a real simple question of economics," said Joseph Sweeney, a board member. "If we have insufficient money for a full athletic program, do we cut some sports and field teams with insufficient coaches? Or do we ask those who play to help pay?"
Given the stringent realities of public budgets, even in this affluent Fairfield County community, and the shrinking constituencies of secondary-school families, this has become a smoldering philosophical financial debate that is creeping through the locker rooms and board rooms of more public school systems across the country.
At the moment, the pay-for-play team is winning. "I've never had so many calls from administrators," said Helen Upton, assistant director of the National Federation of High School Associations. "They're having to justify financially every program, athletic and otherwise."
A year ago, 10 of the 178 schools in Connecticut's Interscholastic Athletic Association had pay-for-play. Now, 18 do. "You don't pay extra for Russian, band or chorus," said Mike Savage, the association's executive director. "Why should public school students be required to pay for something so valuable in teaching values -- teamwork, leadership, time management, sportsmanship?"
Mr. Marcus, in fact, fears public schools may impose fees for any so-called extracurricular activity. "If they pay to play in a game," he said, "why not to act in a play? Or sing? Or work on the yearbook?"
"Let me tell you," warns Mr. Ellis, the principal, "if we charged to work on the yearbook, no one would do it."
This year Ridgefield High's athletic budget for 23 boys' teams and 19 girls' teams is $226,624, including $59,250 paid by 800 athletes (six students eligible for free lunches had the fee waived).
There are, however, sticky problems beyond bookkeeping and cajoling forgetful students to remind procrastinating parents their check is due before the kickoff. It seems that parents who must pay for their child to join a team easily come to believe their child must also play for that team. And as paying parents, they're not hesitant to approach the coach with not-always-friendly suggestions.
"Pay-for-play," said John Fontana, head of Connecticut's High School Coaches Association and first vice president of the National Association, "says, 'We're out here to teach you values, but it'll cost ya.' So it's not how you play, it's who gets to play."
No accident then that the Ridgefield principal's annual Dear Parent letter includes the following paragraph in all capital letters and boldface:
"Payment Of The Fee Does Not Guarantee Any Minimum Of Playing Time Or Any Implied Privileges Beyond Membership."
Some media-savvy boards suggest slashing sports just to get the attention of voters, who will scream for a football squad in a pouring rain but yawn in a comfortable den over the loss of two Spanish teachers. "Athletics is a handy lightning rod," Ms. Upton said. "So we urge administrators to stress sports and music as co-curricula, not extra-curricula."
She cites studies showing 9 of 10 dropouts were not in such activities.
Does any school ever relinquish pay-for-play once it tastes the extra money? "We did," said Nick Zeoli, athletic director at nearby Wilton High, where 72 percent of the 900 students play on at least one of 56 school teams.
Seven years ago Wilton imposed athletic participation fees from $25 for gymnastics to $100 for hockey. Fathers in the affluent town were ribbed unmercifully by fellow commuters about their "poor" school. Opposing athletes also commented. Parents objected to the double jeopardy of fees and taxes. Others complained their offspring did not receive the newest uniforms or equal playing time for the same fee. "We couldn't dump pay-for-play fast enough," Mr. Zeoli said. It died nine months later.
What changed the board's mind so quickly? "Anyone who complained to me," said a straight-faced Mr. Zeoli, "I gave them the board president's home phone. I said to call her only after midnight."

HEADLINE: Bush Considers Tax-Credit Plan To Aid Business

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12

 BODY:
President Bush's top economic advisers said today for the first time that to stimulate the economy, the Administration might favor a tax credit for business investments in plants and machinery.
"The history of investment tax credits is that they are somewhat effective, and maybe for that reason we ought to do it at this time," Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady told the Senate Finance Committee. 
 This kind of tax break, theoretically a boon to manufacturing, has considerable support in Congress and would stand a good chance of enactment if the Administration pushed for it.
The advisers offered no details of what they were considering but suggested that they might favor a credit only on investments above and beyond what a business might otherwise have planned.
 
Specifics Being Prepared
 The testimony from Mr. Brady, Richard G. Darman, the budget director, and Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, was their second in a week, and in most respects, what they told the Finance Committee added little to what they said to the House Ways and Means Committee on Dec. 5.
The Administration, they said, was preparing proposals to improve the economy in the short run and the long run, and these will be in the President's State of the Union Message and budget early next year. No final decisions have been made yet, they said.
But the officials today disclosed some of their thinking about specific tax issues that they had not discussed in last week's testimony. In addition to showing some enthusiasm about an investment tax credit, they opposed outright both the reintroduction of tax breaks for real estate investments and a special tax on people with incomes greater than $1 million.
They said that at Mr. Bush's instructions, they were examining ways to give a tax cut to middle-income families but were not committed to such a step. They also raised the prospect of considering tax legislation next year in two rounds, one right off the bat when Congress returns in January to give the economy a jolt and the other later in the year to deal with longer- range economic problems.
The Finance Committee is one of the most conservative committees in Congress, and many of the Democrats, including the chairman, Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, and David L. Boren of Oklahoma, have views on taxes and economic policy that are quite similar to the Bush Administration's. Mr. Bentsen, for instance, is sponsoring a new tax break for individual retirement accounts for upper-income taxpayers, and Mr. Boren is a strong supporter of a capital gains tax cut.
Still, politics was the order of the day. Over and over, the Democrats hammered Mr. Bush's advisers on the question of middle-class tax relief. The Democrats buttressed their position with new statistics showing how well the richest Americans had done in the 1980's, while the after-tax income of the poor and middle class rose little if at all.
The Administration officials refused to concede that the gap between the rich and the poor had increased in the Reagan-Bush years, something that almost all academics accept regardless of their politics.
 
Elusive Data on the Rich
 Mr. Brady argued that the wealthy were paying a higher percentage of the nation's total tax burden than they used to, a statistic that is accurate because the wealthy have an even higher share of the total income than they did before 1981. And at one point the Treasury Secretary held up a color graphic illustrating that poor people take more out of the economy in benefits than they pay in taxes, while rich people pay more in taxes than they receive in benefits.
Mr. Brady and his colleagues insisted that they felt deeply about the plight of middle-class voters. "If you ask the question, do we want to do more for middle-income Americans, the answer is unequivocally yes," Mr. Darman said.
As for the Administration's diehard support for a capital gains tax cut, Mr. Brady said, "The furthest thing in any of our minds is to create a windfall for people in the highest brackets."
 
Continuing Political Fight
 The back-and-forth over what the Democrats call fairness was, of course, simply another round in the political fight that has occupied the Democratic Congress and the Republican White House for most of the Bush Presidency and that is likely to intensify next year.
But for all the political talk, the biggest news came from a brief discussion of the notion of an investment tax credit.
Such a tax credit was first enacted under President John F. Kennedy in 1961 and except for a few months in the middle 1960's and two years during the Nixon Administration, it was on the books until it was abolished by the Tax Reform Act of 1986.
An investment tax credit would permit businesses to subtract directly from their tax bills a percentage of the money they invest in plants and machinery. Supporters maintain that it would encourage businesses to expand and generate new jobs and a stronger economy. Opponents say it would reward businesses for investments they would make anyway, would help capital-intensive industries more than those that depend largely on labor and would benefit established companies more than start-up businesses.
 
Support in History
 At today's hearing, Mr. Boskin said investment tax credits had been "effective, at least partially" in the past in improving the economy. He said the best bet might be a credit on investments above a certain level to prevent companies from getting a tax break on money they would have spent regardless. Senator Bentsen said he agreed with that view.
The main problem with an investment tax credit is the same as the problem with most other tax breaks: it would produce less revenue and, under the budget law, would require that an offsetting amount be raised elsewhere. The President and Congress might not be able to agree on such an offset.
The idea of dealing with tax policy next year in two rounds, one quickly and the other after more debate and deliberation, seemed to be an approach worked out by Mr. Darman and Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader.
Senator Bentsen said afterward that he opposed such a plan, lessening the prospect that it might be acted on.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long-Term Rates Fall on Reports

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Long-term interest rates moved lower yesterday, helped by an inflation report that was better than expected, as well as by declines in gold and commodity prices, two inflation indicators that are monitored closely by private analysts, as well as by Government officials.
In addition, bond prices benefited from a Commerce Department report that showed the Christmas buying season got off to a slow start in November, as well as from comments by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, who once again said he was favorably disposed to issuing more short-term Government securities to help push down long-term bond yields. 
 The two-tenths of a percent rise in the November Producer Price Index was about half of what most economists had anticipated, and it reaffirmed the notion that inflation remained low.
 
Other Sales Figures
 But at the same time, the three-tenths of a percent rise in November retail sales was above expectations. And the two-tenths of a percent rise in sales excluding automobiles was the first increase since July.
At first blush, the numbers seemed to suggest that consumer activity had begun to pick up. But analysts said the increase was tainted because of downward revisions in sales figures for September and October.
"The revisions showed that consumers are still struggling," said David H. Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International. "Some people interpreted the November figures as saying that Christmas won't be horrible. But in the aggregate, the data don't support that view."
Besides these developments, some traders said an auction of $12.3 billion in new one-year Treasury bills helped to raise the prices of longer-term, higher-yielding securities, including bonds.
 
New Bills at 4.20%
 At the auction, the new bills were sold at an average discount rate of 4.20 percent, well down from the average rate of 4.72 percent at last month's one-year bill sale.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 102 27/32 late yesterday, up by 17/ 32, to yield 7.75 percent, compared with 7.80 percent late on Wednesday.
Bond yields are now about as low as they have been all year, and analysts said additional evidence of economic weakness, as well as more good news on inflation, would be needed before long-term rates could move much lower.
In the secondary market for Treasury bills, the 7.50 percent 10-year notes were offered at 102 9/32 in late trading, up by 6/32, to yield 7.17 percent. But the prices of the 5.50 percent two-year notes dipped by 1/32, to 100 7/8, to yield 5.02 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates moved slightly higher.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 4.14 percent, up 2 basis points, or two one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 4.15 percent.
Activity in the corporate bond market was highlighted by an anticipated offering of $1 billion in high-yield securities for Owens-Illinois Inc.
The 11 percent senior debentures, which mature on Dec. 1, 2003, were priced at $100, or par. The securities are noncallable for eight years.
Merrill Lynch & Company was the lead manager for the underwriting. The securities are rated Ba-3 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and BB by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In conjunction with Wednesday's equity offering, proceeds from the bond sale will be used to retire some $1.8 billion in high-yield securities issued when Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company bought Owens-Illinois in a 1987 leveraged buyout.
Merrill Lynch officials said late yesterday that all of the new securities had been sold.
In other developments, A.T.& T., which last week sold more than $670 million in 40-year bonds, its first public debt offering since 1986, said yesterday that it intended to call some $850 million worth of debt issued in 1970. The company said it would date the formal call notices on Dec. 13, for formal redemption on Jan. 13.
 
Money Supply Up
 The Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week ended Dec. 2.
M2, the monetary aggregate most closely followed by the Fed, rose by $3.5 billion during the period, an increase that was slightly larger than most economists had anticipated.
M2 has been posting fairly healthy increases in recent weeks, but its growth is only just above the 2.5 percent level that represents the lower end of the Fed's growth target range for the 12 months ending on Dec. 31.
"M2 growth is finally above the lower target," said Mr. Resler, the Nomura Securities economist. "That is encouraging, but it has to continue."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Boise Cascade May Cut Dividend

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Boise Cascade, the world's eighth-largest paper producer, plans to sell more assets, and could lower its dividend to reduce debt. Boise Cascade has not cut its dividend in more than 20 years. The board of directors will meet today in San Francisco. "The company's bias is to hold onto the dividend," said Vince Hannity, a company spokesman. "But that depends on business conditions, and they're getting more difficult." 
 The company, based in Boise, Idaho, is losing money this year because of problems at paper mills in International Falls, Minn., Rumford, Me., and Kenora, Ontario. Boise Cascade has also been hurt by declining paper prices that have accompanied the recession. The company has raised about $250 million from asset sales this year.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Visions of Sugarplums And Puns

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
WHAT is it about the holiday season that inspires advertising agencies to play with words so freely?
Commercials and advertisements bursting with puns and other wordplays are inundating consumers this month, for products from cameras and soft drinks to cereal and underwear. Even ads for so-called sin products, like cigarettes and liquor, are joining in. 
 Print ads by Grace & Rothschild for J & B Scotch have white letters on a bright green background that read, "ingle ells, ingle ells," followed by the explanation: "The holidays aren't the same without J & B."
For Sharp's non-alcoholic brew, ads by Frankenberry, Laughlin & Constable Inc. in Milwaukee are headlined, "Noel-cohol" -- with a pair of bottle caps instead of the umlaut.
For the Eastman Kodak Company, ads by Young & Rubicam New York show a Scrooge-type character, next to the word "Humbug," transformed by a Kodak Star 35 camera into a "Shutterbug."
Advertising executives say the wordplay is intended to tap into the spirit of the season, to add joy and cheer to pitches for products like Joy and Cheer.
"It's a lighter, joyous time of year," said Roy Grace, chairman of Grace & Rothschild in New York. "That translates into 'Let's have a little fun, let's do a pun.' "
And there are many other examples of these playful ads:
*For the National Pork Producers Council, which for years has been selling pork as "the other white meat," ads by Bozell Inc. in Chicago carry the theme "White Christmas."
*For Baileys Original Irish Cream liqueur, ads by Geer, DuBois Inc. in New York urge consumers to "Let it flow, let it flow, let it flow."
*For Kix cereal, which contrasts its plain appearance to other brands' colorful gimmickry, ads by Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising depict 38 Kix puffs arranged in the shape of a Christmas tree. The headline reads, "No decorations necessary."
*For Virginia Slims cigarettes, print ads by Leo Burnett U.S.A. in Chicago are captioned, "You've come a fa-la-la-la-la-long way, baby."
While such ads have always been popular at the holidays, executives say there are more than ever this year. The reason, they add, is a belief that humor might, in some small way, help banish the anxieties over the economy that are keeping consumers from becoming customers.
One pitfall to this form of advertising is the subjective nature of the humor: One person's grin is another's groan.
But that has not proved a problem for Sharp's, said Tom Cardella, a category manager at the Miller Brewing Company in Milwaukee, adding that consumers and retailers have responded that the humor "fits in well" with the product's seasonal appeal.
Another potential drawback is the possibility that treating the holiday season in a light-hearted fashion, especially when it comes to the religious aspects of Christmas, might prove offensive.
"There's always the question of the Christmas holiday being exploited for commercial purposes," said F. Forrester Church, minister of All Souls Unitarian Church in New York, "and that does cut radically against the grain of the Gospel."
"On the other hand," he added, "anyone who gets too excited about this is also missing the point of the Christmas season." He cited what he called "my favorite quote in theology," from the writer G. K. Chesterton: "Angels can fly because they take themselves lightly."
"And I've added, 'The Devil falls on account of his gravity.' "

HEADLINE: Wells Fargo to Set Aside $700 Million for Losses

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12

 BODY:
Wells Fargo & Company, the big California bank, said today that it would set aside about $700 million for loan losses, an action that reflects the deepening weakness of California's commercial real estate market.
The San Francisco-based bank, which has an unusually large portfolio of real estate loans, said the action was expected to result in a fourth-quarter loss of more than $200 million. Wells Fargo also announced that it was halving the dividend on its common stock, to 50 cents a share, joining a growing list of banks that have reduced payments to shareholders to conserve capital. 
 Both the $700 million provision for loan losses and the size of the fourth-quarter loss were far greater than analysts had expected. The loan-loss provision reflects the results of a grueling examination of Wells Fargo's loan portfolio conducted by Federal auditors in the last few months.
Nevertheless, Wells Fargo's share price rose $3.25 today to close at $60.50. Investors seem to think that the worst is over and that the bank will be able to solve its problems. Indeed, despite the expected fourth-quarter loss of $4.20 to $4.60 a share, which translates to a net loss of $218 million to $239 million, Wells Fargo said it expected a slight profit for the full year.
"I've never been so happy after such a large loss and such a drop in the dividend," said Thomas Brown, a banking analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. He said he thought regulators had put pressure on Wells to increase its loan-loss reserves.
 
'Environment Full of Pessimism'
 Wells would not comment on the regulators' requirements. Carl Reichardt, the chief executive of Wells Fargo, said in a statement that the bank made its move because "we're operating in a difficult environment, full of pessimism and anxiety about the economy in general and real estate in particular." The statement continued, "In this environment it is only prudent to make a significant addition to our loan loss-reserves."
After booming through the 1980's, California's economy is slumping, and commercial real estate values have dropped so far that some pessimists predict the state will become the next Texas or New England in terms of banking problems. But other analysts say the diversity of California's industries and continued population growth will keep it from sinking into more serious problems.
Donald K. Crowley, an analyst with Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc. in San Francisco, said that he did not expect Wells to have any more big net losses but did think its profits would be held down for several years because of the problems in commercial real estate.
"Their exposure in commercial real estate remains sizable," he said. "It's a wound that's likely to keep bleeding, but it's not your jugular that's been cut."
 
Bank Losses in the State
 California's 485 banks had aggregate losses of $74 million in the third quarter, according to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. Two other big banks, the Security Pacific Corporation and First Interstate Bancorp, both based in Los Angeles, reported losses in the third quarter of the same magnitude that Wells expects in the fourth.
Wells Fargo, the state's third-largest bank, with assets of $55 billion, has long been known as one of the nation's most efficient and profitable banks.
But analysts have become worried because the bank has an unusually large proportion of its loan portfolio in two troubled areas -- real estate and leveraged buyouts. Its loans for land, construction and commercial mortgages account for roughly a quarter of its $46 billion loan portfolio, a percentage more than twice as high as that of rival BankAmerica Corporation and also significantly higher than for the other big California banks.
Wells had insisted that it could avoid problems because it made better loans than its rivals. But it, too, has suffered setbacks. In the second quarter of this year, Wells set aside $350 million for loan-loss reserves related to leveraged buyouts, reducing its profits to a meager level.
 
Actual Expected Loss
 Wells Fargo said it expected that actual loan losses in the fourth quarter would be about $200 million, up from $123 million in the third quarter. That is not as big an increase as expected, which is another reason the stock rose today, analysts said.
With only $200 million in loan charge-offs this quarter, $500 million of the $700 million loan-loss provision will be left for future losses. That reserve will grow to $1.65 billion and will cover about 80 percent of the bank's nonaccrual loans, compared with 63 percent now. That shift will bring Wells Fargo's reserves more in line with industry averages, analysts said.
Wells said it expected its nonperforming assets to grow less than 10 percent in the fourth quarter, from its third-quarter level of $2.3 billion. Nonperforming real estate loans actually grew more, but the bank sold a package of mostly nonaccruing loans during the quarter, bank officials and analysts said.
 Thomas H. Hanley, an analyst with Salomon Brothers, said Wells Fargo was thef irst major bank to emerge from an examination by Federal regulators since the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency announced new guidelines last month intended to relieve what is known as the credit crunch.
 Mr. Hanley said the Wells actions suggested a new strategy by Federal examiners. They will not be so quick to require banks to declare loans as nonperforming. But, he added, it appears that the regulators will insist on higher reserves for future loan losses and will urge banks to cut dividends to raise capital.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Rise 0.2%, Easing Fears on Inflation

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12

 BODY:
Prices at the producer level rose a slim two-tenths of a percent in November, the Labor Department said today, adding to evidence that the faltering economy continued to evade any inflationary pressures.
 The new data suggest the Federal Reserve could move again to cut interest rates without having to fear it would be setting the stage for higher inflation, economists said. 
 The November rise in the Producer Price Index followed a jump of seven-tenths of a percent in October and was generally in line with forecasts by economists.
 So far this year, the index, which measures prices charged by producers of finished goods, has risen at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of two-tenths of a percent.
 The "core" rate of inflation, which excludes the often-volatile food and energy prices, rose three-tenths of a percent after moving up five-tenths of a percent a month earlier.
 
 
No Warning Sign
 Economists were concerned that last month's jump might have been a warning sign that inflation was on the upswing, but additional data seemed to put that to rest.
 "Inflation is essentially the good news in the economy," said Brian Fabbri, chief economist at Midland Montagu. "The Fed can concentrate on stimulating demand," he said, adding that another rate cut might come as soon as next week, after policy makers of the central bank meet Tuesday.
 Lower interest rates can spur businesses and consumers to borrow and give a lift to economic activity.
 Officials in the Bush Administration have been trying to frame a plan to rescue the economy, which appears to have emerged from recession but at such an anemic level that it is hardly being felt.
 The weak performance has set off warning bells at the White House as President Bush's ability to deal with the economy is increasingly being questioned by voters as the 1992 Presidential election campaign gets under way.
 Some economists think the recession may show its face again when this quarter's figures on the nation's total output are released.

HEADLINE: U.S. Growth Figures Seen As Lower

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 12

 BODY:
For the second time in a month, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development has reportedly revised downward its projection for economic growth in the United States.
According to Agence France-Presse, the O.E.C.D.'s latest economic report -- which is embargoed for release until next Friday -- says that the American economy will grow by 2.2 percent in 1992. That figure is down from the forecast of a 2.5 percent American growth rate in 1992 that the Paris-based organization made just one month ago. And last month's prediction was significantly lower than the 3.1 percent growth rate for 1992 that the O.E.C.D. had projected six weeks earlier. 
 The agency also said that according to the new report, America's economic output for all of 1991 would decline by five-tenths of 1 percent, which is several tenths of a percent less than the forecast made last month.
The O.E.C.D., a 24-nation organization that promotes economic cooperation, is widely respected for its economic projections, which are based on sophisticated computer models. Nonetheless, its officials say they have repeatedly had to revise downward their forecasts for the United States because the nation's economic doldrums are proving far more stubborn than anticipated.
Senior O.E.C.D. officials say that the United States will not suffer a double-dip recesson and that the American economy should start to pick up this spring.
One bright spot for the United States is that the new report projects that the American economy will grow faster in 1993 than had been projected, according to the French news agency. The O.E.C.D., it says, predicts that American economic growth will be 3.5 percent for 1993, up from the forecast of 3 percent for 1993 that the O.E.C.D. made last month.
O.E.C.D. officials often say that the deeper a recession turns out to be, the more robust the rebound should prove to be. In addition, organization economists say that the Federal Reserve's repeated lowering of interest rates should eventually give growth a boost.
According to Agence France-Presse, the organization also said that growth in the industrial world would be a tepid 2.2 percent next year, down from the projection of 2.6 percent it made a month ago.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Strong Economic Reports Give a Lift to the Dollar

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar closed mostly higher yesterday after what currency traders saw as stronger-than-expected economic reports.
"There was good reaction to surprisingly strong numbers," said Matthew Robertson, vice president at Banque Nationale de Paris. "The biggest one was retail sales." 
 The United States currency closed at 1.5835 German marks, up from Wednesday's finish of 1.5780. The dollar also closed unchanged at 129.30 Japanese yen.
The Commerce Department reported that retail sales rose three-tenths of 1 percent in November, after remaining unchanged in October. Although the gain was not strong enough to change propects of a dismal Christmas selling season, they were better than some economists had feared.
A fall in new weekly claims for unemployment insurance also helped the dollar.
The statistics helped the dollar but analysts said they did not indicate much strength in the economy.
"Retail sales have been trending lower on a year-over-year basis for the last five months," said David Gilmore, senior analyst at MCM Currencywatch.
Separately, the Labor Department said its Producer Price Index rose a scant two-tenths of 1 percent last month after a jump of seven-tenths of 1 percent in October that had briefly raised inflation fears.
Brian Fabbri, chief economist at Midland Montagu Securities Inc., said the modest rise in wholesale prices should help convince the Federal Reserve that it could lower interest rates again without rekindling inflation.
Many traders expect the Fed to cut its benchmark discount rate soon, and Mr. Gilmore said speculation will heighten before Tuesday's meeting of the central bank's policy-making Federal Open Market Committee.
Although the prospect of a rate cut may weigh on the dollar, Charles Spence, corporate foreign exchange manager at First Interstate Bank, said political turmoil in the Soviet Union could lend some support. The dollar has often been a safe haven for investors in times of crisis.
The British pound closed at $1.8070, down slightly from $1.8080 on Wednesday.
The dollar also closed at 1.3995 Swiss francs, compared with 1.3925 francs Wednesday. It rose to 5.4095 French francs, from 5.2835 francs in the previous session.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Worrying Over Weakened Unions

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
GEORGE P. SHULTZ, who was Secretary of State in the Reagan Administration, is concerned about the possible harm to American industry and society stemming from the declining American labor movement.
Now the recession is further weakening the trade union movement, as always happens in slumps, with layoffs and employers' demands for givebacks undermining the bargaining power and organizing appeal of the unions. 
 "I go back to the old days in industrial relations," Mr. Shultz, who started his career as an economist and labor-management arbitrator, recently told the National Planning Association. "And I think of two things that have come through to me as lessons."
The first, he said, is that in "a healthy workplace, it is very important that there be some system of checks and balances." As an economist, he recognizes that the labor market itself produces checks and balances, as workers compete for jobs and management competes for labor.
But in a society in which individual strength depends on organizational connections, he thought there was still need for the checks and balances that derive from "what used to be called the system of industrial jurisprudence." This covered the entire process of dispute settlement through collective bargaining, grievance procedures, mediation and arbitration, with the right to strike as a last resort.
The second lesson, Mr. Shultz said, is that "free societies and free trade unions go together." It is no accident, he said, that the first thing a dictator does is to get rid of the free trade unions, if there are any. "And it's not an accident," he added, "that a lot of the fire for what happened in Eastern European countries came out of a trade union, Solidarity." Societies that lack the kind of organization that will "really get up on its hind legs and fight about freedom" are missing something.
He noted that in the American private business sector, trade union membership was down to 12 percent of the labor force. Only 10.2 million workers of 84.6 million employed by private businesses now are members of unions. Government unions now have 6.5 million members of 17.8 million employed by Federal, state and local government; that is 36.5 percent of public employment compared with 12.1 percent of private employment. Total private and public union membership in this country is down to 16.1 percent of employment from 34 percent in 1957 and 24 percent in 1973.
Concern about the shrinking size and role of organized labor in the private sector was striking, coming from a man who has not only held the top positions at State, Treasury, Labor and the Office of Management and Budget in Republican Administrations, but has also been president of the Bechtel Group Inc., and is a director of Bechtel, General Motors, Boeing, Chevron, the Morgan Bank and Tandem Computers.
"As a management person," he said, "if I'm running my shop and I don't have a union, I don't want them. But I'm trying to look at this more broadly and ask a question about where we're heading, and I think the monkey is really on the unions' back as much as anything to show a function in a world that is changing rapidly -- the whole workplace is changing, the patterns of competition are changing." Yet, he said, the underlying reality remains that in the workplace restraints on power are needed and, "as a society, we have a great stake in freedom and a lot of that is anchored somehow, historically," in the labor movement.
Why has the labor movement declined? "I don't quite know why that is," Mr. Shultz said. But he thought the nation needed better understanding of how the union role affects the nation's well-being in a rapidly changing industrial and global economic environment.
Sar A. Levitan, director of the Center for Social Policy Studies at George Washington University, attributes organized labor's decline to a combination of factors, including the "unfriendly courts and Government of the 1980's," first signaled by the Reagan Administration's breaking of the air traffic controllers' strike and the unions' inability to make necessary adjustments to the changing labor market, with the entry of more women and minority workers.
The unions, Mr. Levitan said, allowed their functions to be taken over by "a multiplicity of women's, racial and other groups." The unions, he said, did not give leadership roles to people from those groups and "could not take up the cudgels" to fight their causes.
Some business leaders, including at Bechtel, share Mr. Shultz's concern that from a broad social and economic standpoint, the decline of the unions may prove costly. Though it may make sense from the standpoint of the individual company to lay off workers and force down wages, from an overall national standpoint, there goes labor income, purchasing power, consumer confidence and the producers' sales. There is macroeconomic danger ahead if layoffs and payroll slashing become a national fad, the only weapon for raising productivity, and the prime test of managerial guts.

HEADLINE: SOVIET DISARRY;
Baker Sees Opportunities and Risks as Soviet Republics Grope for Stability

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 12

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a speech by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today at Princeton University:
The dramatic collapse of Communism in Moscow and the unraveling of the centralized Soviet state confront the West with great opportunities, yes, but also with ominous dangers. Popularly elected leaders now run large and strategically important republics, including Russia, Ukraine, Kazakhstan. They look to America and the West for guidance and help in launching genuine, far-reaching political and economic reform. If they can succeed, the centuries-old menace posed to the West, first by czarist autocracy and then by Soviet totalitarianism, will have been permanently altered. 
 The opportunities are historic. We have the chance to anchor Russia, Ukraine and other republics firmly in the Euro-Atlantic community and the democratic commonwealth of nations.
We have the chance to bring democracy to lands that have little knowledge of it, an achievement that can transcend centuries of history.
We have the chance, indeed, to help harness the rich human and material resources of those vast lands to the cause of freedom instead of totalitarianism, thereby immeasurably enhancing the security, the prosperity, and freedom of America and the world.
Yet the dangers are equal in scale to the opportunities. Economically, the old Soviet system has collapsed, multiplying every day the threats these reformers face from social dislocation to political fragmentation to ethnic violence. Reconstructing economies that have been devastated by central planning is even more difficult than reconstruction from the devastation of war.
Politically, the dangers of protracted anarchy and chaos are obvious. Great empires rarely go quietly into extinction. No one can dismiss the possibility that darker political forces lurk in the wings, representing the remnants of Stalinism or the birth of nationalist extremism or even fascism, ready to exploit the frustrations of a proud but exhausted people in their hour of despair.
Strategically, both of these alternatives, anarchy or reaction, could become threats to the West's vital interests when they shake a land that is still home to nearly 30,000 nuclear weapons and the most powerful arsenal of conventional weaponry ever amassed in Europe.
Taken together, these dangers serve, I think, as a call to action for America and the West. This historic watershed, the collapse of Communist power in Bolshevism's birthplace, marks the challenge that history has dealt us: to see the end of the Soviet empire turned into a beginning for democracy and economic freedom . . . across the former Soviet Empire.
Here is what we think the West must do:
*As we organized an alliance against Stalinism during the cold war, today America can mobilize a coalition in support of freedom.
*Together with our NATO allies, Japan, South Korea, the other O.E.C.D. states, our gulf coalition partners and international institutions, we must pursue a diplomacy of collective engagement.
*Together with the new democrats in the former Soviet Union, we can help create pathways of hope so that the New Russian Revolution can fulfill the promise of the next generation.

 	 	 		. . .	 	To multiply the value of our efforts, the international coalition must divide its labors. The wreckage of Communism is too large for any one nation to go it alone or to try and do everything. Working in concert, we must make use of the comparative advantages that each of us holds.

 	 	 		. . .	 	To crystallize this coalition, the President proposes that we begin by holding a coordinating conference to better divide our labor and responsibilities to help meet immediate and drastically increasing Soviet humanitarian needs. The United States will invite the advanced industrial democracies, the Central and Eastern European states, the members of the gulf war coalition, and the international financial institutions to join us in Washington in early January to discuss how best to meet ongoing humanitarian needs over the course of the next year.
This conference should work toward helping the Soviet peoples help themselves to get through the winter and to insure that together we take the right steps this winter, spring and summer to insure a better situation next winter. Our work should focus on critical short-term needs: food, medicine, fuel, shelter. In the meantime, the United States will continue its ambitious food and medical assistance program that the President announced a year ago today.
But our collective engagement must extend beyond immediate humanitarian needs and it should be organized around three tasks:
*First and foremost, we must help the Soviets destroy and control the military remnants of the cold war.
*Second, we must help our former adversaries understand the ways of democracy to build political legitimacy out of the wreckage of totalitarianism.
*And third, we must help free-market forces stimulate economic stabilization and recovery in the lands of the former Soviet Union.
Obviously, one of the most vexing questions we face is: Who is the authority or authorities with whom we can deal? In a revolution where political authority has diffused and fractured, the possible interlocutors seem almost endless. In the face of such uncertainty, the West we think should stick to fundamentals and support those who put into practice, those, wherever they may be found, who put into practice our principles and values.
This means that we will work with those republics and with any common entity which commit to responsible security policies, democratic political practices and free-market economics. Fortunately, new leaders are emerging who are committed to these principles.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Unless republic governments respond by complementing their independence with democracy and the equal treatment of persons belonging to minorities, they will soon find themselves suffering the very same crises of legitimacy, cohesion and effectiveness that has caused the centrifugal devolution of power in the Soviet Union itself.
Without legitimacy, there will never be stability, and, without stability, Western security will never be assured.
As I noted when I laid out our five principles in the aftermath of the coup attempt on September the 4th, the United States will welcome into the community of democratic nations those new political entities who believe in democratic values and follow democratic practices; who safeguard human rights including equal treatment of minorities; who respect borders and commit to changes only through peaceful and consensual means; and who will adhere to the international obligations and the norms and practices of the Helsinki Final Act and the Charter of Paris.
But we will isolate those who cloak Stalinism or fascism in a facade of nationalist or liberal or democratic rhetoric.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Now, while we work with Russians, Ukrainians, Kazakhs and others to destroy weapons and to cultivate democracy, the Russian winter, just as in 1812, 1917, and 1941, may again influence history's course.
As the economy collapses with no bottom in sight, the onset of cold weather is exacerbating the situation and is creating acute food, medicine, and energy shortages.
To meet these rapidly expanding needs, the United States has already this year shipped 18 millions tons of food, the largest by far of any Western country.
We have granted $4 billion in C.C.C. food and grant credits this year, $2.3 billion of those just since the August coup.
Through the President's emergency medical initiative, we've shipped through Project Hope close to $20 million in medical supplies and we plan to double this amount over the next eighteen months.
These supplies, which are all donated by American firms and average citizens, have reached the Soviet peoples where they need them most: in the Urals, in the Aral Sea region of Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan, and the Chernobyl region of Ukraine, as well as in Armenia, Moscow, and soon in Belorus.
Over $8 million of these medical supplies have gone to the Baltic countries, and with their independence, the President has created a new and separate program for them.
To facilitate meeting humanitarian needs, we will deliver or expend $165 million in Department of Agriculture grant funds to meet food shortages this winter, and we will draw upon the $100 million Congress has just authorized to transport humanitarian assistance.
We are also acting at this very moment to send food stocks left over from Desert Storm to regions in critical need: Armenia, the industrial cities of the Urals, and Moscow and St. Petersburg. The first shipments of these will be delivered by United States C-5 military aircraft to St. Petersburg and to Moscow next week.
Beyond the humanitarian problems, we know that, at least over the near term, democracy and free markets are unlikely to succeed everywhere across the lands of the Soviet Union as we knew it. There are likely to be "islands" of democracy and free markets that have to stand as bulwarks against other "islands" of chaos or authoritarianism, perhaps even fascism. In this environment, the democrats in Russia, Ukraine, Kazakhstan, Armenia and elsewhere must be able to offer pathways of hope to a better future.
We can help them define that path. For they will turn to us, to America and to Americans, as inspirations for the future, as sources of advice, and as partners in their work. And we can engage with our friends and allies by starting with human capital: people.
In this connection, the best way the West can help is to place Western experts on the ground and to bring Russians, Ukrainians, Kazakhs and others here for training.
The President has already approved an effort to put Americans on the ground to solve long-term food distribution problems; several American firms have offered their executives and will cover the costs to assist this effort.
While much of this effort will have to be done through the private sector, assisted by organizations like the Citizens Democracy Corps, the administration is proposing several steps to augment our ongoing U.S.I.A. efforts and to expand the human factor:
*We will work with the Congress to support an expanded Peace Corps program in at least four republics. And I would like to see at least 250 Peace Corps volunteers on the ground by next winter.
*We will expand Commerce's Business Training Program to accommodate 150 Soviet interns in the coming year.
*We will work with numerous voluntary organizations to look into ways they might expand their presence.
Clearly, of course, the bulk of responsibility must lie with republic leaders who have already assumed primary control over economic policy and resources. They must make the hard choices necessary for economic recovery.

 	 	 		. . .	 	For the administration's part, we intend to be a catalyst for this partnership. We will work with the business community to help bring American business into Russia, Ukraine, Kazakhstan, Armenia and other reforming republics. As a part of this commitment, we are taking the following immediate steps:
*The President today is announcing that Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger will be the United States Government coordinator for all of these assistance efforts. . . .
*We intend to propose authorizing legislation to the Congress, on its return, to facilitate our efforts to provide assistance and technical cooperation. A major aim of this legislation will be to promote trade business, and investment development by American companies in Russia, Ukraine, Kazakhstan and other republics. In addition, the Administration will conduct a thorough review of barriers to American business operating there to make it easier for American businesses to join this effort.
*We will put together, in consultation with Congress, a $100 million technical assistance program for the coming calendar year. Again, a major aim of this program will be to use Government funds to catalyze private sector involvement. This money will, of course, not come from domestic accounts but from assistance to other foreign nations. And given the gravity of the situation, there is no other choice.
*The President will ask the heads of the Trade and Development Program, the Overseas Private Investment Corporation and the Export-Import Bank to examine the possibility of focusing some of their efforts on facilitating the work of American business in the food distribution, energy, and housing sectors.

 	 	 		. . .	 	I believe that having prevailed over the twin fears of nuclear war and Stalinism, we can prevail over the tyranny of the spirit that might threaten reform and democracy and that might bring darkness to our lives as well. We can prevail as well over the fearful isolationism that threatens to return us to the failures of the '20s and the '30s.
We can prevail over political paralysis to forge a bipartisan consensus about what has to be done, and then, united at home, we can join with our allies to form a new coalition. A coalition for a diplomacy of collective engagement. A coalition to create pathways of hope. A coalition to make of the end of the cold war a beginning, a new beginning for all the nations of the world.
Ladies and gentlemen, history and the American people expect no less of us.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d laying out a plan for dealing with the collapse of the Soviet Union during a speech yesterday at Princeton University. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: The Art Market

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:

Suspended: Journal of Art
There seems to be a lot more activity in art publishing right now than in the art market itself.
The biggest news is Rizzoli's announcement that it has suspended publication of The Journal of Art. It was not a gradual slowdown: At 4 P.M. the day before Thanksgiving, the entire staff was dismissed with a week's severance pay. "They told us they didn't need to give us the two weeks' pay we were entitled to because the journal had just suspended publication, not folded," said the circulation director, Helen Ryan. "Then, in the same breath, they told us to file for unemployment and to look for another job." 
 The editor, Barbara Rose, a 30 percent shareholder in the journal, and one of the co-publishers, Alexis Gregory, who owns 10 percent, are suing Rizzoli, which owns 60 percent and decided to close the publication against their wishes. According to legal documents filed in the lawsuit, filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on Nov. 13, Ms. Rose initially invested $300,000 and Mr. Gregory put in $100,000 to rescue the journal from bankruptcy in February 1990. That month, Rizzoli added $600,000 to the investment to take control of the publication. Since then, the company has invested $1.5 million more, according to various art-world sources who spoke only on condition of anonymity.
"The whole thing is a horror show," Ms. Rose said in a telephone interview the other day. "They have bankrupted me, ruined me and made me sick." She said Rizzoli stopped paying her $100,000-a-year consulting fee in September and also had not honored her five-year contract as editor of The Journal of Art.
Gianfranco Monacelli, the president and chief executive officer at Rizzoli International Publications, says the company owes Ms. Rose no money. "We have fulfilled our obligations and more than that," he said yesterday. "This was an unfortunate situation, but in today's economic climate we felt there was a limit to what the corporation could afford."
Trouble began, some former employees say, almost as soon as Rizzoli became the majority shareholder. Those running the publication -- Mr. Gregory, Ms. Rose and Alfredo de Marzio, the other co-publisher, who is chairman of RCS, Rizzoli's American holding company -- were constantly fighting. Mr. Gregory and Ms. Rose asserted in their lawsuit that Rizzoli charged disproportionate amounts of its corporate overhead to the journal for offices within Rizzoli office space and that Rizzoli also disproportionately charged the publication for a computer system used by other Rizzoli publications.
Circulation kept rising, however; Ms. Rose said it nearly quadrupled since the time Rizzoli assumed control. At the time it stopped publishing, The Journal of Art had about 35,000 readers, More than 20,000 were paid subscriptions; the rest came from newsstand sales and free distribution at international art fairs. The publication was also averaging about 45 pages of paid advertising in each 100-page issue. "And the advertising was steadily going up, which was amazing, considering the recession," said the advertising director, Michael Benevento.
Now it is rumored that Mr. de Marzio, the co-publisher, has left Rizzoli. Although no official announcement has been made and the company is denying it, friends said he had told them he was going on a long vacation in Europe and leaving the company. When Mr. de Marzio was called for comment, Mr. Monacelli responded, saying Mr. de Marzio was out of the country and could not be reached for comment.
Meanwhile, Rizzoli is busy looking for a buyer so it can recoup its investment of more than $2 million. No purchase price has been made public. Last week, Maureen and Marshall Cogan, owners of Art and Auction, a general-audience magazine for collectors and art mavens, were reported to be serious contenders, but not any longer. Given the struggle all magazines are facing right now with dropping advertising, and the widespread rumor that Art and Auction is losing money, the Cogans have backed off.
"I decided to concentrate on the two magazines I have," said Mrs. Cogan, referring to Art and Auction and International Design Magazine. Rizzoli is still hoping someone will come along to rescue The Journal of Art. Rumors have been circulating that Brant Publications, owners of Art in America, The Magazine Antiques and Interview, are looking into the purchase. Mrs. Brant could not be reached for comment, but Ms. Rose denied the rumors. Mr. Monacelli said, "We've had a flood of interest, but none of it serious." As for the lawsuit, he said, "I cannot go into details."
 
Sold: Art and Antiques
 Art and Antiques magazine has been sold to the Atlanta-based Transworld Publications, owned by Douglas Billian, its president and chief executive. The 12-year-old magazine reportedly sold for $1,250,000.
This is not Mr. Billian's first foray into the art-and-antiques world. Two and a half years ago, he acquired Antiques Monthly. Since then, circulation has increased from 19,000 to 44,000, Mr. Billian said in a telephone interview this week. "That's not to say we're financially out of the woods yet," he said. "But things are looking up."
His latest purchase, a more arts-oriented, general-interest publication, has a circulation of 151,000, Mr. Billian said. Some consider it an imitation of Connoisseur. "We're not trying to increase it, but rather to make sure the publication fits the reader," he said. Therefore the company has embarked on a serious marketing research program. It is also trying to increase advertising, which has been running 25 percent below last year's figures, he said.
As for editorial plans, Mr. Billian said he was keeping the same editorial staff and working on plans to use some of the same articles in both publications, tailored to each one's readers. "Art and Antiques is aimed at a more general audience than Antiques Monthly," he said. "It won't just be for collectors, but for people who would like to be able to afford to collect."
 
Expanding: Art News
 Art News, the biggest of the art magazines (it reports its circulation at 74,000), is also branching out. In October it plans to launch Art News Japan in conjunction with Dohosha Publishing Company of Kyoto.
"Fifty percent of the editorial will be from the U.S. edition; the rest will be created locally," said the editor and publisher, Milton Esterow. "Initially we'll be printing about 30,000 copies of the Japanese edition."
Art News has also joined forces with Prestel, a Munich-based publishing company, to publish monographs on artists and photographers under the name Art News/Prestel. "I've also got four magazines on the drawing board," Mr. Esterow said. "I'm an optimist. When I bought Art News in 1972, people thought I was crazy. But I'm looking forward to a bright future."

HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By Alex Witchel

 BODY:

The Hellinger Sale
"It's a sign of the times," says James N. Nederlander, chairman of the Nederlander Organization, on the recent sale of its Mark Hellinger Theater, considered a prime musical theater on Broadway, to its longtime tenant, the Times Square Church. 
 "The church had three more years on their lease," Mr. Nederlander says. "And there are no productions around now to fill the theater. We have enough musical houses -- a surplus, as far as we're concerned. If you haven't got anything to put in it, what can you do?"
O.K., times are hard. But after all the efforts in the last few years to preserve theaters by giving them landmark status, why not sell the Hellinger to legitimate theater operators? Mr. Nederlander says that in years past, Michael Bennett, Cameron Mackintosh and Jujamcyn Theaters all expressed interest in buying the theater. But the price was never right. Although Mr. Nederlander would not give the exact figure of the sale, an executive close to the negotiation says it was $17 million.
"There is no way a theater operator can compete with that price," says Rocco Landesman, president of Jujamcyn. "To make it work, an operator couldn't pay more for it than $5 million to $7 million. Even if you take $15 million as the figure, you pay 10 percent interest a year, which is $1.5 million, plus utilities and operating overhead. You have to make $2 million a year just to break even. Even with a really hot Broadway musical, you couldn't make the numbers work."
"What this proves," he adds, "is that landmarking a building doesn't save a theater."
Bernard B. Jacobs and Gerald Schoenfeld, president and chairman, respectively, of the Shubert Organization, Nederlander's major competitor (it owns 16 theaters to Nederlander's 10), declined to comment on the sale. Harvey Sabinson, executive director of the American League of Theaters and Producers, also declined to comment.
Mr. Nederlander says: "This city treats the theaters like orphans. In London, when a theater goes dark, they waive the taxes, but not here. Still, we continue to be in the market for new theaters. We just bought the Shubert in Chicago and the Dominion in London. We need them in cities where we can book them."
Compounding Mr. Nederlander's economic woes in New York is the scheduled closing of the musical "Nick and Nora" on Sunday. It is said that his investment was $1.5 million. "The papers didn't like it, so that's what it is," he says evenly. "In this business, you have to move forward."
 
New Dancers at 'Lughnasa'
 For everyone who has fallen in love with the cast of Brian Friel's "Dancing at Lughnasa" and keeps asking if the Irish actors from the Abbey Theater in Dublin will stay longer than the 20 weeks allowed by Actors' Equity, the answer is no. The company will stay only until March 1, after which the parts must be played by American actors. But when the snob appeal of the Abbey is gone, will the producer, Noel Pearson, go Broadway and find big names to keep profits strong? Can we all look forward to Pia Zadora in "Lughnasa"?
Absolutely not, Mr. Pearson says. "Brian and I have made a very conscious decision to go for an ensemble team like the one we have. There will be no stars, just the best possible actors available. There's quite a lot of Irish-American actors here, you know." Mr. Pearson says he has been approached by a number of stars who want to join the cast, although he declined to name them. He notes that the actor Donal Donnelly will remain in the play, since he had the foresight to belong to the Abbey and live in Connecticut.
"These people in the cast have been doing the play for nearly two years now, in Dublin and London, before they even got here," Mr. Pearson says. "They have children and families, and they want to go home." But some, he says, will return to the United States for the play's national tour, to begin next fall.
 
Playing With Food
 It may look as if Blue Man Group is making an arbitrary mess down at the Astor Place Theater, where its show, "Tubes," is playing. But just for the record, this is art, darling, albeit with a sense of humor, and much of it is edible.
Of the three blue men, Matt Goldman, Phil Stanton and Chris Wink, the last two are former employees of the caterer Glorious Foods, where they learned to use their time, and leftovers, wisely. In one sketch, marshmallows are continually tossed into Mr. Wink's mouth until you think it will burst. But real marshmallows aren't the right consistency for the desired effect. While they were still catering, Mr. Wink says, they had great success with leftover chevre. But once they had to pay for it themselves, they switched to cream cheese, which is molded to resemble marshmallows. Mr. Wink says he is happy with the results, but he has eliminated cream cheese from his everyday life.
Another sketch revolves around the trio and a guest from the audience eating Twinkie Lights. While the Twinkies are being daintily sliced with knife and fork, Twinkie cream starts spurting from the performer's chests. But the cream is really whole bananas being pushed through 20 feet of tubing connected to an air pump and operated individually by foot pedals. It takes two hours just to load one person's tubing. The trio arrives at the theater every day at noon to do this and numerous other intricate setups.
Then there's the Jell-O, 80 pounds a week. It is made in individual molds by Jean-Claude Nedelac, the chef at Glorious Foods. Since the Jell-O is sent flying in one sketch, it is made with a minimum of water to be as dry as possible. The Blue Men say some people take it home as a souvenir.
As for their skin color, they say this isn't just any blue, but Yves Klein blue, inspired by the artist who invented his own shade for its spiritual qualities. It is nontoxic watercolor. "We find stuff used by kids," Mr. Wink says, "since everything we use seems to end up in the mouth."
 
Readings of Capote
 Starting on Sunday, and through Dec. 22 at the Book Friends Cafe, 16 West 18th Street, Chelsea, you can hear Truman Capote's "Christmas Memory" read by a variety of theater stars, including Stockard Channing and Courtney B. Vance, Madeline Kahn, Irene Worth, B. D. Wong, Elaine Stritch and Kevin Spacey, Judith Ivey and Nathan Lane, and Lea Salonga and Howard McGillin. Tickets are $12 Tuesday through Thursday and $15 on the weekend. All proceeds will go to Equity Fights AIDS. Tickets: (212) 982-8356.

The play is to open at the Brooks Atkinson on March 12.

HEADLINE: Lebanon Says French Aide's Visit Opens a New Era of Cooperation

BYLINE: By IHSAN A. HIJAZI, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 12

 BODY:
Lebanon and France began today what officials here called a new era of close cooperation as the French Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas, began a two-day visit, the first by a senior French official in six years.
"The visit reflects the special relationship between the two countries and heralds a new era of cooperation between them," the Lebanese Foreign Minister, Faris Bouez, told reporters after talks with his guest, who will also be going to Syria and Jordan. A French diplomat said Mr. Dumas would explore possibilities for French help in promoting the Middle East peace process, which is co-sponsored by the United States and the Soviet Union. 
 Lebanese leaders attach great importance to Mr. Dumas's visit. The Beirut Government hopes to re-establish Lebanon's traditionally intimate relationship with France, its former colonial master.
French-Lebanese relations soured last year in a dispute over Michel Aoun, a renegade Lebanese Army general who claimed to be the legitimate president of Lebanon. After an attack by Syrian and Lebanese troops drove him from his stronghold in the presidential palace in a Christian suburb of Beirut, General Aoun took refuge at the nearby French Embassy, and France rejected repeated requests from the Government of President Elias Hrawi that it hand him over.
The problem was resolved last summer when General Aoun was allowed to leave the embassy and go to France to live in exile. This cleared the way for a state visit to Paris in October by Mr. Hrawi, who said Lebanon's old relations with France were back on track.
Lebanese officials also hope the Dumas visit will lead to increased French assistance for Lebanese reconstruction.
Lebanon's Prime Minister, Omar Karami, is in Paris taking part in a special session of the World Bank, which is considering plans for aid to rebuild Lebanon after 15 years of civil war. Mr. Karami said he would ask the bank for $4.5 billion to finance the reconstruction of his country's electricity, water, telecommunications and other networks. He estimated Lebanon's total reconstruction bill at $15 billion.

HEADLINE: Guatemalans Irked by U.S. Pressure in Killing

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GUATEMALA, Dec. 6

 BODY:
Pressure by the Bush Administration for the prosecution of army officers for the killing of an American innkeeper in rural Guatemala 18 months ago has raised resentments in the Guatemalan Army leadership.
Gen. Luis Enrique Mendoza Garcia, who was Defense Minister until his dismissal today, recently said, "We don't have any reason to plead guilty to the United States." 
 He asserted that the prosecution of the case "is proceeding according to our judicial procedures and is moving toward a conclusion."
Seven enlisted men have been charged in the killing of the innkeeper, Michael DeVine, but three officers were ordered freed after questioning by a military tribunal.
No explanation was given for the sudden replacement of General Mendoza and his Chief of Staff, but this case is one of several rumored areas of difference between President Jorge Serrano Elias and General Mendoza. He was replaced by Gen. Jose Garcia Samayoa.
Publicly, however, President Serrano has stood behind the army command. In an interview two days before the dismissal, he complained that the United States had made the DeVine case "the central point" in relations between the two countries and asserted that his Government was not part of any cover-up.
"It hurts that they have not recognized the attitude of impartiality of my Government," he added. "We have been absolutely crystal clear in the handling of this case. I have said this to President Bush himself; they have to understand there is no cover-up on our part."
The United States asserts that the army is blocking prosecution of some of its officers in the death of Mr. DeVine, who with his wife, Carol, ran a farm and guesthouse near Poptun in the department of Peten.
Guatemalan officials say American officials simply do not understand Latin legal procedures and are being disrespectful of Guatemalan sovereignty.
President Serrano asserted that private investigators and lawyers hired by Mrs. DeVine were trying, with the help of pressure applied by the United States Embassy, to get the Government and the army to force certain officers to make accusations against others. He said visas to the United States were offered, and other inducements, which he characterized as bribes.
But former President Vinicio Cerezo, who was in office at the time of the killing, recently acknowledged in a magazine interview that some officers "tried to hide evidence" after the killing.
Mr. DeVine, 49 years old, was kidnapped at the entrance to his farm on the afternoon of June 8, 1990, by a group of men in a white Toyota pickup truck, witnesses said. His body was found early the next morning. His hands were bound, there were signs of strangulation, and the head had been partly severed with a machete.
Initially, the killing was thought to have been a common crime, with robbery the motive. But after the investigation led to the nearby army base, the Bush Administration cut off Guatemala's small military aid allotment, $2.9 million, and began to help Mrs. DeVine in seeking arrests and prosecution.
For the United States, the DeVine case has become the top priority on a list of several cases involving abuses by the armed forces. The United States Congress approved a joint resolution conditioning continued economic aid to Guatemala on progress in the prosecution of this and several other cases.
Progress has been made on resolving some of the cases. In case, an army officer and a sergeant were convicted and sentenced to 4 and 16 years respectively for the massacre of 13 residents of the village of Santiago Atitlan a year ago.
In another, a former member of the army's presidential guard, Noel de Jesus Beteta Alvarez, was arrested in California on Nov. 29 for illegal entry and deported to Guatemala to face charges of stabbing to death Myrna Mack Chang, a prominent Guatemalan anthropologist.
