HEADLINE: Comrades in Arms

BYLINE: By Fred C. Ikle; Fred C. Ikle was Under Secretary of Defense in the Reagan Administration. A longer version of this article will appear in the winter issue of The National Interest.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
To start building a lasting peace, Washington should work with Moscow to create an American-Russian Defense Community. This arrangement could take its inspiration from the economic communities formed in Western Europe in the 1950's that made French-German reconciliation irreversible.
The U.S. and Soviet defense establishments have grown unusually warm toward each other; the Soviet military in particular is becoming more open as it undergoes internal stress and upheaval. Military leaders in Russia and the other republics seem eager to reduce nuclear weapons quickly, and they welcome American assistance to make that possible. Many senior officers are showing keen interest in the American principle of civilian control of the military, in U.S. help to prevent nuclear proliferation and in a cooperative approach to creating defenses against missiles from third world countries 
 Ending the adversarial relationship between both military establishments might take years. The confrontation in Central Europe has ended, but other steps must follow in three basic areas: each side's preparations for war, the training and deployment of forces and the developing and testing of weapons.
So far, Americans are resisting changes needed to form a military community more than the Soviets seem to be. Having recently visited Moscow, I have the impression that the end of the cold war has been accepted more readily there than in Washington. The hoary idea that NATO might have to use nuclear arms against conventional attack lingers in U.S. doctrine. And many American nuclear technicians believe that U.S. nuclear testing must continue whether or not testing in the former Soviet Union resumes.
The Defense Community would have to carry out at least four missions to avoid becoming a home for bureaucrats forever in search of a purpose yet always busy with organizational charts.
It would have to eliminate the confrontation between nuclear forces, especially the hair-trigger readiness. It would need to phase out the secrecy between the two establishments. It would need to take steps against nuclear proliferation without running roughshod over the sovereignty of nations with legitimate nuclear programs. And, through efforts (including military maneuvers) in former republics, it would have to strengthen the understanding of the principle of civilian control of the military.
While abandoning the cold war approach to arms control, the community should not seek merely to stabilize the military balance and reduce arms. We can learn from the 1920's, when the major powers, using elaborate naval treaties, sought in vain to stabilize the balance in strategic arms. Instead of keeping the peace by overcoming the sense of military rivalry, they tried to keep the confrontation peaceful. But the naval staffs continued to consider each other adversaries, modernized their navies -- and planned the next war.
An American-Russian Defense Community can end the nuclear standoff. At the end of the road, restructured nuclear forces would co-exist, much like the French and British nuclear forces, without concern about the stability of mutual deterrence. Do French generals worry if their nuclear forces can deter perfidious Albion from launching a first strike against France?
Without the bonding of the defense communities, political forces might push the military, at least in the Russian republic, into a new confrontation with the U.S. There might be a new arms race between the two countries resulting from efforts to defend themselves against other countries such as Iraq, Iran and perhaps China.
Some U.S. defense planners seem too sanguine about our ability to again contain such an expansionist Russia. The Pentagon properly has plans for reconstituting the armed forces over two or three years. But a decision to rearm against a fascist-imperialist Muscovite empire would create discord. We would return to the Vietnam years, not the Truman years, when containment was so successfully launched. Americans and our allies would ask how democracy's victory that ended the cold war could have been foolishly squandered.

HEADLINE: Canadian Health System Continues to Do Well

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A Nov. 24 news article wrongly implies that the Canadian Government is stuck with a politically popular health-care program that the nation cannot afford. Hospital bed closings do not necessarily imply reduction of service. Hospital treatment has represented a much higher proportion of the health-care budget because universal medical coverage began with hospitals: services performed in them were insured, while the same procedure in a doctor's office was not. 
 The concentration of service in hospitals became unnecessary as the program expanded to cover all medical treatment, but earlier expansions had created an enormous number of beds that are now better left unfilled in favor of chronic-care facilities, outpatient services and other more humane, less expensive alternatives.
The fear-mongering done in the United States about waiting lists should also be examined. We have waiting lists for surgery, especially elective surgery. Priority is given to those most in need of the operation, not to those best able to buy their way to the head of the line. No doubt, many hospitals in the United States have no waiting lists -- why be on a list if you will never be able to pay for the operation anyway?
It is true that our federal and provincial governments are seeking ways to cut health-care costs. So are your governments, while the United States spends more of its gross national product on health than Canada does and tolerates infant mortality rates that rival third world countries.
I know that your medical establishment will wage war on proposals to introduce our system. So did our doctors at first, and in some cases those who were in medicine principally for personal enrichment left for the United States. If a billing cap of $400,000 a year for a doctor is parsimonious, perhaps we were recruiting the wrong people into the profession. However, this has not been a serious problem because many doctors prefer not to act as collection agencies.
An informed debate on our system will look at the results: the health of the population and the freedom from the corrosive anxiety that attends loss of benefits or illness in the family.
 
JANET HOWARD
Toronto, Nov. 28, 1991

HEADLINE: Mexicans Head North Despite Rules on Jobs

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TIJUANA, Mexico, Dec. 6

 BODY:
For months, as the United States has raised a heavy metal barricade along its border with Mexico here, officials of the two countries have argued over the symbolism. The Mexicans call it a wall, like the Berlin wall; the Americans say it is just a strong fence.
But each night around midnight, hundreds of men and women clamber over the 10-foot-high structure to offer another definition: It has become a monument, their numbers suggest, to the impossibility of keeping poor foreign workers from better-paid jobs. 
 After a decline following the immigration-control law of 1986, illegal immigration has rebounded strongly, according to recent United States Government statistics and other evidence. And despite stepped-up border enforcement, and a barrier that officials say will eventually close off 12 miles of the border just south of San Diego, experts say that the flow will almost certainly remain high for years.
Both President Bush and President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico have pointed to the free trade agreement they are negotiating with Canada as an important step toward solving the problem. But a growing number of researchers say free trade would take years, if not decades, longer than officials have suggested to raise Mexican wages and employment enough to dim the attraction of American jobs. For some time, many experts say, the disruptions of free trade might even cause illegal immigration to rise.
"Free trade has been oversold as a quick fix to the immigration problem," said Wayne A. Cornelius, the director of the Center for U.S.-Mexican Studies at the University of California at San Diego.
"Most people are focusing on two, three years," Dr. Cornelius said. "You've got to think in terms of 10, 15, 20 years for a free trade agreement to have a demonstrably significant impact on the volume and kind of labor migration that is occurring between the two countries."
For the moment, debate over what free trade might achieve has been overtaken by questions about whether political concerns might prompt the White House to keep a treaty from Congress until after the 1992 elections. The timing of a trade agreement is expected to dominate talks between Mr. Bush and Mr. Salinas at Camp David on Saturday.
American officials have kept immigration questions out of the free trade negotiations. Undocumented immigration has also virtually disappeared as a point of friction, reflecting better relations between the United States and Mexico.
But immigration itself has surged. New figures released last month by the Immigration and Naturalization Service show that for the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30, apprehensions at the Mexican border rose slightly to 1,077,511 from 1,049,680 in 1990. Both years were up considerably from the 854,128 arrests recorded in 1989, the last of three years that registered a decline.
The numbers represent an uncertain fraction of the people entering the United States illegally, and immigration officials attribute part of the rise to better enforcement.
 
'Business as Usual'
 Jorge Bustamante, president of Tijuana's College of the Northern Border, a leading center for immigration research, said the institute's projections showed the illegal traffic stabilizing near pre-1986 levels.
"It has returned to business as usual," Dr. Bustamante said.
Immigration experts and U.S. officials say the 1986 Immigration Reform and Control Act, which require employers to verify that their workers are not illegal immigrants, has been undermined by a series of developments, including weak I.N.S. enforcement of penalties against those who do hire undocumented workers.
Researchers say the law's legalization of 3.1 million foreigners has also created a magnet for those immigrants' relatives and friends. Mexicans call these immigrants "los rodinos," after Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., a New JerseyDemocrat who sponsored the 1986 law in the House.
But most important, underlying economic reasons for the flow have not changed on either side of the border.
In Mexico, inflation has dropped sharply and economic growth is up to 4 percent a year after nearly a decade of crisis. Yet 44 million Mexicans still qualify as impoverished, underemployment remains high, real wages are at about what they were in 1980 and, on average, Mexico pays its workers about one-eighth what they can earn in the United States.
To the north, meanwhile, low-paying jobs in agricultural and service industries remain easily available. In California, for example, lawn and gardening services have roughly doubled their workforce since the early 1980's.
The economics were simple to Fernando Lopez, 24 years old, who waited recently to hop the barricade into California with three other "chickens," as the migrants are called.
Their guide had led them into California four times in two days, and into the Border Patrol's clutches each time. "That's equal to two days of work," said Mr. Lopez, who earned $30 or $40 a week as a carpenter in the central state of Michoacan. But, he added, "Next week, I will make $300."
To stem the tide of such migration, , economists say, Mexican wages do not have to rise to United States levels, but merely come closer. Philip L. Martin, an agricultural economist at the University of California at Davis, said European experiences suggest that migration would begin to ebb when Mexican pay rises from one-eighth the American equivalent to one-fourth.
But some Mexican analysts have argued that such a shift would run counter to a basic equation of free trade: that new jobs will be created in Mexico precisely because of its low labor costs. And while most economists consider it inevitable that the wage gap will narrow, they said that could take anywhere from 10 years to two generations.
In the meantime, new laws allowing Mexican peasants to sell their community lands, along with an expected end to the subsidies that Mexico pays its corn farmers, could propel more people northward. And experts wonder if the jobs that free trade might create in northern Mexico could actually foster illegal immigration by drawing people to the edge of the United States.
The idea of a free trade agreement seemed far off the other night for Luis Campos, another Michoacan native, who earns $10 an hour collecting trash in Anaheim, Calif.; in his hometown of Puruandiro, he said, he made barely $500 a year growing beans and corn.
As for the barrier that the I.N.S. and a military construction corps have halfway completed, Mr. Campos said that it did not make sense. His life is in the United States, he said, and all five of his children were born there.
"We don't do anyone any harm," he said as he leaned against the barricade. "We work hard. I don't know why they just don't let us in."

CORRECTION-DATE: December 14, 1991, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the flow of illegal immigrants across the border with Mexico misidentified the home state of former Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr. in some copies. He is from New Jersey.

HEADLINE: EFFORT TO REPEAL NEW TAX ON INCOME FAILS IN HARTFORD

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Dec. 13

 BODY:
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. today vetoed a plan to repeal Connecticut's new income tax only 30 minutes after it was approved, asserting that the legislature had embarked on a path of "full-scale surrender to fiscal gimmicks and political fantasies." The House then failed to override his veto, eliminating all hope for repeal of the income tax this year.
Although neither the veto nor the failure to override it came as a great surprise here, the day's events nonetheless stood out as landmarks in the 10 months of conflict and passion that have informed the tax debate, capturing both Mr. Weicker's resolve and the legislature's inability to thwart him. 
 Four times the legislature has tried to solve the state's fiscal crisis without taxing wages. And four times the lawmakers' plans have been rejected by Mr. Weicker, a third-party independent governor without a single member of his tiny party in the General Assembly.
 
Looking Now to '92
 "I surrender; we've lost -- for today," said Representative Vincent J. Chase, a Republican from Stratford, speaking on the House floor. "But the ultimate vote on what happens with the income tax will be the vote that's taken next November," when all 187 members of the General Assembly are up for re-election. With that, anti-tax protesters packing the gallery broke into wild applause.
Mr. Chase spoke after the 151-member House failed to muster the 101 votes, or two-thirds, needed to override Mr. Weicker's veto. The vote, at 6:30 P.M., was 84 to 65 -- a clear majority for repeal but still 17 votes short of what was needed under the State Constitution to override the veto.
For some, the final failure of repeal was a flash point of frustration. Tempers flared and bitterness was evident in many voices in the final minutes of the debate.
"This chamber, this body, this government, this state, looks like garbage in the eyes of the people and rightly so," said Representative Richard Foley Jr., a Republican from Oxford who is also his party's state chairman.
Lawmakers said the special session that began last month to reconsider the tax will probably end its work next week, with an attempt to amend the current income tax to reduce the burden on middle-income residents. Repeal leaders have opposed all so-called repair plans, and the Republican minority leader in the House, Representative Edward C. Krawiecki Jr. of Bristol, said he would move to adjourn the session, perhaps on Monday, if a measure was not ready to go forward.
On Aug. 22, a razor-thin majority in the General Assembly approved a law that imposed a 4.5 percent flat rate tax on adjusted gross income and eliminated Connecticut's status as one of only 10 states with no wage tax. Since then, the state has been rocked by protests that were capped in October by a rally that drew more than 40,000 people to the Capitol grounds.
 
Allusions to New Jersey
 But it has also been clear that the debate has touched deeper chords. Many of the hundreds of people who came to testify against the law last month and early this month in public hearings at the Capitol linked the tax directly to the recession and the downturn of Connecticut's fortunes in the 1990's.
Republicans, who led the repeal drive, have also cast the tax as the issue on which public policy will turn next near. They have alluded repeatedly to New Jersey, where voters turned out a Democratic legislative majority last month in what appeared to be a sort of referendum on taxes.
Public opinion polls have also run consistently against the tax, and one anti-tax lawmaker warned tonight that the minority working to sustain Mr. Weicker's veto was falling victim to a "trap" in which he said Mr. Weicker is also caught: believing that what is right must be unpopular.
 
Late-Breaking News
 "The more people shout at him and tell him it's wrong, the more he's convinced that it's right," said Representative Andrew McCall Norton, a Republican from Colchester, referring to the Governor. "You're going to decide, 'it must be right because I'm flouting the people's will,' " he said of the override vote. "Please don't keep doing it in the future. Very often the people are right."
Lawmakers who favor the tax were mostly muted in the debate, which reached a vote just in time for the end of the 6 P.M. local news programs. Some attacked the alternative budget, which would replace the wage tax with a higher sales tax and deeper spending cuts. But since the numbers of votes were clear well before the final tally, most supporters simply stayed in their seats and let the repealers have their moment.
"We had a difficult decision to make and I think we made it," said Representative Miles S. Rapoport, a Democrat from West Hartford who supports the tax law.
Mr. Weicker also announced separately today that another loose string in the state's budget -- involving concessions demanded by the administration from the state employee unions -- had also been resolved. The preliminary agreement, which covers 13 unions and more than 15,000 state workers, would bring back more 1,100 laid off workers in the next month if approved by rank and file members. Layoff notices for another 700 workers would be rescinded.
The agreements vary, but a spokesman for the unions, Robert Krzys, said the key provision -- announced only a few hours before the vote in the House -- would send all laid-off workers back to their jobs. In return, some employees would give back all or part of pay raises awarded last year. Others would forgo raises that would have otherwise been received. Mr. Weicker told reporters in announcing the agreement that there was no connection between the settlement and the final repeal vote.
In the gallery in the Hall of the House, where zealous anti-income-tax protesters had to be repeatedly warned by House Speaker Richard J. Balducci of New Britain not to disrupt the debate, the mood was one of resignation and quiet determination.
"This is back to 'go' and start all over again," said A. M. Melita, a machinist from Stratford who wore a large sign around his neck proclaiming his allegiance to repeal. "We're going to regroup."

The Economy
A Federal fraud case rippled through Iowa's municipalities and counties, freezing scores of local government funds and prompting the S.E.C. to seek more stringent examinations of the nation's 17,000 investment advisers. [Page 35.] 
 Consumer prices climbed 0.4 percent in November, with what may prove to be temporary surges in food, clothing and energy not fully offset by lower inflation for housing and medical care, the Labor Dept. reported. The rise, which followed a 0.1 percent advance in October, was a bit more than expected. [35.]
Sales of U.S.-built cars and light trucks declined 10.6 percent in early December, auto makers reported. Analysts said the drop suggested that retail demand remained weak at best. [35.]
While merchants are busy blaming the economy for their woes, Stanley Marcus, chairman emeritus of Neiman Marcus, points his accusing finger at the merchant. [35.]
The F.C.C. was "asleep at the switch" in responding to a growing threat of widespread breakdowns in the nation's telephone networks, a Congressional report says. [37.]
Declines in newspaper advertising linage appear to be slowing, but no upturn is yet in sight, a group of newspaper company executives said. [37.]
S.& P. lowered California's credit rating from the highest rating of AAA, citing a huge budget deficit. [8.]

International
The link between Robert Maxwell and Goldman, Sachs has become a focus of investigation by British Government officials amid suggestions that Goldman's actions served to support the share price of Maxwell Communication over many months. [35.]
The British underwriters of Robert Maxwell's life insurance policy said they did not consider the Spanish autopsy report to be the final word. They said they would make no payment on the $36 million policy until they had reasonable proof that Mr. Maxwell had died as a result of an accident. [36.]
 
Companies

Grain and soybean futures prices surged as fears of civil war in the Soviet Union receded. [44.]
The dollar advanced against most currencies, helped by concerns about the Soviet Union. Gold prices closed mixed. [44.]

HEADLINE: Iowa Funds Are Frozen In Inquiry

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
Repercussions of a fraud case filed by the Federal Government in Los Angeles rippled through municipalities and counties in Iowa today and were felt here, as well. The funds of scores of local governments were frozen, and the Securities and Exchange Commission was prompted to seek more stringent examinations of the nation's 17,000 investment advisers and higher fees to pay for the reviews.
The problems for Iowa's local governments were touched off when a Federal judge in Los Angeles on Wednesday ordered the $1.2 billion in assets of Institutional Treasury Management Inc. of Irvine, Calif., frozen. 
 The S.E.C. said that at least $74.4 million held by the company for its clients had disappeared. The funds, the agency said, had been improperly used to cover losses from unauthorized bond trades.
The court also froze the assets of the company's owner, Steven D. Wymer, who resigned this week. Through his lawyer, Mr. Wymer has offered to settle the case without admitting or denying guilt.
 
Hearing Next Week
 Other clients of the fund include various government funds from 12 states and Micronesia, but most of the losses uncovered so far involve the Iowa Trust, a pool of assets from municipalities in the state that stand to lose more than $70 million. A hearing is scheduled for next Friday for a judge to determine which of the advisory firm's accounts can be unfrozen.
The order freezing the company's assets threw into question the finances of the many towns and municipalities that invested money with the company to obtain the higher yields it advertised, but as a result of the case are now struggling to meet their payrolls and other expenses. Eighty-seven governments and pension plans in Iowa invested in the fund.
Lori A. Richards, a senior official in the S.E.C.'s Los Angeles office, said the commission felt compelled to freeze all of the company's assets because it was not entirely clear how pervasive the suspected fraud was. "It's possible that most of the funds will be recovered," she said. "It's also possible they might not."
In Iowa, Richard Vohs, a spokesman for Gov. Terry Brandstad, said that so far the state had been called upon to help only the Waterloo office of the state's Department of Correctional Services to meet its payroll. But other institutions were concerned that they could lose substantial sums. The largest investor was the police pension fund of Dubuque County, which gave Institutional Treasury Management $24 million in invest.
"Their interest rates were a little higher but not outlandish, so we didn't think it was too good to be true," said Wes A. Nelson, city finance director for Marion, Iowa, a town of 20,000 not far from Cedar Rapids that invested $4.3 million. He said that since most of the assets invested had been for construction and equipment, the lawsuit would not cause an immediate cash squeeze.
In an interview today, Richard C. Breeden, the chairman of the S.E.C., said the case highlighted the government supervision of an industry that manages more than $5 trillion.
"Regular examinings on average are only done once every 8 to 10 years," he said.
S.E.C. officials said that Institutional Treasury made hundreds of unauthorized trades, and that when those trades lost money, they moved funds from other accounts to make up the difference. The company and Mr. Wymer were also accused of taking Treasury securities worth $65 million from an Iowa fund without paying for them and using the proceeds for other clients' accounts.
In addition to the S.E.C., officials at the United States Attorney's offices in Iowa and Los Angeles are investigating the case, as is the Iowa State Attorney General's office. Investments also came from California, Colorado, Florida, Illinois, Minnesota, Nevada, New Mexico, Oklahoma, Texas, Utah, Virginia and Wyoming.
Michael Perlis, a lawyer representing Mr. Wymer, said his client would consent to a standard agreement with the S.E.C. of an injunction barring him from the industry. "It would leave open issues such as penalties," he said.
Regardless of the outcome of the case, it is expected to have a profound impact on the nation's 17,000 registered investment advisers, many of whom are financial planners. Mr. Breeden said today that the investment advisers could expect tighter supervision and higher examination fees.
They now pay the S.E.C. a one-time fee of $150 to be registered. Mr. Breeden said he would ask Congress to adopt a new law that would assess annual fees related to the size of the funds they had under management.
He said that he had not decided how much to seek, but that the commission intended to raise "millions of dollars."
"It would provide the resources for more meaningful and frequent oversight," he said.
Mutual funds and stockbrokers and dealers now pay annual fees that provide the money needed to cover the costs of examining them. The funds pay fees based on their sales, while the brokers and dealers pay an amount fixed by a formula applied to the value of their trades.
Mr. Breeden also said existing rules permitted virtually anyone who had not been convicted of a Federal crime involving financial wrongdoing to obtain a license from the S.E.C. to be an investment adviser.
"Murder for money would probably bar a person," said Marianne K. Smythe, director of the S.E.C.'s investment management division. "Murder for love probably would not." Indeed, Ms. Smythe said that a few years ago a felon actually applied from prison for a license to be an investment adviser and dropped the application only after the agency tied it up in red tape.
"We felt it might not be appropriate," she said. "But nothing in the law technically precluded him from getting a license."

HEADLINE: SOVIET DASARRAY;
Hurdles, Big and Small, for Baker's Trip

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
As Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d prepares to set off for Moscow, Administration officials acknowledge that even their modest plans for helping to prevent disorder in the crumbling Soviet Union face formidable obstacles -- not the least of which could be finding fuel to power Mr. Baker's plane on his tour of Soviet republics.
Mr. Baker leaves on Saturday for Russia, Ukraine, Kirghizia, Byelorussia and Kazakhstan. The State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said that despite reports of airport closings throughout the Soviet Union because of fuel shortages, the five republics that Mr. Baker will visit have all assured him that they will have jet fuel on hand for his Air Force 707, as well as gasoline for his motorcade. If that does not turn out to be the case, Miss Tutwiler said, the State Department has contingency plans. 
 Speaking to reporters at a White House briefing, Mr. Baker said the Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin, had spoken earlier by telephone with President Bush for 25 minutes. Mr. Yeltsin told Mr. Bush about how other republics were joining the new commonwealth. Mr. Bush later telephoned President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to get his assessment of the situation. They spoke for half an hour.
 
Keeping Neutral Policy
 Despite the gathering momentum for the new commonwealth, Mr. Baker stressed again that "we cannot and we must not inject ourselves into this purely political process" -- meaning that the United States will not recognize this new commonwealth, or drop its support for the rump central Government of Mr. Gorbachev, until there is a decisive conclusion to the power struggle there.
Officials say Mr. Baker will be approaching the Soviets on the nuclear question with plans for best- and worst-case scenarios. The best-case scenario is that the republics, the army command and whatever new commonwealth emerges will be able to maintain a unified, single command for nuclear weapons and supervise the destruction of whatever nuclear missiles are in republics, which say they eventually want to be nuclear free.
Administration officials say that at the moment, the degree of coordination between the commonwealth republics and the army on the nuclear issue is much higher than appears in public, and that explains why Mr. Baker and Mr. Bush for the moment say they are not alarmed.
"What we have been hearing from the republics is 'Just tell us what to do, and we'll do it,' " a senior Administration official said.
 
Offering Technical Aid
 Mr. Baker said in his speech on Thursday that the Administration would offer the Soviets $400 million appropriated by Congress to help them destroy their 27,000 nuclear weapons. Assuming that the army and republics can work together in a reasonably efficient manner on this effort, much of what Mr. Baker will be offering is technical expertise to help transfer missiles to central depots and tag and destroy weapons, as well as advice to each republic on its legal obligations under the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and conventional arms reduction treaty.
American officials say most of the republic leaders have no idea what their treaty obligations are for missiles and manpower on their soil, because all of this was handled by the central authorities.
The worst-case scenario is that the Soviet army will now disintegrate in tandem with the central Government. And if that happens, it is not at all clear that the various republic leaders in Ukraine, Byelorussia and Kazakhstan, who say they want to be nuclear-free zones one day, will have full control over the nuclear weapons on their soil or coastlines.
Soviet nuclear weapons are distributed among different subgroups in the Soviet military. The navy controls sea-based forces; the Strategic Rocket Force controls intercontinental ballistic missiles, and mobile, short-range missiles, nuclear land-mines and nuclear artillery are distributed among operational commands. How these subgroups, once under a central army command, will now relate to the respective republic leaders is simply still not clear.
 
Four-Step Process
 In such a situation, Washington would most likely try to carry out a plan that tracks closely with a proposal made to the Administration two weeks ago by Ash Carter and other members of the Center for Science and International Affairs at Harvard University.
It would work in four stages. First, with American help, the various republics would inventory and tag the nuclear weapons on their soil to keep track of what is there. Second, the weapons would all be pulled together in a central storage depot, so they would be out of the hands of individual units and commanders, who, if hungry or desperate enough might want to use them for blackmail. Third, a program would have to be carried out to neutralize the warheads, a relatively easy process, since they are so electronically sophisticated that the smallest change can render them useless.
Finally, the fissionable material in each of the warheads, material that remains usable for thousands of years, has to be removed and stored in a secure area that would be regularly monitored by the International Atomic Energy Agency. What may turn out to be an even bigger problem, though, American officials say, is how to keep unemployed Soviet nuclear scientists and engineers from selling their expertise abroad.
 
Obstacle to Food Aid
 Regarding humanitarian aid, the biggest problem facing American officials is setting up a monitoring system to insure that food gets to its intended destinations and that not too much is siphoned off by local mafias or ends up in the the Russian republic, where it can be used to dominate other republics.
On economic aid, Mr. Baker's main problem is that no one in the West really knows where bottom is yet in terms of devolution of the former Soviet Union. Will it stop at the republic level or will some republics now start to fragment? Much of Mr. Baker's discussion with republic leaders in this area will be to assess how to get Western experts, who have operated farms and businesses, into each republic, where they can begin to help change business practices and mindsets and improve the distribution system.

HEADLINE: Vehicle Sales Off Again, Falling 10.6%

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT, Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
DETROIT, Dec. 13 --
Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks declined 10.6 percent in early December, the auto makers reported today. Analysts said the drop suggested that retail demand for vehicles remained weak at best.
"There is certainly no evidence of any improvement here," said Harvey Heinbach, automotive analyst at Merrill Lynch in New York. He said the figures, while low, followed a pattern in recent months in which the first 10-day sales period of the month was significantly lower than the following two periods. He attributed the discrepancy to certain estimates used to calculate sales rates. Therefore, "there may not be a new round of further deterioration," he said. 
 Tom Webb, chief economist of the National Automobile Dealers Association, said he was disappointed by the seasonally adjusted annual selling rate -- 5.4 million, compared with 6.5 million a year earlier. But he added that he did not think the number pointed to a further weakening. Indeed, the selling rate over the last 30 days was 5.9 million, down only slightly from the October rate of 6 million and the November rate of 6.1 million.
 Several dealers said sales remained slow, and they said negative reports about the economy had resulted in low consumer confidence. "There's a lot of talk of layoffs here," said Dayton Andrews, owner of a Chrysler-Plymouth dealership in Clearwater, Fla.
For the year, Mr. Andrews's sales are 20 percent below the 1990 level, but in early December they were off 40 percent from the equivalent period of last year.
Other dealers said they sensed that many drivers were planning to wait until spring to buy new cars. "With the economy the way it is, people are just trying to patch up the cars the best they can to get through the winter," said George LePage, sales manager of Houser Mitsubishi in Springfield, Mass.
 
 
Car Sales Drop 14.5%
 For the Dec. 1-11 period, which had eight selling days both this year and last, the domestic manufacturers sold 117,190 cars, a decrease of 14.5 percent. Sales of light trucks dropped 4.2 percent, to 80,428 pickups, mini-vans and sport-utility vehicles. All vehicles built in the United States, Canada and Mexico are considered domestically built.
The General Motors Corporation sold 61,821 cars in early December, a decline of 5.7 percent from a year earlier. Two G.M. divisions posted gains in car sales in the period: Buick, on the strength of its redesigned LeSabre, and Cadillac, because of the strength of its DeVille and new Seville. G.M. sold 31,215 light trucks in the period, a decline of 7.7 percent.
The Ford Motor Company posted a 32.9 percent drop in car sales, to 27,676. A company spokesman attributed the sharp decline to a particularly strong period last year, just before Ford discontinued rebates. Ford's light-truck sales declined 14.3 percent, to 28,998.
The Chrysler Corporation's car sales dropped 30.3 percent, to 12,500, based on estimates by Ward's Automotive Reports. Chrysler does not report 10-day sales figures. Ward's estimated that Chrysler's light-truck sales, including mini-vans and Jeeps, rose 24.4 percent, to 17,800.
The Honda Motor Company sold 6,665 domestically produced cars in early December, a gain of 74.4 percent over the period a year earlier. But Honda executives said last year's figures were particularly soft because a special incentive expired at the end of November. The Toyota Motor Corporation sold 4,858 cars built in North America in the period, an increase of 5 percent.

HEADLINE: Mexico's Chief and Bush to Talk Trade

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 13

 BODY:
When President Carlos Salinas de Gortari arrives in Maryland on Saturday to meet with President Bush at Camp David, he may well have Pennsylvania on his mind.
It was about the time of Harris Wofford's victory in the United States Senate election there last month that Mr. Salinas's overarching goal -- a North American Free Trade Agreement -- became an uncertainty for next year. 
 In his campaign, Mr. Wofford criticized the trade negotiation as evidence that Mr. Bush cared more about foreign relations than American jobs. And in the weeks since, the optimism of Mexican officials has been almost visibly chipped away as American politicians and political analysts have suggested that Mr. Bush might or should delay the accord to keep it from becoming an issue in the 1992 presidential campaign.
Despite the Bush Administration's continuing assurances that politics will not dictate the schedule for a trade agreement, Mexican officials have taken a series of steps to prepare for the eventuality that a trade pact will not be concluded next year.
 
Draft Texts Exchanged
 And Mexican officials said that while Mr. Salinas would go to Camp David principally to seek Mr. Bush's thoughts on the timing of a treaty, he did not expect a final answer.
"Given how the negotiations have progressed, we could have a treaty next year," a senior aide to Mr. Salinas said. "But we will only be able to see in the beginning of the year whether the Free Trade Agreement becomes an issue in the campaign."
In interviews, United States, Mexican and Canadian officials said the negotiations to dismantle trade barriers could be wrapped up by late spring. By this week, the three sides will have exchanged at least some draft texts in nearly all of the 18 working groups that have been negotiating behind closed doors for the last six months.
Draft language has still not been presented on some of the most difficult and complex subjects, including the terms of a regional automotive trade and the elimination of tariff barriers in agriculture. But such issues might end up seeming rather straightforward by comparison to the political process that a final text might have to survive.
 
Fast-Track Proceedures
 With Mr. Salinas's power at a peak and public support for free trade considered widespread, Mexico's approval of a treaty is a given. In Canada, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney has sought to avoid a full-scale public debate on the extension of the United States-Canada free trade umbrella to include Mexico. Some analysts have said that he should be able to keep the talks from becoming a difficult political issue as long as a treaty is concluded before he has to call elections in 1993. But that would depend on Mr. Bush.
Under the so-called fast-track procedures which allow Mr. Bush to submit a treaty to Congress for a yes-or-no vote, the Administration would probably have to conclude a treaty by February to insure its movement through Congress before the political conventions, American officials said.
If the Congressional opposition to a final treaty proved limited, the legislative calendar could be shortened. And despite opposition to a trade pact by organized labor, some environmentalists and some Congressional Democrats, it remains far from clear that a treaty debate would necessarily hurt Mr. Bush's chances for re-election. Some political analysts have argued that Mr. Wofford's stance on trade was not an important reason for his victory.
Nonetheless, Mexican officials said that even a strong public commitment by Mr. Bush to move the negotiations forward quickly would be no guarantee that he would send a treaty to Congress next year. At least as important, they said, would be the performance of the American economy in the first months of the year and the outcome of early Presidential primaries.
 
Delaying a Pact
 Mr. Salinas, a foreign diplomat said, "will probably get a public commitment and then come back and declare victory and the rumors will start all over again."
Economists and Mexican officials consider a free-trade agreement a necessity for the success of Mr. Salinas's economic strategy. But they say that the foreign investment that will reach $14 billion this year could continue flowing into Mexico even if an agreement is delayed -- as long as the United States convinces investors that it has simply been delayed.
Mexico's annual budget, announced last month, set a target of single-digit inflation, a goal that none of Latin America's big debtor nations has been able to sustain recently. Public spending will rise only slightly, despite a reduction in Mexico's debt service. The Goverment also hopes to slow the growth of its current-account deficit. But economists say that will largely depend on how short-term investors in Mexican stocks perceive the future of free trade.

HEADLINE: Warming Up for the Primary Primary

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Dec. 13

 BODY:
New Hampshire is the grim winnower of Presidential politics, its first-in-the-nation primary making some candidates and breaking others, slapping down Presidents and creating instant stars.
On Feb. 18, 1992, New Hampshire voters will have the chance to exercise that power with a vengeance on a fresh and vulnerable Democratic field, and on a nervous President faced with a "send 'em a message" challenger. 
 For President Bush, the primary will be the first test against the conservative commentator Patrick J. Buchanan. And it comes in a state where Mr. Bush could hardly be more vulnerable on the economy, where the unemployment rate has risen from 2.3 percent in October 1988 to 6.6 percent last October, and where bankruptcies have soared. As a result, Republicans here are warning the White House that Mr. Buchanan must be taken seriously.
"The President is going to have to do some vigorous campaigning up here, and I have told him this," said the state's Senator, Warren B. Rudman, who was at a hastily scheduled opening of the Bush campaign headquarters here Thursday night.
And with the Iowa caucuses discounted this campaign season by the presence of Senator Tom Harkin, a favorite son, New Hampshire becomes the first test of a Democratic field that is still largely unknown and so strapped financially that a poor showing here could be lethal for several of these candidates, party strategists say. And if Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York enters the race next week, this state's voters will have the opportunity either to affirm his front-runner's reputation, or to leave him a victim of the expectations game.
Analysts in both parties agree that the economy will drive this primary in unpredictable ways. Raymond Buckley, a Democratic State Representative who knocked on 3,000 doors this year in his successful campaign for alderman in Manchester, said: "If there's one word to describe people, it's 'fear.' People are scared to death. They're afraid they can't pay their property taxes. They're afraid they'll lose their homes. They're afraid they'll lose their jobs. This is not the New Hampshire I was born and brought up in."
Gov. Judd Gregg, who is heading Mr. Bush's campaign in the state, said: "People are frustrated, upset. I call it the X-factor." The danger, he said, is that voters may see the Republican primary as a chance to send a message to Mr. Bush, even though they plan to vote for him the following November.
 
The Tsongas Factor
 There are many X-factors in the Democratic primary. As Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska put it, "It's still a jump ball."
A poll last week in The Boston Globe showed that former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts was ahead of the pack in New Hampshire. But some Democrats say that is largely a reflection of name recognition stemming from his residence in an adjoining state and his six-month jump in organizing. "The field is clouded right now, and Tsongas to a certain extent is the only one with definition," said Mitchell Schwartz, the New Hampshire director for Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas.
Still, Mr. Tsongas has become something of a wild card for the other campaigns, with no one quite sure how solid voters' support is for a candidate widely considered to be one of the longer shots in the race.
In general, the Democratic race is unformed: the Globe poll, which had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 5 percentage points, found that half of the likely Democratic primary voters were uncommitted and that many others seemed open to changing their minds.
In terms of organizing, Senator Harkin got an earlier start than most of his rivals, but Mr. Kerrey and Mr. Clinton have moved quickly this fall, Democrats say. Mr. Kerrey, while still trying to hone his message and performance on the campaign trail, has picked up much of the political network that had formed around former Senator Gary Hart in 1984, a group that is still considered formidable.
The other declared Democratic Presidential contenders are Edmund G. Brown Jr., the former Governor of California, and L. Douglas Wilder, the Governor of Virginia.
 
Rumors on Cuomo
 The undeclared is Mr. Cuomo, who is finally approaching a deadline: the Dec. 20 filing cutoff for the New Hampshire primary. His advisers have been calling political organizers here for logistical advice, and each day brings a fresh -- and to some Democrats, wearisome -- round of rumors.
Some Democrats here say that Mr. Cuomo has missed a valuable month, that if he had entered the race in November he could have wrapped up an enormous amount of support and stopped some of his rivals in their tracks. Still, Mr. Cuomo's admirers here say his message will resonate in this ailing state. And Joseph Grandmaison, the former state Democratic chairman here, said Mr. Cuomo has one very large advantage over his rivals.
"The biggest difference between the Cuomo candidacy and any of the others is these other people have had the terrible burden of introducing themselves and their candidacy," Mr. Grandmaison said.
The declared Democratic contenders, meanwhile, are plugging away with the kind of politics this state expects. At a high school in Milford this week, Mr. Kerrey took question after question from an earnest collection of students, including one young woman who demanded, "Do you have any plans to reduce the blatant patriarchy of the U.S. Government?"
 
Cheers for Buchanan
 On the Republican side, Mr. Buchanan followed the formal announcement of his candidacy this week with a high-profile campaign swing in the state, cheered on just about every day by The Union Leader, the influential Manchester newspaper. The Union Leader's publisher, Nackey Loeb, noted two announcements this week of major new Federal benefits for the state and suggested that Mr. Buchanan's candidacy was already paying off for New Hampshire.
"Call it coincidence, if you will, but Washington is suddenly bestowing financial benefits on our beleaguered state," she wrote.
Meanwhile, the Bush campaign came to town this week to open a campaign headquarters in downtown Manchester. Robert M. Teeter, Mr. Bush's chief political strategist, declared that "we are committed to a very aggressive, well-organized campaign" in the state.
At a news conference with Governor Gregg, Mr. Teeter was asked if Mr. Bush's economic proposals would include more Federal spending for New Hampshire. The Governor interjected, "I certainly hope so."

HEADLINE: Newspaper Outlook Still Dim

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
Declines in newspaper advertising linage appear to be slowing, but no upturn is yet in sight, a group of newspaper company executives said yesterday.
Executives of The New York Times Company, the Chicago-based Tribune Company and the Washington Post Company who spoke yesterday echoed the presentations that others had made at a weeklong conference sponsored by the brokerage firm Paine Webber: 1991 will prove to be a poor year for revenues and earnings, and the outlook for next year is largely dependent on an economic recovery. 
 Walter E. Mattson, president and chief operating officer of the Times Company, said he expected that the company would be able to open its new printing plant in Edison, N.J., with reduced staffing because other unions would follow the example set Wednesday by the drivers' union and reach agreements with the company.
"The plate makers, paper handlers, machinists and electricians are likely to come behind the drivers," Mr. Mattson said.
Mr. Mattson said he expected that the pressmen would settle as well, and that the agreement would lead to reductions in staff levels at the company's plant in Manhattan.
 
Outlook for Ads
 David L. Gorham, chief financial officer of the Times Company, said the outlook for advertising next year in The New York Times newspaper was for an 8 percent decline from 1991. He said company executives expected "flattening out in 1993 before turning up modestly in 1994."
He said the regional newspapers were expecting "a further slight drop" in advertising volume next year, followed by slow growth in 1993. Mr. Gorham said regional advertising was not expected to reach 1991 levels until 1994.
Executives of the company's magazine group said initial indications of 1992 advertising appeared stronger, but cautioned that the indications might not turn into actual pages if the economy remained weak.
Charles T. Brumback, president of the Tribune Company, termed 1991 disappointing because of an "unexpectedly long economic slump." He said the company's earnings would be under $2 a share, compared with the peak of $3 a share in 1989.
He said the collapse of the Maxwell publishing empire and the bankruptcy filing in New York by The Daily News, which is owned by Maxwell interests, were not likely to have an impact on the Tribune Company. The company sold the tabloid to Robert Maxwell after a bitter strike, but had taken charges to cover any contingencies.
He said next year's outlook was for "at best, sluggish economic growth" because of high unemployment and low consumer confidence.
 
Ad Decline Is Slowing
 John W. Madigan, head of the company's newspaper operations, said the rate of decline in advertising linage had slowed in the fourth quarter. He said the company was estimating that newspaper revenues would grow 6 percent next year, at least partly because of new ventures.
Donald E. Graham, president of the Washington Post Company, said, "This has been a terrible year, at least from the financial point of view." He said earnings for 1991 would come in "well behind" 1990, when the company earned $14.45 a share. He said the 1991 earnings would include a one-time charge of $4.50 a share to account for the cost of health care for retired employees.
Mr. Graham said the outlook for 1992 would be soft unless there was some significant upturn in the economy. He said the company's newsprint operations would continue to be a drain as excess capacity and depressed demand held down prices.
Advertising at The Washington Post is still declining, particularly in the real estate, display and help-wanted categories, Mr. Graham reported. "We are not looking for any major improvements at The Post until the economy begins to pick up -- and that may be a while," he said.
Revenue at the company's broadcast stations fell 10 percent in the first three quarters, Alan G. Spoon, an executive vice president, said. He noted that Newsweek magazine, which the company owns, would be the first major magazine to use selective binding, a technology that produces customized editions, as a way to raise circulation revenue.
Subscribers will be offered special added sections on foreign affairs, financial advice, technology and books at a cost of $5 a year for each section. With advertising in decline, magazines have been seeking to use new printing technologies to improve circulation revenues.

HEADLINE: Hard Day for a Willing Shopper

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
While merchants are busy blaming the economy for their woes, Stanley Marcus points his accusing finger at them.
During a recent stroll through some of New York City's finest stores, Mr. Marcus -- who as chairman of Neiman Marcus turned extravagance into necessity -- uncovered thin inventories, listless salespeople and a numbing lack of innovation, glitz or pizazz. 
 "If there is a plot to go out and kill Santy Claus, retailers have succeeded in putting together the right poisons," said Mr. Marcus, a bearded gentleman who looks a little like Santa Claus himself.
Most shoppers, like him, already have all the obvious necessities, Mr. Marcus said, and will buy anything else only if it is presented to them. "I already own more than any human being needs," he said. "Other than things like toothpaste, I don't buy anything that isn't sold to me."
 
Products, but No Pitch
 And as he traipsed around Manhattan's elegant midtown shopping district, hardly anyone tried to sell him anything.
At Neiman Marcus, Mr. Marcus, the retailer's 86-year-old chairman emeritus and the son of a founder, discovered that the right sales approach could even persuade customers to buy his-and-hers mummy cases. Since he retired from an active role in Neiman Marcus he has developed a consulting business.
The holiday sales season is when retailers make as much as 50 percent of their sales and an even greater share of their profits. On a visit to New York from Dallas, his hometown, Mr. Marcus found merchandise stocks too narrow, with the same goods for sale in store after store. The volume of advertising and promotions was too high, he asserted, and the level of service was too low.
Mr. Marcus's targets were not the cash-and-carry, beat-any-advertised-price sort of places. His perambulations along Fifth, Madison and Park Avenues and the side streets that link them took him to several of the city's most fabled retailers, questing after the perfect cashmere cardigan for his wife.
He left the Chanel boutique on East 57th Street after he had stood in the shop for several minutes and failed to attract the attention of anyone working there. A saleswoman in Galeries Lafayette across the street told him she didn't think the store had any classic cashmere cardigans and failed to suggest an alternative. And at Bergdorf Goodman, a saleswoman told Mr. Marcus that there were no cashmere cardigans in her department, neglecting to mention the table stacked with sweaters just around the corner.
Eventually, Mr. Marcus wandered into A. Sulka & Company, the tony men's haberdashery on Park Avenue. He recounted that a salesman came over and asked if Mr. Marcus needed help.
Well, yes, Mr. Marcus related, asking if they carried any women's clothing.
"No," the salesman was said to reply, "but what are you looking for?"
"A cashmere cardigan for my wife," Mr. Marcus told him.
"You know," Mr. Marcus recalled the salesman as saying, "many women buy our cardigans because they're roomier, and the only difference is they button from right to left instead of left to right. Let me show you a few."
As Mr. Marcus said later, "That man made a sale."
Mr. Marcus said that his experience in New York recalls his experiment in 1988, when he decided to make major purchases only if he found salespeople to attend him satisfactorily. A car salesman failed to suggest that he take a test drive, a clerk in a luggage store was too engrossed in a telephone call to help him and a jeweler was unable to give him a good reason to buy a watch. He estimated his savings at $48,732.
Improving service enough for customers to notice is no snap, Mr. Marcus said. At Neiman Marcus, he prodded salespeople to keep records of customers' preferences and sizes, their birthdays and their anniversaries -- services that many other stores have adopted.
"Everybody talks about store service these days like it's something you can run out and buy and rub it on your elbow and suddenly, you've got service," he said. "When I tell them it takes at least three years and lots of money to get a good service program established, they look at me like I'm crazy."
 
 
Rewards for Good Service
 Service is not simply a matter of providing a variety of payment options or staging frequent sales, Mr. Marcus explained. Good service, he said, must be inculcated by top executives who continually educate, re-educate and reward even the lowliest sales clerk for imagination and flair.
"Customers can come up with more problems than the bright people who wrote your operating procedures can foresee," Mr. Marcus said. "You have to empower your sales staff to use their judgment and go beyond the standards set down on paper and by the computer."
While the computer is a powerful tool for supervising a retail business, Mr. Marcus said, merchants are relying too much on computer tapes and too little on their eyes to tell them what to stock. He said retailers had reacted to the sins of two Christmases past, when an overabundance of goods forced sweeping markdowns, by ordering too few goods for this Christmas.
 
 
'Picked Over Already'
 By maintaining such lean inventories, stores will sell out of hot items and miss the opportunity to keep selling them later in the season. In the meantime, less popular items will have to be marked down anyway.
"The stocks I've seen are lousy, picked over already," he said disapprovingly. "The stores have got a bunch of odds and ends from early in the season, so they're handicapped in the final days of the season when they could make the most sales."
Mr. Marcus attributed the unsold holiday inventories of past years to sameness, not slack overall demand. Stores that once distinguished themselves by the exclusive merchandise they carried now stock the same goods as their competitors.
"Seeing so much of the same thing suppresses the desire to buy," he said. "You can only own one red Liz Claiborne blazer."
Mr. Marcus contends that this sameness among retailers is a result of overproduction by a few major manufacturers of clothing and other goods. Too many of the same goods are chasing too few dollars, which in turn leads to promotions.
 
 
Continuous Price Cutting
 This abundance of goods has forced retailers to slash prices continuously rather than periodically, a practice that has made consumers suspicious of original prices, Mr. Marcus said. The result is a worrisome erosion of profit margins and a reluctance among consumers to make purchases at any price.
"People aren't buying because they feel they're going to be suckered when the retailer knocks the price down on a coat three days after they bought it," Mr. Marcus said. "How do you fix that perception?"
At this, even Mr. Marcus paused, then admitted, "Well, I'm afraid that's a problem I don't have an answer to."

HEADLINE: U.N. Urges Nations to Begin Restoring Ties to South Africa

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 13

 BODY:
The General Assembly called unanimously today on all nations to start restoring sports, cultural, scientific and academic ties with South Africa in recognition of the progress it has made toward abolishing apartheid.
The Assembly also said that nations should prepare to phase out remaining economic and other sanctions against South Africa as the country moves toward a democratic non-racial system. 
 The Assembly vote comes a week before the opening of a major political conference in South Africa, that will bring together the white-minority Government, the African National Congress and other political parties in an attempt to lay the groundwork for majority rule.
South Africa's Foreign Minister, Roelof F. Botha, welcomed the vote today, saying it showed that "sanctions are crumbling" despite the General Assembly's continued "short-sightedness on financial and trade sanctions." It is essential, he continued, that the Assembly "support economic growth rather than inhibiting it."
 
Heeding Mandela's Suggestions
 Nonetheless, he said that the Assembly, in the South African resolutions it adopted this year, had recognized several important new political steps taken by his Government.
These, he said, included the signing in September of the National Peace Accord, which is intended to end ethnic violence in the country; South Africa's accession to the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, and its agreement with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to allowing political exiles to return to South Africa.
The resolution on relaxing sanctions roughly followed suggestions made in a General Assembly speech earlier this month by Nelson A. Mandela, leader of the African National Congress. Mr. Mandela said "people-to-people sanctions" were already being phased out, as the Commonwealth countries had agreed at a meeting of heads of state and government in October.
South Africa was admitted to the International Olympic Committee last summer, and the Association of Tennis Professionals doubles championships were held in South Africa in November.
But Mr. Mandela said remaining economic sanctions should be lifted only when the Government agrees to hand over power to an interim administration and convene an assembly to draft a new constitution. He said oil and arms embargoes should remain in force until a new democratically elected government has taken power.
In fact, The United States, the European Community and Japan have already lifted most significant restrictions on trade with South Africa.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
ASSEMBLY SPEAKER GUILTY OF FRAUD 
 The Speaker of the State Assembly, Mel Miller, was convicted of Federal fraud charges in Brooklyn, shattering his career as one of the most powerful politicians in New York. The verdict, convicting Mr. Miller of 8 of the 19 felony charges against him, means that he is automatically expelled from the Assembly and could be imprisoned and disbarred. The conviction threw the state's already chaotic budget negotiations into deeper disarray and raised serious new questions about whether Governor Cuomo will be able to run for President. Pages 1 and 27.
 
ALL ROADS LEAD TO . . .
Rush-hour crowding may be common in the city's subways, but nothing quite matches the crush at Roosevelt Avenue, the busiest station on the busiest line. About 3.5 million people ride the subway daily, and some mornings it feels as if they all pass through Jackson Heights. Crowding is so severe that, when the E and F trains stop running because of mechanical problems or other difficulties, the conductors sometimes have to close off stairs to the platform. Otherwise, the area could get so overcrowded that passengers might fall to the tracks. Page 1.
 
QUEENS DEVELOPMENT STALLED
A long-stalled effort to build a "new town" on a vast ocean-front site in Queens has been stalled again because the poor economy has forced the developer to withdraw. Now city officials say they will try to develop the area, called Arverne, as discrete smaller projects with separate developers. Page 29.
 
NOW YOU HAVE IT . . .
It was a lot of money, but it wasn't theirs for long. Four men robbed an armored car delivering money to a bank of $800,000 but left the money in a getaway car when they crashed while being chased, the police said. Page 26.
 
REGION
 
TWO VIEWS OF A MAYOR
As his fraud trial closed, Mayor Gerald McCann of Jersey City heard his lawyer call him a "visionary" and a "dreamer" who just wanted to be a successful developer. And he heard the prosecutor say he had no objections to Mr. McCann's dreams as long as he didn't pay for them with other people's money. Page 28.
 
CONVICTION IN TROOPER KILLING
Richard Williams, a former member of a violent revolutionary group, was convicted of killing Philip Lamonaco, a state trooper who was shot to death in Warren County 10 years ago. Page 28.
 
TELL IT TO CONGRESS
As a chill rain soaked the bare trees and a "House for Sale" sign outside, 11 people sat around a living room in middle-class Hamden, Conn., and told two members of Congress what the faltering economy had done to their once-satisfying lives. Page 28.
 
TAX REPEAL FAILS IN HARTFORD
Governor Weicker vetoed a plan to repeal Connecticut's new income tax only 30 minutes after it was approved by the House, asserting that the legislature had embarked on a path of "full-scale surrender to fiscal gimmicks and political fantasies." Although neither the veto nor a subsequent failure to override it came as any great surprise, the day's events nonetheless stand out as important landmarks in the 10 months of conflict and passion that have surrounded the tax debate. Page 1.

HEADLINE: Dow Up 19.23 to Close at 2,914.36

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON Jr.

 BODY:
Stocks closed higher yesterday, cementing a broad two-day rally that more than erased losses earlier in the week. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 2,914.36, up 19.23 points for the day and 27.96 for the week.
The Dow rose sharply at the opening and remained above 2,900 for the rest of the day. Advancing issues almost doubled losing ones, 1,090 to 563, and volume on the New York Stock Exchange was heavy at 201.5 million shares. 
 The market responded to gains overseas -- Japan's Nikkei stock index rose nearly 5 percent and European markets were also strong -- and to encouraging news about the November Consumer Price Index, said Robert Wallberg, an equity analyst at MMS International.
"It's also based on the fact that we were technically oversold," Mr. Wallberg added, referring to the Dow's bounce back from the 2,850 level, which is about as low as the average has gone this year.
"I think the test of 2,850 was meaningful," said Gene J. Seagle, director of technical research at Gruntal & Company. "This is more than just a temporary movement. I think this upside momentum will build as the market develops into a year-end rally."
Transportation stocks did well, Mr. Seagle noted, as did many blue-chip issues, as the broad gain affected most sectors of the market.
The Nasdaq composite index rose 4.88 points, to 540.90, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 2.92, to 384.47. The Russell 2,000-stock index was also up, rising 1.72, to 177.51, and the American Stock Exchange index rose 3.35, to 369.48. The New York Stock Exchange composite index went up 1.46, to 211.90.
Among gaining stocks, Employee Benefit Plan, a medical management and service corporation, rose 3 3/4, to 41.
Among losers, Wells Fargo dropped 5 1/2, to 55, after an announcement on Thursday that the bank would set aside $700 million for loan losses, reflecting the depressed real estate market in California. The drop followed Wells Fargo's rise of 3 1/4 immediately after the announcement.
"It's like I.B.M.," said Mr. Walberg, noting that optimistic descriptions of the computer giant's restructuring plans led to a rise in stock price on the day of the announcement. But the stock fell sharply in subsequent days, once the plan had been studied more thoroughly.
Wells Fargo also reported that it would cut its dividend in half to 50 cents a share, and analysts lowered long- and short-term ratings for the bank.
BankAmerica, one of Wells Fargo's competitors. rose 1 1/2 points, to 35.
Elsewhere in the market, Lincoln Financial went up 3, to 24, after the company reported that it had hired Goldman, Sachs to help it examine possible sale of the bank holding company and other options.
The bank reported a loss of $6 million in the first nine months of this year, and last week deferred a decision on giving a fourth-quarter dividend.
Atmel dropped 1 3/4, to 7, after fourth- quarter profits were reported to be modest because of continued softness in the computer industry and the slow economy.

HEADLINE: Zairian Prime Minister Is Certain U.S. Wants Change in His Nation

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
The Prime Minister of Zaire, Nguza Karl-i-Bond, ended a visit here today, saying he was convinced that the United States wants major political changes in the Central African nation that has been ruled for more than a quarter-century by President Mobutu Sese Seko.
Mr. Nguza, a major Zairian diplomat and political figure off and on over the last two decades, said President Mobutu is aware that he cannot expect to cling to power much longer without the support of outside forces. 
 "He knows he is now at the end," Mr. Nguza said. "He knows that all his friends in the West want him to step down."
In an interview, Mr. Nguza, who became Prime Minister in November, the third in three months, said that after months of political and economic chaos, the President fears only two things: "bullets and being brought to court."
The Prime Minister has had a long, troubled relationship with the President. He served in his Cabinet and as an Ambassador, but also became the object of the Zairian leader's wrath, and was for a time under death sentence. He was incarcerated in President Mobutu's prisons. He acknowledges that friends often say his career "has gone like a yo-yo."
Now, he says, the President knows him well.
"He knows I am not going to harm him," he said. "He knows I would allow him to go in dignity."
The President is widely known for his lavish style of living and for corruption in his Government. Mr. Nguza said the President is apprehensive about being forced into exile.
"He knows what happened to the Shah," the Prime Minister said. "He knows what happened to Marcos."
This week in Washington, Mr. Nguza asked the World Bank and International Monetary fund to send teams to run Zaire's central bank and tax system as a step toward reforming the economy. He said today that his request had been granted and that two Zairian officials would remain here to work out details.
 
A Warning About Violence
 Mr. Nguza, who came to the United States a decade ago as an exile to seek, and be denied, backing against President Mobutu, returned to Zaire in 1985 and gradually reconciled himself with the President, a man Washington regarded as an ally against the leftist Government in Angola.
Mr. Nguza served as Zaire's Ambassador in Washington from 1986 to 1988, and then Foreign Minister. He was Prime Minister briefly in 1980.
He said that if President Mobutu is forced from office violently, the country will face civil war because all those who benefited from the President's rule will fight to retain their wealth and privileges. Poorly paid soldiers who went on looting rampages in September would be certain to join in the fray, he predicted.
Mr. Nguza said that he hoped that Zaire could avoid the violent "Liberian model" of political change and instead follow the "Zambian model." In a multiparty election in October, Zambia's President, Kenneth D. Kaunda, accepted his loss at the polls and stepped down immediately, allowing a smooth transition of power to the winner, Frederick J. Chiluba.

HEADLINE: Bush Walks Tightrope: Soviet Aid, Risks at Home

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
The Bush Administration created its plan to aid the Soviet economy in about five days. The plan for American economic recovery will have taken about five months by the time the President offers his promised growth proposals late in January.
This contrast in timing defines the problem Mr. Bush faces as he tries to fulfill the international obligations that are central to his duties as President, while at the same time preparing for an election that could turn on domestic problems. 
 By outlining a policy for dealing with the upheaval in the former Soviet Union, Mr. Bush could satisfy the first set of expectations and solidify his credentials as the leader of the much-proclaimed new world order, even if the plan seems unlikely to make much of a dent in the problems facing the Soviets.
But in dealing with the Soviet crisis, Mr. Bush risks walking into the trap that has been so eagerly laid by the Democrats vying for their party's nomination and by challengers from his own party's right wing.
For months, these critics have complained that Mr. Bush devotes too much attention to other countries' problems and not enough to America's. Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative who entered the Republican nomination race on Tuesday, has been lampooning the new world order as a betrayal of what he calls "America First" principles that ought to prevail when American workers are losing jobs to foreign competition.
Republicans and Democrats, including Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader, have suggested that even if the President is effective overseas, he has done a poor job of explaining himself at home. This image was only reinforced when the new Soviet policy was presented by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d in a speech at Princeton University on Thursday, rather than by Mr. Bush himself in a nationally televised address.
 
Trying to Blunt Criticism
 Administration officials said Mr. Bush's initiative on the Soviet Union had been inspired solely by that country's political and economic crisis, one far deeper and more immediate than American economic problems. But Mr. Baker seemed to be trying to inoculate Mr. Bush against campaign-year criticism as he outlined the new policy.
By following the Administration's blueprint, he said, "We can prevail over the fearful isolationism that threatens to return us to the failures of the 1920's and 1930's. We can prevail over political paralysis to forge a bipartisan consensus about what has to be done and then, united at home, we can join with our allies to form a new coalition."
This fall, Mr. Bush has come under intense criticism, first for his unwillingness to consider economic growth measures and then for the deliberateness -- some say sluggishness -- with which he is developing such proposals.
Now, he has moved with startling speed on yet another foreign policy challenge. His aides are confident this will reinforce his image of a President who can be trusted with the nation's security. They argue that Mr. Bush has freedom to act in foreign affairs that is denied him in negotiating on domestic issues with a Democratic-controlled Congress and that whatever the political climate at home, his diplomatic portfolio is simply too important to be slighted.
 
Democrats' Bind
 Indeed, it has not been that long since Democrats were complaining that Mr. Bush was a passive spectator on the world stage, and the Administration's policy pronouncement left them in a double bind. It was unveiled as one of the Democratic Presidential contenders, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, was delivering a speech saying that Mr. Bush had not taken the lead on the Soviet crisis and suggesting actions that did not greatly diverge from Mr. Bush's plan.
But other opponents on the right and the left quickly moved to further their assault on what they view as Mr. Bush's weakest electoral flank.
"The fact of the matter is that he has come up with an economic plan for the Soviet Union more than a month before we can even expect an economic plan for the United States," said Lorraine Voles, spokeswoman for Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, who is running for the Democratic nomination. "It's once again a sign of the President just ignoring the domestic dilemmas that this country is facing."
Even those Democrats who have been pressing Mr. Bush to do more, not less, to aid the Soviet Union tried to chip away at Mr. Bush's grip on the foreign policy debate and to reinforce what even White House aides concede has been the President's difficulty in explaining himself to voters.
 
Letter From Gephardt
 Mr. Gephardt said in a letter to Mr. Bush on Thursday that his "modest measures are steps in the right direction but, given the enormity of the crisis, more explanations are needed and more actions may be necessary."
Mr. Gephardt urged Mr. Bush to address the nation about his Soviet policy, and his office pointed out to reporters that some key elements of Mr. Bush's plan, including the idea of assembling industrialized nations to coordinate aid, were proposed by Mr. Gephardt nearly two years ago.
Bush aides argued that it is in the direct economic interest of the United States to insure stability in the old Soviet Union.
 
Bush Campaign's View
 Charles Black, Mr. Bush's campaign chairman, said: "Throughout the campaign, we're going to have to repeat a message consistently that there is a threshold requirement for any President to manage national security and foreign relations. From an economic standpoint, there are more markets in a peaceful world than in a dangerous one and as the one superpower still standing, we have the clout to go out and expand markets."
Mr. Black acknowledged that these arguments are difficult to win in an election year, especially with rightists like Mr. Buchanan and liberals like Senator Harkin making emotional appeals to American self-interest.
But Mr. Bush may have no choice but to stick to foreign policy. His aides have yet to agree on any fix for the nation's economic problems, and it will take months to get any results. Beyond that, the Administration fundamentally believes the Government can and should be much more active in foreign affairs than on economic and social issues.
There are also tactical considerations.
"If you don't have any good economic news, you can't just sit there and do nothing," said Lance Torrance, a Republican political strategist. "You've got to show motion and that motion at the current time has to be on foreign affairs. You can be really hurt in politics, potentially fatally, not as the Democrats are saying by being imbalanced on the domestic versus foreign policy side, but by doing nothing."
