HEADLINE: California's Credit Lowered in Face of Deficit

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 13

 BODY:
Citing California's multibillion-dollar budget deficit, Standard & Poor's, one of the nation's top debt rating agencies, today lowered the state's credit rating from the highest rating of AAA.
In a sign of decreasing confidence in the state's ability to solve its fiscal problems, at least in the short term, the downgrading, to AA, means that the state will have to pay higher interest for the bonds that it sells to raise capital.
 
Long-Term Growth Expected
 The lowered rating comes at a time when California is facing an economic crisis that includes a projected $2.2 billion budget deficit, when some big companies are slashing jobs and others are moving out of state. 
 In response, Gov. Pete Wilson has proposed cutting welfare assistance to new residents, many of whom are undocumented immigrants, and has called on the Legislature to meet this month to seek urgent remedies.
The rating agency said, "While S.&P. expects that California's finances will eventually be balanced, it is not likely that the state will be able to improve its financial position to the point where it could avert future deficits resulting from economic downturns for at least several years." It added that it "expects long-term growth for the state, although likely at rates somewhat slower than in the last decade."
State Treasurer Kathleen Brown called the downgrading unwarranted and premature, citing the underlying strength of the state's economy. Saying California has fared better during the current nationwide recession than a number of other states including New York, Massachusetts, New Jersey and Maryland, she said, "Standard & Poor's decision is a little like the Grinch that stole Christmas."
New York State's Standard & Poor's rating has been A since 1989, when it was downgraded from AA minus.
Ms. Brown noted that California, which has historically had high credit ratings because of its ability to balance its budget and overcome its deficits, had in the past bounced back after temporary lowerings of its rating.
Ms. Brown said California expects to issue $11 billion in new bonds over the next two years and that the increased interest it would now be required to pay would probably cost it about $159 million. This would mean an increased cost to the state of about $8 million a year over the life of the bonds, she said.
Controller Gray Davis said, "There's no reason for panic." But he called for urgent measures to stop the flow of jobs and businesses from the state.
In taking today's action, the agency cited a report this week by the Commission on State Finance, a state auditing agency, that forecast a $2.2 billion deficit this fiscal year and a deficit next year of $1.3 billion to $3.1 billion.
"Serious discussions on deficit reduction have not yet occurred, and at this late date it is unlikely that actions can be taken to avert another deficit," it said in a news release. "The likely scenario will be a replay of last year's negotiations, which addressed budget gaps over two years. As a result, the state will be operating at a substantial deficit at least through fiscal 1993."
Under the law, the state is required to have a balanced budget.
Governor Wilson, a Republican, said earlier this week that the state was heading for a "fiscal train wreck." He said he would seek a constitutional amendment that would reduce welfare benefits to some poor families by nearly 25 percent and give him broad new powers to cut the budget. Of this year's $55.7 billion budget, $6 billion is being spent on aid to families with dependent children.
Mr. Wilson, calling for quick legislative action, also proposed spending cuts of nearly $1 billion that would affect renters, state employees and the poor.
Today's action downgraded the state's rating to AA, the level to which it had been lowered for two years in 1983 because of a severe budget deficit. California has had the agency's highest bond rating since 1986, when it was upgraded from AA plus.
New York State's debt rating of A reflects what the agency describes in its published analysis as "a contracting economic base, rising yet manageable debt burden and historically weak financial operations." The state's outlook is described as "negative."

HEADLINE: Hey, Nobody Pays Retail, Right?

BYLINE: By GEORGIA DULLEA

 BODY:
Turning a corner at Times Square, you come upon a line of 30 terrific-looking 25-year-olds outside a small loft building. It looks like the opening of a hot new club. But, no, it's better than that -- a sample sale of Italian sportswear. "Stuff I love," says a tall redhead, rolling her eyes, "and dirt cheap."
You're waiting for a light in the garment center now. Someone hands you a flier for a sample sale of beaded evening dresses. A minute later it's a flier for shearling coats, then lingerie, cashmere sweaters, leather jackets -- all being offered at, you are told, heartbreaking savings. 
 Some of the people passing out fliers hawk designer names like hot dogs: "Bill Blass here! Bill Blass!" A couple of them are moonlighting housewives. They get $8 an hour and possibly a break on the clothes. They're quite chic.
Coming up Seventh Avenue -- what's this? -- a parade of well-stuffed brown paper shopping bags. A bunch of the shopping bags peels off and disappears into an office building. You follow, not knowing you are about to enter a parallel shopping universe.
Inside the lobby is mobbed. "The sale's on the sixth floor -- Harve Benard," says Evelyn Becker, a real-estate agent. She is waiting by the elevators for her cousin to return from the cash machine. "They take credit cards, but we're both at our limit," Ms. Becker says, laughing. "We're sample-sale junkies. It's the sport of the 90's."
Now, as never before, New Yorkers are looking for deals on clothes. For the right price and the right label, some shoppers will ride freight elevators. They will strip down to their BVD's in drafty showrooms. They will carry wads of cash, endure long lines, call in sick with flu when what they really have is sample-sale fever.
"Look, it's a tight economy," said Marshall Goldberg, who owns a direct-mail equipment company and wears clothes by designers like Bill Robinson and Joseph Abboud. "For a bargain on high-quality merchandise, I'll shop on the subway."
 
Like Having an Uncle in the Business
 It may come to that. For the moment, Mr. Goldberg said, he and other men are perfecting the art of trying on clothes in showroom aisles in mixed company. After a year or so on the circuit he has come to suspect that "another guy running around in his underwear isn't outlandish -- not in New York."
Years ago you needed an uncle in the business to shop wholesale. Sample sales were small clubby arrangements to clear out showroom samples and other odd garments that manufacturers could not sell. Seventh Avenue has loosened up a lot since then.
With retail sales sagging, manufacturers and designers are selling off stock at wholesale prices or less to the public directly -- and supposedly discreetly -- though out-of-town tour groups have been trooping through some showrooms recently. There is talk that sample sales may one day replace Wednesday matinees.
"What's new is not just shopping for a bargain, but bragging about it," said Elysa Lazar of Lazar Media Group in Manhattan, which publishes The S & B Report, a monthly guide to unadvertised showroom sales. For $45 a year, the report alerts its 8,100 subscribers to the movement of merchandise from Armani to Valentino. For another $50, they can call in on Fridays for bulletins on late-breaking events like last week's Geoffrey Beene sale.
"It was very nicely done," a Beene customer said. "Two dressing rooms and a lady to zip you up."
This month more than 300 sales are in Ms. Lazar's report, twice the number two years ago. "As retail slips into what probably is its worse season ever, more and more companies are opening their showrooms," she said. "I don't know of one that's not selling the line to the public."
 
Shh! Don't Tell
 The sales are not widely advertised because the companies want to avoid appearing to be competing with retailers that carry their clothes. Word spreads through mass mailings, fliers, newsletters, special telephone lines and, of course, the office grapevine. This lends a hush-hush quality, like shopping in a speakeasy.
Shoppers like Bruce Kramer consider that part of the fun. "Then there's the adventure, the thrill of knowing you're getting unbelievably good-guy prices," said Mr. Kramer, a creative director at an advertising agency. "In New York nobody pays retail, right?"
For big productions, designers are hiring outside companies to stage the events in warehouses and other large spaces. A popular venue is the Parsons School of Design on Seventh Avenue at 40th Street, which some sample-sale buffs now consider their own outlet store. The operation has some of the amenities of retail shopping -- communal dressing area, coat-check room, speedy cashiers at the credit card and cash lines.
"We make these sales real events," said Richard Rosenthal, whose company, Samples Inc. of Pelham, N.Y., often manages group sales for several designers. "For them, it's a way to get close to their markup at wholesale without selling to discounters, to get rid of excess clothes -- either returns, excesses or overages."
Sample-sale managers worry, he said, "that if this thing gets too much attention we're going to have more problems with the stores and it will blow up in our faces."
Mr. Rosenthal added that his company ran the recent Emporio Armani sale in Norwalk, Conn. The decision to hold it there was a calculated one. "The sale had to be out of Manhattan," he said. "Armani was afraid of too much exposure."
Ah, the Armani sale. The Woodstock of shopping. Armani shoppers can tell you the clothes they bought, how much each garment cost -- and would have cost retail.
"You can see a class stratification on the lines to these sales," said Janet Fishman, a criminology professor at John Jay College of Criminal Justice. "A working girl might be at a Betsey Johnson sale. At the Escada sale you see women who might have walked out of Saks."
 
Like Macy's? Better.
 Dr. Fishman was standing in line outside the Parsons school last week for the Donna Karan sale when she saw something unusual. "A group of women standing in a circle around a leader. They were wearing fur jackets, designer sunglasses and the biggest smiles. It seemed almost as if they had come on a tour bus."
They had. The women -- 44 out-of-town visitors -- were on Sara Gardner's three-hour Wholesale Shopping Tour of the Garment Center. Ms. Gardner also publishes a guide to sample sales. It's called Fashion Update and is based in Brooklyn.
"When we start out on the bus," she said, "the ladies always say, 'Oh, Sara, take us to Macy's,' because they know the name. And I say, 'You can shop at Macy's by yourself. I'm going to take you to where Macy's shops."

HEADLINE: November Consumer Prices Up 0.4%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
Consumer prices climbed four-tenths of 1 percent in November, with what may prove temporary surges in food, clothing and energy not fully offset by lower inflation for housing and medical care, the Labor Department reported today.
The rise, which followed a one-tenth of 1 percent advance in October, was a bit more than expected, but analysts said the latest figures did not significantly undermine the conviction that inflation was under control, and with the economy weak, it was unlikely to flare up anytime soon. 
 "The outlook for inflation remains excellent," said William C. Dunkelberg, dean at the Temple University business school and a consultant to the National Federation of Independent Business. He cited a new membership survey showing that more companies cut prices over the last six months than increased them -- the first time this has happened since the survey began in 1973 -- and that companies' plans to raise prices in coming months were also at a record low.
Some analysts, however, struck a cautionary note, saying that while a weak economy produces little demand, it does not significantly expand supplies, a factor that could create bottlenecks and consequently price spikes.
Even though the Consumer Price Index for all urban consumers rose at a 3.6 percent annual rate in the latest three months, up from a 2.7 percent rate in the three months through August, analysts say the Federal Reserve is likely to move again shortly to cut interest rates in an effort to reinvigorate the economy.
Prices in the New York metropolitan area jumped six-tenths of 1 percent last month after edging down slightly in October. Of the other four major cities for which prices are published on a current basis, Los Angeles posted a four-tenths of 1 percent increase, but Chicago, Philadelphia and San Francisco showed no significant change.
A separate Government report today showed that business inventories rose four-tenths of 1 percent in October, the second straight increase, on soaring retailer inventories. Sales grew by three-tenths of 1 percent, however, and the inventory-sales ratio remained at 1.50, meaning it would take a month and a half to clear shelves at the current sales pace.
 
Consumer Sentiment Index
 In the first bit of data for December, the University of Michigan told subscribers that its preliminary reading of consumer sentiment rose slightly, to 70.4, from the 69.1 to which the index plunged in November.
Analysts said that little could be learned from the inventory figures, but that the consumer confidence figures at least seemed to contribute to a rise in the stock market; the Dow Jones industrial average gained 19.23 points today.
Food was one of the biggest factors driving up consumer prices, rising six-tenths of 1 percent after two months of negligible up and down. The price of fruits and vegetables spurted 4.4 percent, with lettuce and tomatoes soaring 44.5 and 12.7 percent, respectively, reflecting whitefly infestations in California. Beef and veal prices rose nine-tenths of 1 percent after five straight declines, but pork, poultry and eggs declined and oranges dropped 17.1 percent after a 14.4 percent drop in October.
Energy prices advanced eight-tenths of 1 percent, with gasoline, fuel oil and natural gas rising sharply, while electricity fell seven-tenths of 1 percent.
 
Core Rate Up 0.3%
 The so-called core rate of inflation, which excludes the often gyrating food and energy components, rose three-tenths of 1 percent in November, about the same pace as the average increase for the two preceding months.
In transportation, the price of new vehicles rose two-tenths of 1 percent -- the proportion of 1992 car models in the index is now just over 50 percent -- and airline fares rose 2.2 percent. But automobile finance charges fell 1.4 percent, their third straight decline.
Clothes prices advanced 1 percent, with women's and girls' clothes up nearly twice that much, the report showed. Seasonal adjustment factors contribute to big swings in apparel, which accounts for only 6 percent of the Consumer Price Index.
Inflation in medical care, which was five-tenths of 1 percent in November, has now eased one-tenth of a point in each of the last three months. Since November 1990 medical costs have risen 8 percent, with prescription drugs up 10.1 percent.
Among other goods and services, a 1.9 percent leap in tobacco prices accounted for nearly two-thirds of the month's increase of seven-tenths of 1 percent.
Viewing the Consumer Price Index market basket another way, goods rose six-tenths of 1 percent last month, twice as much as in October, while inflation in services remained at three-tenths of 1 percent.
A separate index covering urban wage earners and clerical workers, the C.P.I.-W, rose five-tenths of 1 percent last month after a one-tenth of 1 percent increase in October.
Despite the sanguine view taken in today's report, some analysts see little if any further improvement in inflation, which has run at a 3 percent rate over the last 12 months.

HEADLINE: Bond News is Good, but Prices Fall

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved lower yesterday despite a batch of reports that analysts called uniformly favorable for holders of fixed-income securities.
The reports included a four-tenths of a percent rise in the November Consumer Price Index; figures showing that business inventories rose for the second straight month during October, and numbers from the nation's auto makers that indicated the very sluggish sales pace that has been in place for the last several months did not suddenly change during the first 10 days of December. 
 The increase in consumer prices was slightly higher than most economists had expected, but even with the rise on a year-over-year basis consumer prices have risen a modest 3 percent. While the consumer price numbers appeared to reaffirm the sense that inflationary pressures have continued to moderate, analysts said the inventory numbers carried potentially disturbing news for the economy.
 
Inventory Buildup
 "The rise in inventories, particularly among retailers, tells you that stocks are building up at the point of final sales," said Joseph Liro, a senior vice president and economist at S. G. Warburg & Company. "Unless demand picks up to meet those increases, at some point soon production is going to have to be cut."
Rather than focus on the data, dealers instead chose to home in on a rise in commodity prices and on rumors that the Bush Administration was in the process of constructing a highly stimulative fiscal package for the economy. At the end of a week when prices moved generally higher, those developments offered an adequate excuse to lighten positions.
"We are getting closer to year-end, and at this time of the year people want to get closer to shore," one government bond trader said.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 10222/32 , down 5/32 , to yield 7.76 percent, compared with 7.75 percent late Thursday and 7.80 percent on Dec. 6.
 
Treasury Note Trading
 Among Treasury note issues, in late trading the 7.50 percent 10-year notes were offered at 102 1/8, down 1/8 point, to yield 7.19 percent.
Yesterday the Treasury announced it would sell $13.5 billion of new two-year notes and $9 billion of new five-year notes at auctions on Wednesday and Thursday. For many credit market participants, those debt sales will be the last significant events of 1991.
In when-issued trading following the announcement, the two-year notes were offered at a price to yield 5.07 percent. The new five-year notes were offered at a price to yield 6.27 percent.
Rates on short-term Treasury bills were narrowly mixed.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 4.13 percent late yesterday, down one basis point, or one one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 4.16 percent. And rates on one-year bills rose by two basis points, to a late offered rate of 4.20 percent.
Participants in the tax-exempt municipal bond market said that prices of outstanding general obligation bonds issued by the State of California were little changed after the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced it had downgraded its rating on approximately $15.1 billion of the state's debt to AA from AAA.
Although the timing of the move was something of a surprise, the conditions that prompted the change have been known for some time, traders said. Those conditions have been reflected in bond prices for some weeks. Standard & Poor's cited the state's chronic budget deficit as the principal reason for the downgrade.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Closes Mostly Higher And Gold Prices Are Mixed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar advanced against most other currencies yesterday, helped by concerns about the Soviet Union.
Gold prices closed mixed, rising in New York after falling overseas. 
 The dollar, which is seen as a haven amid political uncertainty overseas, generally rises when there is strife in major countries.
But it was unable to rise further because of expectations that the Federal Reserve, whose policy-making committee meets next week, will push interest rates down again to stimulate the economy.
The dollar tends to fall in tandem with interest rates because lower yields weaken foreign demand for American investments.
Traders said the Government's report on consumer prices yesterday gave the Fed more leeway to ease its monetary policy. The Labor Department said prices rose a moderate four-tenths of 1 percent in November.
The British pound gained against the dollar, rising to $1.8160 in New York from late Thursday's $1.8065. In earlier London trading, sterling rose to $1.8165, from $1.8080 late Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's prices, included: 1.5885 German marks, up from 1.5835; 1.4040 Swiss francs, up from 1.3995; 5.4255 French francs, up from 5.4110; 1,198.50 Italian lire, up from 1.196.00, and 1.14255 Canadian dollars, up from 1.13265.
The dollar fell against the Japanese yen, slipping to 129 in New York from 129.30. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar closed at 128.73 yen, down 0.17 yen, and in London, it was quoted at 128.85.
Analysts said the yen was strengthened by the surge in stock prices in Tokyo yesterday.
Gold rose $1.40 on the Commodity Exchange in New York, closing at $359.40 an ounce. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $359.00, up $1.25.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $358.60, down 90 cents from late Thursday. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $358.90 from $359.95. In Hong Kong, gold dropped $6.48 an ounce to close at $359.75.
Silver picked up 1.3 cents on the Commodity Exchange to close at $3.835 an ounce. In London, silver was unchanged from late Thursday's bid of $3.85.

HEADLINE: Your Taxes;
A Court Decision For Scientologist

BYLINE: By Robert D. Hershey Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In a decision that has roiled long-established practice, a Federal appeals court has legitimized a challenge to deductions for certain charitable contributions by a Scientologist, who contended that he had been a victim of discrimination.
At issue is the deductibilty of contributions to religious organizations when the church or synagogue provides something in return. 
 The decision in question, issued this autumn when the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, in Atlanta, vacated a district court's dismissal, backs an assertion by a member of the church that the I.R.S. discriminated against him by denying his charitable deduction on the ground that his payments were tied to a specific benefit: one-on-one sessions with a church figure for which a price list is published and payment required.
George H. Powell's victory means that the matter must now be reconsidered in court, and the I.R.S. and others are forced to take a fresh look at Scientology's contention that mainstream religious organizations also provide a quid pro quo for participation in religious services. At issue are such things as pew rents, Mass stipends, High Holy Day tickets, and tithes. Protestants, Roman Catholics, Jews and Mormons employ one or more of these.
The Church of Scientology has fought with the Internal Revenue Service over its status for years.
Although few believe that the charitable deduction, one of the most widely used, will ultimately be compromised or lost, it seems possible that Scientology will gain equal footing. Consequently, the decision is being taken seriously both by the service and by some church representatives here. "It might stick," said Donald C. Alexander, a former head of the I.R.S. and now a Washington consultant to nonprofit groups. "It's not a frivolous issue."
 
Higher Standard Deduction
 For 1992, according to newly published I.R.S. inflation adjustments, the standard deduction will rise by $300, to $6,000, for joint returns and surviving spouses and by $200, to $3,600, for singles. The deduction will be $5,250 for heads of household and $3,000 for married people filing separately. Each personal exemption will rise $150, to $2,300, with the maximum basic earned-income credit at $1,324 for a worker with one child and $1,384 for two or more children. Those claiming the credit may also be entitled to a health insurance credit of up to $451 and a credit of up to $376 for a child born during 1992.
Additional standard deductions for old age and blindness rise $60, to $700 for couples and $900 for singles.
But the Social Security levy will bite harder for many in the new year as the taxable wage base rises to $55,500 from $53,400. Moreover, the Medicare base rises to $130,200 from $125,000. The combined tax rate remains at 7.65 percent -- 6.2 percent for Social Security and 1.45 percent for Medicare.
Meanwhile, benefits under Social Security rise 3.7 percent in January to reflect inflation as gauged by the Consumer Price Index.
 
Footnotes
 Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said he would seek re-election to an 18th term. Representative Frank Annunzio, who as a result of Illinois redistricting had been a prospective opponent, decided to retire. At the I.R.S., Michael P. Dolan has been named deputy commissioner, replacing Michael J. Murphy.
The New York State Department of Taxation and Finance is one of six organizations to win the first I.R.S. Quality Supplier Awards. They magnetically transmitted more than 500,000 information documents for 1989 and 1990 with no formatting or validity errors.
A deputy registrar in Ohio's Bureau of Motor Vehicles may not deduct as a political contribution any part of the 10 percent of his office's receipts he agreed to pay the Butler County Democratic Party for the support needed to get and keep the job. The United States Tax Court also said in its decision that while a reasonable person in the registrar's position could believe the job to be dependent on the payments -- subsequently barred by Ohio law -- the payments could not be deducted as business expenses, either.
President Bush on Wednesday signed the bill that extends for six months a dozen expiring tax breaks and raises quarterly estimated tax payments for corporations.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Boise Cascade

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: BOISE, Idaho, Dec. 13

 BODY:
The Boise Cascade Corporation reduced the quarterly dividend to 15 cents a share, from 38 cents, saying the slow economy and "unsettled business environment" hade hurt earnings. The company said its policy had been to pay an average of 30 percent of earnings in the form of dividends, and it expected to raise the payout as its performance improved. Separately, the company named George Harad president and chief operating officer. Mr. Harad had been executive vice president in charge of paper operations. Boise Cascade is an integrated forest products company with operations in the United States and Canada.

HEADLINE: Middle-Class and Jobless, They Share Sorrows

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAMDEN, Conn., Dec. 13

 BODY:
As a chill rain soaked the bare trees and a "House for Sale" sign outside, 11 people sat around a living room in this middle-class enclave today and told two members of Congress what a faltering economy had done to their once-satisfying lives.
"We feel we are typical of the people for whom the American Dream fell flat on its face," said the hostess, Elaine Feldman, as the House Majority Leader, Richard A. Gephardt, and Representative Rosa DeLauro nodded sympathetically. "We did everything right. Now, in our 50's, we find ourselves losing our home, and where do we go?" 
 The meeting, arranged by the office of Ms. DeLauro, a freshman Democrat from New Haven, lasted just over an hour. But in that time, an assortment of cries for help went out, from people who had part-time jobs or no jobs, from people worried about how to pay for health care, from people wondering when, or if, the economy would get better.
They included people like Joel Goldberg, who inherited a 15-man electrical contracting company from his father three years ago. Now, he said, the business consists only of himself. And there was Kenny Foscue, who is getting laid off at the end of the month from his job at a nonprofit agency that tries to prevent people in similar straits from being evicted. All were members of a support group based in nearby New Haven that organizes discussions among people who have lost their jobs.
 
'No Magic Button'
 The politicians offered them a few proposals but warned that there would be no immediate improvement. "There's no magic button," Mr. Gephardt said.
The Democrat from Missouri, who said the sickly economy "is the major issue in the country everywhere I go," said he would try to add money to a transportation jobs bill that was approved by Congress last month. He expressed support for job training and a proposed bill, one of Ms. DeLauro's ideas, that would grant tax relief to middle- and lower-income people, which, he said, "would give people a little more confidence to go into the stores, get this economy up on its feet."
Yet the disillusionment described by members of the support group indicated a much deeper problem. "It's not just the blue-collar worker who's involved -- it's everyone," said William Keeley, a former bank vice president who was laid off earlier this year. He spoke of lost self-esteem, as did others, and of being overqualified for the few jobs they managed to land interviews for.
"When you've lived your life a certain way and had a certain kind of job, you have a certain personality," said Lee Russell, who was laid off in April from his job as an engineering firm's librarian. Now he and his wife, Kia, another member of the group, work as part-time Santas at a local shopping mall.
 
Executive Turned Clerk
 Others noted that, in the search for jobs, some priorities fall by the wayside. "There's a difference now," Mr. Keeley said, "between career path and survival." He told of one group member, who did not attend today, a former executive now working as a clerk in a consumer-electronics store.
And Mrs. Feldman told of her disappointment and shock when, after her husband was laid off seven months ago, her $16,000 salary became their primary source of income. This month, they missed their first mortgage payment in 27 years, and they are trying, without much luck, to sell the ranch house where their three children grew up and where the Feldmans amassed the collections of porcelain figurines and antique salt cellars that they display in their living room.
"We were planning to stay here forever," Mrs. Feldman said. They put the house on the market shortly after her husband was laid off, and since then they have cashed in his life-insurance policy, sold some jewelry and budgeted themselves $6 a day for meals.
Most of the time, Mrs. Feldman said, she believes that no one in power realizes her plight. "You feel like that Zen tree that falls, and there's no noise if there's nobody there to hear it," she said. But with two members of Congress in her house today, she said, she was a bit encouraged.
Mr. Gephardt said he had agreed to attend at the request of Ms. DeLauro. He added that he holds the same kind of sessions in his own district and hears the same laments.
Mrs. Feldman's husband, Jerry, said he had heard reports that the economy would recover sometime "in the second half of the third quarter of 1992," but he added, "If I have to wait that long, I'm not going to have anything left."

The meeting was arranged for participants to discuss the effects of the recession on their lives. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Long Delayed, New Town In Queens Appears Dead

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED

 BODY:
A long-stalled effort to build a "new town" on a vast ocean-front site in Queens has stalled again because the poor economy has forced the developer to withdraw, city officials said yesterday.
They said that the 23-year-old Arverne urban renewal project in the Rockaways -- already one of the nation's most notorious examples of redevelopment gone nowhere -- suffered its latest setback when the developer of the latest plan for the site, Oceanview Associates of Manhattan, pulled out last week. 
 Oceanview was to buy the mostly barren, two-mile-long tract from the city for almost $70 million and, over a decade, build a $1.5 billion complex of 7,500 apartments, shopping malls and parks. The apartments, mostly in town houses, were to be priced to sell or rent to families with annual incomes of $45,000 to $80,000 under the plan, announced in 1989.
But Oceanview has withdrawn because "the downturn in the economy has depressed prospects for the successful development of market-rate housing on as large a scale as we had originally contemplated at this site," said Barbara J. Fife, the Deputy Mayor for Planning and Development.
 
Series of Smaller Projects
 As a result, she said, the city and Oceanview had "reached the joint conclusion that it is more realistic to develop Arverne as a series of discrete, smaller projects by separate developers within the urban renewal area, rather than proceeding with a single, master developer."
A spokeswoman for Oceanview, Michele de Milly, said that in the recession there was less consumer interest in buying housing and "financial institutions are not financing real-estate development projects."
Ms. Fife said that specifics of the smaller proposals now envisioned for Arverne were still to be drawn up and that she could not tell how long this would take. But people familiar with the complexities of urban renewal planning said that, at best, the latest setback could further delay the Arverne project by several years.
Last spring city officials spoke of this prospect as both the recession and the city's fiscal problems worsened and there were reports that Oceanview was having trouble obtaining financing. Ms. Fife herself said at that time that the project "may not happen in the next couple of years, until market conditions change."
But it was not until last week that Oceanview withdrew, and Ms. Fife formally announced the action yesterday, after a report of it appeared in New York Newsday.
Ms. Fife expressed optimism that the Arverne site -- 300 acres of mostly barren, weed-filled and litter-strewn lots -- would yet be redeveloped. The tract was approved for urban renewal in 1968 and nearly 4,000 deteriorated old buildings were demolished. However, little of the envisioned new housing materialized.
Obstacles included the city's fiscal crisis of the 1970's and sharp cutbacks in Federal housing subsidies. Other proposals for the tract that came and went involved gambling casinos and a recreation complex similar to Tivoli Gardens in Copenhagen.

HEADLINE: Albert H. Gaynes, 73, Former Steel Executive

 BODY:
Albert H. Gaynes, a retired steel executive and an advocate for political and social causes, died on Monday at his home in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. He was 73 years old.
He died of cancer, his family said.
From 1949 to 1979 he worked for the Capitol Steel Company, fabricators of reinforcing steel for concrete construction. He served as a vice president and director for most of that period and was a one-third owner. From 1980 to 1990, he was a marketing and management consultant and also ran Gaynes Enterprises, a sales company dealing in minerals and ores. 
 In the 1980's he made several trips to El Salvador and Nicaragua, working with groups trying to change United States policy. He also aided efforts to improve relations between blacks and Jews in New York City. He was a director of the National Emergency Civil Liberties Committee, the Fund for New Priorities in America, and Curbstone Press, which publishes material on Latin America. Last year he became a part-time community liaison for Assemblyman Richard Brodsky, a Democrat from Westchester.
Born in Staten Island, Mr. Gaynes grew up in Manhattan and the Bronx. He graduated from City College and for two years was an economics instructor there. He served five years in the Army in World War II, reaching the rank of first lieutenant. After the war he taught for four years at Marymount College in Tarrytown, N.Y.
He is survived by his wife, the former Deborah Libert; two daughters, Elizabeth of White Plains, and Susan of Cazenovia, N.Y.; a brother, Sanford of Plainview, L.I., and two grandchildren.

HEADLINE: So Many Children, So Few Toys

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
When it comes to this year's most popular toys and games forget all that has been said about the recession dampening demand. Retailers and toy industry observers report that the hot items are disappearing as fast as in any other year. And some of the products may not be back on the shelves before Christmas.
This year's spurt of demand for some toys can be attributed both to the usual fads generated by popular movies or television shows and to the soaring number of births that have occurred in the last few years. 
 Manufacturers said there was no way to predict accurately which toys on the market would become runaway best sellers. Each year, they said, there are surprises. When a trend becomes apparent, toy makers try to meet the demand.
United States census figures showed that in 1989, the most recent figures available, there were already two million more children under 5 years old than there were in 1984 -- adding up to about 18.4 million youngsters. Diane Cardinale, a spokeswoman with the Toy Manufacturers of America, a national trade group in New York City, speculates that many of those children are the first-born of older parents. These parents, she said, "have traditionally spent the most on their kids." And the age group provides the biggest market for toys.
 
Buyers FavorLike Dolls and Blocks

 
 Unlike Christmas seasons past, when one item -- the Cabbage Patch doll or the pet rock -- dominated the must-buy lists, shoppers are retreating to more conventional gifts, according to Bob Seligman, the editor of Toy and Hobby World, a trade publication in New York City.
Buyers are favoring dolls and building blocks now. These playthings are very popular, he said, because people seem to be spending moneymore carefully. Parents are also fond of toys that recall their childhood, like Erector Sets. "Even Monopoly is coming back strong," he added.
Among the most popular novelty items is the Nerf Bow 'N' Arrow by Parker Brothers, a toy weapon that shoots spongelike arrows. It is intended for the kindergarteners and sells for about $20. "We're totally out right now," said Brooke Adkins, a spokeswoman for the F.A.O. Schwarz toy-store chain.
Anything to do with mermaids may likely be cleaned off the shelf. Among very young children, the Walt Disney movie "The Little Mermaid" and its video cassette has kept demand high for related toys and games. Retailers say the mermaid dolls are becoming to preschoolers what Barbie has been to their older sisters.
The best selling mermaids are the original Ariel, the Little Mermaid, made by Tyco Toys, and its new Christmas cousin, Holiday Ariel. There's also Mattel's Little Miss Singing Mermaid, whose tail changes its color when the mermaid is slipped under water.
Among the high-tech sellouts are Magic Copier, another Tyco toy that has a screen to draw on and prints out the artwork on colored paper. The new 16-bit Genesis home video game by Sega of America is also big. The Super Nintendo Entertainment System is also selling well; retailers are apparently keeping up with the demand.
Manufacturers are trying to restock items continually, so it is worth returning to the store or calling ahead to find out if the toy you want is there.
One toy retailers are unlikely to get in again soon if it sells out is the new Preschool Radio Control Car from Playskool. The car comes as a fire chief's or police car. Both have taken off with unexpected speed.
"We don't expect to meet demand this year," said Wayne Charness, a vice president of Hasbro, the manufacturer's parent company, based in Pawtucket, R.I.

HEADLINE: The Speaker's Conviction

 BODY:
Yesterday's conviction of Mel Miller, Speaker of the New York State Assembly, effectively ends the political career of a bright, outspoken lawmaker whose liberal views and flamboyant style helped shape the political debate in Albany for years. The guilty verdict also throws a floundering state capital, struggling to cope with the impact of a sinking economy, further into confusion.
Under state law, Mr. Miller's conviction on charges of dealing unethically with clients for personal gain means automatic expulsion from the Assembly seat he's held for 21 years and ends his five-year role as Speaker -- the most powerful Democratic legislator in the state. James Tallon Jr. of Binghamton becomes the Acting Speaker. 
 But until Assembly Democrats select a permanent successor to Mr. Miller, sensitive negotiations to close a daunting budget gap estimated at $4.5 billion are likely to make little progress. That is especially true in light of Gov. Mario Cuomo's protracted flirtation with national politics.
It is of some solace to New Yorkers that Mr. Miller's conviction was related to his private law practice; it had nothing to do with his job in Albany. He contends he was the victim of a "political witch hunt," and an appeals panel may ultimately agree. For now, though, the conviction reinforces the Legislature's reputation for attracting people of questionable ethics and promoting them to positions of power. Even if Mr. Miller's guilty verdict is ultimately reversed, he was guilty of poor judgment and a willingness to cut corners in pursuit of profit.
His downfall is a personal tragedy. It is also a blow to New York, because Mr. Miller often added a voice of reason -- and quirky humor -- to the contentious swirl of Albany politics. An unapologetic liberal, he fought effectively for the poor and elderly, mastered the complicated budget process, hired competent professionals for his staff, and dealt deftly with the difficult Mr. Cuomo and the quietly contrary Senate majority leader, Ralph Marino, a Republican.
Mr. Miller was, as well, every inch a politician. He vigorously advocated an irresponsibly large income tax cut, which has contributed substantially to the state's current budget crisis. Though he first supported a gasoline tax, he later reversed himself in the interests of political expediency. And while he championed full disclosure of campaign contributions, he refused to identify contributors to his legal defense fund.
Whatever his flaws, Mr. Miller's exit from the Albany scene will hurt. It leaves a hole in leadership at a precarious moment in New York. Prompt action by Assembly Democrats to pick a successor is the only responsible course.

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
Running, Anyone?

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN

 BODY:
Talking to Mario Cuomo is like playing tennis with Jimmy Connors. By the time you put down the phone, the only proper response seems to be to kick back, hang a towel around your neck and drink a bottle of Gatorade.
You've made it through the suggestion that you don't take the state budget crisis seriously enough, the quotation from the prophet Jeremiah ("you will find your own strength in the strength of the whole community"), the speech about how liberals lost his parents and the rest of the lower middle class, and a gleeful first person plural recitation of defeat: ". . . when we got killed by Krupsak, when we lost to Koch, when Carey made a fool of us . . ." All in the service of one little question. 
 Everywhere you go people are asking whether Mario Cuomo is running for President. It makes sense to ask the man himself except that in a true/false world, Mr. Cuomo has always been taking an essay test. There will be no simple answers.
Q. "How are you, Governor?" A. "I am ontologically good. That makes them crazy, boy."
He hoped to be like Joe DiMaggio, one of his heroes, a man no one ever made a joke about. Instead Johnny Carson lampoons his indecision. ("Isn't this guy married five times?" Mr. Cuomo rejoins.) There is, of course, another way to look at this, and that is that when Johnny Carson is taking your name in vain, you're at the center of the universe.
Mr. Cuomo's free fall has turned out to be sensationally effective. People on the street who don't know Bill Clinton from Bob Kerrey are asking about Mario Cuomo. He has become a little like the girl in high school whose greatest allure was that she kept turning you down for a date. Even when she turns out to be a perfectly ordinary girl, you've got to continue to invest her with a golden glow so you don't feel the fool.
The other candidates slog through debates and hardware stores, and every day someone takes the temperature of Mr. Cuomo's temperament. After my interview I clutch close a prepositional phrase. "In all likelihood," he said. In all likelihood, if he can reach a budget agreement, he will declare his candidacy for President of the United States.
Incumbent Presidents do this all the time; they say that the affairs of state are so pressing that they could not possibly think about running for re-election. What this means is that they're going to work on their weaknesses before they start formally pressing the flesh on Main Street.
Mr. Cuomo is trying to do precisely the same thing with the state budget. He knows the drill: "Then you're in Indiana saying 'I'll show you how to save this country' and somebody holds up page one of The New York Times and says 'Really, Governor?' " Not this guy. "I could not possibly declare a candidacy until I got this situation reasonably under control," he says. Reasonably under control is defined in classic Cuomo fashion. It is like Potter Stewart's take on obscenity. He'll know it when he sees it.
The deadline for filing for the New Hampshire primary is Friday. Mr. Cuomo rejects unequivocally -- ah, what a relief, an unequivocal rejection! -- the suggestion that if he runs he might skip some primaries. But at the mere whiff of yielding to desire or ambition, he goes up like a rocket. "I've spent a lifetime trying to diminish what I want to do," he says. In other words, the Presidency as self-abnegation.
He dwells on his defeats, acting the underdog. "The state didn't believe I could be governor in April 1982," he says, "38 points behind and no money." And the country didn't believe George Bush could be beaten in April 1991, except for Paul Tsongas, who drew a little graph of the ups and downs of the economy in my notebook, wrote the words "Nov. 1992" next to a big dip, and topped the whole thing off with a question mark.
The question mark remains. It's hard to know how the American people would feel after a year of "ontologically good." But for now Mario Cuomo is the overdog. People like me, with notebooks to fill and an affection for black and white, complain about his indecision, his adherence to his own body clock, his refusal to provide simple answers. And people on the street want to know if he's going to run. The mind of the body politic is on Mr. Cuomo, and Mr. Cuomo continues to play his own game.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: U.S. Shipbuilding Withers as Japan's Thrives

 BODY:
To the Editor:
To the families of the 50,000 American shipyard workers who have lost their jobs in the last decade, the 50th anniversary of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor will be a harsh reminder that the United States shipbuilding industry, which helped bring victory over Japan in World War II, is on the verge of collapse, while Japan has emerged as the strongest shipbuilding country in the world. 
 What happened to reverse the fortunes of the once-proud United States shipbuilding industry, which churned out thousands of ships (5,400 between 1943 and 1945, the height of its productivity) to support the war effort?
Part of the answer lies in government subsidies used to prop up foreign shipyards and thereby assure their ability to capture market share. Japan led the way, pouring billions of dollars into its shipbuilding industry ($4.4 billion was budgeted for this purpose by the Japanese Government from 1987 through 1990 alone). By contrast, the United States industry saw its subsidy program terminated in 1981.
But another part of the story concerns our Government's naive and destructive industrial policies, which have emphasized short-term goals over our country's economic health and impotent responses to predatory practices of our trading partners that have resulted in the export of American jobs. The Bush Administration continues the assumption that American industry is noncompetitive without analyzing the far different structural and protectionist roles employed by other governments.
The beginning of the end for American shipyards was in 1981. At that time, when other governments were escalating their shipbuilding aid, the United States Government not only terminated its commercial shipbuilding support subsidy, but actually passed a measure to encourage United States-flag shipowners to bypass American yards and buy where they could get the best foreign subsidy.
In addition, the Government turned a blind eye to Japanese Government practices that permitted Japan's industry to create a cartel and to manage a restructuring through market allocation and price setting.
In June 1989, the Shipbuilders Council of America filed a trade petition outlining the extent to which foreign governments subsidize their shipyards. Recognizing the petition's merit, Carla Hills, the United States trade representative, initiated an effort within the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development to get foreign governments to cease their subsidy practices. In the subsequent two-and-a-half years of negotiations, little progress has been made.
The Japanese, who deny that their governmental practices distort competitive conditions in the shipbuilding marketplace, have made it clear they are not interested in ending those practices or in disciplining Government behavior in the marketplace.
The United States shipbuilding and repair industry understand that international competitiveness is the key to survival in a marketplace in which defense dollars will be in short supply. But if we cannot get the Japanese to agree to end their shipbuilding subsidies, the question our workers will ask is, What will the Bush Administration do to insure that we are not sacrificed to the predatory practices of others?
Representative Sam Gibbons of Florida, chairman of the House Ways and Means Trade Subcommittee, has introduced H.R. 2056, a bill to penalize foreign ships built with subsidies. We strongly support the shipbuilding trade reform bill.
 
JOHN STOCKER
President, Shipbuilders Council of America
Arlington, Va., Dec. 2, 1991

HEADLINE: Unemployment Issues Go Beyond Race

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Two letters Nov. 12 criticize an Oct. 29 article and comments by me about Timothy Smeeding's study comparing anti-poverty efforts in the United States, Western Europe and Canada. Roger Wilkins complains about the failure to recognize the special American problem, race, and Sheila Kamerman and Alfred J. Kahn disagree with my assertion that social spending in the United States cannot be one-dimensionally compared to that in the prosperous and largely segregated countries of Western Europe. 
 The contradictory nature of the two letters, I think, demonstrates the dangers of cross-cultural comparisons.
Unlike Western European countries, we have large numbers of teen-agers who have babies out of wedlock and then go on welfare. According to the Congressional Budget Office, 77 percent of all unwed teen-age mothers go on welfare within five years of their first child's birth -- and many stay there for 10 years or more.
Few analysts question that welfare payments act as a work disincentive, particularly for young people without work experience; they just argue about its size. In a study for the University of Wisconsin Institute on Poverty, Robert Moffitt estimates that every dollar transferred to female-headed households reduces the mother's work effort by 37 cents.
Of greater concern to me, however, are Professor Wilkins's comments about nonwork being a code word for race. If you don't work, you are likely to be poor (unless you are the child of a millionaire). About half of all the poor do not work at all.
Mr. Wilkins seems to assume that it is blacks and other racial minorities who are not working. In making this assumption, he himself falls victim to racial stereotyping.
Actually, the overall labor force participation rates of whites and blacks are roughly equal. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the rates for white and black 25- to 64-year-olds are about 79 percent and 75 percent, respectively. African-Americans with at least a high school education have higher levels of participation than their white counterparts. Overall black rates are slightly lower than for whites only because blacks tend to have less schooling.
The failure to graduate from high school is now the most important predictor of nonwork among all groups except white female dropouts. Rates for them have risen to those of black female dropouts because they are now substantially less likely to marry. Among male high school dropouts of both races, labor force rates fell by almost 20 percent.
Only among male high school dropouts is the black rate lower than the white (for those 16 and older, about 47 percent to 56 percent). This difference shows the distressing plight of many young, black males. Their condition seems the indisputable result of discrimination -- and attention is required.
These data, however, show a broader -- and deeper -- trend of declining labor force participation among poorly educated men of all races. Are our schools failing the disadvantaged? Or are deeper social processes at work, fed by higher levels of social permissiveness and social welfare incentives against work? My own guess is that it is a mixture of the three.
If we don't confront the issues of nonwork, we will never be able to do anything about the resulting poverty. Probably without intending it, Professor Wilkins has lent his considerable prestige to the quite dangerous suggestion that talking about nonwork is racist.
 
DOUGLAS J. BESHAROV
Resident Scholar, American Enterprise Institute
Washington, Nov. 25, 1991

HEADLINE: OUTDOORS;
Anglers Warm to 'Letting Them Go'

BYLINE: By Ken Schultz; Ken Schultz is a fishing editor for Field & Stream magazine and the author of seven books on angling.

 BODY:
"Let them go, let them grow" is a sport-fishing slogan of the Saskatchewan Parks and Natural Resources Department that reflects a growing attitude in this Western province and across Northern Canada. Steve MacKinnon, a native of Prince Albert and a lodge owner in Northern Saskatchewan, supports the province's catch-and-release policy, even though it occasionally puts him on the defensive.
MacKinnon, whose Ena Lake Lodge opened last summer, voluntarily adopted the policy to maintain and enhance the good fishing at the lake, a 15-mile, glacial-carved body of water just a short cast from the border of the Northwest Territories. 
 "Sure, the catch-and-release-only policy has cost us some business already," he said. "We had two groups that were ready to come here but some of the members wanted to take a trophy fish home if they caught one, and we won't allow it. The leader of one group told me, 'When you change your policy, call me.' I lost over $10,000 from that possible booking, but this is the way it has to be. I want my customers to come back and to know that there will always be good fishing opportunities."
MacKinnon is not alone, and the anglers who won't book a trip because they can't kill what they catch are becoming fewer. There is a growing trend in the fishing lodges in Saskatchewan, Manitoba and the Northwest Territories, where there is a limited fishing season and which are reached by floatplane only, to attempt to conserve the resource that attracts anglers, the majority of whom are from the United States.
Most of the remote lodges charge between $2,000 and $3,000 per week, plus commercial airfare. The astute owners know that for anglers willing to pay these prices, going home with a few fillets of fish is of less importance than having a quality experience, receiving personal attention, recording their catch on camera and having the chance to enjoy a rare commodity.
It wasn't always this way. Not too long ago, many Northern anglers measured their success in the weight of fish boxes leaving the lodge or camp, or the number of trophy fish that they caught. Lawrence Shewchuk of Red Lake, Ontario, a recent visitor to Ena Lake, observed that many lodge owners had allowed their clients to take too many fish out of once-prime water.
A former lodge owner turned real estate agent who brokers fishing lodges, Shewcuk noted the economic irony. "I represent some older lodge owners whose lakes have seen their better days," he said, "and they want to sell their operation for what it used to be, not what it is. Now they offer mediocre fishing, or the better fishing is a long haul away from where their camp is located, and it will be a while before that is changed."
The further north one goes, the more acute this is. In many waters it takes three or four decades to grow a lake trout of trophy proportions (30 to 40 pounds). Now, many anglers and lodge owners realize that such prized fish cannot be replaced quickly, if at all, in their lifetime.
Shane MacKinnon is especially sensitive to this problem. Ena Lake is one of the premier lake trout waters in Saskatchewan. Though smaller than huge bodies of water like Lake Athabasca (which is a short distance to the south) and Reindeer Lake, it has never received commercial fishing (another factor that influences resources in northern lakes), and has only been visited by a few sport fishermen.
The best angling for lake trout occurs in June and September. Twenty-five to 30-pound trout are abundant. MacKinnon's best is a 40-pounder, and a friend caught a 53-pounder at the lake a few years before there was a lodge.
At Ena, with the exception of a few small fish, usually in the five-pound range, that are kept for a shore lunch, all of the lake trout caught are quickly returned to the water. Angling is done only with lures.
MacKinnon requires lures with barbless hooks, those with the barbs of the point pinched or filed down. This aids hook removal and helps prevent damage to the fish. Caught in cold waters, the trout usually have no trouble swimming heartily away after being landed.
Ena Lake provides excellent fishing for northern pike, which are another popular Canadian game fish. These are the mainstays in July and August. They, too, are frequently caught in trophy proportions, from 18 to 26 pounds, and all are released alive.
Twenty anglers were at Ena Lake earlier this summer when I visited. They came from Chicago, Minneapolis, Ontario, Wichita, Kan., and New York. Many were already booked for a return engagement next year.
The catch-and-release policy was not an issue for any of those present. The weather was of greater concern. While the course of the weather was beyond their control, the future of the fishing was not.

HEADLINE: Science Fiction

BYLINE: By Gerald Jonas

 BODY:
These are tough times for science fiction, or at least that part of the genre set in the near future (the next hundred years or so). Whether they come across as prediction, satire or cautionary tale, stories about the near future must build on contemporary events in a plausible way or readers will have trouble suspending disbelief. When the Soviet Union and its bloc began to fission, the rules changed overnight: all stories featuring superpower rivalries -- which meant virtually all near-future stories -- were suddenly out of date.
Under the circumstances, one might think that science fiction writers, who have all of space and time to play with, would steer clear of the near future until some new world order takes shape and reduces the risks of premature obsolescence. But Norman Spinrad has always been a risk taker. His novel "Bug Jack Barron" was denounced in England for its blunt language; "The Iron Dream," his alternative-history novel "written" by the famous science fiction writer Adolf Hitler, was banned in Germany. And in "The Void Captain's Tale" Mr. Spinrad took a deadpan look at the ultimate in unsafe sex: orgasm-powered space travel. Now, with RUSSIAN SPRING (Bantam, $22.50), he tries, and instructively fails, to stay one step ahead of the headlines. 
 In Mr. Spinrad's near-future scenario, a strong, centrally governed Soviet Union has gone "European" and an increasingly isolated United States is turning into a "third-rate country." The trouble with this scenario is not so much that events have overtaken it (who is to say how history may swerve tomorrow?) but that Mr. Spinrad takes it so seriously.
What this 567-page book is really about is the old story of trust and betrayal: youthful dreams eyeball to eyeball with harsh reality. The dream is space travel, the betrayer is the United States of America. Jerry Reed, whose father fed him all the Haagen-Dazs he could eat the night the Apollo astronauts landed on the moon so that he would never forget, exiles himself to Paris to get a job with the only nonmilitary space program still extant. His wife, Sonya, is one of the "new Russians" working for Red Star, S.A., a hugely successful conglomerate also known as "USSR, Incorporated." Their son and daughter grow up in Paris, not sure which nationality to choose.
All of this might have made for an intriguing study of dreams deferred (and recycled) except that the principal characters never seem to change, even when their circumstances do. Jerry Reed's life turns out to be little more than a footnote to that bowl of Haagen-Dazs; he and his family get older without noticeably maturing, their principal virtue being a tenacious loyalty to one another. Mr. Spinrad might have had more time for character development had he not been so busy spelling out the geopolitical-socioeconomic details of an imaginary 21st century that makes little sense as either prediction, satire or cautionary admonition.
The thanklessness of trying to outguess history seems to get even Mr. Spinrad down after a while. Part of the fun of near-future stories is the local color: imaginative flights of fashion, clever twists on contemporary trends, fresh slang. What we get all too often in "Russian Spring" are standard-issue lists of objects and events: "There was a stove, a microwave oven, two old refrigerators, a big restaurant double sink piled high with dirty dishes and grimy pots, and a big redwood picnic table with two long backless redwood benches." It is as if Mr. Spinrad wanted to reassure us, and himself, that the winds of history have not swept everything away. Yet recent events would seem to suggest a different strategy: to keep pace with the march of time, travel light.
The title of Robert Silverberg's new novel, THE FACE OF THE WATERS (Bantam, $20), comes from Genesis: "And the earth was without form, and void; and darkness was upon the face of the deep. And the spirit of God moved upon the face of the waters." In Mr. Silverberg's conceit, the waters are a world-encompassing ocean on a planet named Hydros that was once used as a human penal colony. The descendants of the original prisoners survive on small floating islands that obey the ocean currents. The humans share these islands with the intelligent Gillies, natives of Hydros who barely tolerate their presence. The waters themselves teem with ravenous forms of life that resemble the sea monsters found on old maps of Earth, the barely remembered home planet long since destroyed by a blast of "hard radiation" from its own sun.
When some of the humans learn that the Gillies fear and venerate an unusual island known in their language as "the face of the waters," they set sail in a fleet of ships to find out why. As Mr. Silverberg tells it, this quest is unabashedly mythic: there is a priest searching for God, a self-medicating doctor looking for love, a man of action looking for something to conquer, a woman searching for the truth and so on. But the people themselves are more than allegorical devices; their obsessions are believable, their pain all too real. The opening chapters set the scene with great economy and authority; the ending is both daring and persuasive. The problem comes in the middle, the quest-journey itself, which goes on and on and on, enlivened mainly by attacks from one terrifying monster after another.
Mr. Silverberg exercises considerable ingenuity in devising these creatures, but the exercise grows tedious and begins to look suspiciously like padding. Back in the 1940's and 50's, in the heyday of the science fiction magazine, editors welcomed stories of any length; if a story was too long to be called short and too short to be called a novel, it was published as a novelette or novella.
"Novelette" always sounded to me like something on sale at Woolworth's, but "novella" (which my dictionary defines as "a story with a compact and pointed plot") has been good English since the Renaissance. Many of science fiction's classic stories are novellas. Without its bloated middle, "The Face of the Waters" would have made a perfect novella; readers who don't mind skimming through the middle hundred pages or so may enjoy it as such.
R. A. MacAvoy's KING OF THE DEAD (Morrow, $19) is a worthy sequel to last year's "Lens of the World," the book that introduced Nazhuret, an orphan of uncertain birth but of many talents, including first-person narration; his equally adept lady companion, who goes by the masculine name of Arlin, and their omnicompetent mentor, Powl. As before, Nazhuret and Arlin are reluctant heroes, thrust into the medieval politics of a world where kings, nobles and priests toss the ball of power among themselves in a game that can turn deadly at any moment.
Since swords are the weapon of choice in this world and since supranormal mental powers play a part in the story, I suppose Ms. MacAvoy's novels can be labeled "sword and sorcery." But unlike most specimens of this subgenre, her story focuses on language, not action. Nazhuret is more likely to talk his way out of trouble than to fight, although when pressed he and Arlin kill with efficiency if not relish.
Ms. MacAvoy and her characters take such pleasure in words that it is hard not to be swept along by their windy rhetoric, even when it borders on bombast. Taking the measure of an uncertain ally, Nazhuret muses: "He's a slave, but he's the emperor's slave, and his humility is another man's arrogance." To cow a band of cutthroat nomads, he extemporizes an autobiographical oration that begins, "I was born on the edge of a knife." And to defuse a grandiloquent challenge from his worst enemy -- "But I warn you, treacherous tool, I will make no peace with darkness!" -- Nazhuret replies, as "inoffensively" as he knows how: "Why not, Minsanaur of Rezhmia? Every day does."

SECTION: Section 5; Page 33; Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 1141 words

HEADLINE: See It Now, Save It Later

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL; ALAN COWELL is chief of the Rome bureau of The New York Times.

 BODY:
FLYING from Rome to Paris the other day, I fell into conversation with a Japanese teacher on vacation in Europe and we got to chatting about the cost of visiting what, for many Americans, has become a very expensive continent.
My curiosity had been inspired by the travel documents she had been arranging in a wallet -- hotel voucher from the superexpensive Grand Hotel in Florence, voucher for the Meridien in Paris, round-trip business class ticket from Osaka to London. Without going into detail, she said her outlays had been, well, significant. 
 A few days earlier I had been in Florence myself -- no lines at the galleries in these chill days. But the city was not empty. Tour groups braved the elements and the shopping, many of them Japanese, like the teacher, browsing and buying their way through leatherware and luggage and shoe stores. The story was the same when I got to Paris, where one of the biggest-name stores on the Rue du Faubourg St.-Honore was doing what seemed a very brisk trade in bulk purchases of $200 silk scarves.
The point, however, was not the nationality of the shoppers or even the fawning rapaciousness of the clerks, but in the curious imbalances of how the tourist dollar, or yen, or mark, is spread around the cities we visit: the money, ultimately, ends up with the restaurants and the stores and the hotels, even though we have come to see the statues and the architecture and the paintings. How much of our spending goes to preserving the very spectacles that drew us in the first place, and how much to those who profit from our interest?
During my own trip to Florence, I had spoken with Annamaria Patrioli Tofani, the director of the Uffizi, who had explained how Italy answered that question. The entrance fee at the Uffizi is around $8. A maximum of 7,000 visitors are permitted entry on each day the gallery is open. That makes a high-season average take of $56,000 a day, more than $1.6 million a month. Yet, the director said, she was having trouble finding the money to place screens of expensive, nonreflective glass in front of the Uffizi's prized Botticellis to protect them. The reason was that the gallery's income fed a government budget in Rome, from which funds were reallocated to individual museums and galleries. The reallocation, the director suggested, was not as generous as the contribution.
Some Florentines find it preposterous that a gallery like the Uffizi should be barred from self-financing, but, in a way, its problem reflects the wider quandary. Each year, five million tourists visit the city, and even if each of them spent only a museum fee that would mean $40 million flowing into the city. Yet some of the world's most famous paintings cannot be protected by anything other than a cheaper kind of glass that inhibits the viewer's appreciation of the masterpieces. And this is in a very wealthy place: "They talk about recession," said a public relations consultant in the city. "I don't see it here." If a wealthy spot like Florence has problems, what then of poorer places whose antiquity is just as much a part of our heritage?
Over the last few years, as a foreign correspondent, I've lived in three of the cities on the east Mediterranean tourist trail -- Athens, Cairo and Rome. In all three, I heard the argument that their treasures -- the Acropolis, the Pyramids, the Roman Forum, to name but the most celebrated -- are part of humanity's gift to itself. Yet, in each place, I've watched as the treasures fall prey largely to human folly: the Parthenon and the Forum awash in pollution, the tomb of Tutankhamun in upper Egypt closed to visitors because the visitors' own perspiration gnaws the frescoes; priceless sculpture in Rome and Florence assailed by deranged attackers; the Sphinx of Giza eroded from within by rising ground-water.
It was easy, as a resident, to become blase. The Pyramids became a backdrop to the nine-hole golf course and swimming pool beneath them. The Acropolis was no more than a point of navigation through the ocean of ugly concrete apartment houses that washes around it. And many local people did not seem too bothered about the antiquities, either: if every young Greek or Italian on a motorcycle was indifferent to the damage of exhaust fumes to a priceless heritage, and if every Egyptian hawker -- and quite a few public officials -- saw the Pyramids as no more than a concentration of potentially easy pickings, why should an outsider bother? If the antipollution measures in Rome and Athens are rarely enforced with complete efficiency, why get too steamed up about the damage that's being done?
The answer, of course, is that if there's no conservation, then, one day, there'll be nothing left to conserve and future generations will be the worse off for the disrespect the 20th century has paid to the collective scientific, cultural and artistic underpinnings of our self-image as civilized people.
Our own era's contributions -- the silicon chip and the video camera, for example -- seem a poor substitute. A computer might be able to duplicate Botticelli's "Venus" through advanced graphics or explain the construction of the Pyramids as a mathematical formula; but I doubt if it could generate the glorious inspiration behind them. It might convert the scientific accomplishment of the Renaissance or the philosophy of ancient Greece into a database. But it could not originate genius -- not yet, at least.
If the corollary is that we all have some responsibility for preservation, the question arises: how do we go about it? The germ of an idea began to form in a conversation, again in Florence, with the deputy mayor, Gianni Conti, who is also the senior municipal officer responsible for the city's cultural heritage. He said that 40 of the city's best-known monuments had secured sponsorship from local banks and businesses to insure their preservation. Why not take the idea further? Why not create taxation systems that take at least a slice of our tourist dollars from the stores and hotels and restaurants and divert them effectively to a broader form of sponsorship by the traders who reap most benefit from them?
The drawback is that money is only a small part of the solution: there are plenty of drachmas in Greece, after all, but the city's urban sprawl, its reliance on winter heating oil and cars creates a toxic environment far too complex for simple solutions. And, in Egypt, it is the very press of visitors, along with the country's myriad other problems, that create some of the most severe challenges for conservationists.
So, in the end, as the flight approached Paris and my companion packed away the guidebooks on Italy and began to peruse the map of France, I figured that, maybe, hers was the only practical solution: bite the bullet, see it now -- and hope it lasts.
