HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Office Report Card;
Rating New York City as a Place for Doing Business

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
NEW YORK'S recovery is not around any corner that American business leaders can see. A new survey shows that two and a half times as many executives rated business conditions in the area "poor" this year as did in 1989.
All told, 47 percent of the chief executive officers who say they are familiar with New York believe that general business conditions make it a poor place to locate a business today, according to this year's "Business America Real Estate Monitor," conducted by Louis Harris & Associates for the Cushman & Wakefield real estate concern. 
 And only 11 percent say they believe that business conditions in New York will be better in a year's time, contrasted to 30 percent who said conditions would be worse. That is the gloomiest assessment offered by the executives for any one of the 32 cities covered by the survey.
Notwithstanding the unfavorable perception, however, the New York area is the locale cited by 11 percent of the executives who say that they are actually planning to acquire office space in the next year.
In that regard, it is ahead of every area but Los Angeles and San Francisco.
How to reconcile these findings?
While New York scores poorly in almost every other criterion that corporate leaders use in locating a business, it is still well regarded for the "easy access" it provides to markets, customers and clients -- an attribute judged by the executives to be the single most important.
When it comes to access, 37 percent of the executives believe New York is an excellent office location. Chicago is the only city that gets a higher mark in this vital category.
"Some companies and industries have to have a presence in New York," said James S. Vanderslice, a managing director of Cushman & Wakefield. "There may be things they don't like about New York, but to operate, they have to be in New York."
"Obviously, for the city, this is a good news-bad news story," said Carl Weisbrod, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation. "The good news is that New York's fundamental assets of access, transportation and the like are very strong. Ultimately, the economic health of an area is determined by those fundamentals.
"Given the importance of access to markets as a factor in business decisions," Mr. Weisbrod continued, "and underscoring how well New York does in that area, it's really essential for us to preserve, enhance and improve that asset. One of the areas we're concentrating on now is the regional transportation of goods and services."
At the top of this list is the construction of a 1.8-mile rail connector at Oak Point in the Bronx, part of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's ambitious public-works program. This would allow freight cars to roll from the Bronx to Queens and Long Island. Second on the list is the improvement of air-cargo handling at Kennedy International Airport.
So much for the good news. Only 7 percent of the executives in the survey believe the New York area is excellent when it comes to the cost and availability of labor. Only 11 percent believe the area is excellent for the cost and efficiency of office space.
One percent believes that the quality of life for employees is excellent in the New York area. (Only Detroit fared worse: zero.)
Finally, in the matter of the "climate state and local government creates for business through tax policy and the extent of regulation," not one executive answered "excellent" when it came to New York.
"There's a message for us that we're well aware of," Mr. Weisbrod said. "From time immemorial, New York has been perceived by business as a tough place to do business. It is incumbent on government to improve that perception and make it an easier place to do business. Obviously, a large component of 'climate' is taxes, but it's only one. We're trying to make the city more receptive."
In assessing the climate created by government, 44 percent of the executives rated it "poor," up from 41 percent last year and 22 the year before that. This coincided with the departure of Mayor Edward I. Koch and arrival of Mayor David N. Dinkins, but executives at Cushman & Wakefield believe it is just that: a coincidence.
"DINKINS is dealing with a lot of issues that he inherited," Mr. Vanderslice said. "If Koch were in office, he'd be dealing with the same issues today. It happens to be the timing of administrations."
"The issues that are becoming far more pronounced are budget deficits and where tax increases are going to hit," said David Gialanella, managing director of Cushman & Wakefield. "I think corporate New York is viewing itself as the recipient of any move to increase revenues by increasing taxes."
Cost -- not civic deterioration -- may explain why New York's overall rating, which had been slipping in the late 80's, now seems to plummet from year to year.
"If you look at New York from purely a cost standpoint, it is significantly -- I underline significantly -- more expensive," Mr. Gialanella said. "You have a corporate base whose emphasis is on boosting earnings by reducing costs, so it doesn't surprise me that the problems they perceive in New York might be a little more prevalent now than they have been in the past."
"Are we worse in fact -- as a business center -- by the margin that the poll reflects?" asked Warren Wechsler, first senior vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York. "I don't see the evidence to explain any change in our standing other than perhaps a more deeply ingrained pessimism that's come about as a result of an economy that is stubbornly mired in the worst recession in recent memory.
"I think it is more a reflection of mood than it is a valid assessment of the city's assets as a business center," Mr. Wechsler said.
"HOW many of those executives live in New York? Are they speaking from firsthand knowledge or from what they hear and read in a press that's known to be robust, critical and searching and from a civic community that places a very high demand on those who govern?"
The answer to Mr. Wechsler's question is known only to Louis Harris & Associates, which will not reveal it even to Cushman & Wakefield, for whom the survey was conducted. "They keep to their vest anything that would be remotely construed as getting into the sample," Mr. Gialanella said.
Because of that, it is impossible to conduct follow-up interviews, as The New York Times does in reporting its own poll results.
All that Louis Harris will reveal about those who passed judgment on New York is that they amount to 55 percent of the 400 chief executive officers or their designees who were interviewed.
In the overall sample, 36 percent of those surveyed were from the East, 24 percent from the Midwest, 23 percent from the South and 17 percent from the West. Nearly half -- 46 percent -- represented companies with revenues of less than $500 million. On the other end, 18 percent represented companies with revenues of $1.5 billion or more.
Executives in finance, insurance and real estate accounted for 26 percent of the sample. Manufacturers accounted for 25 percent and wholesalers for 24 percent.
It is worth noting that even among those cities that rank ahead of New York, there has been slippage in recent years.
Atlanta now tops Cushman & Wakefield's list of "Best Places to Locate a Business Today," as it has for five of the last six years. But the number of executives giving it an excellent rating has dropped to 24 percent this year, from 39 percent in 1988.
"Excellent" ratings for Los Angeles have sunk to 4 percent from 19 percent over that same period. Boston has seen a drop to 4 percent from 21 percent. Philadelphia has gone to 3 percent, from 10 percent.

HEADLINE: In This Buyers' Market The Buyers Are Edgy

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
NEALE S. Godfrey fretted before she bought a six-room apartment on the Upper West Side last summer and she is fretting still. Yet she is a pro in weighing economic risks -- a former bank president, the author of a children's book on money management, the host of a radio talk show on personal finance. And the apartment was the third home she had bought.
Moreover, with the price at only $238,000 and the mortgage carrying a 7.5 percent adjustable interest rate, the real estate market hadn't looked so inviting to her since the late 70's. 
 Ms. Godfrey, however, is one of the many prospective and recent home buyers who are in a dither over whether the sour economy will erase the real gains offered by today's sweet real estate opportunities.
To be sure, many families are enthusiastically buying houses and apartments at what they believe are rock-bottom prices and interest rates. But economic uncertainty and a lack of consumer confidence are keeping others from entering the market and unnerving those who have.
Ms. Godfrey, for example, said she had qualms about the impact of the recession on the apartment's investment value and her fledgling consulting and marketing business. She also worried that banks might look askance at a self-employed single parent -- she has a 5-year-old son and a daughter, 8 -- who was already carrying a mortgage on another home.
In fact, her anxiety was even greater than when she bought a house in suburban New Jersey during the Middle East oil crisis in the early 70's or in an explosively inflating market in 1985. "It was much greater," Ms. Godfrey said, adding: "People are very apprehensive about buying. But it has more to do with their own economic circumstances than with real estate values."
Considering the current buyer's market in residences, it might seem that sellers, troubled by falling prices, job insecurities and a glut of homes for sale, would feel the most trepidation.
BUYER anxiety, though, appears to be just as commonplace. And it may even be more prevalent than in previous years when, because of rapidly rising prices and interest rates, buying a home was, for most people, a more daunting proposition.
Donna and Marc Centrelli are to close on a three-bedroom colonial in Ridgewood, N.J., on Jan. 15. Deciding whether to move has been "a much more anxious time" than when they they were looking for their first house, said Mrs. Centrelli.
The couple recently sold that first house -- a two-bedroom-plus-office home in Fair Lawn, N.J., bought as a handyman special for $162,500 two years ago and sold for $180,000. They made no major renovations.
"The main reason is the economy," Mrs. Centrelli said. "My husband is self-employed; he's a chiropractor. We're confident in his ability to increase his practice, but we are also anxious about how everyone is tightening their belts. The first time we bought, he hadn't even started his practice, but we were not as anxious as we are now."
No studies exist that measure buyer anxiety, but the phenomenon may be reflected in the drop in resales of one-family homes in the Northeast, from 703,000 in 1986 to 522,000 in 1990. The pattern also seems to be getting worse: The seasonally adjusted annual rate has fallen for each of the last four months, hitting 490,000 in October.
"There is a fear out there," said William F. Higgins, owner of the Higgins Agency, a 50-year-old real estate brokerage in Hillsdale, N.J. "The buyer today isn't asking about interest rates, but he is asking himself whether he is going to have a job and be able to make the payments. When you hear that I.B.M., Big Blue, is going to lay off 20,000 people, it kind of shakes your confidence."
Even more telling, perhaps, are the national monthly surveys of 5,000 households by the Conference Board of Manhattan, a nonprofit business research organization. They show that the number of American families planning to buy a new home within six months has, for the most part, been falling since January 1987, when it stood at 4.4 percent of the households.
The percentage has also declined for each of the last four months, hitting 2.7 in November. That was the lowest since last January, when it was 2.6 percent. The percentages are part of the Conference Board's overall Consumer Confidence Index, which in November fell to a level lower than the lowest reading registered in the recession of 1981-82.
"Consumer confidence in housing is down -- not to an 11-year low, but it is down," said Fabian Linden, executive director of the Conference Board's consumer research center.
Indeed, these are tense times for home buyers, brokers, builders and sellers. Sale prices in the Northeast, in defiance of the old "it-can-only-go-up" axiom, have been falling for two years, making many shoppers and new home owners wonder about the real worth of real estate.
National Association of Realtors figures show that the median price of a one-family home fell from $145,200 in 1989 to $141,200 last year. This year the price dropped from $143,500 in July to $136,700 in October.
J. I. Sopher, the owner of J.I. Sopher & Company, a realty management and consulting firm in Manhattan, estimated that half of the tenants of the Lucerne, a new Upper East Side apartment building, are renters who could and would like to buy a home.
"But they don't know what the bottom of the market is, whether they will be in business tomorrow or what their taxes or assessements will be," he said. "There is more anxiety in the real estate market today than there has been in the history of civilization."
Michael Kanbar, an importer-exporter who lives in the Lucerne, is an example of someone who is hesitant about buying an apartment or house. "I can't decide," he said. "There are some increasing real estate taxes now, and I believe they are are going to be increased again, and that worries me. The overhead is going to be restrictive."
"I also may not live here forever," he said. "You don't have to be based in New York anymore with communications what they are. So in the meantime I'm renting, because I don't know what's happening."
The recent drop in interest rates is generally seen as a strong enticement to buy. The national average for a 30-year adjustable-rate mortgage has fallen from a high of 12.05 percent in July 1984 to 6.44 percent in November, according to HSH Associates in Butler, N.J. The annual interest on a 30-year, fixed mortgage has dropped from 14.74 percent in July 1984 to 8.8 percent in November.
SOME analysts, though, such as Alan Yassky, president of Rockland Realty in Spring Valley, N.Y., and a past regional vice president of the National Realtors Association, have speculated that a declining rate, paradoxically, may dissuade, or at least delay, purchases.
"It is not anxiety as much as a lack of urgency," he said. "As long as interest rates keep coming down, there is that feeling that they may continue to go lower, and the buyer can wait. If the rates went up by 1.5 points then the real estate market would overheat. They would say, 'I had better get in because the rates have hit bottom and now they are moving back up.' "
Nevertheless, low interest rates and falling prices have made an American family's ability to buy a house rise to its highest level in almost 15 years, according to the National Association of Realtors. That group's housing affordability index stood at 118.8 in October, the most recent month for which statistics have been compiled. It was up 2.5 points from 116.3 in September and the highest since March 1977, when it hit 120.7.
An index of 118.8 means that a family earning the national median income of $36,473 had 118.8 percent of the income needed to qualify for a conventional 80 percent mortgage on a home priced at the national median: $99,200.
In the Northeast region, the October index rose 4.8 percentage points from the previous month, to 94.8. That means that a family earning $43,373 had 94.8 percent of the income needed to qualify to buy the median-priced home at $136,700. The index shows that the gap between incomes and the cost of housing is narrowing in the region but still cuts more families out of the home market than in the nation as a whole.
The rate of interest used to compute the index in October -- 9.02 percent, down from 9.17 a month before -- was derived from a report by the Federal Housing Finance Board of closing rates of fixed-rate and adjustable-rate mortgages on existing homes.
"There is an anxiety level out there that is not in accord with the shape of the economy," said David Feldman, a sociologist who has studied the real estate market and also served as the dean of the business school at United States International University in San Diego. "The problem today is lack of faith."
Every buyer must make his own guess at how prices will move, and many are optimistic. One is Jeremy Barbera, the president of a direct-mail marketing company, who is to close Wednesday on a two-bedroom apartment in a brownstone at 70th Street and Central Park West. He paid $325,000. "I think the market has bottomed out, at least in this area" he said.
Fred H. Steckhahn, a vice president of marketing and sales for a health-care company who is looking for a two- or three-bedroom apartment in the Sutton Place or Beekman Place neighborhoods of Manhattan, is equally confident. "If you are going to stay for a while, I don't see how you can go wrong," he said.
He also said that he and his companion are being very patient in their search. "We're looking for a bargain," he said. "If there is anxiety for us, it is whether to buy a wreck and fix it up or go top of the line."
"There is a lot of tire-kicking going on," said Dick Herbert, a broker with William Raveis realty in Greenwich, Conn. "People are taking a lot of things into consideration beyond a look-see and talking to a broker."
Some real estate brokers dismissed buyer anxiety or downplayed it as ordinary caution. "I think there is less anxiety out there, certainly less than was there was two years ago," said Sue W. Kamm, a broker with the William Pitt realty company in Fairfield, Conn. "The corner has been turned."
"People who are buying now are pretty savvy financially -- they know the economic cycles," added Clark P. Halstead, managing partner of the Halstead Property Company in Manhattan. "As J.P. Morgan once said about economic conditions, 'One thing is for sure -- they will change.' "
FOR those still sitting on the fence, though, such sentiments sound like the relentless "now-is-a-good-time-to-buy" boosterism of professionals whose livelihood depends on selling homes. The elderly, in particular, according to studies conducted by Sanford R. Goodkin, a real-estate analyst with the Peat Marwick accounting firm, seem to be the most anxious group when it comes to buying a new home.
"The empty-nester and the retiree have bought homes to preserve the nest egg," Mr. Goodkin said, "but now they are thinking twice because it may turn out to the opposite or they are reading reports that it may be the opposite."
It is not just skepticism about the market or a collapse in confidence about the economy that is slowing sales, however. Many would-be buyers are simply intimidated by banks' stricter credit requirements.
"Why bother -- why go through the hassle?" said Ms. Godfrey, who is 40 years old and served as the president of First Women's Bank from 1985 to 1988. "It is very difficult to get scrutinized to that extent and be turned down, and people are scared to death of being turned down."
There are no statistics available that compare how many mortgage applications have been rejected each year by all lenders. Such data were compiled for the first time in 1990 as part of the Home Mortgage Disclosure Act. They showed rejection rates of 16.6 percent for conventional loans, 16.9 percent for Federal Housing Administration loans, 15 percent for the Veterans Administration and 20 percent for the Farmers Home Administration. Though lenders are quick to note that the much-ballyhooed "credit crunch" is affecting mostly commercial development, they also concede that approval for a loan on an existing home is more difficult than in recent years.
"As a general rule, on residential loans it is a little tighter," said Robert M. O'Toole, senior staff vice president for residential finance at the Mortgage Bankers of America in Washington. "I certainly wouldn't call it a residential credit crunch, but I'd call it a bit of a belt tightening."
Beside fear of rejection, home buyers are often frozen out of the market because they are also sellers who need to unload their own home to complete a deal but won't set a realistic price. "It gets difficult for them to get out of their house," said Richard B. Peiser, dean of the Lusk Center for Real Estate Development at the University of Southern California in Los Angeles. "They don't want to take a loss."
Then there is the so-called "domino effect." This angst-producing phenomenon occurs when buyer A needs to sell a home to buyer B to complete a deal but can't because buyer B backed out, sometimes because B was selling a home to buyer C, who backed out, and so on.
Mr. Higgins said that such a scenario, the last-minute nightmare of many home buyers, had occurred recently to a couple in Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J.
"It was a three-level collapse," he said. "They were upset, to say the least."

HEADLINE: Talking: Co-op Sales;
Avoiding Rejection Litigation

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
WHEN the New York City co-op market started to shake out in the late 1980's, admissions policies were expected to become more relaxed to accommodate struggling sellers.
Moreover, many legislative proposals introduced in the State Assembly to require boards to give reasons for the rejection of a buyer -- and thus make it harder to do so -- were expected to become law. 
 Neither has happened. State and local laws still let boards reject an applicant without giving a reason -- provided it is done in good faith and not because of legally prohibited discrimination based on race, creed, color, national origin, lawful occupation, citizenship status, age, sexual orientation or the presence of children.
Only if the seller or buyer sues the corporation or files a complaint of discrimination with the Human Rights Commission must reasons for the refusal be revealed, said Morton H. Rosen, a lawyer who has handled many such cases.
Brokers report that in some instances it has become even harder to get a prospective buyer approved. A major cause has been a rise in the number of shareholders not making timely maintenance payments.
Barbara Corcoran, president of the Corcoran Group, a Manhattan real estate agency, said more boards are scrutinizing the reliability, as well as size, of a family's income. "They're much more comfortable if someone has a salary from a large corporation than if they're getting most of their money from bonuses or commissions," she said.
Some assets, such as other real estate, don't carry as much weight as substantial liquid assets, she added.
Even so, boards must be aware that the rejection of a prospective buyer is increasingly likely to result in a suit, irrespective of the reason, because the desperate sellers are more likely to face substantial losses in contrast to the old days when they might have got even more from a subsequent buyer.
Moreover, boards have a fiduciary responsibility to the sellers as shareholders, which they do not have to buyers, said Mr. Rosen.
Consider Straus v. 345 East 73d Street Owners Corporation, currently before the Appellate Division. William A. Straus, the former owner of a one-bedoom apartment at the Upper East Side building is claiming he lost $82,000 because his original buyer was rejected without lawful cause and it took him eight months longer to sell. The co-op claims justification on the ground that the buyer had refused to abide by the co-op's limitations on the maximum number of permitted occupants. A lower court upheld Mr. Straus' argument, but the co-op has appealed.
Consider, also, the potential suit that arrived on the desk of Errol Brett, a Manhattan lawyer, recently and that is to be filed against an East Side co-op by a seller who says that three prospective buyers -- all of whom he insists were financially qualified -- were turned down when they tried to buy his $1.3 million apartment. As a result, the unit has been on the market more than a year and each time someone makes a bid the negotiated price falls a little more. The seller claims that all three applicants were rejected because they had children.
All of which leaves an admissions committee walking a thin line trying to protect its co-op at a time of economic stress while seeking to avoid potential suits by sellers.
Under such difficult circumstances lawyers suggest several strategies. Mr. Brett advises his co-op clients to give a reason each time they reject anyone so there is less room for misinterpreration or festering resentment. But he also warns them not to be paranoid over finances since lenders are getting more restrictive, too. If a lender has approved a loan, he said, it is unlikely the applicant is as marginal as the board might suspect.
FURTHER, he warned against acquiring a reputation among brokers as a "difficult" building since this could affect other shareholders trying to sell. And this could lead to even more trouble collecting maintenance in future if the sellers run into financial diffficulties or abandon their apartments.
When in doubt about the financial stability of a potential buyer, he said, a board might be consider seeking auxiliary assurances. These could include asking a buyer to put a year or two's maintenance in escrow or to have the contract or an agreement co-signed by a better-heeled parent or other relative.
Lawyers say admissions committees should still feel free to ask "life style" questions.
"You can still ask someone if they would be able to serve on a board," said Mr. Rosen, who represents 85 buildings. "Or if they will be using the apartment for parties on a regular basis?. Or even what kind of pet they have and whether they might need to sublet a lot."
A small brownstone co-op with a limited number of potential volunteers, he said, would have a perfect right to reject someone who clearly had no time to serve.
However, a co-op could run afoul of the state's 1983 roommate law, he warned, if someone was turned down because the applicant admitted that a "friend" might also be occupying the unit. Thus he advises checking with a lawyer before providing any reason for rejection.
Sellers, meanwhile, should not remain passive onlookers. They can also help the applicant by learning more about the attitude of their admissions committee and trying to help the seller deflect or overcome any difficulties in advance.
Nathan Fridman, president of Nu-Place Realty of Kew Gardens, Queens, finds that buyers who have never owned a co-op may object to some questions as too intrusive. "They need to be carefully prepared," he said, "or they could become curt or angry during the interview." This in itself could become a reason for rejection, he warned, noting that nobody likes to have someone around who is antisocial or a possible troublemaker.
Ms. Corcoran said it was common for sellers not to list all their assets when first requested to do so by the board -- and for boards to reach a conclusion based on the assumption that everything had been committed to paper. And once a decision is reached it is virtually impossible to have the matter reopened. Thus sellers might delicately make the point that withholding mention of certain assets might make a critical difference between acceptance and rejection -- especially when boards remain so concerned about solvency.

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (91%);

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

Transferring Rent Rights
 
Question: A new Chinese restaurant opened in an annex of my building. A large ventilation system has been installed on the roof directly in front of my kitchen windows. The noise and smells make me nauseous and give me headaches. The new landlord has offered to move me to another apartment in the building. Would I lose my status as a rent-controlled tenant if I moved? . . . Estelle Kochan, Manhattan 
 Answer: No. According to Joseph D'Agosta, an assistant commissioner with the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal, the agency would recognize any voluntary agreement between you and your landlord maintaining your rent-control status.
"The tenant could continue as a rent-controlled tenant with the same rent and rights and protections," said Mr. D'Agosta.
If you decide to move, make sure there is a written agreement affirming the maintenance of your rent status beforehand. A copy of this agreement should be sent to the housing agency so that it can change its records and also to protect your situation in case of a dispute. It should be sent to Rohan James, Individual Owner Unit, Gertz Plaza, 92-31 Union Hall Street, Jamaica, N.Y. 11433.
 
Problem With Pigeons
 
Question: We are having a serious problem with pigeons that goes beyond the way our building looks. We believe it is a serious health threat. Is there a way to clean up the problem that is legal and inexpensive? . . . Robert McGill, Flushing, Queens
 
Answer: Yes, but extermination is not an option because it is against the law to kill pigeons. You can set traps so they can be moved to another location or you can discourage roosting and feeding by using a repellent or barrier.
"It is also important to find the cause of the problem," said Edward Boyce, director of Veterinary Public Health Services for the city's Health Department. "It might be that someone in the area is feeding the birds, which is against the law."
Pigeon removal services can be found in the Yellow Pages under bird repellents and controls. For more information call the Health Department's general information number: 212-285-9503.
 
Building Air Vents
 
Question: My 30-year-old high-rise building was built with vents instead of windows in the kitchens and bathrooms. These vents are connected by ducts to rooftop exhaust fans. Due to complaints about excessive wind noise -- especially on the high floors -- the exhaust fans are turned off between midnight and 5 A.M. Is this permissible under New York City law? . . . George Steinberg, Brooklyn
 
Answer: Only in part. According to Roz Post, a spokeswoman for the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, the city has rules specifying the times that vents can be turned off. The vents that operate in kitchens must be open 24 hours but the vents that circulate air in bathrooms may be shut down from midnight to 6 A.M.
 
Hallway Smoke Detectors
 
Question: Tenant shareholders in our co-op have written to the board because we want to install smoke detectors on each apartment floor. There has been no response after 18 months. Can we install them ourselves? . . . Nadine Keller, Flushing, Queens
 
Answer: No. You would need the permission of the board to make additions or changes in the building's common areas. According to John J. Hodgens, acting chief for fire prevention for the Fire Department, the law requires that there be a at least one smoke detector in each dwelling unit. Detectors are not mandated for the corridors of apartment buildings but Chief Hodgens said that they would provide an extra measure of safety against fires that originate in corridors and stairwells.

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
For Churches, the Bells Now Toll 'Build'

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
MENTION Connecticut and a town green comes to mind, complete with a pristine white clapboard church at one end, its spire rising above other buildings. Its simplicity bespeaks the old New England virtues of piety, modesty and thrift.
Most of these churches are Congregational and the parishes date to the 17th century, when church and state were intertwined. To form a town, settlers first had to form a church. Today there are 270 Congregational churches in 168 of Connecticut's 169 towns. (only Waterford is without one). 
 Along with other denominations, dozens of them are starting building programs to accommodate growth in income-producing outreach programs, increased Sunday school enrollments for baby-boomer children and historic preservation.
In typical New England fashion, they are seizing the opportunity to do so at a time when costs are down, and in the process they are providing architects and construction workers with much-needed income.
"Any buyer of such services is not going to find a better time to go forward than now," said Charles Grove, executive director of the Associated General Contractors of Connecticut in Wallingford. "Bids are coming in at 10 percent less than estimated costs."
Churches seem able to raise money in spite of the economic downturn, according to Frederick Biebesheimer, architect for a $200,000 addition to the Ledyard Congregational Church, built in 1740. "They obtain pledges from parishioners," he said. The pledges serve as collateral for bank loans and are due in three to five years. "Banks look favorably on church loans because they rarely default," he said.
"All the major buildings in Old Lyme were built during recessions," said Audrey Philcox, associate minister of the town's Congregational Church. Its 800 members will vote this month on plans for a $1.5 million addition and renovation. "We have outgrown our Sunday school space, and the auditorium only holds about 11 percent of the congregation," she said.
Founded in 1665, the church has been rebuilt four times as a result of fires or growth. The last reconstruction, in 1907, cost about $50,000, divided among 187 parishioners who paid $270 each. The cost per member for current renovations will be $1,870.
Current church school expansion follows a pattern of public school expansion over the last three years at the elementary level. "People are having children again," said the Rev. Fred Coulter of the Ledyard Congregational Church. "Our Sunday school has tripled in size."
While population shifts from southwestern Connecticut into the rest of the state account for increases in some congregations, church membership statewide is static, according to the Connecticut Council of Churches in Hartford, but outreach programs are growing.
"Churches are learning that a building used only a couple of days a week is not cost-effective," said Susan Chandler, historical architect of the Connecticut Historical Commission in Hartford. "They are opening up to Alcoholics Anonymous, community day care, soup kitchens, homeless accommodations, concerts, lectures and sharing space with minority congregations with no facilities."
The need for physical facilities has generated a marked increase in calls to Ms. Chandler and Judy Edwards, executive vice president of the Connecticut Society of Architects, from churches planning additions.
Richard Bergmann, a New Canaan architect, is designing a 10,000-square-foot-addition to St. Peter's Lutheran Church in Norwalk, doubling its space at an estimated cost of $1.5 million. He recently completed a renovation at the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien, where a chapel was provided for a Korean Presbyterian congregation that had no home of its own.
IN New Milford, the 158-year-old Congregational Church on the Green is seeking to raise $800,000 to rebuild the deteriorating steeple and to bring the building up to current codes for fire, safety and access for the disabled. At least $200,000 of that is to be raised among townspeople who are not members of the congregation, on the premise that the church is a historic landmark and an important community asset.
In Middletown, $675,000 was raised to restore the steeple of South Church, built in 1860. "If it isn't fixed, you will be looking at an uglier Main Street," was the admonition used last year to whip up community support by Ann Street, director of the Greater Middletown Preservation Trust. She organized a conference on stewardship of historic religious properties, which 140 people from around the state attended on Nov. 2.
To prepare for it, she visited several churches, which she described as "huge physical plants with gross underutilization of space, or if used, not paying their way." Churches, she said, "feel they must offer space free to anyone who wants to use it."
"Maybe they get a $35 fee," she said, "which doesn't begin to cover janitorial services, heat and electricity."
Putting a day-care center into a historical building, she continued, "requires more than buying a bunch of toys."
"There are codes and regulations regarding parking, egress, handicap access, fire safety," she said. "Ninety percent of the people who use churches for other than religious purposes don't pay anything toward support of the property."
The laws governing church and state probably need rethinking, Ms. Street concluded. "Churches may need to operate some facilities as profit centers," she said. "It may be a reasonable trade-off to having churches pay some taxes."
In Stamford, St. John's Episcopal Church receives a substantial six-figure income on the lease of its land to Canterbury Green, a residential and office complex built in the mid-1980's.
"The money helps us survive," said Craig Ferguson, former church treasurer. Its tax-exempt status is preserved by limiting use of the funds to maintenance of church property and social programs.
Doreen Fundiller-Zweig, a tax specialist at the Hartford law firm of Robinson & Cole, said that "many tax-exempt institutions such as hospitals and universities set up taxable affiliates engaged in activities that provide income for the institutions."
"The leasing of land by churches is looked upon by the Internal Revenue Service as a passive, tax-exempt investment," she said. "If churches engage in taxable, profit-making ventures they may be perceived by existing businesses as unfair competition because of their tax exemptions. Nevertheless, I think this is the trend."

HEADLINE: DINING OUT;
Savory French Fare Unseats Nouvelle

BYLINE: By PATRICIA BROOKS

 BODY:
IT has been four years since Bertrand first opened its doors in Greenwich. At the time the food was often ambrosial, and our major caveat was about service lapses that seemed surprising in a place otherwise so professional. Recently we decided to venture back to see how this excellent French restaurant, whose prices were in the expense account stratosphere, was faring in these difficult economic times.
Superficially, nothing has changed. The restaurant is as sparklingly well-kept as it was when opened. The restaurant, which is in a building dating from 1917, has an interior that blends brick columns and arches with vaulted ceilings of golden-toned Guastavino ceramic tiles as well as apricot-hued walls, brass sconces emitting soft lighting, polished brass railings leading to the most appealing second tier dining area and mirrors with ornate bronzed frames. Banks of fresh chrysanthemums separate two sections of the upper level, and fresh flowers are on each impeccably groomed table. An atrium on the lower dining level makes this a good lunchtime choice. 
 The French menu is as appetite sparking as ever, though the imaginative flourishes of its former nouvelle creativity seem to have given way to slightly more predictable classic fare. As for service, it was prompt and flawless except for the server who brought our entrees and had to ask who got each dish.
We were also surprised that the long list of special appetizers and entrees was recited, with detailed descriptions of each dish. Where is the printed list of daily specials so many other fine restaurants have adopted?
As for the food, there were almost no misses, from the mildly spiced sausage en croute served before dinner, to the bite-size petits fours served with coffee at meal's end. In between we savored a starter of cassolette of bay scallops with basil, tomatoes and garlic in a succulently herbed sauce. Another cassolette, of crabmeat and shrimp with saffron and coriander, was equally savory. As a cold hors d'oeuvre, nothing topped the terrine of superlative foie gras -- a rosy, exquisitely textured and flavored slice, with its own gelee, served with a slice of duck pate en croute and its natural gelee. A rousing $20, it justified the splurge.
Also worth attention was a terrine of herbed goat cheese, served with lightly mixed salads. Only the lasagna of tuna was questionable; one of the layers of fish, alternating with the al dente pasta, was suspiciously strong.
The entrees we tried were all first-rate -- as well they should be at Bertrand prices, which hover at or near the top of the dining scale (though portions seem larger than in the past).
Among the entrees, veal chop stuffed with wild mushrooms and spinach in a sauce of natural juices, accompanied by pureed sweet potatoes, was expertly prepared, as was roast saddle of rabbit sliced into attractive ovals, each piece adorned with fresh basil and chopped tomato, served with a cake of grilled noodles rife with wild mushrooms. Civet of venison was a classic, a ragout of venison chunks, tiny potato rounds and onions, plus several kinds of mushrooms, in a luscious red wine sauce. Confit of duck in a peppercorn sauce, served with wild rice, was as perfect as we remembered it.
Desserts are almost de rigueur at Bertrand. In addition to a memorable passion fruit souffle (one of six hot souffles that must be ordered at the same time as dinner) there was a splendid warm apple tart in a chocolate-flecked caramel sauce. Chocolate shortcake in a delectible pistachio sauce, profligate with chopped nuts and chocolate swirls, was also a triumph, but a plate of sorbets made on the premises more than held its own and made a refreshing finale to a substantial meal. The raspberry, passion fruit and cassis flavors were intense, enhanced by fresh raspberries, strawberries and slices of honeydew melon.
A three-course dinner for two came to $103.50 before tax, tip and drinks. The wine list, with selections from French and American vineyards, is well-chosen and fairly priced. Though Bertrand is expensive, it is as exemplary as when it opened in 1987. Bertrand has two four-course prix-fixe theme dinners, on Dec. 19 ($38) and Dec. 26 ($40); such prices are an attempt to cope, no doubt, with the current economy.
 
Bertrand
Excellent
253 Greenwich Avenue (between Havemeyer Place and Railroad Avenue), Greenwich. 661-4618, 661-4459.
Atmosphere: Two small, elegant dining areas on two floors of a former bank building; pale apricot walls, ceramic-tiled ceiling, brick arches and columns, skylight, banks of fresh flowers.
Service: Smooth, generally professional.
Recommended dishes: Terrine of fresh foie gras, cassolette of bay scallops, cassolette of crabmeat, terrine of goat cheese, civet of venison, stuffed veal chop, roast saddle of rabbit, confit of duck, plate of sorbets, chocolate shortcake with pistachio sauce, passion fruit souffle, warm apple tart.
Price range: Lunch entrees $17 to $22.50, prix-fixe three-course lunch $25, dinner entrees $19 to $28.
Credit cards: All major cards.
Hours: Noon to 2:30 P.M. Monday through Friday, 6 to 10 P.M. Monday through Saturday. Closed Sunday.
Reservations: Recommended.
Wheelchair accessibility: Ground-level entrance to bar, four steps to first dining level, more stairs to major dining room.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Rush Hour Fees Urged for Flights

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
There may be slightly fewer rush-hour flights and consequently fewer and shorter delays -- at some major airports following the Transportation Department's suggestion last month that congested airports impose surcharges on planes using the runways at the busiest times of day. The question for travelers is whether the new guidelines will also mean much higher ticket prices for those who take off or land at busy times of day.
The department's proposed "peak hour" surcharges would mainly affect flights in the early morning and early evening. The idea is that the high costs would encourage airlines to divert flights to other time slots, smoothing out the flow of traffic and cutting down on delays. Officials said that even shifting a handful of flights can make a substantial difference in delays. 
 The department is not requiring this change. It is merely outlining for airports what kinds of charges would not be viewed as discriminatory or as impeding interstate commerce and thus be acceptable to the Government. Some airports officials have said that only the assumption of Government opposition was preventing them from imposing rush-hour charges.
Because the fees would be divided among hundreds of passengers on large jets, according to Clifford Winston, an airline economist at the Brookings Institution who has advocated such charges, they might amount to only $10 a ticket, probably not enough to make those customers change their flying times. After all, as the airlines point out, ticket prices already tend to be discounted in nonpeak periods.
But when applied to small planes, such as those used by commuter airlines, the fees might prevent flying at rush hour, Mr. Winston said. For most private pilots and users of corporate jets, the extra fees would be prohibitive. With the smaller planes out of the way, he said, the flow of heavier jets should be much smoother.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Can a Rebound Turn Into a Rally?

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
In recent years, investors in the United States have increasingly been advised to diversify their portfolios by buying stocks overseas. But Americans who invested abroad at the beginning of 1991 probably are finding it would have been better to keep the money at home.
Most of the bad news for overseas investors occurred very late in the year, although some stock markets seemed to be bouncing off the bottom last week, in the wake of a rally on Wall Street. 
 In London, the Financial Times index of 100 leading stocks rose 71.4 points, or 3 percent, on Thursday and Friday. And in Tokyo, where the Nikkei index of 225 leading stocks closed just points above its 1991 low on Wednesday, the index climbed 1,042.33 points, or 4.8 percent, on Friday. Stock markets also rallied in Norway, where the market hit three-year lows at the beginning of the month, and even in Germany, which has been stubbornly sluggish most of the year.
Looking back, the undoing of the Soviet Union has sent ripples though stock markets all year. The Persian Gulf War turned out to be a help, pulling markets out of the slide that began with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
But the expectations for a moderate economic recovery in the United States turned out to be overly optimistic. The disappointing American growth, in turn, seemed to heighten the worry about the faster-than-expected slowdowns in economies abroad. And though stock markets generally do not slavishly follow Wall Street's lead, it seems they are waiting for a signal from that source now.

 According to the Financial Times world index, European markets as a whole are up just 4.1 percent in dollar terms since the beginning of the year. Japan is up only 5.9 percent, even with Friday's surge.
Investors who decided a year ago to keep their money at home seem smart now, with the American market up 17.5 percent in the world index.
The only markets really revving up have been outliers, like Mexico, which is up 109.5 percent; Hong Kong, up 40.4 percent; South Africa, up 36.0 percent; Singapore, up 29.4 percent, and Australia, up 25.6 percent. They have been propelled by factors distinct to their own economies, and some have been good choices for American investors because their currencies are tied directly to the dollar, so they were not hurt by fluctuations in that currency.
Investing overseas looked a lot easier earlier in the year, even though the dollar was stronger and world markets suffered a sharp downturn in January as the deadline for the Persian Gulf War approached. In the first 16 days of the year, European markets fell 6.7 percent, on top of a decline of more than 18 percent between Aug. 2, 1990, the day of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, and the end of last year, according to the Financial Times index.
But by early March, the euphoria over the success of the Allied effort in the Persian Gulf had helped to push the Financial Times index of European markets up 12.6 percent in dollar terms, the high for the year. In September, the European markets hit their 1991 high in local currencies: a gain of 20.6 percent through Sept. 2.
Japan's market reached its high point in dollar terms in February, up 17.8 percent, and in local terms, up 17.1 percent, in March.
As a whole, the Financial Times's index of world markets is up 10.4 percent in dollar terms so far this year. But that is just two thirds of what the gain was when the index reached its high for the year just over a month ago, right before the American market took its big tumble on Nov. 15.
The lost gains seem even more dramatic in terms of local stock market indexes, which are in the home currency and have a different blend of stocks than the Financial Times index. By this measure all the stock markets in the Group of Seven are below their highs by about 50 percent or more -- except in the United States.
In Germany, the Dax index of 30 leading shares is up 11.5 percent for the year, after rallying to a 23 percent gain at its high. In Canada, the Toronto index of 300 shares is up only 3.2 percent after an 11 percent high. In Japan, the market was up 14 percent at its peak but then was down 10 percent until the Friday rally, which leaves it down 4.6 percent for the year. The CAC index of 40 shares in France has fallen sharply recently and is now up 11.2 percent for the year after reaching a peak gain of 24 percent.
In Britain, the FT-SE 100 index reached an all-time high in September, putting it up 25 percent for the year. But that gain has now shrunk to 14.4 percent. In Italy, the 20 percent gain seen in June has evaporated. The Banca Commerciale Italiana index is now down 4.6 percent for the year.
For the American investing abroad, the dollar's performance has been important. Its rise against European currencies contributed to the lackluster performance there. But it fell against the yen, helping turn losses into gains. And if the dollar, which was up about 25 percent against the German mark this year, had not fallen sharply recently, the small gains would probably have been losses.
In Europe, the dollar is still up about 10 percent against the mark and that was enough to cut the stock gains, when they are translated back into dollars, to 4.1 percent in dollars from 10.6 percent in local terms by the end of last week.
Right now, the outlook for next year is not great. While the recent declines would suggest there are bargains available, the list of negatives is hard to ignore. Among the problems: high interest rates in Europe and no likelihood of an easing soon; worries about the recovery in Britain and the United States and the slowdowns elsewhere in Europe and in Japan; downgrades in estimates of corporate earnings almost everywhere because of the sour economies, and worries about the course of events in the former Soviet Union, which have a dramatic impact in Germany.
In addition, there is the dollar. If the American economy does begin to recover and confidence rebounds, the dollar is likely to begin to rise again. And that would cut into profits when investments overseas are turned back into dollars.
In its most recent world investment report, Goldman Sachs takes a view that blends advice to practice restraint with the need to sell stocks. The firm concludes:
"There are good reasons for believing that equities might underperform in the short term, including the possibility that markets are likely to remain nervous about the economy. However, investors might consider that equities do well in January, that it pays to buy undervalued markets in January and that by being out of the market now, investors could miss a significant up side."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Inflation: Just What America Needs

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
In 1933, with the country in a deep depression, J. P. Morgan the younger, then unquestionably the most important banker in the country, was called to testify at a Congressional hearing that in some ways resembled an inquisition.
Reading the transcript of Mr. Morgan's testimony nearly six decades later provides proof that, if nothing else, this economic downturn is not going to be a rerun of that Depression. 
 The politicians then, as now, were concerned about the way bankers decided who should be able to borrow money. One answer from Mr. Morgan stands out. "Do you make any loans on real estate?" asked Senator Duncan U. Fletcher, a Florida Democrat. "We never have," replied the banker. "You do not make any?" inquired the amazed Senator. "No," said Mr. Morgan.
In those days, bankers believed that real estate was too illiquid, and its value too subject to possible declines, to be suitable collateral for loans from a top-flight bank. By the 1980's, such attitudes were incomprehensible to bankers. But, first in Texas and then in Boston and New York, bankers have learned just how soft a real estate appraisal can be. Now San Francisco's Wells Fargo is getting the message.
The fact that Wells Fargo had some bad news to disclose was not exactly a surprise. Weakness in the California economy has been well publicized, and California bank stocks have been slipping since Labor Day. So the first Wall Street reaction was a sigh of relief that the bad news was out, and a wave of bargain hunting. Wells Fargo stock went up $3.25 a share.
Having bought the stock, the clever traders sat down to actually look at the numbers, and on Friday the share price plunged $5.50, to $55, the lowest close since January. It did not help that Standard & Poor's, warning that "the impact of the recession on California is worse than previously forecast," cut the state's bond rating.
Wells Fargo's problems illustrate why the recession has lingered. The basic problem is not just that companies and workers are earning less. It is that assets are worth less than they were supposed to be. The solution, it would appear, is to get assets to be worth more. Unfortunately, neither a stimulative monetary policy, which has been tried for a year, nor a stimulative fiscal policy, which Washington seems to be about to try, directly addresses that problem. What is needed is a little well-placed inflation.
Stock traders are still willing to bet that something will work -- and soon -- to get the economy growing and end the wave of layoffs. Share prices recovered last week following the report that November retail sales were not so bad, and as word spread that the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index had stabilized. Perhaps Christmas will be a decent one after all, as millions of consumers decide that things aren't so bad that they can't buy gifts. Now if they would just start bidding up real estate prices.

The New York Times

 

PUB-DATE: December 15, 1991

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1717 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/December 8-13

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Wells Fargo Battens Down the Hatches for a Lingering Slump 

When times are tough, it is not return on capital that's important, its return of capital. That's the problem Wells Fargo & Company, the big California bank, is facing. Last week it set aside $700 million for loan losses from its large portfolio of real estate loans (they make up 28.1 percent of its outstanding loans, the largest percentage of any major bank). Carl Reichardt, the bank's chief executive, said in a statement that "in this environment it is only prudent to make a significant addition to our loan loss reserves." California's economy (its bonds were downgraded last week) is the reason for the losses. "It is a year behind New England," said Jeff Thredgold, chief economist at Keycorp Inc., a banking company in Albany. Though shallower than New England's slump, California's is likely to last longer -- especially in real estate. "Seven of the 10 largest development projects in the nation are in Los Angeles," Mr. Thredgold said.

 
Orion's Hits Aren't Enough
 
The Orion Pictures Corporation has had some winners this year -- "Dances With Wolves" and "Silence of the Lambs" -- but neither generated enough revenue to keep the company from filing for bankruptcy protection last week under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code. The studio, which is controlled by the billionaire John Kluge, missed an interest payment of $17.4 million last summer on its subordinated notes and debentures and was unable to pay $50 million of principal due Aug. 31. Talks with creditors about restructuring about $700 million in debt fizzled. Orion has postponed the release of several films that had already been shot. "We have taken this step," said William Bernstein, Orion's president, "because our discussions with the bondholders have broken down." Orion will try once more to restructure itself.


Trying to Be More Like Pan Am
 
Capitalists, by nature, are an optimistic bunch. That's why one restaurant opens after another just closed at the same location. It's also why the bidding was so fierce last week for the Latin American routes of defunct Pan American World Airways. Though Pan Am, encumbered by debt, couldn't make a go of it, American, United and Delta Airlines were sure they could. What was supposed to be a one-day auction conducted by Judge Cornelius Blackshear of the United States Bankruptcy Court, lasted two days. In the end, United Airlines won Pan Am's routes. It will pay $160 million in cash and hire 1,000 former Pan Am employees. (American bid $155 million.) There is a gleam in United's eye because it is now America's only global carrier with routes to Asia, the Pacific, Latin America and Europe, a route structure not unlike Pan Am's -- in the old days.
 
 
Talk about optimists. Carl C. Icahn, who owns ailing Trans World Airlines, and Robert R. Ferguson 3d, president of bankrupt Continental Airlines, began talks last week about merging their carriers. Mr. Icahn initiated the talks, Continental said.

 
Back to Pizza Again
 
Last week, Thomas Monaghan re-emerged after what was called a "religious reawakening" to take control of the daily operations of Domino's Pizza Inc. Two years ago, Mr. Monaghan left Domino's to devote himself to religious studies and charity work. He put the company on the block -- he owns 99 percent of its stock -- for $1.2 billion, but found no buyers. While he was away, profits slipped. Domino's had sales of $2.65 billion at its franchise stores and company revenues of $1.2 billion, but it delivered profits of only $5.4 million last year. Those slim profits -- and Mr. Monaghan's faith -- brought him back to pizza making. Though he has vowed to improve the quality of Domino's pizza, at least twice a week, Mr. Monaghan eats nothing but bread and water. "God will help him find his way," said Mike Jenkins, Domino's public relations director.
 

TRW Tries to Shape Up
 
They called it a "service-sector recession." The Middle West, with its manufacturing and export-oriented industries, was about all that kept growth positive. But last week, TRW Inc., the big Cleveland-based industrial company that makes, among other things, air bags, truck axles, brakes and communications satellites, said it was restructuring. TRW will sell businesses worth $400 million to $500 million; cut capital spending by more than $100 million next year (about 16 percent) and lay off 2,500 employees. The company will take a $250 million after-tax charge in the current quarter. "It's grabbing the bull by the horns," said Howard A. Rubel, an analyst at C. J. Lawrence. TRW's stock gained $2.875 on the annoucement to reach $40, and closed the week at $38.25.


Xerox and the American Dream
 
The Xerox Corporation is America in microcosm. It created a new industry from scratch -- plain-paper copying -- got rich and, well, got a little lazy. Xerox lost market share to Japan. Xerox -- like America -- fought back. It grew leaner, improved its quality and buffed up its image. It even won back market share from Japan. But last week Xerox acknowledged it has been hurt by the recession and must trim down. So the company will cut its payroll by 2,500 and reduce its costs by $150 million next year and $200 million in 1993. It will take a $175 million pretax charge against earnings. "It's a first step in the right direction," said Curt Rohrman who follows Xerox for First Boston.
 
 
 
ECONOMY

 
Tax Credit With a Pedigree
 
The Administration has seized upon an economic idea with an interesting pedigree. Last week, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, told the Senate Finance Committee that to get the economy rolling, the Administration might favor a tax credit for businesses that invest in plants and machinery. "The history of investment tax credits is that they are somewhat effective and maybe for that reason we ought to do it at this time," Mr. Brady told the Senate Finance Committee. Such a credit existed until 1986, when the tax code was revised. But lately, the chief proponent of the credit is not a conservative Republican at all. New York Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, a Democrat, has been touting the investment tax credit in speeches since May.

 
Sad Showing at Retail
 
For the nation's retailers, the holidays are usually the best season. If only that were the case now. Cautious consumers are wandering the malls, but they are hardly spending. Retail sales rose just three-tenths of 1 percent in November, the Commerce Department said last week. Those gains come after a downward revision of retail spending for October. "The November retail sales figures confirm that the holiday shopping season was slow getting out of the blocks," said John M. Albertine, a Washington economics consultant. Not only that, but inventories grew last month by 1.5 percent, the Government said. That's not supposed to happen around the holidays.
 

Bright News on Inflation
 
A slow economy keeps prices stable. Only business naifs and the auto companies would dare raise prices when the goods don't move. So it was no surprise when the Labor Department reported last week that prices at the producer level rose a slim two-tenths of 1 percent in November.


Spikes in Consumer Prices
 
At first the figures looked worse than they were. The Consumer Price Index rose by 0.4 percent in November, the Labor Department said. But on closer examination, there were just three major culprits. The first was the whitefly infestation in California. Those tiny insects, munching on produce that's still in the fields, have damaged crops and driven food prices higher. Then there were rises in the prices of prescription drugs and of gasoline. Consumer prices have risen just 2.9 percent so far this year.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Detroit, Meet Tokyo
 
Next month, when President Bush visits Japan, he will have some unusual traveling companions: Lee Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, and Harold Poling, chairman of the Ford Motor Company. Robert Stempel, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, is still mulling over the invitation. Mr. Bush and the automakers will go to Japan, Mr. Iacocca said, to make Tokyo realize America is serious about trade. The United States and Japan have been talking seriously about trade since 1978. Last month, Japan's trade surplus nearly tripled, to $6.56 billion from $2.24 billion a year earlier. More than half of that surplus -- $3.59 billion -- resulted from trade with the United States.


Britain's Escape Plan
 
Unifying Europe has not been easy. It took 2,000 years of warfare to determine today's borders (more or less) and 30 years of talks to decide on how to dissolve them. Last week at Maastricht, the Netherlands, the Community's 12 heads of state outlined the next step in the unification process -- the creation of a single currency and a central bank to manage it by 1999. But the British have been extremely reluctant about giving up control of their currency. So Prime Minister John Major of Britain accepted the plan -- but with a caveat. Britain reserves the right to opt out of the single-currency scheme any time before January 1997. To appease British sensibilities, the communique that was issued omitted what was referred to as the F-word -- federalism. Britain, you see, is a nation, not simply one of a dozen states.
 
 
Copying the Community
 
While Western Europe was unifying, the Soviet Union was becoming unglued. Last week Russia's President, Boris N. Yeltsin, and the leaders of Ukraine and Byelorussia, replaced the union with a new commonwealth. The republics will use the ruble as their common currency, defend themselves jointly and harmonize their economies. Five Asian republics joined the commonwealth last week. That leaves the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, "a king without a country," said Vladimir Kvint, a lecturer at Babson College. In the new commonwealth, "the relationships between the republics will be like the relationship between countries in the European Community," he said. That is a remarkable transformation. All that's needed now is a workable economic plan. Some things remain the same.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Restoring Loyalty to the Workplace

BYLINE: By MICHAEL MASTANDUNO and RAYMOND VERNON; Michael Mastanduno is assistant professor of government at Dartmouth College. Raymond Vernon is emeritus professor of international affairs at Harvard University.

 BODY:
As United Nations inspectors scour Iraq in a desperate hunt for contraband and nuclear materials, Washington is abuzz with schemes to insure that future Saddam Husseins don't turn up on the world stage. The coming debate over the lapsed Export Administration Act will enable members of Congress and the Administration to offer their plans, and high on the list will be proposals for the United States to impose even tighter export controls.
Yet as we approach the first anniversary of the gulf war, one lesson that every policy maker should have absorbed is this: Export controls are no panacea. Such controls, especially unilateral ones, have proved inadequate against the determined efforts of governments to develop a capacity for the mass destruction of their neighbors. 
 During the 1980's, Saddam Hussein managed to obtain -- from many suppliers -- sensitive technologies and more than $40 billion in military equipment. During the Cold War, despite history's most prolonged and ambitious system of export controls, the Soviet Union designed and produced tens of thousands of nuclear warheads and created a formidable conventional capability.
If export controls are to be effective, they must be focused narrowly and have multilateral support. American controls against the Soviet Union, for instance, were most successful when coordinated with other countries and targeted at technologies with clear military significance. Compare this with Washington's first moves after the gulf war. To control the spread of biological and chemical warfare capabilities, it tried to ban anything -- even trucks and typewriters -- that seemed destined for use at such facilities. And, according to current plans, export licenses are required for anything an exporter "knows" will contribute to development of lethal weapons. The House's version of the legislation contains some control proposals that are similarly comprehensive -- and equally unlikely to win multilateral support.
Measures like these play well in Peoria. The Government gives the appearance of leaving no stone unturned as it tries to bottle up gruesome technologies and punish companies that trade with the enemy. And the Administration knows that nobody wants to be accused of promoting the spread of chemical and biological weapons -- least of all an American exporter who might one day need the support of regulators.
Yet such measures actually do great mischief. They undermine the chances of establishing a system of deterrents that may really count. And, with enterprises and technology moving easily across borders, they invite American producers to move their facilities elsewhere. They also weaken the United States economy and saddle exporters with the stigma of being unreliable.
For 40 years, the United States has led the world in the zealous use of export restrictions, with efforts that, at times, have seemed ludicrous. These efforts have included attempts in the 50's to control the export of machetes and mosquito netting to suppress agrarian rebels in Latin America, and efforts in the 70's and 80's to restrain the export of personal computers and oilfield equipment in the Soviet Union. At times, other nations have been greedy and irresponsible in resisting sensible American appeals for their cooperation. Just as often, their resistance has been based on the conviction that the American proposals were futile, misguided and counterproductive.
Export controls should be used more as a scalpel than as a wrecking ball. They cannot produce results when sources of supply are numerous and the products are common commodities.
The key ingredient for maintaining peace in the modern world is nurturing and strengthening a consensus worth maintaining. Such a consensus was an indispensable element in NATO's success in containing the Soviet Union and in the success of Desert Storm in containing Iraq. Any policy that weakens the chances of building and maintaining such a consensus -- such as the indiscriminate use of export restrictions -- must be curbed.

LENGTH: 1140 words

HEADLINE: The Executive Computer;
Hands Off the Keys, Noses Into Books

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
Not long ago, as part of a national survey, an advertising agency asked computer industry engineers and managers about their favorite leisure activities.
Among those who responded, reading (18 percent) was by far the most popular choice, with golf (5 percent) a distant second. Other pastimes included: being with the family, travel, music, computer hacking and fishing (all 4 percent); woodworking and gardening (3 percent each), and sex (1 percent). 
 So, without drawing any conclusions from the data, here are some suggestions for reading material and gifts.
"Cyberspace: First Steps" ($24.95, Massachusetts Institute of Technology Press, Boston) is an anthology of essays and musings on one of the most exciting, exotic and least understood frontiers of computing.
The term cyberspace, popularized in William Gibson's science fiction novel "Neuromancer," refers to the ephemeral otherworld that exists in the global electronic web of computer and communications networks. Although it has its genesis in science fiction, it is a mistake to conclude that it has no significance in the business world.
If information is indeed the oil of the 21st century, computers are the refineries and networks are the the pipelines. Many companies, especially banks and other financial institutions, exist in the electronic twilight of computer systems. What is the essence of a bank, after all, if not a flow of data?
Michael Benedikt, a professor of architecture at the University of Texas and editor of the book, refers to cyberspace as an "elusive and future thing," and it remains elusive at the conclusion of the book. Yet the descriptions offered in the book are compelling. The writers work at companies and institutions including the International Business Machines Corporation, Electronic Data Systems, Texas Instruments, Bull Worldwide Information Systems, Stanford and M.I.T.
"The advent of cyberspace will have profound effects on so-called post-industrial culture," Mr. Benedikt writes, "and the material and economic rewards for those who first and most properly conceive and implement cyberspace systems will be enormous."
Nearer on the horizon, and also promising rewards for business, are expert systems. "The Rise of the Expert Company" ($19.95, Times Books, New York City), by the artificial intelligence experts Edward Feigenbaum, Pamela McCorduck and H. Penny Nii, is subtitled "How Visionary Companies Are Using Artificial Intelligence to Achieve Higher Productivity and Profits."
Artificial intelligence is one of those unfortunate terms that promises more than it delivers. Computers are not yet "smart," but they can serve as repositories for the collected wisdom and experience of senior executives.
Others, then, can extract the intelligence and apply it to problems that range from product development and administration to manufacturing. A new breed of computer experts called knowledge engineers are creating a form of artificial intelligence known as expert systems.
Expert systems allow companies, not just individual executives, to work smarter, and among the companies profiled are Du Pont, Fujitsu, Navistar, Northrop, Canon, I.B.M. and American Express.
This book first appeared in 1988. But the vision it describes is perhaps more important today. Tom Peters, a management consultant and author, writes in the forward, "Any senior manager in any business of almost any size who isn't at least learning about artificial intelligence, and sticking a tentative toe or two into A.I.'s waters, is simply out of step, dangerously so."
And then there is a book for executives and dreamers who are ready to go beyond toe-dipping and take the plunge.
"High-Tech Ventures, The Guide for Entrepreneurial Success" ($29.95, Addison-Wesley Publishing Company, Reading, Mass.), is by C. Gordon Bell, with John E. McNamara. Mr. Bell, a scientist and engineer, worked 23 years as a research and development director at the Digital Equipment Corporation before becoming a principal in more than 20 high-tech start-up companies. Some succeeded, some failed. The lessons from each are laid down here.
Anyone thinking of starting a high-tech company, or investing in one, will find this book valuable. Mr. Bell dissects start-ups including Ovation, Analytica, Cirrus Logic, Thinking Machines, Apollo and Sun, in each case offering behind-the-scenes insights into the heady world of high tech.
"High-Tech Ventures" includes an explanation of the Bell-Mason Diagnostic and Prescriptive Method, developed with Heidi Mason, a specialist in high-tech marketing and sales. The Bell-Mason method is a rule-based tool that systematically assesses the health and wisdom of a start-up at several well-defined stages.
There are charts and graphs aplenty, a natural given Mr. Bell's background as an engineer. These reveal the relative strengths and weaknesses of four key elements of any high-tech start-up -- technology/product, people, marketing/sales and finance/ control -- at each of four stages of growth.
Each area, in turn, is measured in three dimensions. For example, the people quadrant is broken down to the chief executive, the directors and the team. A company can be strong in one area and weak in another, but rarely does a fledgling company succeed with the wrong leadership.
"High-Tech Ventures" concludes with a look ahead, and its predictions are provocative: the United States will continue to lead the world in inventiveness; the Japanese will dominate every market through their strength in innovation.
One area where American innovation may save the day is in computer programming, especially in an emerging field known as object-oriented programming.
"Object Oriented Technology, a Manager's Guide" ($19.50, Addison-Wesley, paperback), by David A. Taylor, is one of the first accessible guides to the most important trend in software development.
Mr. Taylor, a management consultant, has a knack for explaining highly technical concepts in a way that executives, managers and other nonprogrammers can grasp. The simple diagrams and illustrations make it virtually painless.
Object-oriented programming (OOP) holds the promise of making it easier for executives to get the data they need, and it promises to allow businesses to construct software applications in a fraction of the time now needed. It does so by using software "packets" that contain data and the instructions necessary to act on the data.
Only a few personal computer software companies, notably Borland International Inc., are pursuing OOP relentlessly.
Philippe Kahn, the founder and chief executive of Borland, recently made a videotape explaining "The World of Objects" through the medium of Mr. Kahn's jazz band -- an analogy of individual components that know their own data and also how to act on it.
