HEADLINE: Technology;
Trout From a Tank - Maybe Fertilizer Too

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

DATELINE: ITHACA, N.Y.

 BODY:
In a converted dairy barn, a stable and a boat storage shed outside this Finger Lakes city, a number of fledging entrepreneurs and Cornell University professors are trying to make aquaculture history.
For nearly a year, they have been raising trout indoors. More important, they have been doing so with a method so economical of space and energy that three tanks, a water recycling system and a starter crop of 2,500 fingerlings would cost under $10,000. The system would require little more than a gallon of water per fish and comfortably fit in 750 square feet -- a typical one-bedroom apartment. And if it works, it could make fish farming as viable in abandoned inner-city warehouses as it is in Idaho's open fields. 
 "We've figured out how to make water recycling cost-effective almost anywhere," said R. G. Douglas Ley, manager of the Northern Fresh Fish Cooperative, a consortium of eight would-be fish farmers who are serving as the new system's guinea pigs.
The "we" that Mr. Ley referred to comprises professors at Cornell University's College of Agriculture and Life Sciences, who were looking for an industry that could enhance their Tompkins County economy. Already a billion-dollar business in the South and Midwest, trout farms seemed tantalizing, except for their intensive use of water.
Most trout farms are near flowing streams, which send millions of gallons of fresh water gushing through the man-made ponds on a one-time ride. Tompkins County, despite its lakes and its frequent snowfall, does not have water to spare.
But it does have an agricultural college with professors itching to solve seemingly insurmountable problems. Indeed, for five years, several of them have been tinkering with ways to raise trout in recycled water.
The system they came up with uses standard circular grain bins with polyvinyl chloride liners, each 12 feet in diameter and about 3 feet high and with a capacity of about 2,500 fish. A feeder above the tank sprinkles fish food every 15 minutes.
The fish feed constantly -- and therein lies a recycling problem: what to do with the inevitable aftermath of that feeding. Fish excreta are very high in ammonia, which can be toxic to the fish. In flowing streams, naturally occurring bacteria convert the ammonia to harmless nitrites and nitrates. In a closed system, the ammonia can build up so fast that even the hungriest of bacteria cannot keep up. Since bacteria multiply in direct proportion to the surface area available for them to grow on, the trick was to create a large surface area in a tiny space.
Cornell's answer, on which it has a patent pending, is its rotating biological contactor, a lattice-work wheel consisting of hundreds of honeycombed plastic cylinders that provide the bacteria with huge amounts of surface on which to grow. Water is continuously pumped from the fish tanks into a separate vat that holds the wheel, which is constantly rotating to keep the water aerated and to give the bacteria a chance to work.
"Without the contactor, none of us would have thought of going into a water-intensive business like fish farming," said Laurene M. Gilbert, a landscape-architect-cum-fish-farmer and the cooperative's chairwoman.
Theoretically, once the water is ammonia-free and nitrate-rich, it is safe to pump back into the fish tank. But in practice, it often contains solid waste residue, which although chemically harmless could lodge in a fish's gills and interfere with its breathing.
"No question, filtration of solids is the weakest link," said Richard J. Marisa, a member of the cooperative.
The novice fish farmers and the Cornell professors together are experimenting with processes to get rid of solids. One prototype system, which pumped water through a fine nylon mesh, required too much energy for the pump and too many unclogging sessions for the screen. The group is now trying a gravity-based system that has the water flowing through a black plastic material that looks like corrugated cardboard; the plastic retards the flow, thus letting the solids settle out by weight.
Mr. Marisa is about to try a third system, patterned loosely after the closed-cycle cloth-towel mechanisms common in public washrooms. A plastic cylinder hooked to the edge of the tank will rotate fine-meshed plastic screening through the water, where it will pick up solids. As the plastic emerges from the tank, a jet spray of water will blow the solids off the plastic into a nearby settling tank. The cleaned plastic can then rotate back into the tank. An added bonus: the nitrogen-rich solids can be collected for use as fertilizer.
Any one of these systems could clean and aerate water from tanks much larger than 12 feet across. But the professors are advising the cooperative to expand by adding many small tanks, to prevent diseases, contaminants or accidents from jeopardizing an entire crop of fish.
"One large tank may seem more efficient, but how much risk do you want to associate with one unit breaking down?" asked Michael B. Timmons, a Cornell associate professor and one of the researchers.
Another source of risk, of course, occurs on the business side of the venture: To wit, will restaurants and supermarkets buy the fish?
There is a lot to be said for farmed fish. Unlike meat, fish is not government graded. That means that fish caught in polluted waters can pass through the distribution process undetected. It also means that old fish, skillfully filleted, can be sold as fresh.
But traditional fish farms have their own problems. There is the danger of having something toxic get into the local water table. Moreover, the operators cannot guarantee absolute freshness to someone in a distant town any more than a purveyor of fish caught in the wild could.
The inexpensive Cornell system would make it practical for fish farmers to establish tank setups so that any customer could get fresh fish on command. The cooperative members are banking that local customers will pay extra for the privilege.
There is some indication that they will. Robert Dennerlein, purchasing director for the Statler Hotel -- the on-campus hotel operated by Cornell's School of Hotel Administration -- has negotiated to buy fish from the cooperative at $3.25 a pound, untrimmed, even though he could get fully trimmed trout from Idaho for well under $3. "Fish that has to be flown in can't be as fresh," he said.
John Parmalee, who owns the Old Port Harbor Restaurant in Ithaca, agrees and plans to sign up as a customer as soon as the fish are available. "The fact that this is locally produced and could be supplied 365 days a year would be worth $1 more a pound to me," he said.
And there is vast potential in economies of scale. This coming year, the experimental setups will probably produce just 30,000 one-pound fish, so when marketing, water testing, fish fingerlings, feed and other costs are factored in, these trout will cost about $3 a pound to bring to market. But Professor Timmons believes that once the cooperative is producing 250,000 pounds of fish a year -- doable, Mr. Ley expects, within two years -- it could get the cost as low as 90 cents, making it easily cost-competitive with outdoor-grown fish.
The indoor system may help the cooperative reach that volume. Trout grow fastest in oxygen-rich water that is kept at about 65 degrees Fahrenheit -- a good 15 degrees warmer than most mountain streams -- and constant light retards the fish's sexual maturation and shifts its energy from reproduction to growth.
That knowledge is useless for outdoor fish farms. Warm water does not hold gas well, and the inexpensive bubble machines that can easily oxygenate a 12-foot tank of water would be inadequate for aerating a deep outdoor pond. As for light, no one can legislate the setting sun.
Indoor fish farmers, however, can easily regulate electric light and heaters. And by doing so, they can compress a trout's hatched-egg-to-dinner-table cycle to 12 months. In the wild, it takes two years.

HEADLINE: All About/Debt Collection;
Persuading People to Pay Their Bills During Hard Times

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
Debt collectors, the enforcers of the credit world, have long been plagued by a reputation as unscrupulous thugs who work in fly-by-night operations and delight in pouncing on people when times are tough.
But the debt-collection industry says it has been misunderstood and unappreciated. Today's debt collector, industry executives assert, is a well-educated and courteous professional who is regulated by strict laws and uses the latest technology to perform a vital service in a credit-driven economy. 
 To be sure, the business has undergone fundamental changes in the last two decades that have improved its reputation, regulators say. Nationwide companies with hundreds of closely supervised collectors and computerized operations have arisen from an industry once comprised exclusively of small firms serving businesses in their neighborhoods.
The American Collectors Association, a 3,600-member trade group, has worked to pass laws regulating the business. It has also sponsored a campaign to educate collection agencies about proper conduct and the public about its rights -- all in the interests of making people more agreeable if collectors come calling.
These changes came just in time for agencies to benefit from the debt-clogged 1980's. The industry has expanded rapidly in recent years; collectors handled $66.5 billion in debts in 1990, up from $14.5 billion in 1980, the association said.
But even Linda Russell, the association's president, acknowledges that no matter how much the industry reforms, debt collectors will be unpopular and unwelcome to much of the public. That is particularly true in the current recession, when more and more people have fallen behind in their payments and debts are more difficult to collect.
"I think the debt-collecting industry is a lot more understood now than it used to be," said Mrs. Russell, chief executive of CollectionCenter Inc., a privately owned agency, which is based in Rawlins, Wyo., and employs 31 collectors in five offices.
"But I guarantee you that there are many, many people who will never understand what it is," she said. "People feel very distressed when someone reminds them of their debts. And I don't think there is a thing that we can do to change that."

 
 
Modern-Day Collectors
Politeness and Some Psychology
 The 6,000 or so collection agencies in the United States typically work on commission, earning about 25 percent to 35 percent of what they collect for businesses that give them "listings" of people behind in their payments. Collectors working for agencies are usually paid a salary and a commission, which varies from company to company.
Industry executives say their clients are divided into four major groups: health care, including hospitals and doctors' offices; retail businesses, including department stores and credit-card companies; utilities, and commercial accounts, for businesses owing money to businesses.
After receiving a listing, the collection agency writes to the debtor, explaining that it has been given the account and requesting the money owed. This step can be complicated, though, for it is often difficult to find the debtor's address.
In the past, collectors often visited debtors' homes. But to cut costs, most now use the phone. Some agencies have developed sophisticated strategies for talking to debtors; some have employed industrial psychologists to devise scripts. But in general, most agencies tell their collectors simply to be polite and sympathetic.
"You don't collect bills by screaming at someone," said James R. Bohmann, a senior vice president at Payco American, the largest agency in the country. "You collect bills by understanding people."
The debtor usually does not pay immediately, prompting the collector to try to fashion a payment plan. Eventually, many agencies will threaten to sue a debtor.
"There are two things collectors look for: ability and willingness," said George Goodyear 3d, the president of Goodyear & Associates, a privately owned agency in Charlotte, N.C., that employs 34 collectors.
"If the consumer-debtor has the ability to pay, then almost everyone would say that he or she should pay," he said. "If he or she does not have the ability, but does have the willingness, we will work out a solution."
Debt collectors are regulated by the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act, which is administered by the Federal Trade Commission. Under the 1977 act, collectors cannot threaten debtors, lie to them or call them at inappropriate times, like the middle of the night. Conversations and correspondence with debtors are confidential. And debtors can tell collectors to stop contacting them.
Industry executives and regulators say the debt act has helped reduce the instances of some of the industry's more unsavory practices -- like threatening phone calls or harassment of debtors' employers or families.
David Medine, an acting associate director at the F.T.C., said the agency does not keep track of how many complaints it receives. But he said there had been a "significant downward trend" in the last decade.
"Some of the worst abuses that were widespread have been reduced," he said. "Across the board, I think that there probably has been improvement, though it certainly has not been uniform."

 
 
Computer Helpers
They Keep Records And Dial the Phone
 Twenty years ago, the office of a typical collection agency was awash in note cards recording each time a debtor was contacted or payment was made. That changed in the early 1980's, when agencies began using computers to maintain files on debtors, call them and search for their addresses.
These days, the offices of companies like Payco American seem like huge data processing centers. At Payco's headquarters in Brookfield, Wis., nearly 100 collectors work on computers linked to a mainframe system the company spent $20 million designing.
Payco, a publicly traded company with $106.3 million in revenues last year, had profits of $5.42 million, a 34 percent increase from the previous year. Payco uses the system to monitor accounts at its more than 40 offices and to set work standards for its 2,500 employees. When the company receives a list of debtors, the computer automatically sends the accounts to collectors who specialize in areas like transportation, health care, student loans or credit cards.
At Nationwide Credit, an Atlanta-based company with 11 offices and 900 collectors, automatic dialers call debtors until the phone is answered; at that point, the call is sent to a collector and the debtor's file appears on the collector's computer screen. The system frees collectors from wasting time with busy signals or calls to people who are not home.
To find addresses, agencies also use computers to access "skip tracers" -- national data bases with information gleaned from telephone directories, subscription houses and voter registration files.

 
 
A Time of Debt
During a Recession, It's Harder to Collect
 Though collection agencies profit from financial misfortune, most do not like recessions. The number of people owing money may increase -- drastically in some areas of the country; but at the same time, debtors' ability to make payments declines, forcing collectors to work much harder.
So while collection agencies may not be suffering as much as other businesses in the current recession, most are not reaping any windfalls. The number of people paying off debts to agencies fell from 21 percent of listings in 1988 to 18.3 percent last year, the American Collectors Association said.
"We're getting more of it, but it's less collectible," said Larry Sheridan, a vice president at Nationwide Credit, which is a subsidiary of First Financial Management Corporation, a publicly traded company. "People think that because there is more business coming to the agency, we should be doing better. But we're not doing any better than before."
Mr. Sheridan said Nationwide's revenues had declined in 1990 and 1991, but did not give the figures, which First Financial does not disclose separately.
Mrs. Russell said small agencies were running into trouble because struggling businesses have withheld listings rather than pay collectors' fees. But she said in the long run, the small agencies would not be harmed or swallowed up by the bigger ones.
"There is a market niche for each of us," she said. "The Paycos will get the large national firms. But there are a lot small businesses that are much more responsive to dealing with someone who is also a local business person. What we return to small businesses might make the difference in whether they survive or not."
Mrs. Russell -- who cheerfully acknowledges that she does not fit the stereotype of the debt collector as a "rough-talking large male who browbeats people" -- said she hoped the industry's ability to weather the recession would encourage more people to become collectors.
"Contrary to popular image, it's a fun job, because you deal with people," she said. "And the real fun is that you can tell when you are a success."

 
 
HOSPITALS MAKE GREAT CUSTOMERS

In the days when most doctors made house calls, hospitals and medical offices rarely hired debt collectors. But as health care costs have soared in recent years, more and more people are having trouble paying for medical care, forcing more billing departments to hire collection agencies.
The health care market for debt collectors has grown so much in the last decade that many agencies now consider it their No. 1 source of clients.
James R. Bohmann, a senior vice president at Payco American Inc., called the increase "dramatic." He said many hospitals, facing strong competition, found that in the past they were losing money because too many bills went unpaid.
"What is occurring is that there used to be inefficiencies in the cash-flow process in the health care system," Mr. Bohmann said. "They have to be better managers of their cash flow. They can't afford to make interest-free loans."
George Arges, a senior policy analyst at the American Hospital Association, said many hospitals have become bogged down in compiling and mailing bills as they try to meet the specific requirements of the more than 5,000 insurance companies in the United States.
"You're spending more resources trying to send out billing information," he said. "It's very time-consuming. Hospitals don't have the staff to follow up and collect the money as well."
The growth of this market has led agencies to train collectors who specialize in deciphering complicated medical bills so they can better serve clients and have more of a chance of persuading debtors to pay.

HEADLINE: Camera

BYLINE: By John Durniak; John Durniak is a freelance writer, editor and consultant on photography.

 BODY:
Today is the 200th anniversary of the ratification of the Bill of Rights, the first 10 amendments to the Constitution. And when Bob Adelman, a freelance photographer in New York, found that the Government was not planning to celebrate this anniversary formally, he decided to do it himself with a book, which appeared last month: "Visions of Liberty, the Bill of Rights for All Americans" (Arcade/Little, Brown, $24.95).
Caught by the recession in publishing and advertising, many freelance photographers are poorer this year, and some have been forced out of business. But ideas, like the one for this book, have made this a good year for Mr. Adelman. Making his living by shooting photographs mostly for publications, Mr. Adelman expends the rest of his professional efforts on packaging original books. 
 Book-packaging involves finding a saleable idea; researching, obtaining, and editing pictures; hiring a writer and designer, and contracting with a publisher to distribute the finished work. Sometimes, a book starts with a grant, but usually the packager risks his own money.
Mr. Adelman said many lawyers who bought "Visions of Liberty" considered it to be a picture book because it includes about 100 photographs. But photographers consider it to be word book because there are more pages of writing by Ira Glasser, the executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union, than there are pages of photographs.
Throughout his life, Mr. Adelman said, he has been driven by a strong sense of justice inspired by his parents and the Harvard Law School. He left Harvard before receiving a degree to pursue photography and to study for a master's degree in philosophy at Columbia.
In the 1960's, Mr. Adelman assigned himself -- out of conscience, he said -- to shoot pictures of the civil-rights movement when most professional photographers were saying there was no money in it. Then, they were right, but Mr. Adelman gained national recognition as a photojournalist for his efforts. In addition, he now gets a steady stream of revenue from this unpaid work, which is now being sold to publishers by the Magnum picture agency.
Mr. Adelman created images that have become famous: his picture of the water-hosing of black demonstrators in Birmingham, Ala., in 1963, a photograph that appears in the "Visions of Liberty," and a strong candid portrait of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., which has been used in publications hundreds of times.
In pursuing special projects, Mr. Adelman has kept his overhead to a minimum.
"I live modestly without a flashy car, no designer clothes and no posh apartment," he said. "When I need a studio, I rent it, and the client pays for it. When I need special equipment, I don't buy, but rent."
Mr. Adelman's apartment in Manhattan looks like a giant photo gadget bag with a built-in library. It is a hive of film, lighting equipment, layouts for proposed books, rechargers for batteries, contact sheets, lenses and a professional darkroom.
To save time and money, he has analyzed the basic lighting situations for most of his shooting and has chosen six films that work best in those environments: three color films (Kodachrome, Ektar and Ektapress) and three black-and-white emulsions (Ilford FP-4, Kodak Tri-X and T-Max 3200.)
Mr. Adelman also teaches a course with John Loengard, a former picture editor of Life magazine, at the International Center of Photography at Fifth Avenue and 94th Street in Manhattan.
He tells his students to seek out a broad market if they wish to be successful freelancers. "A professional today can no longer think of his market as New York or the United States only," Mr. Adelman said. "Now we have to consider the world market. Rome, London and Munich are important and contribute much to the photographic economy."
Although Magnum sells his civil-rights work, Mr. Adelman handles most domestic and overseas sales of his photographs himself, eliminating the middleman. "When two photo agencies, one here and one abroad, sell a picture story," he said, "the photographer gets the least amount of money out of the deal."
This year, Mr. Adelman put together a British edition of "Carver Country," his 1990 book about the short-story writer Raymond Carver. He has also begun work on a book about Grace Kelly, using more than three decades of photographs by Howell Conant, the star's personal photographer.
Mr. Adelman's advice to photographers is simple: expand your imaginations and not your studios.

HEADLINE: A 'Golden Opportunity'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Donald V. Fites, chairman of Caterpillar Inc. ("Trapped in the Impoverished Middle Class," Nov. 17), says: "There is a narrowing of the gap between the average American's income and that of the Mexicans. As a human being, I think that what is going on is positive. I don't think it is realistic for 250 million Americans to control so much of the world's G.N.P." 
 As a reflection of the plantation-owner mentality of the new class of the very wealthy in this country -- whose fortunes have soared while everyone else's have plummeted -- this statement by a prominent member would be hard to beat. It says everything that arrogance, scorn and condescension could suggest concerning his own employees, his fellow townspeople of Peoria and of working American families generally.
One wonders how willing Mr. Fites would be to tread water until his salary and bonuses are matched by his counterparts in the third world. According to a recent study, the salaries, bonuses and other emoluments earned by top executives in this country are not just outrageous but grotesque. Assuming Mr. Fites's compensation fits the pattern, here is a golden opportunity to set an example.
 
EDWARD KERN
New York, Nov. 18

HEADLINE: HEADLINERS;
Crossfire

 BODY:
Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator, announced his candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination last week, charging that the vision of a New World Order dancing in President Bush's head will make the United States keep playing the role of global sugarplum daddy.
"America First" is Mr. Buchanan's not-exactly-new theme, and Mr. Bush was quick to attack those very words and the isolationism they stood for before Pearl Harbor. But Mr. Buchanan argues that alliances created to face down the Soviet Union, under which the United States footed the defense bills for much of the world, need to be re-examined now that a uniting Europe and a Japan-led Asia are powerful competitors. Acknowledging that he is a long shot, he hopes that New Hampshire, bludgeoned by the recession, will prove a good field for his domestic theme: that Mr. Bush, not liberals, is to blame for huge deficits and for the switch from "read my lips" to mere lip service to the idea of lower taxes.

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
The Tax Recipes Vary, But Share a Sour Taste

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
For years, policymakers have held strong opinions about the best mix of taxes. Some criticized New York State for getting over half its revenue from income taxes, compared with about a third for other states. Too volatile a source, critics said. Legislators will be sorry when a recession hits.
Others blamed Connecticut for refusing to impose any income tax and relying so heavily on sales and business taxes. Its 8 percent sales tax and 12 percent corporate income tax rates were the highest in the nation. Too consumption-oriented, they said, and unfair to companies. And that could leave the state especially vulnerable in an economic downturn. 
 New Jersey, on the other hand, was criticized for the hefty property taxes its local governments imposed, leaving the state able to get away with relatively low sales and income taxes. Too much of a penalty to homeowners, some said. While all levels of New Jersey government got about 42 percent of their revenues from property taxes, the average in other states was about 30 percent.
New York City was considered at fault, meanwhile, for being more reliant on taxes generally, and for being particularly wedded to personal income taxes and sales and consumption taxes, all of which are deemed to be more sensitive to the ups and downs of the economy.
The Financial Control Board, a state agency set up in the fiscal crisis of the mid-70's to monitor the city's fiscal health, noted recently that the city depends on local taxes for about 58 percent of its operating budget, compared with about 40 percent for the average local government. And while municipalities typically derive about 75 percent of their tax revenue from property taxes, which are considered relatively stable, New York gets about 44 percent of its tax revenue from that source. The board concluded that its predictable spending needs coupled with its particular mix of taxes "is a major cause of New York City's fiscal problems."
 
Wrestling With Deficits
 Everybody has a pet peeve when it comes to tax policy, but what is striking when one looks at the tax receipts for the three states and New York City is how different they are in composition, yet how similar their problems quickly became when the bottom fell out of the economy. Though they each took very different paths to get there, New Jersey, Connecticut, New York State and New York City all ended up with serious budget deficit problems that they are still wrestling with.
As Cynthia B. Green, a senior research associate at the Citizens Budget Commission, put it, "When times are bad, times are bad."
The earliest sign of trouble was the decline in corporate income taxes. It hit New York State first, but by the 1990 fiscal year all three states were suffering an absolute decline in their takings from that category. Steven D. Gold, director of the Center for the Study of the States at the State University of New York in Albany, does not find that surprising.
 
Slow Reflexes
 When an economy goes into a recession, he said, companies' costs continue to rise even though their revenues are not going up as quickly. It is hard for them to react as quickly to revenue shortfalls as individuals can.
"Corporate profits are the most volatile part of the economy," Mr. Gold said. "Corporate tax revenue has been very weak throughout the country."
By fiscal year 1991, it was clear that the effects of the economic downturn were working their way into other tax categories. The fiscal year begins July 1 for all these jurisdictions except New York State, whose fiscal year begins April 1. Both New York and Connecticut suffered declines in income tax receipts, with Connecticut also enduring a drop in sales tax revenue. Both states found themselves having to make do with lower total revenues that year, which is one reason they enacted a variety of tax changes to increase their future receipts.
Of course, tax revenues would look even worse for the three states and New York City if legislators had not reacted to the recession and the threatening deficits by raising various tax rates. New York City's Finance Department has calculated that if the city had not raised its income tax rates, revenues in that category would have been $355 million less in fiscal year 1991 and $683 million less in 1992, resulting in two years of actual decline. The same is true for property taxes: without the various increases in rates on different classes of properties, New York City's property tax receipts would have been $319 million less in 1991 and $670 million less in 1992.
The assumption that revenues would rise in fiscal 1992 in the three states and New York City reflects similar kinds of emergency measures. New Jersey raised its income tax rate substantially, while Connecticut, after much hand-wringing, decided to impose an income tax for the first time in its history.
Of course, forces within those two states' legislatures have been threatening to undo those tax measures, but if they do they will simply have to come up with funds from elsewhere. And they may have to anyway, given that they both appear to be facing growing budget deficits.
In a severe economic recession virtually all taxes are likely to be hard hit. At that point a state's ability to weather the storm has more to do with how quickly it responds by raising rates and cutting costs. And with deficits looming in all three states and the city, two state legislatures already in revolt over tax packages passed earlier and a third trying to cobble together a multi-year package for this and the following fiscal year, the jury is decidedly out on which jurisdiction is performing best.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Seen Again at Maastricht: Adam Smith's Invisible Hand

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY

DATELINE: MAASTRICHT, The Netherlands

 BODY:
As they struggled to put at least some of the pieces of what used to be the Soviet Union back together again last week, Boris N. Yeltsin and the other leaders of his new Commonwealth of Independent States would have done well to keep one eye on the leaders of the European Community.
Europe is steadily pulling itself together, but for the last 46 years it has been a lot easier to do that economically than politically. Last week's European summit meeting at Maastricht was no exception. The 12 leaders who gathered here agreed relatively quickly on a single currency to go with the single, barrier-free market they will have by the end of next year, but they could not advance as far as some had hoped down the road to political union. 
 Still, when the talks were over it was a lot easier to see what the European Community would look like by the end of the century than it was to see what would become of the Soviet Union. By the year 2000, it is now clear, the European market will be far bigger than that of the United States or Japan, with close to 350 million people and a single currency, at least among the countries on the Continent with the strongest economies; this new currency should be a powerful stimulus to trade, commerce and investment.
 
An Expanding Club
 The new Europe will stretch from the Atlantic to at least the Russian border, if Finland, Sweden, Austria and perhaps Norway have joined by then, as expected. Austria and Sweden have already applied and could be accepted as early as 1995. Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary also want in, but for them, as well as for Ukraine if it decides to try, more time will be needed to build market economies.
Economic necessity gave birth to the European Economic Community in 1957. Even Britain, which at first was frozen out of the fledgling Common Market by France and later became fastidious about whether the club was really good enough for it to join, has no serious questions any more about the economic benefits of membership. Prime Minister John Major does not really have any about the benefits of a single currency, but to satisfy the doubters at home who have gathered under the banner of his predecessor, Margaret Thatcher, he had to get his 11 partners to agree that Britain could remain outside the monetary union agreement until its Parliament made the final decision on whether to join.
There is no real doubt that Britain will finally do so, according to politicians of all the major parties there. And that time will come by 1997 if a majority of the European countries qualify as economically ready then or, at the latest, by 1999, under the treaty.
Britain's consistent skepticism about rushing into things is based on an acute awareness that when countries agree to a common currency, they in effect surrender some of their most basic sovereign rights, pooling their sovereignty in monetary affairs. The threat to the pound sterling has been vigorously debated in Britain for months and months. The threat to the mark seems to have caught the German public unaware, according to German diplomats and journalists here who said that only last week did it dawn on Germans that the mark would soon be replaced by something else -- the European Currency Unit, or more felicitously, ecu, the same name taken by a royal French coinage in the 17th and 18th centuries.
But in Europe, E pluribus is definitely not yet unum -- far from it, as shown by Britain's insistence on staying out of a European-wide program of improvements in working hours, minimum wages and conditions of employment. The leaders of the 11 other community countries argued about this with Mr. Major most of Tuesday before finally throwing up their hands and exempting Britain altogether while they pledged to go ahead on their own. O.K., Mr. Major and his officials joked, if the others want to encourage the Japanese and the Americans to build all their plants in Britain, that's all right with us. The 11 others hope for a British change of heart later on.
 
'Harmonization'
 Continentals often do think in more Cartesian ways than Anglo-Saxons, and the European Community's Executive Commission in Brussels has been pushing for "harmonization" of everything from working hours to value-added taxes on a Continent where no two countries have exactly the same electric plugs, telephone connections or even languages, let alone cultures or historical traditions.
Words mean different things, as well. To Germans, "federal" has come to connote a comfortable decentralization with local control; the structure of Germany's federal republic lets the states decide their own educational and cultural policies. To Britain, whose central Parliament can do or undo systems of local government all over the sceptered isles on the whim of whatever majority is in power in London, talk of a "federal" Europe connotes only an unwanted loss of sovereignty to Brussels.
Differences far smaller than these led to the American Civil War only 78 years after the more perfect union described in the preamble to the United States Constitution. In the preamble to the political union treaty signed in the wee hours Wednesday, Mr. Major made the others take out a reference to a federal vocation for the European Community and settle instead for an "ever closer union among the peoples of Europe," who all now also enjoy citizenship in what the treaty calls the European Union.
It is easy to wonder what exactly that is. Political union remains a vague goal, even though the leaders agreed last week to implement joint foreign policy decisions by majority vote in four areas -- arms control, disarmament, nuclear proliferation and economic aspects of security. They also decided to awaken the long-slumbering nine-nation Western European Union and direct it to strengthen Europe's contribution to NATO and build the framework for an independent European defense.
But first the Europeans have to show that they have joint policies, something they haven't demonstrated in relation to the Yugoslav civil war at their eastern doorstep, or even for what has been the Soviet Union. But for all the vagueness and talk about national sovereignty, the outlines of a new Europe are slowly becoming clear. It is something that will give not only Russians but Americans a lot to think about in the years to come.

HEADLINE: RISING HUMAN NEED OUTSTRIPS GIVING

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
In a converted warehouse that serves as an emergency shelter for homeless families here, the recession's pain is felt equally by those who give and those who receive.
As the economic downturn makes it more difficult to find willing contributors, the Star of Hope, the local charity that runs the shelter, struggles with staff cuts and budget deficits even as a growing number of people seek help after losing their jobs and then their homes. 
 Around the country this holiday season, charitable organizations large and small are finding themselves in the same bind: needs are increasing much faster than contributions.
 
Frayed Safety Net
 At a time when social welfare benefits have been trimmed and eligibility for them has been restricted, charity is the final safety net for those already poor and incapacitated, as well as for the economy's freshest victims, and now that net is becoming frayed and tenuous.
With traditional year-end charity drives in full swing, Americans are still contributing despite the hard times. The United Way of America, by far the largest program collecting money for charitable groups, is expecting to gather 2 to 3 percent more than it did last year, but that would be the smallest increase in more than 30 years.
"When Americans see their neighbors in trouble, they give more," said Col. Leon Ferraez, director of national communications for the Salvation Army, "so our income is up nationwide by as much as 16 percent, and that's not unusual in a recession. The downside is that demand for services has increased by more than 25 percent."
And increasingly the demand is coming from people who have never sought charity before.
"I used to see the homeless people on TV and think that could never happen to us because we've got jobs, but it happened to us," said Mamie Brown, a nursing assistant who is now living in the Star of Hope shelter, along with her husband, Walter, a construction worker, and their six children. "We lost our jobs and now we are here."
The Star of Hope operates five shelters in Houston that can house a total of 600 people. Kathy Tabor, director of development, said the group is now running a 15 percent deficit because people started filling the shelters to capacity in July, in the hot weather, and the number seeking help has not tapered off.
"It should have dropped off in the fall, but it didn't," Mrs. Tabor said. "Most of the time people say they've been evicted because they can't pay the rent."
Nine staff positions have already been cut so that programs can continue, and only a holiday surge in giving will stave off further staff reductions.
"We're seeing larger donations in the last two weeks than they have been all year, but we need about three Decembers," said Mrs. Tabor.
 
Similar Predicaments
 Interviews with officials of charitable groups around the country this week showed that hundreds of other charities are in similar predicaments.
In San Francisco, Project Open Hand distributes meals and groceries to 1,200 people with AIDS every evening.
"We have gone from beef three times a week to chicken three times a week, and instead of chicken, we sometimes serve a vegetarian dish, or macaroni and cheese," said Steve Burns, executive director.
Although he vowed there would be no interruption in service despite decreased donations, Mr. Burns said: "We're keeping our fingers crossed. November was not as good as we thought it might be, and we're holding our breath at this point."
 
Cut in New Orleans
 In New Orleans, the Salvation Army has cut its paid staff to 20 from 37 four years ago. Associated Catholic Charities has fewer bus tokens to give the unemployed searching for work, and last year one family counseling program was absorbed into another, producing ever longer waiting lists.
And at Hope House, a community agency at the edge of the St. Thomas Housing Project in New Orleans, Don Everard, the director said: "We're always in a shortfall because the needs are just out of control, but in the past three or four months, it's been more so than ever. At the point we are now, the issues keep coming back to, 'Can we keep it going, can we meet the salaries to keep it going?' "
In Chicago, Ronald Hitchcock, a 43-year-old unemployed laborer, rang a bell at a Salvation Army kettle on State Street outside a symbol of the recession, the empty storefront of a recently closed men's clothier.
Hundreds of office workers and shoppers passed by the busy downtown intersection, but few bothered to put money in Mr. Hitchcock's kettle. Most people did not look his way. And some even walked between Mr. Hitchcock and his bell stand.
"I guess some people don't give because they don't have it, and others because they don't want to," Mr. Hitchcock said.
 
'Every Little Bit Helps'
 Greg Jacobsen, a 22-year-old insurance company worker was one of the few who did, donating $1.50.
"I was standing at the corner waiting for the light and I heard the bell ring," he said, "so I dug in my pocket and gave what I have. I feel good. I mean, if I was in need of money and gifts for Christmas, I'd hope somebody would give to me. I donated just because people need help now and we're in an economic recession and every little bit helps."
Donations to the Salvation Army in Chicago are down 19 percent, and Robert Cotner, director of development, said several programs would probably be altered or scaled down even though Illinois officials warned that there would be increased requests for help next year because of cuts in assistance programs for low-income residents.
For some leaders of charitable organizations, the squeeze this holiday season is the culmination of events dating back a decade, and perhaps a turning point as well.
The Rev. Thomas J. Harvey, president of Catholic Charities USA, said, "During the Reagan Administration the responsibility for many social welfare programs was shifted from the Federal level to the states, and now with some 40 states facing budget deficits, the government role is really contracting."
Needs, however, did not shrink during the 1980's. While poverty figures fluctuated in the economic boom, the proportion of Americans living in poverty rose from 13 percent in 1980 to 13.5 percent in 1990, with a sharp upswing in the last year of that period. The Census Bureau reported that there were 33.6 million people living in poverty in 1990, an increase of 2.1 million from the previous year, when the poverty rate was 12.8 percent. The Government's poverty threshold is increased each year to reflect inflation and stood at $13,359 for a family of four in 1990.
Analysts at the Census Bureau expressed surprise at the sharp increase, since the recession did not begin until about halfway through 1990. "Our plate," Father Harvey said, "was full when this recession started."
An annual survey of the 163 Roman Catholic dioceses that support agencies affiliated with Catholic Charities found that in 1980 only 23 percent of the agencies' clients needed emergency services like food and shelter to make it through another day. By 1990 such services were sought by 62 percent of the agencies' eight million clients.
 
Competition Is Increasing
 Faced with increased competition from nonprofit organizations in fields like the environment, animal rights or the arts, social service agencies often found it more difficult to raise money.
"A majority of people in this country are far enough away from any direct experience of poverty that they do not identify with it even as a national problem," said Father Harvey. But he believes this changes with a recession.
"This kind of downturn," he said, "reminds people that there are capricious forces at work. It explodes the myths that the poor are poor out of choice because people see their neighbors going unemployed due to circumstances beyond their control."
An indication of that was reflected last year in The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund as it collected more than $4.4 million, a record amount. Nancy Nielsen, spokeswoman for The Times, said, "This year even though contributions are down a little right now, we hope to break another record because people do make an extra effort during hard times."
Other charities are also seeing this effect. Harvey Vieth, director of Camillus House, a social service agency in Miami, told of the effect of the increased visibility of poverty that he had seen: "At Thanksgiving we were expecting 100 turkeys and we received 400, and we received so many canned goods we could hardly store them. I think so many people are close to it now; they see friends without jobs. It's hitting closer to home.
"Over the last six weeks the face of the homeless has begun to change. More Hispanics and whites are now in the food lines; more people are closer to the work force; some are just out; some of them have jobs and/or homes, but no money for food."
These are what social service workers are calling "the new poor."
"They are people who are poor for the first time," said Ann Maguire, the executive director of the Boston's emergency shelter program. "They always had a job. They paid the rent every month. Now, they need to ask for help. There are a lot of these folks."
In Miami, Dr. Bernard Baumel, director of the Neurological Centers of South Florida, is one giver who has been moved by the recession's effect. "The economy has affected my income but I have not cut back my giving," Dr. Baumel said. "The need is so apparent. Homelessness is much more prevalent; you see it. It's been a bad year for everybody but the needy still need more. The appeals have been so much more emotional. I think it's my conscience. I look at it as an obligation, another bill to pay."

HEADLINE: New Teamster Chief's Motto: Honest Work for Honest Pay

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
In the truck yards and teamster union halls of America, the ghosts of Jimmy Hoffa, Jackie Presser and other godfathers of a more brazen era linger in the tales of gangland muscle and mysterious disappearances, of payoffs, sweetheart contracts, looted pension funds and rigged elections.
But there is a new legend in the making these days for the rank-and-file of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. Its unlikely hero is a 55-year-old former United Parcel Service driver who, after 23 years leading a local in Queens, has just been elected to a five-year term as president of the 1.5-million member international union. 
 His name is Ronald Carey, and they say he is an honest man.
 
'A Frank Capra Figure'
 "The fact that he's won is astounding," said Stanley Aronowitz, a labor expert and a professor at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York. "He's a real outsider. This is 'Mr. Smith Goes to Washington.' He's a Frank Capra figure. He's the unexpected guy coming in from left field yelling about corruption and the need for militant unionism and getting elected."
Mr. Carey, a former marine and a father of five who buys his suits off the rack, eats tuna sandwiches for lunch, drives a 1989 car and has lived in the same Kew Gardens house for 35 years, is a man who shuns extravagance, stays at budget hotels, carries his own suitcases, accounts for every penny of his expenses and for years has gone daily to the yards to talk to members.
"What's important is getting the confidence and trust of the members," Mr. Carey said in an interview on Friday after the final tally confirming his election. "They haven't trusted their union for years. It's their union. They want it to work for them. It hasn't. We're only caretakers. It's turned into a dictatorship over these years. Now we've got to get democracy back."
Associates say Mr. Carey works 12 hours a day, six days a week, almost never takes a vacation and truly earns his $45,000-a-year salary as president of Teamsters Local 804 in Long Island City. Many of his 6,800 members earn more than he does and revere him for what they call an unswerving integrity typified by his first announcement as international president-elect -- that he would cut his salary from $225,000 to $175,000 and then "get the bums out."
To a nation long accustomed to a teamster clan run by cigar-chomping thugs who sold labor peace to the trucking industry and drew whopping salaries while defying investigators and keeping potential rivals under the thumb with threats and loaded bylaws, the election of an all-but-unknown dissident seems almost as improbable as the end of the cold war, the Soviet Union and apartheid.
To hundreds of thousands of teamsters, who in the union's 88 years had never cast secret ballots to choose their international leaders, the election was a triumph that could spell vast reforms. Mr. Carey has vowed to sweep out the old guard, cut bloated salaries and expense accounts, rewrite sellout labor contracts and return the union to its members.
And to Mr. Carey, the success of an uphill two-year campaign to wrest away the presidency of the nation's second-largest union has abruptly propelled him onto the national stage, with the potential to be a major player in decisions on economic policy and, by his union's endorsement, a factor in the 1992 Presidential race.
 
A Determined Revolution
 Within the union, the hard-won victory will pose great challenges for Mr. Carey. He faces struggles to root out nepotism and greed in many of the union's 615 locals and in an entrenched bureaucracy at the union headquarters in Washington. And he faces the huge task of rebuilding a union whose power has waned.
In mail balloting supervised by Federal courts under a settlement in an anti-racketeering suit brought by the Justice Department, Mr. Carey had 188,883 votes in a race against two old- line leaders, R. V. Durham, who had 129,538 votes, and Walter Shea, who had 71,227. Mr. Carey will succeed William J. McCarthy, who did not run for re-election, in about a month.
The story of Mr. Carey's rise to the helm of one of America's most corrupt unions on a reform ticket is the story of a revolution within the international, according to labor experts and others familiar with the fight.
"It's a triumph of union democracies over organized crime," said Herman Benson, the secretary-treasurer of the Association for Union Democracy, a civil liberties group. "Carey deserves credit for having the courage to run at the beginning. This is a union where people get murdered."
 
Product of a Union Family
 Ronald Robert Carey was born in Manhattan on March 22, 1936, the second of five sons of Joseph and Loretta Carey. His father, a frugal man who instilled the work ethic in his children and believed strongly in the union movement, was a United Parcel Service driver for 40 years. The couple, who died earlier this year, raised the family in Astoria and Long Island City.
Ron Carey, a strong, athletic youth who loved to swim, graduated from Long Island City High School in 1953 and enlisted in the Marines. In 1956 he joined United Parcel as a driver, a job he kept for 12 years, delivering packages mostly in Woodside and Maspeth, Queens. He and his father pooled their money and for $18,000 bought and began sharing a modest two-story home in Kew Gardens where he still lives.
In 1958, Mr. Carey, already an ardent unionist, became a shop steward for Local 804. Soon, he began taking labor-relations courses. He ran unsuccessfully for local trustee in 1962 and for recording secretary in 1965, but was not discouraged. In 1967, he ran a well-organized campaign for the local presidency and won. He took office in 1968 and gave up driving.
Mr. Carey proved to be a solid, intense negotiator at the bargaining table. He led the local in strikes ranging from 9 to 13 weeks in 1968, 1971 and 1974, and by 1977 had more than doubled his workers' hourly wages and had won major improvements in working conditions and benefits, including the right to retire after 25 years.
Throughout those years, associates say, Mr. Carey, who was eventually re-elected eight times to three-year terms by landslide margins, kept Local 804's affairs relatively independent of the international union, whose spreading stain of corruption was making it harder to organize new shops.
 
Distance Ffrom the International
 The teamsters represent more than truckers. On its rolls are factory workers, health-care workers, police officers, firefighters and other municipal workers, flight attendants, pilots and employees in other industries. About 10 percent of the members are U.P.S. delivery and warehouse workers.
While Mr. Carey tried to distance himself from the international, he was quick to support work stoppages by other New York locals, associates recalled. "Any time I had a strike or any of the locals had a strike, the U.P.S. drivers under his instructions refused to cross the picket lines," said William Nuchow, secretary-treasurer of Teamsters Local 840 in Manhattan.
Visiting yards and garages to talk to his members daily, working nights and weekends to address their grievances, cracking down on corruption in the local, even taking a cut in his own salary when the local treasury was low on funds, Mr. Carey, by all accounts, became increasingly popular with his members and acquired a reputation as an honest, straightforward leader.
He made it a policy of his local that no relatives of any officer could be hired for a union job, and he insisted that his fellow officers also visit the yards daily to talk to members.
"That's what this job is about," he said. "It's out there with the members. You'll never service the members sitting in an office. I see a union as a mechanism to help people."
He held members to his own standards, as well, said Kenneth Spillane, a vice president of Local 804. "He's been known to chew out workers trying to make frivolous complaints or trying to get out of work. He believes in a hard day's work for an honest dollar."
 
In Touch with Workers
 In the yard, Mr. Carey had a subdued way about him that the men liked. He had been a driver and spoke their language, understood their problems and took them seriously, members said, and he did not act like a big shot. "He's for the people; he's for us," said Robert LeDux, a driver for four years.
But at international headquarters where leaders enjoyed multiple salaries and perquisites from limousines and jets to lavish entertainment and travel accounts, associates said Mr. Carey was viewed first as eccentric, then as something of a troublemaker.
The disaffection was mutual. Mr. Carey tossed the international's fliers into the waste basket. But while he shunned the international, it was virtually impossible for his local to break away. Under the union constitution, only 7 of the local's 5,000 votes were needed to block independence.
After 1979, the local's longstanding right to negotiate its own contracts with U.P.S. was "stolen from us," Mr. Carey said, when the international forced it to accept nationally negotiated bargaining results. While Mr. Carey headed one of the largest U.P.S. locals and had a name as a top negotiator, he was not appointed to the teamsters national bargaining team.
And when the resulting settlements with U.P.S. in 1982, 1985 and 1987 won wage increases as small as 2 percent, Mr. Carey campaigned against ratification of what he called "sweetheart" deals. He lost those fights, mainly because union bylaws allowed rejection of a proposed contract only when two-thirds of the members voted against it, an all-but-impossible goal to meet.
Mr. Carey filed a lawsuit against the provision in 1987, and the union's executive board, apparently fearing an adverse ruling, changed it to permit a majority to reject a proposed contract. Mr. Carey also began to speak out more forcefully against the international leaders' lavish incomes.
Now perceived as a growing threat, Mr. Carey found his name expunged from international newsletters and house organs, and at a national convention the microphone was cut off once as he appealed for a cut in dues. Occasionally, his friends said, there were threatening calls in the night.
His increasing prominence and his willingness to take on the union bosses in Washington -- portrayed in news accounts as a David-versus-Goliath battle -- upset the international leaders. But his rebellion generally coincided with new setbacks that were preoccupying the union.
Since the 1950's, Federal investigators said, the international union had been mired in corruption. Three of the union's last five presidents -- James R. Hoffa, Dave Beck and Roy L. Williams -- went to jail on charges of bribery and tampering with pension funds. A fourth president, Jackie Presser, was indicted for embezzlement but died in 1988 without being tried.
 
New Rules From Government
 In 1988 the Government filed an anti-racketeering suit against the union and a panel was named to oversee its affairs. In 1989, to settle the suit, the union allowed the Government to expel 138 leaders and agreed to have leaders chosen by members' secret ballots rather than delegates in convention.
This radically changed the prospects for Mr. Carey and his insurgency. Backed by Teamsters for a Democratic Union, a small but growing movement to fight corrupt leaders from within, and encouraged by a real chance of election, Mr. Carey began a two-year campaign for the presidency.
Mr. Carey did not join the group, but its grass-roots network was vital to him, providing heavy support among truckers in the Midwest.
His campaign was financed mostly by small contributions of members, who put up $200,000. He criss-crossed the country in a beat-up station wagon, staying at members' homes and low-budget hotels, meeting teamsters in yards and halls, and talking about corruption, bad contracts and a membership that had declined from 2.2 million in 1979 to 1.5 million.
After the results were in, Professor Aronowitz, of the City University Graduate Center, attributed the victory to Mr. Carey's determined democratic stance and clean image and to a low turnout that enhanced the value of his enthusiastic supporters.
Mr. Carey celebrated yesterday with his wife, Barbara, a sales clerk at Macy's in Queens, and their five children: Ronald Jr., 35, Daniel, 33, Sandra Perrone, 32, Barbara Marchese, 30, and Pamela Casabara, 28.
"It's a new union for the members and their families," Mr. Carey said. "It's goodbye to all the things of the past. The Mafia. The mob. All those who don't want to work hard. Goodbye to those who put themselves first, who are not concerned with the members or their families."

HEADLINE: Bush Tells Mexico He Wants a Free-Trade Pact Soon

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14

 BODY:
President Bush today told President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico that he wanted a free-trade agreement as soon as possible, even as support is waning in Congress for considering such a pact in an election year.
In talks at the President's Camp David retreat in Maryland, Mr. Bush also told Mr. Salinas that Mexican concessions would be needed to obtain a politically acceptable deal, according to an Administration official who insisted on anonymity. 
 The official said that the two presidents and their advisers had disagreed in particular on the extent to which Mexico would open its oil-services industry -- which many Mexicans consider to be part of the national patrimony -- to American competition.
 
'A Lot of Work' Ahead
 Mr. Bush called for a draft agreement, with differences between the two countries noted in brackets, to be ready by the end of next month, the official said. The President also noted that reaching a pact "would take a lot of work and include some give on the part of the Mexicans," the official added.
Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said in a statement after the meeting, "Acknowledging the substantial progress that has been made to date, the two presidents reaffirmed their strong commitment to the achievement of a North American Free Trade Agreement."
The Administration official who requested anonymity said that while Mr. Bush had told Mr. Salinas and advisers that he "wants a good agreement as soon as possible," no specific month was set for concluding the talks and submitting a deal to Congress. Mr. Bush and Mr. Salinas also spoke for an hour without any advisers present and did not reveal the nature of their discussions, the official added.
 
A Divided Administration
 Administration officials had told industry lobbyists that a deal could be submitted to Congress next year and approved before the election. But controversy last spring over whether a complicated agreement could be negotiated that fast, and a lingering recession that has magnified concerns about possible job losses from a trade pact, have left the Administration divided on when and how to proceed.
The Commerce and State Departments have been more enthusiastic for prompt action in recent weeks than the Office of the United States Trade Representative.
Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher said on Dec. 2 that he hoped to have a draft agreement ready for Congress by next March. But Carla A. Hills, the Trade Representative, has for the last eight months resisted providing any target dates for legislation. "We have no intention of substituting speed for substance," she said again at a White House news briefing on Friday.
When Administration officials were wooing industry lobbyists early last spring to join them in pushing for a deal, they spoke in terms of submitting a package to Congress in early 1992 for approval before the election. But the Administration retreated from this position in late spring when it was criticized for being too willing to rush an agreement.
If an agreement is not approved next year, it could become a political casualty of the recession. The agreement's fate in 1993 would depend on whether President Bush and members of Congress who support a deal are re-elected.
Democratic senators and representatives with strong free-trade beliefs joined Republicans last May to renew President Bush's legal authority to negotiate trade agreements and submit them for expedited consideration by Congress. The votes in both houses then were viewed as ballots on whether the United States should seek a free trade agreement with Mexico.
 
Warning From Democrats
 But in telephone interviews this week, some of the same Democrats were unenthusiastic about trying to pass an agreement next year. They warned that as long as the economy is weak and public opinion polls show wide concern about unemployment, a trade agreement that promises not only job gains but also highly visible job losses will be very hard to sell in Congress.
"It's not in the President's interest to bring this up," said Representative Robert T. Matsui, a California Democrat and strong free-trade supporter on the House Subcommittee on Trade. "He'll lose it on the floor of the House and Senate next year if he brings it up."
House and Senate leaders are more reserved while beginning to express similiar worries to Administration officials.
"I'll tell them what the problems are, and they'll face a tough political time in the Congress, but it's their decision," said Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who chairs the Senate Finance Committee.
Senator Max S. Baucus, the Montana Democrat who chairs the Senate Subcommittee on International Trade, said that "the mood of Congress has shifted somewhat" and made it tougher to pass any international trade pact.
Mr. Baucus, Mr. Bentsen and Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon led the successful "fast-track" renewal effort last May. Mr. Packwood, Republican, does not expect the Administration to submit the agreement to Congress next year because so many complicated issues remain to be negotiated, said a Republican Senate aide.
Support for the prompt passage of a free trade agreement has also been weakening in the House. The majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt, said that while he was still willing to vote for an agreement that protected the interests of American workers, he was increasingly skeptical that the Administration was able or willing to negotiate such a deal.
The Missouri Democrat's reluctant endorsement last May helped secure the renewal of the President's "fast-track" authority.
But Representative Don J. Pease, an Ohio Democrat who has opposed a free-trade agreement because of concerns that American workers cannot compete with low-wage Mexican workers, said that it was too soon to dismiss the possibility of Congress's approving an agreement.
"The situation is still pretty fluid," he said. "Members of Congress traditionally don't engage issues before they have to."
Opponents of a free-trade agreement seized last month on the election in Pennsylvania of Harris Wofford to the United States Senate on a campaign that included criticisms of a trade pact with Mexico as well as calls for change in the nation's health-care system. But Pennsylvania, with its long-struggling steel industry, has long ranked as among the most protectionist states in the nation, and few members of Congress see it as representative of national sentiments on trade.
"For 20 years, every senator, every representative they have had from that area has been very protectionist," said Representative Sam M. Gibbons, the Florida Democrat who chairs the House Subcommittee on Trade and was elected to the House in 1962.
The protectionist theme of conservative columnist Patrick J. Buchanan's campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination has made the prospects for a North American Free Trade Agreement even murkier. Under President Ronald Reagan, by contrast, the isolationist and protectionist currents in the Republican Party's conservative wing had been muted.
"If they become more nationalistic, there's not going to be many people in this country who are free traders other than a few intellectuals in New York, like the Council on Foreign Relations and a few others," Mr. Matsui said.

HEADLINE: With Little Meaning, Florida Offers First Democratic Contest

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla., Dec. 14

 BODY:
It was perhaps fitting that the first contest of the 1992 Presidential campaign is being staged in the shadow of Walt Disney's Magic Kingdom.
All the trappings of a legitimate political event were on display today at the Florida Democratic Party's convention: There were fiery speeches. There was a hall jammed with placard-waving delegates. There were balloons and bumper stickers. There were competing cocktail parties with the candidates. 
 But even the Democrats' leading cheerleader, Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, showed up at the convention, on the eve of a straw poll of the delegates, to throw cold water on the whole affair.
"I don't like beauty contests, I don't like straw polls," he said. "There's been some experiences in the past that those who win straw polls don't win primaries."
 
'This Doesn't Mean Anything'
 Although party leaders dismissed the nonbinding poll as meaningless, four Democratic candidates sought today to win support. Not willing to forfeit an event that could carry symbolic significance, the candidates worked quietly but aggressively to court the more than 2,300 delegates who will vote on Sunday.
After a day of speeches where the candidates united in their bashing of President Bush for the sorry state of the economy, one delegate who was not fooled was Sam C. Loper 3d, a salesman from Seminole, Fla.
"In the end," Mr. Loper said, "this doesn't mean anything. Nine months from now, what happened here probably won't be what happened in the rest of the country."
The cynicism did not dampen the enthusiasm of Simon Ferro, the state Democratic chairman, who in a burst of overstatement proclaimed to the delegates: "The 1992 Presidential campaign starts here today, this weekend. We Florida Democrats are going to play a crucial and relevant role in choosing our party's nominee."
The frenetic campaigning of four candidates here -- Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas and former Senator Paul Tsongas of Massachusetts -- belied their aides' efforts to play down the poll's symbolic significance. Mr. Clinton and Mr. Harkin were the most aggressive behind the scenes, with their campaigns sending letters and videotapes of the candidates' speeches to potential supporters.
 
Saving Barbs for Bush
 In speeches here today, each of the four contenders sought to convince state party officials that he should win the straw poll and that he would capture the nomination next year. The candidates took pains not to directly attack one another, saving their barbs for Mr. Bush, who they assailed as neglecting the nation's domestic needs.
Mr. Clinton, the first to speak, described himself as best positioned to defeat Mr. Bush. In a clear response to critics who say he is too moderate, he defended his Democratic credentials.
"I've heard all that rhetoric about who's a real Democrat," he said. "I've supported every Democratic nominee since I was old enough to vote. I remember two Democrats accused of not being liberal enough: John Kennedy and Jimmy Carter."
Accusing Mr. Bush of lacking a vision to deal with joblessness and education, Mr. Clinton said, "We do not need a president of either party who doesn't know what he wants to do for America."
Mr. Kerrey, vowing to "make George Bush a one-term President," called for "fundamental change" in how the Government is run. "We've been led on a course of economic decline," he said. "We have been led off course by a President who has invited a season of cynicism."
Mr. Harkin sounded his theme of a return to unabashed liberalism. "I'm going to make George Herbert Walker Bush apologize for what he has done to America," he said. "I want a president who feels at home in America. It's time for us to take our traditional Democratic values to the American people. And those traditional Democratic values can be summed up in two words: economic opportunity."
Mr. Tsongas derided Mr. Bush as a "foreign minister -- not a president." He said "George Bush has finally met an unemployed person in New Hampshire: His name is John Sununu." Saying that calls for a middle-class tax cut amounted to political rhetoric that would not truly help the middle class, he assailed them as "twinkie economics -- it tastes great but no nutritional value."
Mr. Tsongas also insisted that he was not in the race to lose. "Some have said losing is good for your character -- I have enough character."
 
Waiting for Cuomo
 Several delegates said after the speeches that no candidate emerged from the pack by virtue of his oratory. But even as they played down the importance of a horse race, many delegates seemed to agree that the contest for first place was between Mr. Harkin, who benefits because so many delegates are from organized labor, one of his bastions of support, and Mr. Clinton, who has the regional advantage of being from the South. Two candidates did not attend: Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia and former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California.
Several delegates said the relevance of the convention would be further called into question if Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York announced his candidacy. A handful of convention delegates were still holding out, wearing "Waiting for Mario" buttons on their lapels, and some Cuomo partisans were passing out business cards today promoting a write-in effort on Sunday.
Former Gov. Reubin Askew of Florida placed first in the straw poll in 1983, but fell short of a majority because of strong labor support for Walter F. Mondale, who ultimately won the nomination. Four years ago, the national party frowned upon the straw poll as needlessly exhausting the candidates' time and money and prevailed upon Florida Democrats not to hold the event.
But this year, state party officials, seeking to bolster Florida's profile in national politics, said that since the field was off to a relatively late start it was important for contenders to get an early opportunity to make a mark.
"It's not a sacrificial thing -- bite your tongue," insisted Mr. Ferro. The outcome, he said, will show Floridians who is best organized in advance of the state's primary on March 10 when 160 delegates, the seventh-largest delegation of any state, will be up for grabs.
Many party officials say the results of the poll will be further overshadowed by Sunday night's first national debate among Presidential candidates. But Warren T. Zeuch, a delegate and retired deputy sheriff, said the poll may not be for naught. "We may just be a straw ballot today," he said. "But it could be a strong indicator of how the country feels tomorrow."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Four Democratic Presidential candidates have been working to win support from delegates at the Florida Democratic Party's convention in Lake Buena Vista before a straw poll, considered the first contest of the 1992 campaign. Senator Bob Kerrey, a candidate, greeted delegates there yesterday. (Associated Press)

LENGTH: 735 words

HEADLINE: CHINA'S INDUSTRIES QUITTING THE HILLS

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GUIYANG, China

 BODY:
A postscript to the cold war is being written here: a missile factory has been converted to make refrigerators.
Just as important, the refrigerators are rolling off assembly lines not in the company's old location in the mountains of south-central China but in a new industrial zone here in the provincial capital. As the people here say, the tiger has come out of the mountains. 
 The tiger is China's so-called Third Line of industry, built mostly in the 1960's. Fearing attack by the United States or the Soviet Union, Mao Zedong ordered 2,000 companies representing a large share of China's industrial and military capacity removed from vulnerable coastal areas to remote hillside towns in the country's interior. Mao thought that the Communists could rely on that Third Line of industry even if an enemy attacked the coast.
It was an extraordinary scheme, the most daring and perhaps the most ill-considered industrial relocation plan that any country had ever attempted. From the mid-1960's to the mid-1970's, nearly half of China's budget went to Third Line construction, but the new factories tended to be inefficient because of poor infrastructure and supply lines.
 
Moving Back to Cities
 In this post-Mao, post-cold-war era, the Third Line companies are now moving back to the cities, and in many cases retooling to make consumer goods instead of weapons. Across the nation, enterprises that once produced tanks and missiles and other military products are now making 650 kinds of civilian goods. Here in Guiyang, the capital of Guizhou province, two new industrial zones are filling up with Third Line factories making everything from transistors to automobile headlights.
"Intellectuals are very happy with the move, after being in the mountains for two decades," said Wang Quan, director of the Guiyang office of the Zhenhua Electronics Industry Corporation, one such enterprise. "Life is better here, there is entertainment and culture, and there's better education for the kids."
Of the 700,000 industrial workers in Guizhou Province who work in Third Line enterprises, about a third have already moved to the cities or are in the process of doing so, according to Hu Lun, chief economist of the Guizhou Province Planning Commission.
 
Efficiency and Location
 "We plan to move all our workers to Guiyang," said Mr. Wang, of Zhenhua, which has 30,000 employees at 21 factories scattered across Guizhou. "But that will depend on economics and on how efficient the factories are here."
One of the factories that already has moved and started operations in Guiyang is the Jianxin Machine Factory, a unit of Zhenhua that makes stone cutters, drill presses and other industrial equipment. In the past it exported some goods to Eastern Europe and now the managers are hoping that the improved location will improve exports to the West.
"It's much more convenient here," said Feng Yisong, a senior engineer of the factory. "Transportation is much easier, and it's far simpler to make contacts and get a hold of people. So our efficiency is much better now."
The factory shop -- emblazoned with huge red characters across the wall declaring: "Socialism is Good. The Communist Party is Good" -- is spacious and is taking advantage of a tax break to install some brand-new equipment in addition to assembly lines brought in from its old location near the town of Duyun.
 
Creating a Society
 The director of the nearby New Cloud Equipment Factory, Long Hanmin, said that though there is a hefty cost to moving the plant and all of its employees to Guiyang, the move will soon pay for itself in improved efficiency and reduced transportation costs.
"We used to be a company town and had to create our own society," said Mr. Long. "We had to provide schools, restaurants, a movie theater and a hospital. In Guiyang, we don't have to do any of that."
Mr. Long's factory used to make electronic components for the army, but it shifted a half-dozen years ago to manufacturing similar civilian products, like transistors and capacitors. These days, the transition from military production to civilian production is well underway, not just in Guizhou but throughout China.
For Guizhou Province, one of the poorest in China, that switch -- coupled with the emergence from the mountains of the Third Line "tiger" -- also offers an important opportunity to lure foreign investment.
