HEADLINE: The Kind of Ransoms We Paid for Hostages;
For Reform in Iran

 BODY:
To the Editor:
For the first time since the seizure of the United States Embassy in Teheran in November 1979, no American is being held as hostage in Iran or Lebanon. While there is every cause for joy and celebration to mark this event, it is nonetheless prudent to bear in mind, once the dust has settled from the mood of euphoria, that every person responsible for instigation of the policies that held the United States and its Western allies hostage to their every whim remains in high office within the so-called Islamic Republic of Iran. 
 All the underlying reasons for their resorting to hostage taking and international terrorism in the first instance, such as a strong sense of insecurity, have been exacerbated by widespread unpopularity, largely as a result of futile warmongering and the worst economic crisis in Iran's modern history, imposed by incompetence and mismanagement.
"Hostages and Haste" (editorial, Dec. 3) draws attention to some of Iran's other sinister activities, which have always been overshadowed by the plight of the hostages, and I strongly agree that the restoration of normal relations by the West should be made contingent on genuine internal political reforms in Iran.
I am deeply concerned that in the aftermath of Iran's apparent exoneration from the Pan Am 103 tragedy, that the release of nearly all Western hostages should not give the Islamic authorities carte blanche to deal as they see fit with the suffering people of Iran. I should like to remind the international community that no sooner had Terry Anderson reached the Syrian Foreign Ministry in Damascus than Iranian authorities announced the execution of several "antirevolutionaries and monarchists" out of 300 who were arrested on the day Joseph Cicippio was freed.
I am hopeful that the release of all hostages marks the end of Western governmental cynicism to the plight of the Iranian people, and I believe that the international community, in particular the United States, no longer has any reason to be reticent about voicing uncompromising support for political freedoms and human rights in Iran.
 
REZA PAHLAVI
Mclean, Va., Dec. 5, 1991
 
The writer is the son of the late Shah.

HEADLINE: SOVIET DISARRAY;
A Texas Maverick Is Bullish on the Russian Bear

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14

 BODY:
President Bush named Robert S. Strauss as Ambassador to Moscow figuring his old friend was just the man to sell capitalism to the Communists and the Soviet Union to American capitalists.
But capitalism has fallen on hard times at home, Communists are an endangered species, the Soviet Union is vanishing and the crusty Texas millionaire with a reputation for being able to sell anything to anyone is finding this sale the toughest of his life. 
 During a weeklong visit to Washington, where he does as much of his real work as in Moscow, Mr. Strauss sounded like a latter-day Horace Greeley urging young Americans to go East, occasionally like a diplomat analyzing Soviet affairs, and mostly like the political strategist that he has been for decades.
"We've got a natural political problem here," he said, growling down the phone line from his spartan State Department office to Robert W. Galvin, the Motorola chairman, who is helping him rally business to the cause of investing in the Soviet Union. "People are going to say, 'Why the hell are we creating jobs over there when we should be creating jobs here?' "
 
A Familiar Argument
 Mr. Strauss nodded as Mr. Galvin made the argument that Mr. Strauss often makes: investing abroad creates jobs at home and a prosperous, democratic Soviet Union will make the world safer. "You put the case just like that and tell them I'm behind you and I've talked to Jim Baker about it," Mr. Strauss said.
This is just the sort of thing Mr. Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d had in mind when they hired Mr. Strauss in August to serve as Mr. Bush's conduit to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and to promote American investment in the Soviet Union.
Mr. Strauss talks of his friendships with Mr. Gorbachev, Boris N. Yeltsin, the K.G.B. chief, and other luminaries with his usual flair and abandon, and with the homespun humor and Texas epithets that make him a brass band in the chamber-music world of diplomats and Sovietologists.
No one who knows the 73-year-old lawyer doubts that he has established a rapport with the former Communists, just as the Democratic back-room strategist made friends in both parties over the years.
 
An Old Pitchman
 Mr. Strauss is an accomplished pitchman, putting enough humor and skepticism into his tone (reminding everyone, for example, that he has no intention of voting for Mr. Bush next year) to make it seem that if it is snake oil he is selling, it is still worth buying.
"If I was 40 years old and I had $100,000 and I wanted to run it into $10 million, I'd go to the Soviet Union and I would find a place and invest it there, because it is going to be a booming economy one of these days," he said, adding with a laugh: "If I was worth $10 million, I would take that $10 million and I'd invest $100,000 of it in the Soviet Union, and no more."
It is not easy to get businessmen to invest in a country that looks like it might explode into civil war at any second -- especially when Americans are increasingly concerned about their own problems and skeptical about helping a far-off country that used to be the enemy.
This week, on one of the trips home that Mr. Strauss said he intends to make every two months or so, he met with dozens of businessmen, persuaded seven investment banking houses to send representatives to the Soviet Union, testified before Congress and delivered two speeches.
 
Frustrated Enthusiasm
 He tried to sound enthusiastic, but at times was clearly frustrated.
"I spend an awful lot of time feeling like I'm not accomplishing anything or it's a waste of time or I wish I was home," Mr. Strauss said in an interview on Friday. "Then about every three or four days, something will come up and I'll have a feeling that, well, the President was right, I did something today that my background and my experiences made me well-suited for."
Mr. Strauss's ability to make friends may have been far less important than Mr. Bush had anticipated before the aborted Kremlin coup in August stood Soviet politics on its head. Mr. Strauss arrived in Moscow on the day the coup began collapsing.
"Everyone thinks highly of Strauss, but he was overtaken by events," an Administration official said. "He went with a mandate to develop a personal relationship with Gorbachev. He was going to be the symbol of the Western economic model for Gorbachev." The official said that "the ground rules changed" with the decline of the Soviet center and that Mr. Strauss's relationship with Mr. Gorbachev would now have no impact on events there.
 
Political Instincts
 But John Lewis Gaddis, a historian of Soviet-American diplomacy, said that Mr. Strauss has strong political instincts and an access to Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker denied many ambassadors.
"My sense is that Strauss is pushing an agenda at the moment that is a little different from what the White House is trying to do," Mr. Gaddis said. "Strauss is running around raising the alarm that we ought to be doing something, although it's not entirely clear what. The Administration seems to be holding back waiting for the dust to settle."
Mr. Strauss's approach to the Soviet Union as a larger version of his native Texas may seem simplistic. He is not the sort of ambassador to provide historical sweep, as George F. Kennan did in 1947 by articulating the policy of "containment" to stop Soviet expansion. He will never master the Russian language. And he has had to learn from scratch facts of Soviet life that are old news to a Kremlinologist.
 
Knowing One's Audience
 But Mr. Strauss countered that Sovietologists are not his audience -- the President and American businessmen are.
"I didn't go over there to learn the culture of the Soviet Union," he said. "I went over there to get my hands on their problems. Everyone knows I'm not a Sovietologist. I am familiar with dealing with political problems and political power and from time to time have had the experience of trying to influence the direction that power flows."
While Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker avoid analyzing the Soviet power balance, Mr. Strauss does not mind at all. Here is his assessment of Mr. Gorbachev, Mr. Yeltsin and President Leonid Kravchuk of Ukraine:
"Obviously President Yeltsin's standing in the polls is much higher than Gorbachev. He's a far more popular person, but as he and Chairman Kravchuk, for example, get together, each of them begin to find they're not quite as popular as they were before they got together, because Mr. Kravchuk ran on a campaign that did not indicate he was going to be in bed with President Yeltsin. And President Yeltsin, who in taking care of his business denounced Chairman Kravchuk with regularity, is in bed with him. And we might as well be in American politics."
 
Politics as Poker
 Mr. Strauss is frank about the risks of investing in the Soviet Union. "What we invest may go up in smoke," he said, and then added: "Certainly you can make an argument that they're heading for anarchy, that despair and hunger and homelessness will take over and out of these ashes will come another demagogue, another Stalin. That is a real possiblity and our money will have been lost."
Mr. Strauss says repeatedly that he would be cautious with American aid. "I'm a poker player, Mr. Chairman, a pretty good one," he told the House Armed Services Committee last week. "And they say I talk loose and play tight and I think I would probably talk loose about that aid and would play tight. I'd want to be damned sure we got our money's worth out of it."
But he is fervent in making the case for American investment in the Soviet Union.
"The next big ethnic fight we're going to have to deal with is, I think, that the Germans and the Japanese are going to meet somewhere in the Urals and we're going to see the damndest fight you ever saw, because they're each coming from different directions and we're going to be on the sidelines," he said.
"In my lifetime," he said, "we have won a major war and won this peace, and we now have won a second war, and we're at risk, great risk, of not winning the peace."

HEADLINE: A Holiday Season With Little Cheer

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN

 BODY:
Christmas hangs in the air over New York City, like the aroma of chestnuts roasting in the pretzel vendors' carts. It sounds like Christmas, with the voices of Dean Martin, Vickie Carr and the Chipmunks wafting from different store windows and spilling onto the sidewalks.
In some parts of the city it even looks like Christmas, with the explosion of white lights on the Rockefeller Center angels, the 55-foot balsam fir at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx and the clever displays in the windows of Barney's that really have very little to do with Christmas. (There was, for example, Margaret Thatcher sporting black leather and chains and a belt buckle that said Tory Toy. A few windows down, a two-headed Norman Mailer stood beside two erupting volcanoes that said Ego and Erudition.) 
 Though there is nothing like Christmas in New York, this year the holiday cheer was as fragile as a glass ornament. Not only has the weather been mild, but the economy has been as bad as anyone remembers in recent times, and it shows.
At Macy's, where giant wreaths fill the air with the scent of pine, executives are worried about revenues and perennial rumors of the company's impending demise. The Pan Am building looming over a festooned midtown is a grim reminder of a recently shuttered airline that left 7,500 people unemployed. With the city's unemployment rate at 10.2 percent, the highest for a November since 1977, it's little wonder that holiday shoppers seem to be wary of sinking further into debt.
Ahmed Aliyu, a taxicab driver, has his own barometer for measuring the state of the economy.
"In other years around this time, you wouldn't be picking up anyone without shopping bags," Mr. Aliyu said. "On Wednesday, I don't remember picking up even one person who had a shopping bag."
 
Maybe It's the Weather
 New Yorkers are trying to get into the spirit of the season, but there is an undercurrent of worry, or at least a sense that this year things are not as merry as in Christmases past. And in some parts of the city, there are few signs of the holiday at all.
On Columbus Avenue near 77th Street, David Richardson, an architect and former New Yorker who now lives in Baltimore, said that he was surprised at the paucity of Christmas decorations in some parts of the city and that Baltimore seemed to be the same way this year.
"But it's better than this," said Mr. Richardson, who was in New York visiting friends. "I guess I figured it would be jumping more than this. It seems like New York is on its back."
Audrey Shepps, a video editor who was shopping near 76th Street, agreed. Maybe the weather had something to do with it, she wondered. "There's no Christmas spirit at all," she said. "It's like Miami here."
 
One Wish Come True: A Job
 While a crowd of children lined up to wait for a breakfast with Santa at Lord & Taylor, dozens of adults packed into its personnel office.
Charles Bullitt emerged smiling.
The 30-year-old Mr. Bullitt had been unemployed since January, when he was laid off from his job as sales manager of a shoe department in another store. Last month, his wife was laid off by American Express, so things have been touch-and-go for the Bullitts and their 2-year-old daughter.
Two days ago he was notified that he had been hired as a shoe salesman for Lord & Taylor. He was at the store yesterday filling out paperwork and said he had only one wish for this Christmas: "To be able to get a couple of gifts to give my wife and kid."
 
No 'Ho, Ho, Ho'
 At the Queens Mall, a throng of shoppers swarmed in and out of stores with children in tow.
Jerome McCray, who stood watching a huge teddy bear display with his wife and three children, said the weather was making all the difference this year. "There's some spirit but it's not like when I was growing up," he said. "Then, snow would be on the ground already."
Mary Moraglia of Howard Beach, who works in advertising, stood near a railing waiting for her husband.
"I feel like everything just changed," she said. "It doesn't feel like Christmas anymore. People don't have a 'Ho, ho, ho!' kind of feeling. There's too much stress."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Passers-by stopping to look at the Christmas displays in the windows of Lord and Taylor on Fifth Avenue. (Edward Keating/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Old World With One Currency Is New to U.S.

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14

 BODY:
Though this week's decision by the European Community to adopt a single currency by the end of the decade could affect everything from the dollar's role in global markets to the price of French wine at the local store, the implications for the United States of the action are little known and less discussed.
The Treasury and State departments have barely begun to analyze the issue, and at banks and corporations the thinking on the subject is largely confined to economists and foreign exchange experts. 
 For Americans abroad, the significance of a single currency is clear. "The simple answer is that when traveling in Europe, he does not have to change his money every time he crosses a border," said Horst Schulmann, the managing director of the Institute of International Finance.
But for American consumers at home, the question is more complicated. It rests in part on whether the new currency would supplant the dollar among countries, said Eric A. Feldstein, the treasurer of General Motors' European operations. German cameras and Swiss watches could become expensive.
As for businesses, the answer varies. For David L. Fiedler, the director of foreign exchange planning at Eastman Kodak, which sells film all over the world, a single European currency could simplify his job of preventing the company's overseas profits from being wiped out by exchange rate changes.
For American corporations with large manufacturing operations in Europe, like General Motors, the issue is especially complicated. These companies now spread their parts and assembly plants across Europe, trying to produce goods in the country where they are sold because markets supplied with exports can be easily lost in sudden swings in exchange rates.
Multinational companies are already beginning to concentrate production in a few low-cost countries as they prepare for European customs barriers to fall next year. The decision on whether to consolidate factories further will depend in part on whether the advantages of dealing with fewer currencies offset the risk that inflation rates may vary widely among countries, said Eric A. Feldstein, the treasurer of General Motors' European operations.
For most bankers, corporate executives, economists and Federal officials, however, the opportunities -- or dangers -- are unclear.
Charles H. Dallara, until last summer the Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for international affairs, said the Bush Administration had not reflected enough on the implications of a single European currency. "There is hardly time to think, much less reflect, because budget constraints have left the Treasury short on planning staff."
The exact effects of a single European currency would depend on the political independence and foreign currency reserves of a possible European central bank -- two key issues that have not yet been decided.
A weak central bank would allow a high-inflation currency that would tend to devalue slowly against other currencies, thereby reducing its acceptability outside Europe.
On the other hand, if the Europeans can come up with a persuasive means to limit its supply, the new currency might begin to supplant the dollar.
With that erosion could come a slow erosion of the dollar's exchange rate, experts said, and that would tend to make imported products ranging from German cameras to Chinese toys more expensive. But the world's central banks, which according to the International Monetary Fund held $472 billion in dollars and dollar-denominated securities at the end of April, have little incentive to sell large chunks of their reserves. Such selling would push down the dollar's value quickly and leave their remaining holdings worth less, several economists contended.
For American corporations, the immediate effect of a common European currency is likely to be administrative. "I think we could probably do with fewer foreign exchange traders," as well as fewer multiple currency bank accounts and other costs, Mr. Feldstein of General Motors said.

HEADLINE: The Fall Of Gorbachev/A special report.;
A Russian Is Swept Aside By the Forces He Released

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 14

 BODY:
Looking back now, the August coup was both Mikhail S. Gorbachev's finest moment, and the start of the final act in his tumultuous reign.
The collapse of the pathetic coup was his victory. It demonstrated that the freedoms he had loosed had taken root, and it brought out the qualities of courage and determination that brought about the end of the cold war. 
 But with the collapse of the coup, the last pillars of the old order also collapsed, setting the republics free to partition what remained of the empire and perhaps to seek their destiny in a new commonwealth, not Mr. Gorbachev's.
 
Seven-Year Journey Ends
 Now, the man who set out almost seven years earlier to reform the world's biggest empire finds himself on the verge of being swept aside by the very forces he set loose. And although his Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, was still calling on him today not to resign, it seems more and more certain that he will have to give up the role he has played in exchange for some unknown future.
In the four months since the coup, Mr. Gorbachev seemed to have relived his entire remarkable career. Back on that August night when he returned to Moscow in his tan windbreaker from 72 hours of captivity, the President had seemed aglow with moral triumph, with the conviction of a destiny affirmed.
It was a golden moment, and it seemed that he was aware of this. "They say I've returned to a different country," he said. "I could even say another country."
But once again events seemed to slip past his grasp. He could have gone straight to Boris N. Yeltsin's euphoric White House, home of the Russian republic's government, where the crowds that had faced down the tanks would have hoisted him on their shoulders. He could have embraced Mr. Yeltsin, and with him the new era that had opened.
But when Mr. Gorbachev did appear on the next day, it was at a news conference at which he once again invoked the forgotten Lenin and the tired "socialist choice." He talked of the coup as an attack against him personally -- "The President of the country was isolated from the country and the world. The objective was to crush the President morally, to crush his family, but they failed" -- but he failed to see that people had stood up not for him, but for the freedoms he had enabled them to taste.
By the time he appeared before the Russian Parliament, the sympathy was draining, and the moment was lost. His expressions of gratitude to Mr. Yeltsin sounded forced, as did his acceptance of a measure of responsibility.
From that moment, it seemed, his final course was set. Without the pillars of the old order on which to lean, there was only the strength of his character and the symbolism of his name left to resist the sacking of his "center."
Slowly, inexorably, he changed from a champion of a new order to an obstacle in its way. Instead of a new partnership, he entered on the final collision course with his nemesis and alter-ego, Mr. Yeltsin.
The moment of greatness followed by a maddening stubborness in these last four months seemed almost a replay of a career that both electrified and frustrated his nation and the world.
On coming to power in March 1985, Mr. Gorbachev began processes that nobody could have foreseen. The people of his country were given back the right to think and speak, taboos that had held one-sixth of the world's land mass in thrall were broken, and an East-West confrontation fueled by enough megatons of nuclear arms to pulverize the earth began to lift.
The "new thinking" wrought miracles abroad. Eastern Europe was set free. Soviet troops pulled out of Afghanistan. The cold war came to an end. Mr. Gorbachev was greeted around the world by admiring crowds chanting, "Gorby! Gorby!" He was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
 
Fatal Flaw
World Hero Misreads Home
 But at home, from the outset, he seemed incapable of fully comprehending the forces he had released. He tried to impose change from above, the way Communists were taught. He tried to impose a homogeneity on a land when it was only beginning to recover in diversity.
Instead of riding with history, in the uncharitable words of Anatoly A. Sobchak, the St. Petersburg Mayor, "he tried to reform the unreformable." He sought to tailor the pace of reform in society to the evolution of the Communist Party, convinced that the party could be "renewed" and that socialism could be made to function.
Again and again, he accepted the inevitable only when it was too late. He resisted every vital change -- private property, radical economic reform, the ouster of the Communist party, power-sharing with the republics -- until the country came to the edge of chaos. He bullied and bloodied the Baltic states until they were left with no choice but to leave the union entirely. He resisted federation and power-sharing until the centrifugal forces became all but unmanageable.
Proud and stubborn, he drove his most devoted comrades away and surrounded himself with Communist toadies, and he refused to sack them even when men like Eduard A. Shevardnadze, his Foreign Minister, and Aleksandr N. Yakovlev, a well-trusted top aide, screamed that they were plotting against him.
That Mr. Gorbachev already has carved out a deep niche in history is self-evident. But whether historians prove to be as tolerant as his contemporaries have been depends to a great deal on the fate of the processes he set loose.
If they fail -- if the Soviet land disintegrates into chaos, famine, civil war, fascist dictatorship or some other horror -- he may go down in history as the man who missed the opportunities. If they succeed, chronicles may record him as a visionary who managed to ease out the world's most formidable totalitarian dictatorship.
Today, to those now watching spellbound as he ponders his exit, he appears a tragic hero, a giant whose decline and fall stem from the same qualities that raised him to greatness: self-confidence and stubborness bordering on arrogance; pride that defied humiliation but made him deaf to critics; a decency and morality that gained him trust, but made it hard for him to shed the illusory humanitarianism of the Marxist faith.
He is a child of the Soviet 60's, a generation that still believed that the romantic Leninist faith could be melded with the democracy and market forces of the West. It was a generation that refused to accept that the failures of the system were inherent in the ideology. In the words of Aleksandr Bovin, the new Soviet Ambassador to Israel and himself a product of the 60's, it was a generation that "wanted its sausage and its freedom, too."
 
Early Euphoria
Old Guard Out, Glasnost In
 Mr. Gorbachev came to power convinced that the sausage would come with the freedom. He was not alone in that belief. Many in the West also seemed convinced in those less complicated times that if only a breath of openness was allowed into what President Reagan called the "evil empire," people were certain to recognize the error of their ways and to choose happiness and prosperity.
The accession of Mr. Gorbachev, then 54 years old, was accompanied by enormous hoopla at home and abroad. The "old guard" had literally expired at the controls with the rapid-fire deaths of three Soviet leaders, Leonid I. Brezhnev, Yuri V. Andropov and Konstantin U. Chernenko.
Simply by being young and alive, Mr. Gorbachev represented a dramatic change. He did not disappoint. He plunged into the streets to preach a new gospel of "glasnost" -- openness. He ousted the corrupt old guard and brought in a team of decent, honest men, among them Mr. Yeltsin. He also declared war on vodka, which was highly symbolic in a land where drink had become a widely sought refuge. He promised far-reaching reform that would bring prosperity.
The euphoria was palpable as the dark truths of the Soviet past were brought to light. Soon other chains began to lift. The great dissident Andrei D. Sakharov returned to Moscow, Anatoly Shcharansky was released, hundreds of other dissidents were set free, the arts bloomed and religious faiths were set free. Intellectuals sang the praises of the new leader, while dissidents in China and Eastern Europe made his name a rallying cry.
The new era quickly spread beyond the Soviet borders. Eight months after coming to power, in November 1985, Mr. Gorbachev met in Geneva with President Reagan, signaling a new era in East-West relations.
With Mr. Shevardnadze at the Foreign Ministry, Soviet foreign policy entered an era of "new thinking." Nuclear arsenals were sharply reduced, the Afghan war was brought to an end, Germany was reunited, and the Iron Curtain became a curiosity for souvenir hunters.
At home, Soviet citizens voted for the first time in multi-party elections in 1989, granting seats in Parliament to Mr. Sakharov and other reformers, and the Communist Party formally surrendered its monopoly on power in February 1990.
 
The Decline
Economy Sinks And Yeltsin Rises
 But by this point the decline had also become clear. By his fifth anniversary in power in March 1990, Mr. Gorbachev was on the defensive. People now grumbled openly about the failed promises of economic reform. In response to Lithuania's declaration of independence, the President ordered an economic blockade, setting in motion a chain of events that would lead to bloodshed in January 1991.
His supporters argued ever louder that Mr. Gorbachev required a genuine popular mandate through national presidential elections to gather the strength needed for the radical reforms needed to save the economy. Instead, he sought and got a more powerful executive presidency for himself.
The first signs of disarray had already appeared long before. However great the changes in society, the economy continued to deteriorate, gripped by a jealous party bureaucracy that smothered efforts at reform. By his first anniversary in office Mr. Gorbachev was already railing at bureaucrats and red-tape.
Soon Mr. Yeltsin and other critics began to accuse Mr. Gorbachev of being too soft, too slow. Instead of heeding him, Mr. Gorbachev dismissed Mr. Yeltsin in November 1987. It would prove a fateful decision. Cut off from all traditional sources of power, spurning the party, Mr. Yeltsin would become the first major leader to rise via the newly opened route of democracy and politics in the republics.
The lifting of the lid off long-suppressed national ambitions also fired new independence movements in the Baltic republics, Georgia and Ukraine, and reopened ancient feuds between Azerbaijan and Armenia.
At the May Day parade in 1990, conservatives and liberals alike jeered Mr. Gorbachev. Soon after, Mr. Yeltsin won election to the Russian presidency, giving him a powerful new platform from which to combat Mr. Gorbachev and touching off a debilitating "war of presidents" that would end with troops in the streets of Moscow.
The end game probably dates from the summer of 1990, when Mr. Gorbachev rejected the "500-day program" of radical reform prepared by a group of liberal economists who wanted to speed the nation toward a free-market economy.
As Mr. Gorbachev's support among liberals waned, he turned increasingly to a clutch of uninspired party conservatives to run his Government. In December his closest comrade, Mr. Shevardnadze, quit with a dire warning of an impending coup. In January tanks took over the television tower in Lithuania, killing 14 people. In March when a pro-Yeltsin rally was scheduled, 50,000 troops converged on Moscow to prevent it.
Finally, in April, Mr. Gorbachev tried to turn back from the path he had taken away from his reform-minded advisers. Turning back to his old supporters, he gathered with leaders of nine republics to negotiate a new Union Treaty. But this one last attempt to change course abruptly proved too late.
On Aug. 19, the conservatives he had brought into the Kremlin put him under house arrest and declared martial law. It was a pathetic attempt, terribly planned by men oblivious to the degree to which fear had been lifted from society in the six years of glasnost.
Immediately after the coup, Mr. Gorbachev unleashed a quick torrent of measures that seemed to conjure up the Gorbachev of the summer past. In its wake, he suspended the party, dismised his Cabinet, purged the K.G.B., created a new power-sharing State Council and recognized the Baltic states. He seemed to be moving toward a new Union Treaty, with a new lease on life for himself, as disoriented republic presidents huddled around the Kremlin, alarmed at the prospect of chaotic disintegration. In this post-coup period, he even had a last hurrah on the international stage like the Gorbachev of old, when he matched President Bush's sweeping cuts of tactical weapons in early October.
But soon it became evident that suspiciousness of a new center across the nation outweighed all the arguments for it. When Ukraine finally declared that it would have no part of any new Moscow-based federation or agreement, and when its residents voted overwhelmingly for independence at the beginning of December, the union was finished.
It remained for Mr. Yeltsin to join with the leaders of Ukraine and Byelorussia last week to sign a death warrant for the old union and to proclaim a new commonwealth. Other republics, at first wary of the "Slavic union," soon flocked to the new banner. But this time, there was no room for Mr. Gorbachev.
 
Godunov's Fate
'Hunger, Plague, Fear and Ruin'
 In a nation that seeks precedent in literature, not in history, Mr. Gorbachev's fate oddly paralleled the lot of the 16th-century Czar whose portrait was drawn by the poet Pushkin in "Boris Godunov," and made by Moussorgsky into the most Russian of all operas.
Anguished by mounting troubles in his kingdom, the Czar broods over his fate in these lines:
I have attained the highest power,
 For the sixth year now do I rule in peace.
 Yet my tortured soul can find no happiness. . . .
 Here there is conspiracy, there sedition of the boyars,
 Lithuanian plots and secret machinations,
 Hunger and plague, fear and ruin. . . .
 Like wild beasts the people roam, stricken with disease!
 Russia groans in hunger and poverty!
The image of Boris Godunov anguishing over his fate as the end drew near seemed particularly tempting when Soviet television showed Mr. Gorbachev's three-hour session with Soviet reporters this week, a meeting many took as a farewell.
Ranging broadly over his record and the abrupt chain of events that had suddenly brought him to this turn, Mr. Gorbachev was at times angry, at times thoughtful, at times almost lighthearted -- and at times the familiar, wordy preacher.
Never a man given to self-pity or to displays of emotion, he was still in control, still coldly analytical, still proud of his achievements, and proudly firm that he and he alone would decide when it was time to exit from the stage.
He reiterated his conviction that the new Commonwealth marked a disastrous dissolution of the state he had tried so hard to preserve. But it was equally clear that he was steeling himself for the inevitable:
"I will resign. If the process ends this way I will resign. This is absolutely clear, no question. I am a moral man. Some of these new ones, I don't see morality."
There were also flashes of the Communist faith that Mr. Gorbachev could never fully shake.
He insisted that the party's rank and file could not be blamed for the sins of its leaders, and he argued that the original impetus for change came from the party, saying: "It was in the party that those very forces were born which had the boldness to launch these reforms. They did not have to. My generation, which came to power at its peak, could have assured itself of 10 peaceful years."
But as the conversation ranged back and forth, it seemed that both the President was groping for some deeper explanation, some clearer understanding of how things had come to this pass.
"I did all I could," Mr. Gorbachev said, almost with resignation. "You know, I think in my place others would have long quit this business."
He seemed conscious that he had fallen short somewhere, but if he was slow to order change, he argued, it was because he himself could change no faster. It would be easier for his daughter's generation, he said, adding: "We were already formed, and we began this process already when we were ripe. It is not so easy to break oneself. The most difficult thing is to break oneself."
In any case, he declared more than once, the main goal had been achieved: people had been irreversibly changed. "For all the mistakes, miscalculations, or on the contrary for all the great leaps, we accomplished the main preparatory political and human work," he said. "In this sense it will never be possible to turn society back. It cannot be penned in again by any force."
And yet as he spoke, it seemed that dark doubts stirred in the background. A man of strong principles and strong nerves, he seemed to be alarmed not by the specter of resignation but by the thought that his life's work might be in peril.
"Am I happy?" he mused. "A great task fell to my lot. I believe that I fulfilled it, that it came to be. The main achievement of my life has come to pass, and all the rest... Maybe others will come, maybe they will do more. But understand, I want this to succeed. This is my peculiarity: I do not want it to fail."

HEADLINE: A Day After the Jury's Vote, Miller Feels Fatalistic

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 14

 BODY:
Mel Miller, whose 21-year career in state politics was vaporized Friday night by the lightning strike of a jury's verdict, said today that he viewed his conviction with the same fatalism he feels when watching voters go to the polls.
"It's like losing an election," the former Assembly Speaker said in a telephone interview from his home in Brooklyn. "It's terrible. It's awful. But it's over. It happened. It's gone." 
 Mr. Miller and Jay Adolf, his former law partner and legislative aide, were convicted late Friday afternoon of 8 of the 19 Federal charges against them in a case in which the two were accused of cheating legal clients out of some of the profits from investments in cooperative apartments. Mr. Miller has yet to be sentenced and plans to appeal, but state law requires the immediate expulsion of legislators convicted of a felony.
An irrepressibly brash and flamboyant leader who was the consummate master of Albany's inside political game, Mr. Miller chose to view the verdict in electoral terms.
"We came in having to win all 19," Mr. Miller said, referring to the counts against him. "We won the majority but this was a case where the majority wasn't enough."
 
His Own Voice
 Even as his former Democratic colleagues were orchestrating the ascension of Assemblyman Saul Weprin of Queens as the new Speaker, Mr. Miller spent some time reflecting today on the legacy he left behind.
He said he was proudest of his ability to transform the Assembly, which now has a 94-to-55 Democratic majority, into a more substantive policy-making body, particularly on fiscal issues. He also said he was pleased to have given junior members of the Assembly majority a greater voice in the chamber's decision-making process and to have assembled a staff that is admired for its competence and professionalism.
Aided by his staff and his own encyclopedic mastery of the state budget, Mr. Miller made the Assembly an incubator for fiscal policies that often provided an alternative -- albeit a Democratic one -- to those of the Cuomo administration. He also relished his role as a guardian of New York City's interests and as a strong leader of his Democratic caucus who was not intimidated by Mr. Cuomo.
"He'll be remembered for nurturing a Legislature that became the equal of the executive in many ways," said Norman Adler, a political consultant who served as an assistant to Mr. Miller at the beginning of his tenure as Speaker.
 
Pushed Tax Cuts, Increases
 In 1987, Mr. Miller's first year as Speaker, he pushed for a multi-year cut in the personal income tax that Mr. Cuomo signed reluctantly after warning that it was too large. The tax cut is now widely considered to have contributed to the state's recurring budget gaps and the final phase has been postponed for two consecutive years.
When the state had to fill a huge budget gap last year, Mr. Miller proposed raising income taxes on the wealthy, another plan that was opposed vigorously by Mr. Cuomo. The two Democrats and the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, a Republican from Long Island, eventually agreed to a modest income tax increase to break a lengthy deadlock over the state budget.
In another battle with the Governor, Mr. Miller backed an ethics bill in 1987 that Mr. Cuomo did not find sufficiently stringent. The Governor vetoed the bill and initiated a public relations assault on the ethics standards of the Legislature, which left a mark on Mr. Miller.
The criminal charges against Mr. Miller had nothing to do with his duties as a legislator. But several legislators said Friday's verdict, which was the fourth felony conviction of a legislator in the last four years, would reinforce a loss of public trust in the state's elected officials.
 
Little Shift in Ideologya
 Legislators said they expected little shift in the Assembly's liberal ideology under Mr. Weprin, who like Mr. Miller is a supporter of abortion rights and an opponent of the death penalty. But they predicted a significant change in style.
Many Democratic legislators said they expected Mr. Weprin to be less dogmatic and more of a consensus-builder than Mr. Miller, who ruled by the combined force of his knowledge and his personality. Mr. Weprin is far more easygoing than his predecessor and more likely to delegate responsibility to his staff, they said.
"He's a mellow guy," said one New York City legislator, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "He doesn't like conflict. But he's very shrewd. He likes subtlety. I think he'll be softer, but I think he'll be a different person once in office in ways I can't predict now."
An upstate legislator summed up the differences between Mr. Miller and Mr. Weprin this way: "Mel couldn't stop talking and he couldn't listen. Saul listens great."
 
'A Very Technical Case'
 Even today, Mr. Miller did not stop talking. Although physically and emotionally drained, he seemed in good spirits after a day of fielding telephone calls from well-wishers. One anonymous caller, he conceded, told him, "You deserved what you got."
Mr. Miller said he took his traditional morning jog, went shopping and rearranged the books on a bookcase. The only departure from his usual Saturday morning routine was that he could not convince Mr. Adolf to keep their regular tennis date.
He continued to maintain his innocence. "From the day we were indicted, I think Jay and I both realized that the probability of winning was not heavy," he said. "It was a very technical case. But I don't think I committed a crime. I never had any intention of defrauding anybody."
Mr. Miller, who faces a maximum sentence of 40 years in prison and fines of up to $2 million, said he would hope for a favorable sentence, leave the details of his appeal to his lawyers, and begin thinking about the rest of his life. He will be disbarred if the conviction sticks, but he said he has no plans to continue practicing law in any event.
Even with the help of a legal defense fund mounted by his friends, the 52-year-old Mr. Miller predicted that he will still owe at least a half-million dollars in legal fees. Although he said he has no assets other than his house and retirement accounts, he said he was not worried about either money or future employment.
"I can drive a cab," he joked. "I'm crazy enough to drive in New York City. I'm eligible for a modest pension. My wife Liz is still working. I've got a daughter who is making a lot of money. She said she'd send me $10 a week allowance. I suppose somebody in the country will find that I have some value."
Mr. Miller said he would not spend time second-guessing his failures. "It's like trying to analyze why you lost a race," he said. "You sit and analyze it for two years but it doesn't change the result. The hardest thing for me to do is I can't figure out what I'm supposed to do Monday."

HEADLINE: SOVIET DISARRAY;
Yeltsin Sees Food Baskets 'Two-Thirds' Full in a Year

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 14

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian republic, calling on the people of the crumbled Soviet Union to rally for a grim period of transition, promised in an interview published today to stabilize the economy in a year and have food baskets "two-thirds filled, not more."
"The main thing is trust," he said in the newspaper interview in which he set basic national goals to survive what he conceded would prove a very difficult year. 
 "No pessimism," said Mr. Yeltsin as he prepared to start his plans for reconstruction. "Don't lose hope. This is what is most important today."
In the interview, Mr. Yeltsin made his first broad pledges to the public since the republics put their future hopes in a commonwealth association. As the elected leader of Russia, the republic that is by far the largest part of the ocmmonwealth, and the chief political force behind the new union, he acknowledged that times would be hard and talked in the most simple food-basket terms as he sought to bolster public morale in the interview with the newspaper Trud.
 
'We Know Where to Head'
 "I promise the food basket of a Russian citizen in one year's period will be two-thirds filled, not more," he said. "But we will do our best that it won't be less than two-thirds, irrespective of price rises, and we won't allow any hunger."
Conceding that his popularity will dip in the coming harder days, Mr. Yeltsin vowed to have the reeling economy stablized within a year.
"Gradually in the five following years we'll start increasing living standards," he told a public desperately in need of fresh confidence.
"As President I see these goals," he said. "We know where to head and we are sure that we will achieve these goals."
 
Complaints of Gorbachev
 Severe tests are fast approaching for Mr. Yeltsin's free-market economic reforms and commonwealth plan, with consumer prices expected to be free to rise on Jan. 2 after seven decades of state subsidies. Those transformations will key market changes in other republics of the new Commonwealth of Independent States, which Mr. Yeltsin and the leaders of Ukraine and Byelorussia proclaimed a week ago and which has since been endorsed by most former Soviet republics.
Mr. Yeltsin's interview was published as Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d headed here today from Washington to survey the latest survival plan of the collapsed Soviet empire, already on notice that he must face the complaints of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev that the Bush Administration has proved disloyal to him as Soviet President.
In an interview released today, Mr. Gorbachev said: "Mr. Baker was overly hasty in saying 'The Soviet Union no longer exists.' While we're still trying to figure things out, the United States seems to know everything already."
"I don't think this is loyalty," he said in the interview with Time magazine. "Particularly for those who favor partnership and full-fledged cooperation. It is our common interest that this process should end successfully without any surprises."
 
Union Treaty Plan
 As politicians awaited Mr. Gorbvachev's resignation, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, estimating that social tensions were increasing, said he had urged Mr. Gorbachev "not to rush into any resignation."
Endorsing the commonwealth, Mr. Shevardnadze said he believed President Gorbachev "can do many useful things for this process."
But Mr. Gorbachev, in an interview today in the paper Nezavisimaya Gazeta, once more raised the subject of somehow salvaging within the commonwealth some part of his proposed union-treaty agreement.
That treaty's chances were dashed by the republics' choice of a commonwealth approach that eliminates the central union state to which Mr. Gorbachev still clings. He talked of possibly blending the two in a "joint understanding," but the republics already have made clear that they want no part of reviving the union idea.
 
Call for U.S. Aid
 Mr. Gorbachev has continued to give no hint of when he might quit and he has maintained that his presidential role is still needed to insure an orderly, lawful transition in government.
"I want a stage-by-stage, step-by-step process that will not stimulate chaos," he told Time magazine.
In the interview, the Soviet leader, who is generally considered likely to resign soon as the commonwealth plan takes effect, issued his most urgent plea thus far for United States aid.
"We need your help now," he said. "Immediately. Stop hesitating or we will all have to pay a greater price in the end. If you have given aid to Poland and Hungary, Russia certainly deserves it."
On Thursday, Mr. Gorbachev was quoted as saying he would be obliged to resign if the republics did not revive the old union. But on Friday, politicans said he was likely to stay to meet Mr. Baker after he arrives Sunday.
 
Soviet Military Loyalty
 On the military front, the Soviet Defense Minister issued a statement calling for continued military allegiance to Moscow. In the face of continuing suggestions by Ukraine that the government in Kiev intends to take over army units on Ukrainian soil, Defense Minister Yevgeny Shaposhnikov issued a statement saying that all units of the Soviet military should stay loyal to him.
President Yeltsin conceded in his interview that, with free-market elements expected to aggravate the inflationary spiral further, the government is preparing to distribute free food to the large part of the nation trying to survive below the poverty line.
"I don't think there can be any talk of civil war or interference by the military," the Russian republic's leader said, tersely rejecting the warnings of President Gorbachev about the dangers of the new commonwealth.
In interviews all week, Mr. Gorbachev has portrayed himself as trying to prevent trouble for the republics' transition, not invite it by his opposition to the commonwealth.

HEADLINE: Jobs Make Ireland's Young People a Resource

BYLINE: By JAMES F. CLARITY

DATELINE: DUBLIN, Dec. 14

 BODY:
In 1729 Jonathan Swift satirically proposed dealing with this country's essential problem by eating Irish children -- "a reasonable dish, and seasoned with a little pepper or salt." Today the country's overbearing problem is still too many children.
Ireland has the youngest population in Europe, half of it under 30 years old; its women lead Europe in child-bearing ratios in a nation where abortion is illegal and the dominant Roman Catholic Church inveighs constantly against contraception. 
 But now the Government is meeting with some success in insuring enough jobs for its young work force. After centuries in which the only hope seemed to lie in emigration by the millions to Britain, the United States and Australia, it has been gradually creating more work at home by attracting foreign companies here.
They are being lured by tax breaks, low labor costs, few problems with unions and the prospect of a foothold in the single-market European Community. American companies provide the major share of the work, with 45,000 employees in 357 companies.
Corporate taxes for American companies here are no more than 10 percent on profits until the year 2010, and in many instances the Government, through the Industrial Development Authority, pays the first year of wages.
While the foreign presence alone will not vitalize the weak Irish economy, it is a bright spot for a work force of 1.2 million people saddled with an unemployment rate of 20 percent and the prospect of fewer jobs abroad as a result of the global recession.
Irish had been emigrating at an annual pace of 30,000 until last year; now net emigration is at zero, the amount of money being sent back home is decreasing, and tens of thousands of young people are leaving schools each year without much hope of finding jobs.
But Ireland, according to the Minister for Trade and Commerce, Desmond O'Malley, is trying to turn its youth into an asset.
"We have a guaranteed educated population into the next century, " he said in an interview. "We have the only indigenous population in Europe that is growing. Germany is running out of young Germans, for example."
Irish officials and foreign commercial and economic experts say that few countries in Europe, or anywhere, can offer such a combination of educated, English-speaking, ambitious workers at such a low cost.
The American industrial presence can be felt virtually everywhere.
In Dublin's Financial Services Center, there are units of Citibank Corp. and Black & Decker, General Electric Co., IBM and others. Operating through Irish subsidiaries, they are preparing to increase their share of business in the 12-nation European Community as it moves toward a single market of 340 million people.
In Cork and Kerry and Galway, the insurance companies Metropolitan Life, New York Life and Cigna and others employ several hundred people to process claims. The claims are flown to Ireland overnight, where workers here tap into computers in the States and calculate payments that are then made back at the home office. The companies avoid high American wages and get more use out of their New York computers in the off-hours.
In Cork, Apple Computer Inc. employs 950 people in its expanding production of laptop computers.
In Limerick, Dell Computer Co. opened in April and now employs 200 people. One of them is Linda Cowell, a secretary who was lured away from a competing firm by Dell's salary and working conditions.
"This is lively here," she said. "You work hard, but they're a good bunch to work for. The other place, things were getting stale." She said the pay at Dell was better than what most of the young people working there could find anywhere in the area.
The director of the bright, quiet computer assembly plant is Buddy Griffin, a 42-year-old native Irish engineer who was recruited personally by 26-year-old Michael Dell, who created the the Austin, Texas, company.
"We've a bunch of enthusiastic kids who want to work," Mr. Griffin said. He said that the starting salary for an assembly worker was about $12,000.

HEADLINE: New York Backs Columbus Center Plan in Court

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN

 BODY:
Lawyers for New York City -- which is counting on the millions that a huge development planned for Columbus Circle would generate for mass transit -- are arguing before a Federal appeals court that it makes no sense to block the project just because environmental inspectors found high levels of carbon monoxide on the other side of Central Park.
"It does not make sense to hold this project hostage for a problem it has nothing to do with," Linda Young, an assistant Corporation Counsel, argued in Federal court on Friday. The city is seeking to overturn an order issued last summer that effectively halted a project that is now also threatened by declining economic conditions. 
 In a July 10 ruling sought by opponents of the plan, Judge Shirley Wohl Kram of Federal District Court ruled that it could go forward. But she said it could be halted if the city failed to meet a Nov. 15, 1992, deadline to produce an air-quality plan that would comply with standards set in the Federal Clean Air Act.
Judge Kram also said she would fine the city at least $15 million if the deadline were not met. Her ruling was appealed by the city to the Second Circuit Court of Appeals, which heard opposing arguments on Friday.
The plan involves the demolition of the New York Coliseum and the sale of a surrounding 4.5-acre tract, owned by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, to a company headed by Mortimer B. Zuckerman, who would then build a 2.2-million-square-foot Columbus Center.
When first proposed in 1985, the center included twin 925-foot towers -- one commercial and one residential -- that critics said would cast long and forbidding shadows across the southwest corner of the park and sabotage the city's efforts to clean its air as ordered by the Federal Government.
The latest plan has scaled the towers down to 752 feet. But with the stubborn recession and the growing oversupply of Manhattan office space, developers question whether Mr. Zuckerman can attract enough large commercial tenants to make the project profitable.
 
Hot Spot Across the Park
 A spokesman for Mr. Zuckerman's real-estate company, Boston Properties, previously described Judge Kram's ruling as "a very serious blow to the viability and future of the project."
A crucial argument advanced by lawyers representing the Coalition Against Columbus Center and the Committee for Enviromentally Sound Development was that the project would worsen a so-called hot spot of vehicle-generated carbon monoxide air pollution centered on East 59th Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues 3 1/2 blocks from the site.
 
Citywide Compliance Sought
 Moreover, they argued that major projects like the one at Columbus Circle should be halted until the entire city is in compliance with Federal air quality standards.
But Ms. Young argued that the project "had nothing to do with that problem on 59th Street." She also argued that Congress had extended the Federal deadline for compliance to 1995.
But in her ruling last summer, Judge Kram said the city had consistently missed previous Federal deadlines and appeared headed toward missing the one set for next year.

HEADLINE: BACKTALK;
New York Plays Timekeeper and Turns Back the Clock

BYLINE: By MALCOLM MORAN

 BODY:
The guests in tuxedos and elegant dresses were stacked from the floor of the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria in balconies nearly all the way to the ceiling. From South Bend and Columbus, the people had come; from State College and Norman and Los Angeles and Tallahassee and Gainesville and Lincoln.
Many of the names, when introduced at the annual dinner for the National Football Foundation and College Hall of Fame, were instantly recognizable: Paterno, Bowden, Majors, Spurrier, Cozza, Curry. Gifford, Conerly, Rote, Cassady, Griese, all of them in New York, the center of the college football universe, if only for little more than a week. 
 That is about all that is left these days, a period that began with the dinner last Tuesday night and concludes with the Heisman dinner this Tuesday night. Once, the city was the glittering focus of college football on the field and off. New York was N.Y.U. and Fordham, or Gene Rossides to Bill Swiacki pushing Columbia past Army. In recent years, Heisman recipients could not make it to New York for the announcement, appearing only on television screens, via satellite, because of football business conducted elsewhere.
 
Fight Songs Made Fancy
 The room at the Waldorf was transported to that earlier time, with spotlights and tuxedos, candlelight and chandeliers. Fight songs, played by an orchestra, suddenly sounded almost elegant. Memories, some originally in black and white, were colorized.
These tuxedos and dresses had come from a time when it was easier to accept the notion that football was a gentlemen's game, demanding qualities that translated to success in business and politics and victory in war. Look at the organization's gold-medal winners: Eisenhower, MacArthur, Hoover, Kennedy, Nixon, Reagan, Ford, and this year, a baseball guy named Bush.
Any such notions might have seemed more acceptable because the times were as relatively simple as the day's short list of New Year's Day bowl games. It was not politically correct to examine the percentage of players with meaningful college degrees, or to question the techniques used to obtain these athletes, or to wonder about the glaring absence of black students on too many teams.
Super-slo-mo had not yet been developed to reveal the extent of the violence and the details of how the bodies are broken. And economics had not yet forced most private schools to re-evaluate their ambitions, or just get out of the game.
 
Banners on the Balconies
 The balconies at the Waldorf were covered with the multicolored banners from the days when big-time football was a different business: Manhattan, Marquette, Santa Clara, Holy Cross, Georgetown, Fordham, alongside the major-conference schools of then, and now.
Scoreless ties -- "Much ado about nothing to nothing" -- linked programs that have since headed in different philosophical and economic directions: Fordham and Pittsburgh, three times; Army and Notre Dame in the glare of No. 1 vs. No. 2 in a packed Yankee Stadium; and Columbia and Stanford at the Polo Grounds in 1937, the third Lion shutout over Stanford in a coast-to-coast three-game series.
For one night, the room belonged to a time when major league sports had advanced no farther west than St. Louis and no farther south than Washington, leaving cities as big as Atlanta, Minneapolis and Los Angeles as sporting outposts -- except in the fall. And when teams were ready to make a national impact, coaches would remind their stars, before or during the train ride east or north, that if they wanted to become all-Americans, New York was the place to start.
After New York writers created a campaign to have Columbia play in the 1934 Rose Bowl, KF-79 -- Al Barabas's naked reverse that shocked Stanford -- became a joyous secret code for Lions everywhere to celebrate their upset victory in Pasadena.
When Fordham beat Missouri in the Sugar Bowl, 2-0, in the rain 50 years ago this Jan. 1, Kate Smith rooted for the Rams, Joe E. Brown conducted the band, and William Frawley became a fan, long before television made him into Fred Mertz.
And when the Rams returned home and Toots Shor held a party, a backup center named Jerry O'Brien -- a backup center -- sat between two people and made the discovery of a lifetime. To his left sat Gary Cooper; to his right, Joe DiMaggio.
Half a century later, Joe Paterno, child of Brooklyn, stood in a spotlight and accepted the foundation's Distinguished American Award, a distinction that had once gone to Archibald MacLeish, Vince Lombardi, Bob Hope and Jimmy Stewart. "When you're from Brooklyn," Paterno said, "being called a distinguished American is really significant." And everyone laughed.
But he also said how much it meant "to come to New York, to this banquet, and realize that what is important to me is shared by all of you."
 
The Gun Sounds
 Soon there were cabs to catch, and tuxedos to return, and everyone went out into the New York night, into another world. The tuxedos will be gone soon, headed for business at places such as the Orange Bowl, where the Manhattan Jaspers remain an enduring trivia question.
Nearly 60 years ago, Manhattan College became an attraction in something called the Palm Festival, an opportunity for Miami to use a football game to attract curious snowbirds. The Jaspers were imported to face the University of Miami, an institution in its infancy, trying to fight its way out of bankruptcy.
Manhattan's guarantee of $3,000 was secured only after the promoter, Earnie Seiler, made the Miami chief of police the game's finance chairman, and a roundup of local bookmakers produced the money. The University of Miami outlasted bankruptcy and saw its football program advance all the way to the 1962 Gotham Bowl at Yankee Stadium. It was a frigid, barren occasion held after Fordham and N.Y.U. had gotten out of the business, and it is best remembered only as a tribute to its survivors.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Laughter Came First, Then Change

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY

 BODY:
THEY were proud and they were good and they won every championship there was. Now they are running out of money and they are running out of resolve, with a bitter winter facing them.
No, no, no, we are not talking about the Yankees, that tottering baseball team. We are talking about that other formerly arrogant giant, the sports machine of the Soviet Union, or whatever is left of it. 
 The news came out of Moscow a week ago Friday, that the central government could no longer subsidize sport. The Olympic committee apparently has funds to send a team to Albertville, France, in February, and probably to Barcelona, Spain, in late July. After that, who knows?
Tell me there is no more Pan American, the airline that sent clippers winging across the Atlantic. Tell me there is no more NBC Radio News, no more three chimes that sounded like the American version of Big Ben. Tell me that raiders killed department stores you thought would last forever. "Unbelievable," I will mutter, yet this is the way it goes in the shark pond of capitalism.
But Gossport? Gossport was the most powerful national sports agency in the world. It financed all those gold medals, all those trophies, the ones that substituted for meat and shoes.
The premise was always that "the people" would support all the swimmers and the skaters, but the premise was ultimately wrong, once "the people" began to have a voice in it. They stood up to tanks in Moscow last summer; somehow they also stood up to subsidizing athletes.
Laughter was the first sign that even sports could be affected by the changes. I remember the laughter from 1988, when Arvidas Sabonis, the basketball center, said he would speak only Lithuanian and English from now on. Russian was the language of the invaders, the oppressors, and he was not going to speak it anymore.
Sabonis came to New York for a news conference and he made jokes that 41 road games in the National Basketball Association could not be as grueling as 20 road games in the stark Soviet Union.
"We always told jokes," Sabonis said in halting English. "They just weren't as loud." Asked if he wasn't afraid of the heavy hitters in Gossport, Sabonis laughed, a deep, throaty laugh. They needed him because he is 7 feet 3 1/4 inches tall, so he laughed at them.
Lithuania did not have a team in 1988, not yet, so four Lithuanians helped the Soviet Union outplay and outthink an American college team en route to a gold medal. Next June, at a 16-team tournament in Spain, Lithuania and a team from the shell of the Soviet Union will battle for four places in the 1992 Summer Games. Nobody will be laughing if Lithuania should meet the mostly Russians. The revolution finally caught up with sports.
"For us, medals were ideological weapons," said Sergei Guskov, a marketing official from Moscow, and a former member of sports committees, who happens to be visiting the United States.
"In my country, sports are very conservative; there was no perestroika for a long time," Guskov added, using Mikhail Gorbachev's familiar Russian word for restructuring. "The trade unions paid for sport because gold medals were our face, but now the unions cannot pay anymore."
Guskov, who has a doctorate in sports economics, said even popular sports lose money. The budget in first-division soccer is approximately 20 million rubles, which is nearly impossible to compare with American dollars. But the gate from 4.3 million fans at 2.50 rubles per ticket is only 10.75 million rubles, barely half the budget, Guskov added.
Plus, Aeroflot or Lada cars are not exactly paying huge amounts of rubles for advertising, the way our Western "benefactors" do, so all of Soviet sport is scrambling to stay alive. Gossport used to demand all the dollars its athletes won out of the country, but feisty Natalya Zvereva and other tennis players rebelled.
We had an insight into Soviet sports realities a few years ago when Tamara Bykova, the worldly high jumper and a trained journalist, came to New York for a meet. My wife escorted Bykova to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where they visited the gallery of designer clothes.
"I have one like that," Bykova said, pointing to a lovely Italian gown. She had been to Italy 17 times. She dressed well. And before getting back on Aeroflot, Bykova and her teammates visited a Russian-speaking electronics store in Brooklyn, to spend every dollar while it still had value.
"It is funny you mention Bykova," Guskov said. "I did a survey of our top athletes a few years ago. In the U.S. you call them state amateurs, and that is a fair term. I asked how many of them considered themselves professionals, and 49 percent of them said they were. Bykova answered that she was an amateur because the level of support was amateur."
And that was when Gossport was solvent. Nowadays, to bring dollars into Russia, the authorities have opened the foreign-currency stores to elite athletes, selling Japanese electronics goods at favorable prices. But who will subsidize perks like state apartments and state cars and state pensions for sports heroes? And who will locate and train the next generation of athletes? The system is tapping out. Unbelievable.

HEADLINE: In the Nation;
Mr. Bush's Socks

BYLINE: By TOM WICKER

 BODY:
Anyone who expected a new chief of staff to produce a fast turnaround in White House attitudes toward the slumping national economy must have been disappointed last week by testimony from President Bush's principal economic advisers.
They told the Senate Finance Committee that the President might propose an investment tax credit for business -- but only for some investments. 
 The Secretary of the Treasury, the budget director and the chairman of Mr. Bush's Council of Economic Advisers called once more for a capital-gains tax reduction. They said they were considering but were not committed to a tax break for the middle class, and squarely opposed a tax increase on higher incomes.
If Mr. Bush decides on any kind of tax action, he'll let Congress and the nation know in next month's State of the Union and Budget Messages.
If that's urgency, what would apathy be like?
It's not that a tax credit for investment is a bad idea; the tax code included such a credit most of the time from 1961 to 1986. But if Mr. Bush won't even propose the idea -- even if he decides in favor of it -- until next month, many months more would pass before anyone could be assisted.
Congress would take time to act -- perhaps a lot of time because, under the present budget agreement, any revenues to be lost would have to be made up by tax increases somewhere else, or by spending cuts. Businesses would need further time to plan and make investments, particularly since the credit would be available only for those not already scheduled.
Still more time then would be required for such investments actually to put people to work. Besides, even a tax credit might not persuade business people to make costly new investments when consumers seem to have so little confidence in the economy.
That was evidenced once again in the Commerce Department's report that retail sales rose only three-tenths of a percent in November, as holiday shopping supposedly began -- a statistic that anyone can verify empirically by checking the uncrowded aisles of department and other stores. And retail sales account for a third of all economic activity.
As for the future, the 24-nation Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development is reported to have again lowered its estimate of U.S. economic growth for 1992. Ten weeks ago, it forecast 3.1 percent growth; in two revisions, that figure has fallen to 2.2 percent.
Because of such gloomy economic news, Samuel Skinner, the new White House chief of staff, pointedly said he would focus on action to stimulate the national economy. He hardly has had time to have much impact on policy, but the Administration's testimony to the Finance Committee suggests that Mr. Skinner may need a good deal more than time to achieve his goal.
The economic advisers, while paying lip service to the need for helping middle- and working-class Americans, seemed more concerned about the rich. They not only touted again a capital-gains tax break and ruled out a new tax on million-dollar incomes; but Treasury Secretary Brady pointed out that wealthy people's share of the total tax burden already had gone up. So, of course, has their share of the total national income.
President Bush may have hit inadvertently upon a better idea than any of these advisers seem to have, though his Administration's policies do not reflect it. In the kind of symbolic action for which he is justly renowned -- proposing the flag-burning amendment at the Iwo Jima Monument, for instance -- Mr. Bush ventured out to J.C. Penney's and bought $28 worth of socks.
That sum will not put any of the more than eight million unemployed Americans back to work. But they and millions of others who used to be consumers either have no money to spend because they have no jobs, or are hoarding what money they do have because they fear they'll lose their jobs. So Mr. Bush's socks symbolize the need to stimulate consumer spending, hence the economy, by putting jobless people back to work.
That will cost money -- for public investment, for instance, in highways, bridges, sewage facilities, etc. Like a tax credit, public investment will take time to have effect. It may require breaking the budget agreement. But it will get help directly to those who most need it; and more people working will mean more people spending -- and not just for socks.

HEADLINE: Venezuela Is Expanding Its Role in Caribbean

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela

 BODY:
When Haiti's President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, was spirited to the airport after his overthrow by soldiers in September, the foreign jet awaiting to fly him into exile was not sent from Washington or Paris, traditionally the most influential of the Caribbean nation's foreign partners.
Instead, in a gesture that diplomats and political analysts say reflected his country's increased diplomatic presence in the region, it was Venezuela's President, Carlos Andres Perez, who sent his personal plane to carry Father Aristide to Caracas, where he has lived in exile since. 
 Experts on Caribbean affairs say Mr. Perez has deftly brought his country into the hemisphere's select circle of diplomatic powers by using its vast oil wealth and the yearning of many for a counterweight to the United States in a region composed of tiny islands.
Venezuela has more foreign embassies and cultural centers in the Caribbean than any other country. With few exceptions, each of the region's islands relies on arrangements, sponsored by Venezuela and Mexico, that help them finance vital oil imports.
The United States recently sent ripples through many of the Caribbean's thin economies by announcing its Enterprise for the Americas Initiative, an ambitious two-way free-trade program. Under the Caribbean Basin Initiative, which the new program will replace, the region's exporters had special access to the American market while giving up little in return.
Venezuela's response was to grant five years of duty-free entry for Caribbean products into its booming economy. The presumable payoff, many figured, would eventually be greatly increased access to the region for the country's rising industrial sector.
"The Caribbean risks becoming the most destabilizing factor in all of Latin America, because these countries can be subject to undesirable interests," Mr. Perez said in an interview at the presidential palace. "I am speaking about narco-traffickers, and all sorts of economic mafias that prey upon weak countries like these. Our policy is aimed at assuring the stability of the region, which will help assure its development."
Venezuelan commentators say healthy doses of self-interest as well as Mr. Perez's fondness for international diplomacy figure prominently in the country's aggressive foreign policy.
"Obviously commercial interests play a big part too," Andres Serbin, director of the Venezuelan Institute for Social and Political Studies, said of his country's growing interest in the Caribbean. "But there really is a great concern for the political stability of the region. Virtually all of our imports and oil exports pass through these waters."
In the case of Haiti, Mr. Perez invoked a historical debt, as well as what he said was a fear for democracy elsewhere in the hemisphere should a coup against an elected leader be allowed to stand.
"Simon Bolivar, our great liberator, received important aid from Haiti, and yet we in Latin America have done little to help this country, which is now the most backward in the hemisphere," Mr. Perez said, referring to two of the revolutionary's passages in exile through Haiti.
"After a history of abominable dictatorships, the first election that was authentically free gave us Jean-Bertrand Aristide," Mr. Perez said, speaking in Spanish. "If you were present, you saw the explosion of popular satisfaction when he took power, people running in the streets with joy. That was an experience that few of us can match."
"It is evident that President Aristide thought the use of the masses in the streets would enable him to reach his political objectives," he said, commenting on assertions that the Haitian had used crowds and the threat of violence to intimidate his opponents. "This was one of his errors. Direct democracy has not worked anywhere in the world."
"What is of crucial importance, though, is that we in Latin America cannot accept any more military coups," he added. "After all the dramas we have gone through, that would be fatal for our region."

LENGTH: 499 words

HEADLINE: Mr. Quayle's Irregular Regulation

 BODY:
The Task Force on Regulatory Relief didn't amount to much when George Bush headed it as Vice President. But when Mr. Bush moved up, he renamed it and recharged its batteries. As the Council on Competitiveness, it has become a powerful force for watering down regulation -- and, not incidentally, for burnishing the image of its chairman, Vice President Quayle.
The council has drawn the justified fire of environmentalists, public-interest groups and Democrats in Congress for diluting proposed regulations. The council's defenders claim it has less power than the critics say, but there's no doubt Mr. Quayle has made it a friendly place for business to turn with complaints. 
 The council has been unnecessarily zealous in toning down the Environmental Protection Agency's plans for clean-air regulations. It wants to open up vital wetlands for development despite Mr. Bush's campaign pledge to protect them. Even its welcome move to speed Federal approval of new drugs has been challenged as too lenient.
The President has a legitimate interest in seeing that regulations don't exceed the law's authority, contradict his objectives and impose higher costs than they're worth. But the council's secrecy creates concern that businessmen are getting their way through the back door.
President Nixon began coordinated White House oversight in the 1970's, to get a handle on the flood of new regulation that flowed from the Johnson years. President Carter later institutionalized it in a Regulatory Analysis Review Group under the Council of Economic Advisers.
It remained a relatively benign procedure until President Reagan arrived and put the Office of Management and Budget in charge. He gave it the power to stall or block all regulations that didn't square with his anti-regulatory passion.
Frustrated Congressional Democrats, seeing their legislative intent subverted, have tried unsuccessfully to curb the O.M.B., or at least make its proceedings more public. Now they're targeting the competitiveness council too, mainly for secrecy and a pro-business slant. But they have also spotlighted the staff director's apparent conflict of interest as a stockholder in a utility holding company, and last week he agreed to put his holdings in a blind trust.
The council's structure belies its influence. Its members, six Cabinet officers, meet infrequently. Its staff numbers fewer than a dozen. But it can call on other Government agencies -- and outsiders -- for whatever help it needs.
The council is not shy about disclosing its achievements. However, its intrusions are not on the public record, where all concerned parties could keep track and chime in. The council claims executive privilege as an arm of the Presidency, but that's an all-too-common White House dodge for avoiding embarrassing disclosures.
When a President is formulating policy, he and his office have a right to confidentiality. But when they are rewriting regulations, the public has a right to know.
