HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
A Grand Aid Gesture?

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
Bush Administration officials say that the deteriorating situation in the former Soviet Union is filled with the most dangerous consequences. And yet, the help they offer to arrest those trends is most modest.
Bluntly, there is a galactic gap between the problems they say we face and what they are prepared to do about them. 
 Is this a lack of vision and political courage that will come back to haunt us? Or is it good sense?
Begin with one almost incomprehensible fact: The Russian empire, the Soviet Union, the center or whatever has vanished from the chessboard.
In its place is a commonwealth of independent republics. Its members, former Soviet republics, asserted control of military forces on their soil. But nobody knows if they have actual control. They say they have "united command" of some 27,000 nuclear weapons. But there is no central authority and therefore no common political control. They promise to build economic relations and use the ruble to settle accounts. But they have no mechanisms for doing so, and their economies are in a free fall.
Robert Gates, the Director of Central Intelligence, called this situation "the most significant civil disorder" since the 1917 Boslshevik revolution. He told Congress that "the situation is dangerously unstable." Secretary of State James Baker warned of resurgent Stalinism, fascism, extremist nationalism and militarism.
And how did Mr. Baker and President Bush propose to respond to such dire threats? First, they would spend the $400 million just voted by Congress -- with absolutely no help from the White House -- to begin dismantling nuclear weapons. Good. Second, they would spend $100 million just approved by Congress -- again with the White House standing by cravenly in silence -- to transport emergency humanitarian food and medical supplies. Good, again. Third, they would throw another $100 million into the pot to "catalyze private sector involvement," whatever that means. And fourth, they would convene an international conference next month to coordinate emergency relief aid this winter. Overdue, but in the right direction.
Is this a plausible recipe for heading off dictatorship and militarism in the former Soviet empire? Not likely, as Bush Administration officials privately admit.
But they say, and they are right, that the more relevant question is, would it work to do a lot more? Hardly anyone still advocates a massive Marshall Plan-style aid effort. Neither the Commonwealth nor the republics have the organization and stability to handle that. The money would simply disappear into bureaucratic pockets and foreign bank accounts. There is no "there" there to manage megabillion-dollar programs.
What about a smaller, multibillion-dollar effort to cushion against inflation and help pay for needed imports? Ambassador Robert Strauss publicly asked the White House to take that gamble last week. For fear of a few billion dollars going "up in smoke," he said, "we risk saying 10 years from now . . . $2 billion to $3 billion in this effort could . . . have prevented" fascism.
That's powerful rhetoric. But it is hard to see how a few billion, or even a few billion from many nations, would make a material difference in a sprawling trillion-dollar economy whose financial transactions currently rest on corruption and barter.
I once believed in a major aid effort based on Soviet performance to head off just the kind of chaos that impends. I could be persuaded to go somewhat in that direction again. But that depends on whether the Commonwealth and republics can get their acts together first. In any event, the topic should be on the agenda for the emergency conference next month.
None of these choices are happy ones. But for the time being and belatedly, Mr. Bush and company have zeroed in on the least wasteful, least impractical objectives: rounding up the nukes, staving off starvation in big cities and helping increase energy production.
Those goals are much smaller and less noble than preventing fascism and militarism. But they are also within our means and roughly attainable.
To attempt more would be to stage-manage an earthquake. It would be a grand gesture -- that would sap support for bold plans when the time might be right.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: About Cars;
Volvo Makes Its New 960 a Safe Bet

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:

DEAR SIR,
For a family vehicle, safety is paramount. Your review of the infant seats in the Chrysler vans did not mention whether the doors now have steel beams. If I were in the market for a family vehicle, the steel beams would be far more important than pull-down child seats. It's too bad the Government has not changed the safety standards to require those beams in the doors of minivans. -- NORMA M. BRAUDE, Fredonia, N.Y.
 
DEAR SIR,
I am a mom with four little kids, and I don't want to make ANY compromises on safety. I have been saving my money for four years now, planning to buy a minivan when they finally meet the safety standards for cars. But guess what -- my money is still sitting in the bank. 
 Built-in baby seats are great, but they don't address the fundamental problem that people have with minivans. You can always buy a great baby seat, but you can't go out and buy a crush-proof roof or interior-door supports for side collisions. -- ELLIE DUNHAM, West Chester, Pa.
AS those and other letters indicate, safety is on the minds of buyers and would-be buyers today. And Volvo, which was trying to push safety long before it was chic good business, now has at least a partial answer to side impacts with its all-new 960 model.
Granted, the 960 is not a minivan, but it is the flagship of the line and it can be had as a relatively large and boxy station wagon, as well as a sedan.
For 1992, the company's SIPS design takes direct aim at the concerns of those who would like a minivan but worry about accidents. The Swedish alphabet soup stands for "side impact protection system," and it is the feature of a current ad campaign whose target is the minivan.
According to the experts, side impacts are the second most common type of accidents, after frontal collisions. One of five accidents is said to involve a side impact, and while most of them occur at relatively low speeds, they produce more than their share of injuries.
Federal side-impact standards will go into effect in 1994, and while some vans -- notably Toyota's Previa -- already incorporate door beams, most do not. In defense, the other makers say that the different configuration of vans and the added height makes them inherently safer.
Part of the reason for the high injury rate in side impacts, of course, is that there is little distance between the passenger and the vehicle that is T-boning the car. Only the doors and the B-pillar (the post between the windows) stand between the impact and your frail self.
Volvo's spokesmen say that years of study went into designing the new system and that the engineers finally came up with a method that spreads the accident forces over a larger portion of the vehicle's structure as it reduces intrusion into the passenger compartment.
The design, used in the company's 7-series cars as well as in the new 960, is the result of mathematical models as well as other tests, and it strengthens the B-pillars and floor members while reinforcing the door sills and roof rails. The engineering allows crash forces to be dissipated throughout the body and redirected around the "safety cage" that houses occupants. Projections from test results indicate a 25 percent reduction in fatalities or serious injuries in SIPS vehicles.
None of the new toughness shows, of course, because this is Volvo we're talking about. In fact, you might be hard pressed to notice anything special at all about the 960. Volvo is like that.
But the car is a delight. In my case, it was a dark aqua (officially called blue-green in a winning case of corporate candor) four-door wagon that shared the somewhat fluid lines of last year's new 940. The wagon sticks to what it does best, though, and its 74.9 cubic feet of cargo capacity make it a natural for any family that wants a luxury hauler.
That luxury includes a leather interior, tan in the case of the tester but also available in black or gray, full power equipment, a sunroof that either slides fully open or serves as a vent with a flip-up panel, and such niceties as a three-position memory for the driver's seat. In fact, the only option is a compact-disk player at $795.
You can add that figure to a base of $34,655, plus about $500 for preparation, and that means that this car is no cheap thrill. But given the competition and unless your ego demands turned heads, it may well be worth the ticket.
The heated front buckets are well designed and add to the general comfort of the car, while the rear bench offers more legroom than you see in far larger vehicles. A fat four-spoked steering wheel, wrapped in black leather, holds an air bag in its center. Unlike many cars, though, that doesn't mean tiny and hard-to-find horn buttons; for safety, the entire hub serves as a horn.
There is a black dash, whose analog instruments are dominated by a tachometer and large 140-m.p.h. speedometer, and the controls are easy to use. Much of what you get in the new 960 goes beyond creature comforts, however. It is beneath the skin in the form of an all-new aluminum engine and a new four-speed electronically controlled automatic transmission.
The engine, an inline six that is just four inches longer than a Volvo four-banger, uses 24 valves and dispenses with the conventional distributor, replacing it with individual ignition coils that sit atop each of the spark plugs. The powerplant displaces only 2.9 liters, but it puts out 201 horses, healthy delivery in a vehicle whose weight is about 3,400.
The power is delivered to the rear wheels through the automatic, which has three selectable modes: economy, sport and winter. In the economy mode, upshifts are gentle and are executed at relatively low engine speeds. A push of the sport button allows higher revs before shifting, and the winter setting locks out first and second gear to prevent wheel spin on slippery roads.
Another feature is the "down-slope mode," in which the transmission senses when the vehicle is descending a hill and automatically engages a lower gear to provide engine braking. Actual stopping power is provided by the standard antilock brakes.
On the road, the car is a joy: steady, stable and solid. And, again, while it is no minivan, Volvo's new wagon just might be the answer to a family's prayer.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Volvo's 960 flagship can be had as a wagon or sedan and features side impact protection. (Volvo Cars of North America)
 
Diagram: The 960's 201-horsepower engine is hooked to a new transmission that offers pushbutton control of winter, sport and economy modes.

HEADLINE: New G.M. Leadership Flails for Ways to Halt the Car Maker's Slide

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
Robert C. Stempel became the General Motors Corporation's 11th chairman in August 1990, amid widespread hope that "Team Stempel" could turn the nation's largest company around. As an engineer, in contrast with the series of accountants who preceded him, Mr. Stempel seemed well positioned to overhaul G.M.'s car and truck models to compete against the Japanese. And his collegial and attentive style was expected to inspire initiative and free expression among the troops, loosening up the authoritarian culture that had prevailed when Roger B. Smith was chairman.
But 15 months later, there is little evidence that his leadership has unraveled G.M.'s most confounding predicaments. The company's customer base in North America has failed to grow from depressed levels despite huge investments in new models, losses have mounted, and credit analysts have threatened to downgrade its debt rating -- a prospect that could severely undermine its ability to finance purchases by buyers and dealers. 
 Now, under escalating financial pressure, Mr. Stempel has fallen back on the same strategy for coping with problems as the one preferred by his much-criticized predecessor. Last week, Mr. Stempel announced deep cutbacks that will probably include plant closings, layoffs and the second charge against earnings in 18 months. Although some details of the plan will be announced Wednesday, and others later, the moves are designed to close the widening gap between G.M.'s production capacity and its sales.
But unlike past revampings, this round may reshuffle G.M.'s top brass -- Mr. Stempel and the five G.M. executives who also serve as directors. According to two associates of G.M. board members, the company's nonemployee directors have asked Mr. Stempel to evaluate his top-management team with an eye toward change -- a powerful departure from custom.
Like many old-line industrial concerns, G.M. has a deep-seated cultural aversion for holding managers and executives accountable when they perform poorly. Mr. Smith, for instance, was retained as chairman for years after people both inside and outside of G.M. had concluded that he was ineffective. Analysts agree that a reshuffling would be a heartening signal to workers that top management was finally taking responsible for G.M.'s poor performance.
"This is the third restructuring charge in three years -- a lot of changes and G.M. is still losing money," said Jack V. Kirnan, automotive analyst for Kidder, Peabody in New York. "Changing top G.M. executives will instill in the younger G.M. executives the idea that you are rewarded for excellence, not mediocrity."
Analysts believe any reshuffling of top management is likely to affect Lloyd E. Reuss, G.M.'s 55-year-old president. Mr. Reuss is directly responsible for North American operations, the source of most of G.M.'s problems, and had been in charge of all or most of North America for four years before becoming president. This year, analysts say, Mr. Reuss's operations will lose up to $8 billion, an increase over last year's $4.5 billion loss.
Mr. Reuss was not the board's first choice as president. When Mr. Stempel first took office, nonemployee directors had preferred John F. Smith Jr., 53, the respected head of G.M.'s international operations who became popular with Wall Street after a successful tour of duty in Europe. When Mr. Stempel insisted on Mr. Reuss, the board acquiesced, but declined to give Mr. Reuss the additional title of chief operating officer, which would have formalized his status as Mr. Stempel's No. 2 man.
A G.M. spokesman, responding to widespread speculation on Wall Street and within the company that Mr. Reuss might be replaced as president, said no management changes will be announced until Wednesday.

FOR Mr. Stempel, the cutbacks are a bruising reminder of his promise when he took over to have G.M. operating at full capacity by next year. As recently as this summer, he had been predicting that the crop of 1992 models would be the crowning glory of a long-awaited turnaround in G.M.'s share of the North American market.
While executives admit that the company neglected new-model development and quality in the early 1980's in favor of building new factories, G.M. has made up for it since then. In the last five years, it has invested roughly $7 billion annually, mostly to revamp car and truck models. The culmination of that program came this fall, when G.M. divisions introduced nine new car and six new truck models -- the most ever by an auto maker during one 12-month period.
From the compact Saturn to the glitzy Cadillac Seville, the new offerings are higher in quality and in technology and more aggressively priced than previous new models, earning high marks and even some raves from reviewers.
But their retail sales haven't been high enough to cover the enormous cost of operating 32 North American assembly lines and associated parts plants. The North American operation has been losing an estimated $500 million a month, according to some analysts.
Some of the blame can be tagged on the recession. The entire market for new vehicles in this country shrank to a four-year low of about 12.7 million in 1991, down from 16 million in the mid-1980's. Consumer confidence is low, consumer debt is high and the Big Three have been far less aggressive in subsidizing fleet sales to daily rental companies than they have in the past.
"If the economy had been recovering, Stempel might have been able to follow his original plan and make piecemeal improvements without any big write-offs," said a financial analyst who insisted on anonymity because of Securities and Exchange Commission restrictions in connection with his brokerage's underwriting of G.M.'s $1.5 billion preference stock offering. The offering, set to close this week, is designed to fortify G.M.'s diminished equity base.
But G.M.'s problems also stem from the new models' failure to win back many buyers who defected to competing brands. Through November, G.M.'s share of the North American market was 35.1 percent, down from 35.7 percent last year and 40 percent in the early 80's.
Leon Mandel, publisher of Auto Week, says it's too early to make final judgments about the new models. "No one is making money, not even the Japanese," he said. "So it's not surprising that the biggest auto maker is losing the most money."
Yet G.M.'s Chevrolet division has had almost 400,000 fewer sales this year than last. The full-sized Caprice sedan, which was new in 1990, took a steep dive after its first year. The Buick Park Avenue near-luxury sedan, quite popular when it was introduced last year, has also begun to lose sales, in part because Buick is offering financing discounts to introduce its slightly smaller but similarly powered Buick LeSabre. Considering the value of 2.9 percent financing, the LeSabre sells for roughly $10,000 less than the $25,285 Park Avenue, yet looks virtually the same.
Could it be that today's car buyers haven't recognized the change in G.M.? "Perceptions lag reality," said James Fitzpatrick, G.M.'s vice president of marketing and public affairs. Mr. Fitzpatrick said top G.M. executives are convinced their vehicles are precisely what the public needs and wants. Advertising has stressed improvements in quality, safety and other equipment features, as opposed to "image" advertising showing portraits of happy customers exclaiming over their vehicles.
Many marketing experts believe G.M. confuses customers with too many brands and too many models in overlapping market segments. Stylists have differentiated models from various G.M. divisions so they don't look as much alike as they once did. The Chevy Lumina, for example, doesn't look as similar to the Oldsmobile Cutlass Supreme as it did six years ago.
But now there is a new problem: quite a few models sold by the same division are the same size and appeal to roughly the same group of buyers. That's the problem with the Buick LeSabre and the Park Avenue.

JUDGING from readers' letters to automotive magazines, many former G.M. owners still hold grudges about bad experiences they had with G.M. cars they once owned. Many switched to competing brands and aren't interested in switching back. It is a problem, in fact, for all domestic makers, who have lost a whole generation of buyers to Japanese vehicles.
Until some of these buyers return, even an economic recovery might not be enough to bring G.M.'s huge fixed costs in line with revenues, making plant closings inevitable. Excess capacity has grown since 1986, reaching 50 percent of production this year. G.M. has tried to increase capacity use and reduce fixed costs without shutting entire plants by cutting assembly lines and making the ones left more flexible and efficient.
Plant closings almost certainly would stir rancor from G.M.'s 300,000 hourly workers. The current labor contract precludes closings, but G.M. has used contract loopholes before to shut plants. The union understands that the auto maker can't build cars for which there are no customers.
Yet the union has resented having to bear so much of the burden for G.M.'s poor performance, as it did in the 80's, while executives sacrificed little. G.M. has tried to mend relations with workers to improve quality on the line, arguing that higher productivity is the only true form of job security. Overall quality at G.M., as measured by independent testers like J. D. Power & Associates, has improved, but it still lags behind the Japanese.
The Big Three virtually guaranteed up to 85 percent of wages for all United States auto workers, regardless of whether they are working. G.M. alone committed up to $3.35 billion to cover jobless benefits and has spent $1.2 billion of that amount. Referring to hourly jobless benefits, John Maciarz, a G.M. spokesman on labor issues, said "we don't have an endless supply of income."
Mr. Stempel may ask the union to reopen the labor agreement and discuss trimming those benefits. But, union officials say, without a signal that top management also is willing to take responsibility for G.M.'s ailments, Mr. Stempel is likely to get a chilly reception.

 
 
THE RAVAGING POTENTIAL OF A DOWNGRADE
 In announcing cutbacks last week, the General Motors Corporation's most immediate concern was to reassure credit analysts that it was serious about shoring up its weakening balance sheet. In early November, agencies that evaluate G.M. bonds and commercial paper warned of a possible downgrading of the company's debt ratings.
Such a downgrading could be devastating to G.M. Its General Motors Acceptance Corporation finance arm is the second-largest user of the commercial credit market after G.E. Credit. It has used its highest credit rating to raise money cheaply to lend it to finance consumer purchases of cars and trucks, fleet sales and dealer inventories at a healthy profit. Over the last seven years, G.M.A.C. has netted $1 billion or more.
A downgrading could squeeze G.M. out of the top-rated commercial paper market, forcing the auto maker to use more expensive borrowing for consumer financing. Earlier this year, Chrysler was forced out of that market because of its poor debt ratings. Where Chrysler will find money for financing next year is a large question.

HEADLINE: Perspectives: The Spitzer Outlook;
On Alert for Sites As the Cycles Turn

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
THE developer-owner who finds himself without a site that he is currently developing might well bristle at the idea that he is inactive. He is out there looking. He is also tending to the property he already owns.
So it is with Bernard Spitzer, a 67-year-old builder and investment-owner, a civil engineer with a taste for esthetics and design, a reputation as an insightful taskmaster and a preference for residential buildings in prime Manhattan locations. If there is an unusual construction challenge, so much the better. 
 In almost 40 years of building in New York City he calculates that he has been without a site under development only 15 percent of the time. This is such a time, although he is actively considering buying any of three.
The direction of his current activities illuminate the near-term course of most Manhattan investment-builders. They are unlikely to start major new residential projects soon and they are tending to improvements on their own property at a time when competition for tenants is strong.
But, as Dennis Brady, vice president of Jack Resnick & Sons, put it, "Our interest never wavers. We are always out there looking."
What they are finding, in many cases, are uncompleted construction projects that can be purchased at favorable prices and completed. With an excessive supply of new housing built at development costs that are no longer justified by market prices, New York City is in a period of workouts that may shut the door on new unassisted development until the mid-90's, many builders say.
"One doesn't think of new sites these days," said Henry Elghanayan, a principal in Rockrose Development Corporation. "The thought is that there are problem projects out there that can be bought at reduced prices and turned around."
On the commercial side, Mr. Spitzer is involved with just such a property. With two partners, Marvin Winter and Jerome L. Greene, he bought the Crown Building, at 730 Fifth Avenue and 57th Street, at a foreclosure auction last February for $93.6 million. The 300,000-square-foot building was 50 percent vacant. The lobby and other public spaces have been improved and about 10 percent of the vacant space has been leased.
But in most of his career Mr. Spitzer has concentrated on residential buildings, often with garage and commercial space as well. He has built about 2,000 apartments as rentals, co-ops and condominiums, and he still retains what he describes as a "substantial" number of them.
A vacancy typically means an improvement costing $25,000 to $150,000, depending on how long the apartment was occupied. At 200 Central Park South he has spent $100,000 this fall to improve an apartment that had been occupied for 20 years. It is on the market for $6,000 a month.
In the same building he has already rented out for $6,250 a month a 1,600-square-foot apartment that was rebuilt at a cost of $200,000. It has three exposures from the 27th floor.
It makes no difference from the owner-developer's standpoint whether the apartment is within a co-op, condominium or rental structure. The vacancy, in these prime locations, leads to a major improvement to justify the maximum rent the market will accept. Public spaces in the rental buildings also are redone.
MR. SPITZER'S construction career began in 1952 when he was 28 years old. He was a field supervisor for the late Sam Minskoff, founder of the Minskoff Brothers building firm, when he decided that the future lay in building for his own account.
So he bought land in Riverdale and produced the 88-unit building at 3640 Johnson Avenue. Then came the 21-story 112-unit apartment house at 3131 Grand Concourse, completed in 1958. Both were subsequently sold to raise money for further activities.
In Manhattan since then he has built three times on Fifth Avenue (No. 1050, an 88-unit co-op at 86th Street; No. 985, a 48-unit rental between 79th and 80th Streets, and No. 800, a 208-unit rental at 61st Street); twice on Central Park South (No. 200, a 312-unit rental, and No. 210, a 90-unit rental, both subsequently converted to co-ops) and once each on Park Avenue (No. 1020, at 85th Street, since converted to a co-op), and East 72d Street (No. 220, near Third Avenue).
The residential portion of the 72d Street building, with 147 rental apartments, is above six floors occupied by Marymount Manhattan College. In some of these projects, Mr. Winter and Mr. Greene were partners.
Mr. Spitzer also built the Corinthian, his most recent project, and one of exceptional scale for a Manhattan residential building. It has 865 apartments on 54 residential floors, plus about 90,000 square feet of offices and a 150-car garage. It is on the site of the former East Side Airlines Terminal on First Avenue between 37th and 38th Streets.
Mr. Spitzer has a particular taste for complicated construction challenges, but they are overcome in his view only if they achieve an economically sound project as well.
The Corinthian was a notable challenge. He bought the 81,000-square-foot site at a Metropolitan Transportation Authority auction in 1985 for $90.6 million. "The building could have been overpowering and perhaps monstrous esthetically," he says.
Instead he settled on a tower that has a long curving central corridor from which 17 lines of apartments jut out, ending in living rooms with long circular windows and extensive views. The architect for this and other projects was the firm of Michael Schimenti of Valley Stream, L.I., now run by the late Mr. Schimenti's son, John. The design architect of record on the project, Der Scutt said of Mr. Spitzer: "He was the most organized and demanding developer I ever worked for. He holds the line on budget and schedule and at the same time demands good design."
THE builder himself, who made numerous design changes personally, says he fell "madly in love" with the Corinthian and hoped at first to keep it as a rental. But the condominium market was peppy at the time, and a rental would have been a heavier risk for the builder and his partners and probably more difficult to finance. As a condominium, about 75 percent of the apartments were sold at an average price of about $350 a square foot over a year and half, Mr. Spitzer said. The remaining apartments are still owned by the partnership or its individual members, with some being rented.
Another design challenge involved the site on the west side of Seventh Avenue at Central Park South, which became 200 Central Park South. Mr. Spitzer admired the location from a taxicab window in the early 60's, and set out to find how it could be assembled. The key property was a 12-story building on 28,000 square feet owned by the Shubert Organization. It and neighboring properties were duly purchased.
The distinctive curving shape facing northeast at the intersection was sketched out on a three-by-five card at a kitchen table by the builder.
According to Mr. Spitzer, about one development plan out of 50 ever reaches fruition. One notable recent failure explains why he is without a buildable site at present.
He bought three small properties on the south side of 57th Street near Lexington Avenue, occupying 7,500 square feet of land, in the mid-80's in hope of purchasing the neighboring 8,000-square-foot site where the Transit Authority operates a substation.
The idea was to interest the authority in improving its operation largely at developer expense, in exchange for providing development rights for a new 175,000-square-foot building above. The substation's generators would be temporarily relocated during construction and ultimately replaced by new equipment.
The Transit Authority was agreeable, but when it auctioned the site with the conditions that the winning bidder had to meet, Mr. Spitzer was outbid by the property owner to the east, Dr. Axel Stawski. The winning bid was $6.125 million.
So Mr. Spitzer will forgo the responsibility of sinking columns for a new skyscraper through an operating substation without decommissioning the East Side subway system. That challenge is Dr. Stawski's. Mr. Spitzer is ready for another.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 18, 1991, Wednesday

The company will perform at 8 P.M. Friday and Saturday (not tomorrow), at the college's theater at 221 East 71st Street in Manhattan.

HEADLINE: Economic Pulse: New England/A special report.;
New England's Siren Call of 80's Becomes Echo of the Depression

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NASHUA, N.H., Dec. 12

 BODY:
It seemed like the American dream to Barbara Cleland when she moved here from Massachusetts eight years ago to open a private educational testing and tutorial service. Nashua was the fastest growing town in the fastest growing state east of the Mississippi River, after Florida, and soon, with a bank loan against her house, the former teacher had two busy offices with 25 employees.
 But now, with New Hampshire's economy in a shambles, Miss Cleland's students have defaulted on their tuition. She herself had to declare bankruptcy and has lost her business, her house, her savings and her car. 
Miss Cleland, a 45-year-old divorced mother, may even have to skip Christmas. "My daughter and I decided we would only buy each other a book, but we can't afford it," she said.
 
Worst Since 1930's
 Miss Cleland's plight is only one example of the hardships forced on the six New England states over the past two years, as the region's economic slump has turned into by far the worst for this area since the Great Depression in the 1930's. According to economists, it may prove to be the worst recession since the 1930's for any region in the country by the time it ends.
 Already New Hampshire has lost 10.7 percent of its jobs since 1989, said Andrew Sum, the director of the Center for Labor Market Studies at Northeastern University in Boston. He said Massachusetts has lost even more, 11.1 percent of its jobs in that time.
 The only state to suffer heavier job losses since the Bureau of Labor Statistics began to collect data in 1939 was Michigan during a somewhat longer period, from 1979 to 1982, Mr. Sum said. Michigan lost 12.2 percent of its jobs in those three years.
 But what makes the situation seem even worse in New England is, unlike Michigan where four out of five jobs lost were in manufacturing, here they have been shed across the board, in every sector but health care, said Sara Johnson, a regional economist with DRI/McGraw Hill, an economic consulting company. Construction, computers, banking, retail trade and local government all have lost workers, many of them well paid white-collar employees largely untouched by the nation's last recession in 1981-82.
 
Spotlight on Region
 The severity of New England's suffering will be in the national spotlight soon, with candidates and journalists trudging through the snow for New Hampshire's Presidential primary in February. A recent Boston Globe poll of 880 voters in that conservative state found that 74 percent disapproved of President Bush's handling of the economy. In a hypothetical election between Mr. Bush and his unknown Democratic opponent, the President barely prevailed, 35 percent to 31 percent. The poll's margin of sampling error was plus or minus five percentage points.
 People in New Hampshire are so angry and frustrated that the state has experienced its first large exodus since just after the Civil War. According to the New Hampshire Office of State Planning, 5,000 people left between mid-1989 and April 1990.
 And the economic projections say things will get bleaker in New England before they get better. "Our forecast for New England is that employment will decline for the first three months of 1992, and then begin a slow recovery by spring," Ms. Johnson said.
 Even this recovery depends on a national recovery first, the specialists say, a shaky proposition at present. "Without the engine of the national recovery, there is not going to be any train," said Frederick Breimyer, the president of the New England Economic Project, a forecasting group.
 In fact, the long run prognosis for the six states of New England -- including Maine, Vermont, Rhode Island and Connecticut besides New Hampshire and Massachusetts -- is that they will not recover their peak level of employment until the year 2000, Mr. Breimyer said.
 
Problems of 80's Remain
 The reason for this pessimism is that the problems that ended New England's boom of the 1980's, when it enjoyed the greatest improvement in living standards of any region of the country, have not been overcome.
 These include some of the nation's highest wages and housing prices, which, although they have declined somewhat with the recession, remain generally high and make New England unattractive to business investment. They also involve trouble in the region's primary industries, with cutbacks in military spending and a shift in the computer business away from minicomputers, which had been the mainstay of high-tech industry in Massachusetts and New Hampshire. Minicomputers, middle range machines that displaced mainframes in the late 60's and 70's, have since been overcome by smaller desktop and personal computers.
 The effects of the recession have been compounded by crises in each of the state's budgets, as governors and legislators have wrangled over increases in taxes and cuts in services. The proposed solutions have varied from state to state, but all six have endured some paralysis in state government and widesrepad public anger.
 For New Englanders, the recession's effects have been magnified because, having led the rest of the nation into the recession, they have been mired in it much longer. More and more of the unemployed here are becoming long-term unemployed, with all the stress that brings, said Mr. Sum of Northeastern.
 At present, 42 percent of all the unemployed in New England have been out of work for more than 15 weeks, Mr. Sum said. And 25 percent of the unemployed in the region have not had jobs for 26 weeks, meaning that they have exhausted their unemployment benefits, at least until a new law passed by Congress last month extending these benefits kicks in.
 "The problem is, a lot of these individuals are exhausted, they've used everything up," he said.
 One indication of this has been a calamitous surge in the number of bankruptcies, like that filed by Miss Cleland in Nashua. New Hampshire led the country with the largest increase in personal and business bankruptcy filings between 1989 and 1990, jumping 94 percent, to 2,568 from 1,324, according to court records. Indeed, the six New England states were the six highest in the nation in that category.
 Similar financial pressures have triggered a stunning increase in the number of welfare caseloads in the six New England states, led by a whopping 160 percent rise in cases in New Hampshire of Aid to Families With Dependent Children between October 1988 and October 1991, according to state figures.
 Paradoxically, Miss Cleland found that she is ineligible for welfare because her daughter just turned 18, and ineligible for unemployment compensation because she had been self-employed -- even though she had regularly paid taxes for all employees, including herself, into the state's unemployment fund. She has appealed the latter decision.
 In the meantime, Miss Cleland has taken a job teaching in a private day-care center. She is making $6 an hour, or $12,000 a year, with no benefits. When she graduated from college 20 years ago, her starting salary as a grade school teacher was $14,000.
 
Declining Services

 Schools Struggle In Massachusetts
The pain and ravages caused by the recession can be found everywhere in these small old states.
 At the Peck Middle School in Holyoke, an aged industrial city in western Massachusetts, the number of teachers was cut in half this fall. There is no more physical education, no shop, no home economics, no foreign languages and no guidance counselors. The computer room, with 50 new machines, is simply locked up.
 The Holyoke School Department, ordered by a deficit-plagued city to cut its budget, also reduced the number of school buses for the Peck School in half, so more students must walk to class. Attendance is down, grades are slipping and the number of disciplinary suspensions is up.
 "I think there is a promise that has been broken, to do for kids today what our parents provided for us," said George Counter, Holyoke's school superintendent. Overall, Mr. Counter had to lay off 220 teachers this fall, or 36 percent of his entire teaching staff in this city of 44,000 people.
 Efrain Santos has 40 students in his fourth-grade bilingual class at the Lawrence Elementary School. Last year he had 22. By state law bilingual classes may not exceed a maximum of 18 pupils; a group of Hispanic parents is suing the city on that point. Meanwhile, 7 of the 24 classrooms in the school are empty for lack of teachers.
 Mr. Santos, a native of Puerto Rico, like most of his students, has six levels of reading groups in his jammed class, but he cannot get to each everyday. "Some of the kids are not learning as fast as they did before," he observed. "I often blame myself."
 One of his fellow teachers, Noreen Kane, who was born and raised in Holyoke and has taught in the city's public schools for 19 years, decided to put her own two sons in private school this fall. "I am embarrassed for my city, but I had to do it for their sake," she said.
 Holyoke's school crisis has been brought about by a combination of cuts in Massachusetts state aid for local education, the city's shifting of the schools' utility and maintenance bills onto the School Department and voters' repeated rejection of tax increases for education.
 In November Holyoke's voters approved higher taxes to maintain city trash collection but again turned down more money for the schools. Opposition to school spending is widespread in Massachusetts, part of general outrage against higher taxes, but it has been worsened in Holyoke by the large proportion of elderly voters there and a backlash against Puerto Ricans whose children make up two-thirds of the public-school students.
 At the Peck Middle School, Kate Sandoval, a seventh grader with braces, misses gym, music, art and cooking classes. "It seems like we're just staying in one classroom all day now," she said.
 She blames "the older people in Holyoke who got their education when they were young."
 "It's unfair," said the 12 year-old. "How will we get jobs?"
 With unemployment in Holyoke running at 13 percent, voters last spring also rejected a proposal to continue financing the city's public library. So to try to keep the library open at least a few hours a week, the institution's board of directors last month auctioned of most of its collection of paintings that had been donated in flusher times by wealthy mill owners. That brought in more than $600,000.
 But to Roland Pineault, a local art dealer, the auction was an insult. "It was just another nail in the coffin of the deterioration of the city," he said. "They are giving away our heritage."
 
Shrinking Economies

 In 4 States, Less To Go Around
 New Hampshire and Massachusetts have had the sharpest downturn, but the region's other four states have all suffered. Even largely rural Vermont has experienced a 42.5 rise in welfare cases since 1988. Vermont's construction industry has collapsed, as the market for vacation homes has vanished, and many workers have been laid off in the high-tech companies around Burlington.
 Some Vermonters blame the economic hard times for a jump in the state's murder rate, which has reached 22 this year, tying the record for homicides, set in 1978.
 "I'm sure that people are under more stress because of the recession," said Tom Slayton, the editor of Vermont Life, a magazine that trumpets the virtues of the Green Mountain state. "Basically a lot of people buy the pastoral myth of Vermont, that Vermont is somehow apart from the rest of urban America," Mr. Slayton said.
 "It's a good myth, it's a myth that true," he said.
 "This is a state where people literally don't lock their doors," Mr. Slayton added. "But this concentration of murders has brought people up short. More people are locking their doors than they did before."
 In Maine and Connecticut the contracting economy has meant sharply lower tax revenues and has produced angry clashes over the states' budgets.
 Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut announced recently that less than three months after the largest tax increase in state history and the introduction of an income tax, Connecticut's budget was already headed for another deficit. Despite this, the Legislature convened a special session and, on Friday, voted to repeal the new tax law. Governor Weicker, an independent, promptly vetoed that repeal and the House failed to override his veto.
 The lengthy dispute over tax increases has made business leaders even more uncertain and has aggravated the recession, said Nicholas Perna, the chief economist for the Shawmut National Corporation, the large bank, in Hartford. "For all intents and purposes, Connecticut doesn't have a budget," he said. "Forget about what you think of the income tax. The issue is, businesses can't plan."
 In Maine, Gov. John R. McKernan, a Republican, invoked his emergency powers last month to cut state spending by $22.5 million through December, with the biggest reduction coming in state aid to schools. In July, Mr. McKernan shut down the state government for a week when he could not reach agreement with the Legislature on a budget.
 In Rhode Island, the effects of the recession have been worsened by a banking crisis touched off when Gov. Bruce Sundlun, a Democrat, shut down 45 banks and credit unions in January after the failure of the state's private insurance fund, the Rhode Island Share and Deposit Indemnity Corporation. The fund crumbled after bailing out the Heritage Loan and Investment Company.
 Governor Sundlun has since reopened 32 of the 45 institutions. But out of the original $1.7 billion in frozen assets, more than $1 billion remains in limbo and may take years for depositors to recover, if at all.
 For Connie and Daniel Thornton, of Warwick, who had deposited more than $100,000 from the sale of their house in the Rhode Island Central Credit Union, the crisis has meant having to postpone retirement and cut back on virtually all expenses. "At this point in our lives, we were looking forward to enjoying a little more," said Mrs. Thornton, a controller in a law firm.
 "It's like they stole a year of our life from us," Mrs. Thornton said. "We eat at home. We don't go out that often. We can't travel."
 The Thorntons had bought a new home for retirement, but without access to their money they are having trouble meeting the mortgage payments. "I don't know how long we can afford to stay here," said Mrs. Thornton, who joins other pickets every day at lunchtime in front of the closed credit union.
 "It is our money, we shouldn't have to beg for it," she said. "I'm never going to trust another politician again."
 
Disappearing Jobs

 Growth Industries Decline From 80's
 In Nashua, a city of 79,000 on the Massachusetts border, the high-tech and military industry companies that fueled its growth in the 1980's have been laying off workers by the thousands. Robert Tamposi, the director of the city's understaffed welfare office, said applications for emergency relief had jumped 72 percent between 1989 and 1990, to 6,000 families.
 Many of them were well-educated, affluent people like engineers, marketing representatives or managers who have never been laid off before, he said. Some are assigned by the local general relief office to menial tasks like sweeping leaves in exchange for help.
 At the Nashua Soup Kitchen and Shelter, Lisa Christie, the director, said she had given out 1,679 food baskets so far this year, each with a three-day supply of groceries. That is up 200 percent from last year, she said.
 "Middle-class people are coming in who would never have dreamed they would come to a soup kitchen," she said. "They still own a home, but can't afford food."
 Carl Swenson, the director of the Nashua Pastoral Care Center, said people were stunned by the speed with which their lives are unraveling. "It's incredible how fast you can do down," he said. "Up here there's no public transportation, so when the bank comes in and repos the car, you can't get to work anymore."
 "We estimate that, in a middle-class family with both partners working, after the first job goes, within 90 days, the family is losing their house and vehicle and looking for food," Mr. Swenson said.
Greg Staradub, a 50-year-old systems engineer, was laid off after 26 years at Lockheed Sanders, a major military electronics manufacturer. Mr. Staradub, a graduate of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, looks with sadness on the strip of fake colonial shopping malls and car dealerships that sprung up during the boom of the 1980's around Nashua, replacing the pastoral country roads that originally attracted him here.
 "The trees and the woods are gone, and now those buildings are empty," he said. "In a sense, they chopped it all down for nothing."

HEADLINE: Helping Employees At Small Businesses

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
WITH the recession still going strong and companies putting renewed emphasis on increasing efficiency, executives are looking for ways to help their employees address personal problems that produce stress, which can reduce their performance.
Many large corporations have expanded employee assistance programs, confidential intervention and consultation systems for workers and their families. A good program provides assessments, brief counseling and referrals for problems of substance abuse, work stress, family relationships and personal problems. 
 Because the small companies that employ a majority of American workers can seldom afford their own in-house programs, they depend on help from outside concerns like Longview Associates, a nonprofit firm in White Plains.
"Employee assistance programs provide access to professional counselors who meet with employees on the outside," said T. J. Elliott, a vice president of Longview. "We also help write company policy manuals, set up procedures and train managers and supervisors to become sensitive to employees' problems and tactful when dealing with them."
 
Finding Outside Help
 The assistance can produce results for small employers. "In a company as small as mine, you don't have a human resource director, you don't even have a personnel office; you try to deal with employees and their problems all by yourself," said Joan Corwin, president of Chappaqua Transportation Company, a school bus company that employs 110 people.
In 1989, Ms. Corwin said, "when the law decreed that we had to have a drug-testing program because we were in the transportation business, I didn't even know what an employee assistance program was, and I was not anxious to spend money for one. But because I needed help with setting up a drug-testing program in the company, I was put in touch with Longview Associates."
"Not only did they write a policy and help us implement it," she said, "but they helped me deal with our drivers, who were sort of apprehensive about the whole thing."
 
'An Additional Benefit'
 Mr. Elliott, Ms. Corwin said, "came up here and gave talks to the drivers in our office, explaining the process, and walked the shop steward and myself through the whole procedure."
The drivers now like the program, Mrs. Corwin added. "They see it as an additional benefit and one that can help them with personal problems on the home front," she said. "With the recession, there's an awful lot of stress around. Even in a business like mine, which is pretty stable -- kids go to school in good times and bad -- a lot of our employees have difficult personal problems."
When employees with problems are referred to Longview, Mr. Elliott said, "the first thing the counselor will do is give them a chance to ventilate, to air their grievances."
"We'll go back and get a more accurate picture of the problem. Troubled employees meet with a counselor for three sessions. But when more help is needed, as is sometimes the case with drug or alcohol abuse, referral to a long-term treatment center is arranged by us."
During the current recession, the number of calls for help for stress-related problems has risen sharply, he said. "Although drug and gambling addiction problems have flattened out, there are more people with serious financial worries brought on by salary cuts or such things as the loss of a spouse's income," Mr. Elliott said. "And we find more people are abusing alcohol, the legal drug, and each other. For instance, cases of domestic violence against women, who are being abused physically and verbally, have soared during the past two years."
 
Low Fees for Many
 Longview Associates was originally organized as a department of the National Council of Alcoholism and Drug Abuse in White Plains. The department split off and became a freestanding designer of employee assistance programs in 1975.
"As a not-for-profit organization, we continue to serve over 50 percent of our clients at cost," Mr. Elliott said, "and that includes about two-thirds of all schools in Westchester, hospitals and colleges."
Mr. Elliott, who is an accredited certified counselor in New York State, formerly ran the employee assistance program for 50,000 employees of American Airlines on the East Coast. He said that while large companies have the resources for in-house employee assistance programs that are staffed by full-time counselors, the majority of Americans, who work for small companies, don't have access to such services even though they may often have the most need for them.
"We have designed and implemented affordable programs for small companies that cost anywhere from $20 to $24 per employee a year," Mr. Elliott said. "Good employee assistance programs make a big difference to a company. For example, a single case of an employee suffering from a nervous breakdown can wreak havoc with a small company's medical coverage. A good employee assistance program should be able to find the best treatment for the employee without raising the company's medical coverage costs."
 
Potential Savings
 On July 26, 1992, Mr. Elliott said, the Americans With Disabilities Act becomes law. "It will change American business because employers will have to be concerned with whether they are reasonably accommodating workers with alcohol, drug or addictive problems," he said. "Now, recovering alcoholics are often turned down for a job because of their past history."
In the short term, he said, the new law may be viewed as a real squeeze, during a recession, on businesses that have to pay for a safeguard to deal with troubled employees. "But I would hope companies would consider installing employee assistance programs to help them deal with the new law," Mr. Elliott said, "because in the long term they will more than pay for themselves in increased productivity and a smoother work-place operation."
At Curtis Instruments in Mount Kisco, Ann Papaelias, vice president of human resources, said more Curtis employees were taking advantage of the company's employee assistance program.
"I think the value of the program is that it catches problems before they really get bad," Ms. Papaelias said. "Our employees are either referred to Longview counselors by their supervisors or they go for help on their own. But every case is treated in strictest confidence. Other employees are not aware when an employee goes to seek help because appointments with counselors are held off-site."
 
More Clients This Year
 And even though business is stable at Curtis, a manufacturer of instruments and controls for electric vehicles like fork- lift trucks and golf carts, Ms. Papaelias said employees are exhibiting signs of stress, which leads to serious problems.
"Financial pressure is the most obvious sign of stress," she said. "Both blue-collar and pink-collar workers are under a lot of financial pressure today because living in a high-cost area such as Westchester often takes two incomes, and if one income stops, the problems begin."
More Curtis employees have used the program this year than last, she said. "I think it's a sign of the times. They sought help in categories headed by financial-legal and marital, followed by alcohol and drug abuse."
Fred Collett, vice president for human resources of Hudson Valley National Bank in Yonkers, said Hudson Valley has had an employee assistance program for five years. "There was no mandate for an employee assistance program in our industry, but it was the result of a volunteer decision made by top management," Mr. Collett said. "They realized that employees' personal problems can adversely affect job performance, their attitude and their attendance. It's proven to be a cost-effective and timely benefit."

HEADLINE: Charities Say Tough Times Soften Hearts Of Donors

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
LIEUT. RONALD B. COX was on duty at the Salvation Army in Stamford earlier this month, when a man came in and said he had just stood behind a woman in a supermarket checkout line who had to return her Christmas turkey to the freezer, because she did not have the money to pay for all her groceries.
"This was a man who had never contributed to the Salvation Army in his life," Lieutenant Cox said. "He wrote me a check for $1,000." 
 That act of generosity was not an isolated incident. Despite an economy more sour than Scrooge before visitations from spirits, several charitable groups in the state report encouraging responses to holiday season appeals.
"This year we expected a serious lag in fund raising at Thanksgiving," said the Rev. William O. Johnson, director of A.B.C.D. Inc., the antipoverty agency in Bridgeport. "But we were able to raise $15,000, up slightly from last year, and we were able to help about 8,000 people." Mr. Johnson said he was heartened by the contributions. He cited the case of a woman who operates a soup kitchen in Bridgeport. When robbers took $1,000 worth of supplies from her, she received contributions worth $10,000 within a few days, he said. In Norwalk the assistant director of Family and Children's Aid, Patricia P. Benzien, said this year's donations to the organization's Holiday Gift Share program are triple those of 1990.
"When it comes to Christmas presents, people have just opened their hearts," Ms. Benzien said. "Giving has not reflected the economy."
The Rev. Kenneth L. Davis, of the Horace Bushnell Congregational Church in Hartford, said that 750 turkeys were donated within a few days after a newspaper reported that he needed 500 more to fill the needs of 1,600 needy families that had signed up for the church's Thanksgiving giveaway. The extra turkeys will be distributed at Christmas, he said.
 
'Stocked to the Ceiling'
 "I came in the first morning after the article appeared, and the phones were ringing off the hook -- people who wanted to donate money, people who wanted to buy us a turkey, people who got a turkey at work and wanted us to have it," Mr. Davis said. "A lot of people have realized that even if they're not in as good a shape as they were last year, there are a lot of people who are worse off."
Sister Joan D'Amato of the New Covenant House of Hospitality, which operates a food bank and soup kitchen for southwestern Connecticut, said: "I just came in and found 37 bags of food on the doorstep. The pantry is stocked to the ceiling."
Sister Joan said the donations of time, money and provisions are even more encouraging because people are being squeezed.
"Those who have been blessed, they call in and say God has been good to them, and they wish to do something for others," she said. "If you ever wanted to donate, the time is now."
Sister Joan noted that, unlike in the past, the nation's economic problems have become personal for many people in Fairfield County. "Everyone knows someone who has fallen on hard times," she said.
Ms. Benzien agreed that people who have enough to get by this year are much more aware of those who do not. While giving to the gift sharing program has tripled, she said, so have requests for children's gifts.
"Organizations like the Salvation Army do a little better when the economy is bad," Lieutenant Cox said. "When the economy is bad, the middle class person is hurting a little more, and they can relate more to people in need."
Noting that "we're a country of people who rise up to any crisis," Lieutenant Cox said that last year at this time his office had requests for almost 1,000 Christmas food baskets. This year more than 1,300 requests have come in. Last year at this time his office was handling about 300 social service cases a month; last month the number was 998.
"With Thanksgiving coming a week later than last year, it's created a bit of a problem -- how do you raise more money in less time?" Lt. Cox said. "It's still going to be a very, very tough Christmas."
And while people are giving food and other gifts, like clothing, the charities said they were short of cash.
"Raising food has never been a big problem," said the Rev. Kenneth P. Bonadies, director of the Christian Union Soup Kitchen in Hamden. "Where we have a problem is meeting our bills. Everyone is tight with money, but they have a can of food in the cupboard or a turkey in the freezer, and they're more likely to give it to us."
While special appeals have outpaced expectations, organizations that rely on financial pledges to be paid throughout the year have felt the downturn in the economy.
Susan Dunn, a spokeswoman for the United Way of the Capitol Area, said a campaign just ended raised $26.5 million, $500,000 more than last year, but only because of a $1.4 million emergency supplement initiative organized by the campaign chairman, George David, an executive vice president at United Technologies Corporation.
"We realized that three or four weeks from the end of our campaign we were way behind," Ms. Dunn said. "Our agencies are seeing a real explosion of need at a time when their funding from state sources is being cut. And we couldn't let that happen."
 
Poor Timing This Year
 The $1.4 million was raised in one-time special gifts, including a $100,000 challenge grant from an anonymous donor who matched any new giving of $500 or more, Ms. Dunn said.
She said the campaign starts every year on Oct. 1, which was poor timing this year. "That's right when state income tax withholding started," Ms. Dunn said. "So people were seeing a new deduction from their check. And here comes the United Way asking for more."
Ms. Dunn said layoffs by insurance companies and other employers eliminated about 15,000 jobs in the Hartford area since the 1990 campaign, so even though participation was good, the organization had to scramble, because it was working with a much smaller base.
In addition, the capitol area appeal relies heavily on state employees Ms. Dunn said. This year those employees were so worried about their own jobs, because of state cutbacks, they were reluctant to pledge heavily, she said.
"There were no hard feelings," Ms. Dunn said. "It's just that people said, 'These are tough times, and I have to think about my own family first.' ".
The acting president of the Combined Health Appeal of South Central Connecticut, Malcolm J. Doyle, said that the group was trying to equal last year's donations of $225,000, but that the total could fall about 10 percent short of that.
"The state income tax has really hurt charitable giving" at a time when many nonprofit groups are seeing their government funds cut back. Mr. Doyle said. "People just don't have the discretionary income they used to have."
 
Worries About the Winter
 Even charities that have benefited from the holiday largesse said they were worried about what would happen after Jan. 1. Without the holiday spirit, they said, donations could drop off.
"What's depressing is that even with all these donations that are coming in right now, we're still not going to be able to cover the need if we have a bad winter," said Mr. Johnson in Bridgeport.
Mr. Davis said: "People are very reluctant to commit to something they might not be able to follow through on. What's happening is good and bad. It's good in that we get an overwhelming response during the holidays. It's bad because this is the only time of the year a lot of people think about the needy.
"My job is really easy this time of year. I get one article in the newspaper or a notice on the radio, and the stuff comes rolling in. I can't do that in the summer. But hunger doesn't take a vacation. It's a year-round problem."

HEADLINE: Determining What Shapes a Successful School

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG

 BODY:
BY conventional wisdom, the American educational system is no match for its global counterpart. Politicians and pundits alike criticize the failures of the nation's schools, citing high drop-out rates, violence and teen-age pregnancy, illiteracy and deficient technological skills.
But there are some notable exceptions that defy the prevailing gloomy outlook. 
 Two Westchester high schools, in Bronxville and Pleasantville, were singled out earlier this fall as schools of excellence by President George Bush. The program, begun by President Reagan in 1982, recognizes successful schools and holds them up as models for other institutions.
 
No One Formula for Success
 To gain the honor, which was awarded to 222 other middle and high schools nationwide this year, a school must be nominated by state education officials. Applications include a description of the community's demographics and student population, as well as course offerings, extracurricular opportunities, disciplinary methods, student and faculty leadership procedures and any other distinctive programs.
If a school is selected for possible designation as a school of excellence, Federal Department of Education inspectors then visit to assess the school's operation. They try to determine how well these schools meet national goals in areas like literacy, multicultural diversity and fostering technological skills among students.
There is no single formula for scholastic success. But the Bronxville and Pleasantville schools offer telling insights into what ingredients can help shape successful schools.
"Both were very impressive," said Dr. Regina E. Hansen, a Department of Education inspector who is project director of the De La Salle Model, a program that helps at-risk high school students. "Their curriculum matched their clientele very well, and they developed a lot of creative and energizing programs. There was tremendous vitality at both schools."
The high schools in Bronxville and Pleasantville have relatively small student bodies. There are about 270 students in Bronxville, while Pleasantville has about 350. Both schools have attractive sites; the Bronxville school resembles an English Tudor-style building that could easily fit in on an Ivy League campus, while Pleasantville offers its students a tranquil, secluded suburban campus that features brightly lighted halls and abundant space.
And in both schools, the overwhelming majority of students are college bound, with 96 percent of Pleasantville's students going on for higher education, and nearly 100 percent of Bronxville alumni enrolled in college.
But those factors alone do not explain why these schools were singled out for recognition. What seems to make the difference are factors like a well-defined mission that the principal communicates to faculty and students; opportunities for staff and students to participate in decision making at the school; varied teaching techniques that address students' different abilities; strong parental and community involvement and support, and an ability to adapt to changing educational and social needs.
 
The Need for a Vision
 At these schools, apparently, leaders and teachers do more than pay lip service to the idea of individual needs. "It's important for a school to have a vision," said Dr. Donald A. Antonecchia, principal of Pleasantville High School for eight years. "We want our children to be ready for the challenges of the 21st century, and we want them to be drug free, literate and computer literate."
Toward that end, Pleasantville has developed an innovative program to stimulate student interest in writing. The school provides a wall in the main corridor that features the work of a different student writer and artist each month. These works are just as likely to come from learning disabled or average students as from advanced placement or honors students.
"We want to celebrate writing and make it as popular as football," Dr. Antonecchia said. And as part of the effort to develop literacy, Pleasantville students share creative writing workshops with students in Greenburgh's Woodlands High School.
To offer a more extensive curriculum than would be economically feasible in a district its size, Pleasantville is involved in long-distance learning programs to accommodate students whose academic interests would otherwise not be met by the school. Similarly, Pleasantville also includes an alternative education program to address the needs of students considered potential dropouts.
"You have to ask yourself whether you're meeting the needs of bright students, kids at risk for dropping out and the learning disabled," said Theresa Bronkowski, a guidance counselor at Pleasantville.
 
Going Beyond Standards
 One of the hallmarks of a school of excellence, according to Federal standards, is that students consistently exceed the minimum competency requirements set by the state. At Pleasantville, for example, 87 percent of the students take more than the required two years of mathematics. They also participate in community-service activities, including working in the elementary school, as part of their education.
Strong extracurricular and arts programs are also part of the recipe that makes for a successful school. Federal inspectors were impressed, for example, that Pleasantville's dramatic productions bring out parental and community involvement and support. Similar efforts were also cited at Bronxville.
Bronxville's innovations include a student-faculty legislature that lets students, teachers, parents and staff set the school's policies. "Students are empowered; everyone is empowered," said Michael Saltman, assistant principal at Bronxville High School.
The school also offers a seminar program that gives students the chance to tackle issues like self-esteem, leadership, group decision making and community service. Finally, Project Adventure, part of the physical-education curriculum, offers an Outward Bound-type of experience for ninth and tenth graders.
 
Range of Opportunities
 Despite its small size, Bronxville is able to offer an advanced-placement French class for seven students, or advanced-placement Spanish for four students. Yet students take classes in heterogeneous groups, and, Mr. Saltman said, "It's a tribute to our teachers that they can make the work challenging to everybody without being discouraging or simple."
While these schools are flattered by the attention that the designation as a "school of excellence" has bestowed upon them, neither is content to rest on laurels.
"It's very gratifying to be recognized, to have somebody else affirm what we know," Mr. Saltman said. "What we are trying to do is produce thinking students who are well grounded in the fundamentals and who are creative and thoughtful. But if you look at the best students in other countries, that consistently says to a school like Bronxville 'good as you may be, you have to be better.' "
Dr. Antonecchia added: "You're not in competition with other schools, but against yourself. You have to keep improving."
