HEADLINE: Down and Out: When There's Nowhere Else to Go

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
MARY PETERSON lives in an abandoned lot by the waterfront in Yonkers, with a grand view of the Palisades. By her standards, she says, she has exactly what she wants: the closeness of her family and the freedom to do as she pleases.
"There's no one making noise upstairs, nobody below and nobody complaining about my dogs," the 38-year-old woman said. "I don't take welfare, and I don't owe anyone anything. Just let me be free. I like it this way." 
 Ms. Peterson, her 51-year-old cousin, Peter Consadori, and her mother, who is blind from cataracts, live in two small trailers propped up on concrete blocks. Scrap wood in a makeshift fireplace outside burns night and day now that the weather has turned cold. Inside, a small propane stove warms the interior.
Ms. Peterson earns her living collecting scrap metal and crocheting hats and scarves. She lived in one place for most of her life and held various jobs in supermarkets and offices, she said, but when her father died seven years ago and her mother's sight began to fail, she moved her family from the Bronx to Westchester. She worked as a building superintendent for a time, sold castoffs at tag sales to earn money, but finally decided, "It wasn't worth the hassles."
 
A Different Story
 The three moved to their current home on public land several months ago, after being forced from another Yonkers site by the property owner. They are among the county's estimated 4,278 homeless people.
Michael Gallagher is 19, and he, too, does not have a place to live. But his story is quite different.
Mr. Gallagher stepped out of a van late one night last weekend and walked up the broad steps of the county's new emergency drop-in shelter for the homeless, the large bath house at Tibbetts Brook Park in Yonkers.
"I went to the streets a year ago," Mr. Gallagher said. "I've been in and out of shelters and the County Jail. I've been all over -- Los Angeles, Cincinnati. And here I am now."
He said he recently quit a job in Manhattan, at Macy's department store, and did what has been his habit since he can remember. "As usual," he said, "I burned all my bridges." He said he had had difficulties in school, had run away from home and later dropped out of a drug-rehabilitation program. "I know I have problems," he said. "But I'm trying to get myself together now."
Mr. Gallagher is one of a growing segment of the homeless population, young people in their late teens and early 20's, said Catherine J. Marsh, director of the Westchester division of the Volunteers of America, a nonprofit organization that is the state's largest provider of shelter services for single adults.
 
Second Only to New York City
 "The 18- to 20-year-olds, they are one of our biggest problems," Ms. Marsh said. "It's heartbreaking. For a lot of them, the future is not good."
"In a different economy or a different environment, they might have survived marginally," Ms. Marsh added. "But in Westchester we don't have flophouses or rooming homes. There's no place for them to go but to the streets."
As of October, the County Department of Social Services reports, there were 1,342 homeless single people and childless couples in Westchester along with 938 families, a category that included 1,074 adults and 1,862 children.
After New York City, Westchester has the largest number of homeless residents in the state. In two studies prepared by the State Department of Social Services last May, Westchester had 4,364 homeless residents. The next highest concentration of homeless was 914 in Suffolk County.
"We've been working nonstop on the issue of homelessness since 1983, when the problem grew bigger than our efforts to stem the tide," said Mary E. Glass, Acting Commissioner of the Department of Social Services.
The number of homeless rose sharply in the county during the late 1980's, to 4,455 in 1989 from 1,173 in January 1985. The numbers since then have stabilized, with 4,472 reported last year and 4,553 counted in January this year.
 
Motels Average $3,000 a Month
 The county's 1991 budget for sheltering the homeless and providing services to them is $72.6 million, with the cost of housing a homeless family in a motel averaging about $3,000 a month, Ms. Glass said. At the Westchester County Airport Shelter, the cost of providing housing, food and services for a single person runs $2,997 monthly.
But the costs are not the major problem, Ms. Glass said. The county, in fact, is coming in $17 million under budget this year.
"The biggest frustration," she said, "is the absence of affordable housing in Westchester. This is a difficult real estate market. By the year 2000, it will be more difficult yet. Government employees, social workers and even teachers cannot afford to live in Westchester, much less the homeless."
Local opposition to county-run housing for the homeless has also made it difficult for the Department of Social Services to move families out of motels and into permanent scatter-site shelters, Ms. Glass said. The county's 46 municipalities each have independent local zoning ordinances.
 
Transitional Housing Set Up
 The county has succeeded in establishing some transitional housing, including a 108-unit building next to Westchester Community College in Valhalla, a 106-unit family center in Elmsford and a 34-unit building in Mount Vernon. Because Westchester interprets the State Constitution as prohibiting a county from building housing, it contracts with nonprofit organizations to build and manage the housing.
Among organizations contracting with the county is Westhab, a nonprofit housing, development and social service agency, which administers 200 apartment units in 60 buildings for the homeless.
At the County Airport, the Volunteers of America runs a shelter for 58 singles; it also manages an annex for 19 in Ossining. The airport shelter also serves as an intake and assessment center, where the homeless receive physical examinations, psychiatric evaluations and addiction counseling. From there they are referred to residences and job-placement programs, Ms. Walsh said.
The Volunteers of America also runs the new emergency drop-in shelter in Tibbetts Brook Park, which was opened just before Thanksgiving.
 
Largest Concentration in Yonkers
 "A drop-in center keeps them out of the cold and alive," Ms. Walsh said, "but it doesn't help the homeless get back on their feet. That's where the assessment center comes in. We develop a plan."
The largest concentration of the county's homeless lives in Yonkers, where a total of 404 families with 831 children and 44 adults and 579 singles was counted in October. The Sharing Community operates two shelter programs in Yonkers. One provides accommodations for up to 55 homeless people, the other for 19.
The organization is a nonprofit one, founded in 1983 by members of the clergy and people from the community. "What we originally intended, nine years ago, to be just a temporary program is still here, because the problem keeps growing," said the Rev. George Anthony Hoeltzel, an Episcopal and the executive director of the Sharing Community.
Father Hoeltzel, a critic of what he calls the county's bureaucratic red tape in processing the homeless, said the Department of Social Services' intake procedures at the airport "scare away" many of the homeless.
 
Alternative Procedure Suggested
 "They are already frightened by the system," said Father Hoeltzel. "They look at an assessment procedure far from their neighborhood, and they tend to bolt and go back to fending for themselves."
Father Hoeltzel said the homeless should be admitted into the system by a county team that travels to neighborhood shelters where the homeless feel safe.
Anthony Wynne, who until last week was the executive director of the Coalition for the Homeless of Westchester, a Yonkers-based advocacy group, accused the county of using the three-day assessment as a "cover to throw people off the system, because if you don't show up, you don't get assistance."
"They're throwing a lot of red tape at people who can't handle it," he said.
 
Approach Called Humane
 Ms. Glass disagreed. "If a three-day assessment is too complicated, then that's their decision," she said. "The homeless are transported in vans to the airport, and they're not up to their armpits in forms."
"We ask them, 'How's your health?' and 'When did you last eat?' There are nurses and doctors and a humane approach. We try to identify the problems and make referrals. It's a very sensible system."
By law, a homeless person cannot spend more than one night in a county-financed shelter unless he is assessed by the Department of Social Services at the airport shelter.
In White Plains, the Rev. Peter Larom, another critic of some of the county's policies, oversees a 40-bed shelter at Grace Episcopal Church and the 19-bed Open Arms Shelter nearby.
 
'County Is Dragging Its Feet'
 "The county," he said, "is making the motel owners rich. What we need is more permanent low-income housing. I'm furious because the county is just dragging its feet on this issue."
Among Westchester's 1,295 homeless single people and childless couples in October, 370 were in shelters, 284 were in motels, 55 were in emergency-housing apartments and 586 were in a category called "made own arrangements," which means they were, like Ms. Peterson, homeless but not seeking housing placements from the Social Services Department.
Of the 938 homeless families in October, 273 had been placed by the county in motels, 205 were in emergency housing, 306 were in special family shelters and 154 had made their own arrangements.
Despite the criticism, Ms. Glass said she felt the county had made progress. "I think we're finally turning a corner and hitting a plateau in terms of numbers," she said. "To the extent that we can set aside our criticisms of each other and devote ourselves in a cooperative effort to solve this problem, we can lick it"

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
The Office Party Gets A Dose of Downsizing

BYLINE: By Nancy Marx Better

 BODY:
How many office parties will you attend this holiday season? If the answer is a scaled-back one -- or none -- you're not alone.
According to Battalia Winston International, a New York executive search firm that asked 500 of the country's largest companies about their holiday plans, it's beginning to look a lot less like Christmas across corporate America. While 66 percent of respondents were invited to company-wide galas and 16 percent were invited to departmental celebrations, 18 percent reported that no parties were planned at all in their offices. 
 "The results were pretty depressing," said Dale Winston, president of Battalia Winston. "When companies are going through a period of downsizing and eliminating jobs, nobody's in the mood for parties. It's not just an issue of saving money. It has to do with peoples' state of mind."
Cost-cutting measures range from shortening parties to holding them at lunchtime instead of at night. Some companies are asking employees to chip in a share of the expenses, or to buy drinks at a cash bar. "This isn't a time for excessive spending," Ms. Winston said. "It's embarassing for companies to act like we're still in the 80's."
Executives responsible for planning events are well aware of this. At Ogilvy & Mather Direct, a division of the New York advertising agency, past holiday parties were held at grand venues, including the New York Public Library and the Museum of Natural History. Last year's bash was a somewhat more subdued affair at the Tribeca Grill, a trendy Manhattan restaurant owned by Robert DeNiro. This year, employees toasted each other at the office last Thursday.
"Given the economy, we figured we should scale back," said Ray Rowell, an Ogilvy & Mather Direct spokesman. "But we wanted to do something to thank our people for all their hard work."
The theme of the event: "A Snowball in Hell" (the company is located in the Hell's Kitchen neighborhood on the West Side of Manhattan). The invitation featured a styro foam snowball, there were decorations in the cafeteria and, instead of live entertainment, the 350 guests were treated to a rented Karaoke machine, the Japanese gadget that lets people sing along to recorded music.
With more and more companies entertaining on their own premises, restaurant owners are adapting. Some are trying for a profit by hosting a larger number of smaller parties.
Chris Carey, general manager of the Hudson River Club, a Wall Street area restaurant, said his business is up about 20 percent from last season. "Bookings from the Wall Street firms are solid, but not lavish," he said. "People are looking for more practical ways to do parties. They might go for a two-hour cocktail party, instead of four. They don't want to do a party that's too elaborate or ostentatious."
Amid all the penny pinching, experts advise executives to make the most of holiday parties. Ann Humphries, president of Eticon, a Columbia, S.C.-based etiquette consulting firm, lectures clients -- including Arthur Andersen, Hoechst-Roussel Pharmaceuticals and BellSouth Mobility -- about proper reception manners. "I tell people to eat before they go to parties, so they can concentrate on working the crowd," she said. "They should be out meeting people, not stuffing themselves with hors d'oeuvres."
In addition to suggesting conversation topics and instructing executives about how to make introductions, Ms. Humphries addresses strategic issues. "Everyone wants to know how to wedge into a cluster of people surrounding the C.E.O.," she said. "I tell them not to bother. Try to make eye contact with him, and give a nod. Then write a thank-you note the next day."
Most important, Ms. Humpries said, "Keep in mind that a holiday party is a business function, and that people are still judging you in a business capacity. You can't afford to let your guard down by drinking too much or acting unprofessional in any way."
Some executives will be relieved to be excused from parties entirely. Fundamental Brokers, a New York-based firm that sells Government securities, departed from its habit of chartering yachts and renting hotel ballrooms and is contributing upward of $30,000 to a charity group. "Hopefully, this will have a better impact on the community than taking our clients out for an endless evening of drinking," said Julie Epstein, a partner in the firm.
Other companies are incorporating charitable activities with holiday festivities. Recognizing the especially harsh impact of recession on New England, Reebok, the athletic footwear maker, is hosting a party for handicapped children in South Boston. But that's not all; the company is also holding a bash for 900 employees and their families, complete with clowns, games, prizes and a Santa Claus. "We like to bring everybody together during the holidays," said Bernadette Mansur, Reebok's vice president of communications. "It's become a tradition."
At McMillen Inc., the New York-based interior design firm whose clients include Rupert Murdoch and Carter Burden, employees have celebrated in the same fashion for 75 years. "We decorate our offices, and we drink egg nog from the recipe of Eleanor Brown, a founder of our company," said Betty Sherrill, McMillen's president.
But even tradition can take on an unconventional spin. In late 1988, after the financier Sandy Weill acquired Primerica, his staff sang Christmas carols around a fire in the office library. Flush with merriment, a couple of staffers penned new words to an old patriotic standard. Result: "God Bless Primerica." "Now it's become a tradition," said Mary McDermott, a company spokeswoman. A new stanza appears each year.

HEADLINE: Send Help Before It's Too Late

BYLINE: By Angela Stent and Daniel Yergin; Angela Stent is a professor of government at Georgetown University. Daniel Yergin, president of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, is author, most recently, of "The Prize."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
At Princeton University on Thursday, Secretary of State James Baker announced a new strategy to deal with the grave risks arising from the social and economic disintegration of the former Soviet Union. His speech recalled Secretary of State George Marshall's historic address at Harvard in 1947, launching the reconstruction of a devastated Western Europe.
But time is crucial, as it was in 1947. While an airlift of some essentials begins this week, the main planning -- the "coordination conference" -- is not to convene until mid-January. This delay is highly risky, given how close the former Soviet Union is to chaos. What Marshall said of Europe 44 years ago applies to the Soviet economy today: "The patient is sinking while the doctors deliberate." 
 Twentieth-century history is littered with "what ifs" -- catastrophes and evils that might have been avoided by prudent action. We may look back and realize that this was one of those junctures when a great opportunity slipped away. The West may demand reforms before aid, but the reformers may not survive long enough to get around to the reforms.
We must get food shipments moving on a sufficient scale, and take the program out of election-year politics. The Soviets need a "Strategic Food Initiative." This would work in the same way that the U.S. Strategic Petroleum Reserve does: it insures that supplies are plentiful enough to counteract hoarding and panic buying. Once the hoarders learned of Western intentions to supply the Soviet Union with food, they would have no reason to hold on to supplies.
Food shipments by the West will further help defuse the crisis as Russia and other republics prepare to free prices and move to a market system. The main targets should include big cities, the Urals industrial region and hard-pressed Armenia. It is critical to feed the cities: That is where food is in shortest supply and where revolutions or counterrevolutions are most likely to begin. The likelihood of panics and upheavals increases day by day. The West can make a crucial difference, and we need the resulting influence to support the move to democracy and markets and help stabilize the Soviet nuclear arsenal.
The initiative should be coordinated by the Group of Seven, to avoid duplication and conflicts. The Japanese need to move beyond pledges of funds to actual expenditure. Results would be almost immediate if the European Community financed the shipment of Polish and Hungarian food surpluses to the Soviet Union.
The Bush Administration should appoint an administrator for the Strategic Food Initiative with the skill and stature to cut through the many Gordian knots. At the same time, leading U.S. agricultural cities, like Des Moines and Omaha, should establish partner relationships with Soviet cities, engaging farm and business groups and spearheading deliveries. This would strengthen the people-to-people character of the Strategic Food Initiative and make it less political. The U.S. mayors could visit their Soviet counterparts as soon as possible.
The difficulty would come once the food was in the Soviet Union, where the distribution system has broken down. One channel for the initiative could be through local city leaders, who in turn could arrange use of empty stores. The proceeds from the sale of the food would be put in accounts to finance the privatization of state enterprises (on which the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development would help). There could also be direct delivery to the most vulnerable groups, old people and children. Inevitably, some food would be wasted or end up on the black market, but most supplies would get through.
To work, the Strategic Food Initiative needs leadership. The Administration and Congress must together respond and develop a consensus that swift, comprehensive action is in the crucial interest of the U.S. in these first unsteady days after the death of the Soviet Union.

HEADLINE: The Stuff That Made Us What We Are

BYLINE: By David Nasaw; David Nasaw, a professor of history at the College of Staten Island and the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, is the author of "Children of the City: At Work and at Play."

 BODY:

VICTORIAN AMERICA
Transformations in Everyday Life,
1876-1915.
By Thomas J. Schlereth.
Illustrated. 363 pp. New York:
HarperCollins Publishers.
$27.50. 
 IN the epigraph to "Victorian America," his new book about everyday life in America in the 40 years preceding World War I, Thomas J. Schlereth cites the historian Siegfried Giedion's claim that "for the historian there are no banal things." Consider the safety razor and disposable blades patented by King Gillette in 1895. Until their invention, men had three choices: to grow beards, to make regular trips to the barber, or to court certain discomfort and probable injury by shaving at home with caked soap and straight razors. The safety razor, Mr. Schlereth observes, "not only contributed to the full beard's decline and spared men frequent trips to the barber shop," but as Gillette's advertisements proclaimed, it provided " 'the modern man' with an opportunity each day to be the 'master' of his own time and appearance." Ironically, as Mr. Schlereth comments, "its successful promotion established greater male uniformity in personal grooming. . . . Soldiers in World War I were provided with 3.5 million Gillette razors and 32 million blades to keep the armed forces looking clean shaven, trim, athletic, energetic, and youthful.' "
Thomas Schlereth's book is full of capsule histories like this, packaged into chapters about moving, working, housing, consuming, communicating, playing, striving, and living and dying. Framing the chapters are a prologue, "interlogue" and epilogue on the world's fairs of 1876, 1893 and 1915, where scores of new products -- from ready-made shoes in 1876 to dollar watches in 1915 -- were introduced to the American public. The book is illustrated with black-and-white reproductions of photographs, posters, cartoons and advertisements of the period.
Others have described this era in United States history by focusing on the rise of the corporation, or the city, or the professional middle classes. Mr. Schlereth does not. His book is, in fact, without any real thesis or connecting threads to bind his disparate mini-essays conceptually. Still, in his relentless piling on of information and his encyclopedic grasp of the era's material culture, he succeeds in accomplishing what he sets out to do. Mr. Schlereth, a professor of American studies at the University of Notre Dame, tells the story of everyday life in America by examining the objects that Americans lived with and for.
At times the cataloguing of case histories is a bit confusing, as when Mr. Schlereth, in the chapter on working, follows a discussion of the daily lives of agrarian workers with a brief history of meat packing, tobacco processing and cigarette manufacturing. And yet, even when the arrangement is confusing, the individual studies are fascinating. In the section called "Packing and Canning," for example, we learn how industrial workers and capitalists like Gail Borden, H. J. Heinz and James Buchanan (Buck) Duke transformed the nation's cooking, eating and smoking habits by preserving milk in cans, meat in tins, pickles in jars and leaf tobacco in cigarettes -- all of which could be shipped across the country in railroad cars and stored on shelves until taken home by shoppers.
"Why did American consumer habits gain such momentum from 1876 to 1915?" Mr. Schlereth asks. Because, he explains, "more people . . . had more money and more time to purchase more goods, mass-produced more cheaply and advertised more widely."
The coming of what Lewis Mumford called "the goods life" transformed every aspect of daily existence in America, including the domestic arrangements we tend to think of as timeless. In the early 19th century, householders began to separate their "sleeping quarters from social ones, using their parlor as a ceremonial and social space." In the early 20th century, nurtured by "etiquette manuals, domestic advisers, and furniture manufacturers," and fed by an avalanche of mass-produced, marketed and advertised commodities, the parlor became a national institution, transcending "social class, economic status, or geographic location."
Women in suburban bungalows, city tenements and rural farmhouses, Mr. Schlereth notes, assembled overstuffed "gender distinctive" furniture (thronelike chairs for the men, armless chairs for the women), brightly colored lithograph prints and mass-produced bric-a-brac in formal parlors where "marriages, wakes, clergymen's calls, holy day and holiday celebrations" were staged and the family's "treasured possessions" and history ("framed photographs, marriage certificates, and the like") were put on exhibit. The modern bathroom was also invented in this period, as householders with indoor plumbing brought together in one room the toilet from the outhouse or closet, the washbowl from the bedchamber and the tub from the kitchen.
Not all Americans were able to decorate parlors or afford elaborate bathrooms. Nor were they all comfortable with the encroachments of progress as defined by a newly ascendant "Victorian middle-class coalition." Mr. Schlereth narrates the outsiders' story as well, though perhaps not in as much detail as he might. He tells us not only about the scientific managers who tried to raise efficiency by regimenting factory labor, but also about the workers who struck rather than accept the discipline of the stopwatch; not only about merchandisers like Sears, Roebuck and Montgomery Ward who sold everything from the "Instant Home" to embalming fluid through the mails, but also about country storekeepers and small-town merchants who fought back by lobbying against rural free delivery and parcel post and urging townspeople and farmers to turn in their catalogs to fuel a "Home Town Industry Jubilee and Bonfire" in the public square.
MR. SCHLERETH'S range is extraordinary. On almost every page we encounter a new item with its own particular history. Root beer, we learn, was created as "the National Temperance Drink" by Charles E. Hires, a Philadelphia pharmacist. The lawnmower, "put into large-scale production by several American firms by the 1870s, contributed to the trend to make the lawn a necessary element of the suburban house." Until this date, homeowners had cut their grass but once or twice a season, and "only country estates and city mansions had large, manicured lawns."
In the end, accumulating detail on top of detail, Thomas Schlereth succeeds in demonstrating the truth of Siegfried Giedion's statement, reproduced in his epigraph: "The humble objects of which we speak have shaken our modes of living to its very roots. Modest things of daily life, they accumulate into forces acting upon whoever moves within the objects of our civilization."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 2095 words

HEADLINE: Democrats Debate Over Taxes and '92 Funds

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
In the first nationally televised debate of the 1992 campaign, the six major candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination squabbled fiercely among themselves tonight over tax policy and the role of special interest money in the Democratic Party.
The debate, held on NBC nine weeks before New Hampshire's primary on Feb. 18, found the Democrats united in attacking President Bush's foreign policy and economic stewardship. They asserted that Mr. Bush had presided over economic decline at home and an uncertain, anachronistic foreign policy that had failed to adjust to the end of the cold war. 
 But the Democratic attack on the opposition often gave way to even angrier exchanges among themselves. Former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, considered one of the longer shots in the race, often drove the debate with his repeated assertions that special interests were "buying politicians" and the American people "had lost control" of their political system to career politicians.
At one point, Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska turned to Mr. Brown and noted, with a very tight jaw, that Mr. Kerrey had run for office for the first time in 1982, when Mr. Brown was already a "a full-time politician." Mr. Kerrey added: "I resent all this PAC and special interest stuff. Are you saying I'm bought and paid for? I resent that."
In between the fighting, the candidates each tried to present both a little personal history, a lot of message and some careful positioning. Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, who seemed to be trying to present a cool, understatedimage for the television audience, used the opportunity to talk about his concern for the middle class. Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia delivered an impassioned defense of affirmative action policies, while assailing the Republicans for permitting a deterioration of race relations.
Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts talked of his economic expertise, and Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa stuck with his pledge for a huge public works program to put people back to work. Mr. Kerrey talked about the need for fundamental rethinking of domestic and foreign policy in the aftermath of the cold war.
The debate, moderated by Tom Brokaw, was the first of seven nationally televised debates to be held among the major candidates for the Democratic nomination, a critical chance at prime-time exposure for a field still struggling for money and recognition.
National polls show that most of the candidates in this late-starting race have barely penetrated the public's consciousness. And the potential candidate who has probably made the strongest impression among Democrats, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, has muddied the field with two months of indecision. That may reach a resolution by Friday, the filing deadline for the New Hampshire primary.
 
Specialized Audience
 Beyond the voters at large, the candidates tonight were wooing another, more specialized audience: the political professionals and financial contributors who need to be persuaded of a candidate's viability.
The candidates disagreed sharply over tax cuts for the middle class, an idea that got vocal backing from Mr. Kerrey, Mr. Wilder and Mr. Clinton. Mr. Tsongas, a critic of what he describes as traditional Democratic economics, asserted that cutting taxes for the middle class was an idea straight out of public opinion polls. Mr. Harkin scornfully brandished a dollar bill to demonstrate his assertion that this was all the middle class family would get each day from his opponents' tax cut.
"What the middle class needs is jobs," Mr. Harkin said.
One of the clearest image-building efforts under way tonight was Mr. Kerrey's attempt to tell his personal story to a national audience. Mr. Kerrey, a Navy commando who lost his leg and won the Medal of Honor for heroism in Vietnam, repeatedly referred to his past as he talked of his views on both foreign and domestic policy.
He said he would "take nothing away" from what American forces had accomplished in the war in the Persian Gulf, but he rebuked Mr. Clinton for suggesting that all Democrats should concede that Mr. Bush had acted wisely. Mr. Kerrey voted against the use of force in the Persian Gulf and tonight criticized Mr. Bush for never clearly explaining his actions, noting that Saddam Hussein was "still alive and still running and still terrorizing the people of Iraq itself."
 
Position of Grim Prophet
 At one point, Mr. Kerrey referred to remarks by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d that the action related to American jobs. "He said this is about 'jobs, jobs, jobs,' and where are the jobs?" Mr. Kerrey asked.
The other clear attempt at image-building was Mr. Brown's repeated effort to position himself as the grim prophet of political corruption. He rode over Mr. Brokaw's injunction to avoid fund-raising appeals and twice gave his 800 number.
He jabbed at most of his fellow candidates and seemed to keep them off stride. Sometimes they seemed amused, more often they did not.
One effect of this, perhaps, was Mr. Clinton's surprisingly muted performance tonight, after a series of speeches in which he got good reviews from party audiences.
Another was that the debate turned into a free-wheeling, angry clash on the nature of the political system instead of the smooth and unified attack that party leaders had hoped to launch against a President sagging in the public opinion polls.
 
Reasons for Running
 Mr. Brokaw asked each man why he sought the nomination. Senator Harkin, who has urged a return to old-time Democratic values, said he was driven by his sense that President Bush was out of touch with the suffering of the American people.
Mr. Tsongas, who campaigns as a pro-business liberal, said he decided to run after concluding that the "old-style Democratic message" offered no hope of economic growth.
Senator Kerrey said President Bush was too closely tied to the past and the cold war.
Mr. Brown said Americans had lost control of their political system, losing their voice, he said, as monied interests captured the electoral process.
Governor Clinton said he had the most comprehensive strategy for a struggling middle class.
Governor Wilder cited his record in balancing the budget in Virginia without a tax increase and said he could do the same for the nation.
While many of the candidates tried to distance themselves from Democratic orthodoxy, they also suggested that Democrats should not be ashamed to embrace some of the party's traditional causes.
Governor Clinton, for example, said he welcomed the opportunity to talk about welfare. He said he agreed with Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, that the nation should provide more education and training, health insurance and adequate child care, so welfare recipients could obtain jobs.
Asked about the merits of affirmative-action progams for women and minorities, Governor Wilder said there should be a clear distinction between quotas and other forms of affirmative action that he finds essential."I wouldn't hire anyone based on a quota," Mr. Wilder said. "The playing field has not been level," Mr. Wilder said, referring to the United States' history of job discrimination against blacks and women. "There has to be some affirmative response to the years" of systematic denial of job opportunities for such people, he said.
On military spending, Governor Clinton said, "the defense budget was based on the existence of the Soviet Union," adding, "We spent billions of dollars to win the cold war." He said the United States "should help them get through the winter," but said that it also should spend money to dismantle Soviet nuclear weapons.
Governor Wilder and Senator Harkin both said food aid to the former Soviet republics should be conditioned on further reductions in their military, especially reductions in nuclear weapons.
Senator Harkin said that as the Soviet Union disintegrated, President Bush had missed an opportunity to negotiate cuts in tactical nuclear weapons. Reminded by Mr. Brokaw that Mr. Bush and the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, both recently endorsed such reductions, he called these agreements "sort of fluff and everything," and said that Soviet weapons should be put under control of inspectors for the International Atomic Energy Agency.
 
Warning of Takeover
 But Mr. Tsongas said that unless the United States sent aid quickly, a right wing or military takeover might occur. He called for sending about $1 billion or $2 billion now in the military budget to aid the collapsed Soviet empire.
The Democrats all criticized Mr. Bush on foreign policy, arguing that he had failed to react properly and promptly to the rapid developments in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.
Mr. Brown suggested that the United States "work with the Europeans" to end the conflict in Yugoslavia. He did not directly answer the question of whether this meant sending American troops or just aid.
Senator Kerrey said Mr. Bush was "getting cold feet at the wrong time," by failing to come up with an economic plan of aid and cooperation with the emerging commonwealth in the Soviet Union. He also called for a coordinated response by the United States and the other industrialized nations to shore up the economy of the commonwealth by stabilizing the ruble.
"The President is not moving boldly enough," Mr. Kerrey said.
The candidates also found fault with Mr. Bush's handling of Japan.
Mr. Tsongas said that when the President traveled to Japan next month he should tell the Japanese that the cold war was over and that "the time for fair trade is here." Mr. Tsongas said Mr. Bush should tell the Japanese, "It's time to open up your trade doors to our products."
Governor Clinton said Japan was now at least as rich as the United States and should bear a bigger share of responsibility for its own defense.
"We're going to insist on fair trade," Mr. Clinton vowed. But the Arkansas Governor said also that "we ought to learn something from the Japanese," and said the United States had stubbornly refused to develop the social policies and human resources needed to compete effectively with Japan.
 
Aiming at Trade Deficit
 Senator Harkin noted that although the United States was a creditor nation when President Ronald Reagan was inaugurated the country now had a trade deficit. "I would tell the Japanese that in my term as President we are going to reduce that trade deficit to zero," he said.
Asked about a proposed free-trade agreement with Mexico, Governor Wilder said he would strive to protect American jobs. Businesses "have moved out of Virginia to Mexico, where labor is cheap," he said.
Senator Harkin asserted that the Bush Administration was "taking jobs from this country, lowering our living standards and the living standards of people in Latin America." He urged that the United States insist that Mexican workers have health care, social security and other benefits enjoyed by American workers.
Mr. Clinton took issue with the President's decision to provide most-favored-nation trading status to China.
"He let his friendships in China obscure what those kids did in Tiananmen Square," the Governor said.
Mr. Brown accused the Republicans of repeatedly lying both about Administration policies in the Middle East and arms shipments to Iran.
"We're not getting the truth," he said. Asked to elaborate, he said, "I'm accusing them of not really talking straight to the American people."
Driven by Mr. Brown, much of the debate centered around the system of financing political campaigns. Mr. Tsongas challenged the other candidates to make an immediate vow: "Everybody pledge tonight, no more PAC money after tonight."
Mr. Harkin replied: "That is about the phoniest argument I ever heard. You received over $7,000 from eight executives" of an electronics company.
On the issue of abortion, the arguments were mainly about whether the candidates would insist that judicial candidates embrace Roe v. Wade, the 1973 court decision that made abortion a constitutional right.
Senator Harkin said he "would not appoint any Supreme Court nominee that wanted to overturn Roe v. Wade, period." Governor Clinton said that the Roe precedent was right and that if it was overturned there should be Federal legislation to insure that women could choose to have an abortion. Senator Kerrey, saying he expected the Court to overturn Roe v. Wade, promised to introduce legislation that would preserve the legality of abortion.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: SOVIET DISARRAY;
RUSSIA ASKS BAKER FOR A RECOGNITION OF INDEPENDENCE

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 15

 BODY:
The Russian republic asked the United States today to recognize its independence and that of Byelorussia and Ukraine, a move that could force Washington to choose between President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the new commonwealth led by Boris N. Yeltsin.
The Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei Kozyrev, made the request to the visiting Secretary of State, James A. Baker 3d, saying recognition would help crystallize authority in the new commonwealth and prevent a slide toward further political disintegration. Mr. Baker said the United States would consider the request. 
 American recognition of Russia's independence would end any hopes Mr. Gorbachev might still have of holding together some remnant of the old union, with himself at the center.
 
Signals to Gorbachev
 With that prospect, some American officials today for the first time clearly signaled by words and deeds that they hoped that Mr. Gorbachev would either leave the stage or make an accommodation with the new commonwealth before they have no choice but to come out against him.
That was apparent in the fact that Mr. Baker, along with Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney, pointedly took issue today with remarks made by Mr. Gorbachev in an interview with Time magazine. Mr. Gorbachev had criticized a Baker assessment last week that the Soviet Union "as we know it" is finished.
While Mr. Baker was more reserved in his public remarks, Mr. Cheney declared in a television interview that Mr. Gorbachev was not recognizing reality. He added that if he did not do so soon, the United States should abandon its neutrality in the internal power struggle and come down on the side of the new commonwealth.
 
'Have to be Hard-Nosed'
 "We have to be very hard-nosed about our approach, and we have to recognize reality," Mr. Cheney said on the NBC News program "Meet the Press," adding:
"And reality is that that there has been a new commonwealth formed, that in forming that commonwealth, the republics, in effect, said 'The center is dead, the old Soviet Union is dead, and now we've got to get on with a new organization,' and we've got to deal with that new mechanism. Reality is now being shaped primarily by Boris Yeltsin and other leaders."
Mr. Kozyrev, the Russian Foreign Minister, said after meeting with Mr. Baker that he understood that the United States was in a delicate position and did not want to appear to be interfering in internal affairs.
Nevertheless, in a news conference with Mr. Baker after their two hours of talks in the Russian Foreign Ministry, Mr. Kozyrev said: "Basically we do ask now for full diplomatic recognition of independent states, those which created this new commonwealth. This will help crystallize authority, which stems from the people's vote in Ukraine, Russia and Byelorussia, and stop the further disintegration."
In the rush to sovereignty after the collapse of the Kremlin coup in August, Russia did not join most republics in formally declaring independence, but it did so in effect a week ago in declaring the formation of the commonwealth with Ukraine and Byelorussia. Since then, they have been joined by five Central Asian republics.
Mr. Baker, while reiterating his standard line about not wanting to interfere in the internal affairs of the former Soviet Union, said, "We will obviously be looking at the suggestion that has been made here, just as we are now looking at a similar request from the Ukraine."
The United States has already welcomed Ukraine's independence and said it will extend de jure recognition and open an embassy in Kiev after it is satisfied that the Ukraine government has met certain basic American principles. These include either destroying its nuclear weapons or putting them under a single central control, agreeing to respect minorities' rights, taking some responsibility for Soviet debt and agreeing that any border changes can come about only by negotiation.
Mr. Baker told the Russians that their adherence to those principles would also determine how the United States responds to their request.
 
Commonwealth in Progress
 American officials added that while their discussions today made clear that the tide here is overwhelmingly in favor of the new commonwealth, and not Mr. Gorbachev's union proposals, the whole commonwealth plan is still very much a work in progress, and that some of the most basic questions about how the member republics will relate to one another politically, economically and militarily still have not been worked out. This has been an important factor in American reluctance to openly embrace the idea up until now.
The Russian request for recognition came just a few hours after Mr. Baker landed in Moscow, carrying aboard his Air Force 707 medical supplies for hospitals in Minsk, the Byelorussian capital; Yerevan, the Armenian capital, and Moscow. Two other cargo jets, one American and the other Soviet, left Andrews Air Force Base in Washington shortly after he did with more medical supplies and food destined for other hard-hit Soviet cities and children's hospitals.
On the flight from Washington, the Secretary of State responded to Mr. Gorbachev criticism of Mr. Baker's declaration a week ago that "the Soviet Union as we know it" no longer exists.
In the Time interview, Mr. Gorbachev said: "Mr. Baker was overly hasty in saying, 'The Soviet Union no longer exists.' Things are in flux here. While we're still trying to figure things out, the U.S. seems to know everything already. I don't think that's loyalty, particularly toward those of us who favor partnership."
 
Long Support Cited
 Mr. Baker, briefing reporters at the start of his five-day trip, responded: "If it's true, that it was a criticism, then I would regret it, because I don't think anyone has been more supportive of President Gorbachev and indeed his administration and what they have done, than I have -- both privately and publicly -- in the counsels of the United States Government and otherwise. I have been outspoken in praising him and saying none of this would have happened but for one man, Mikhail Gorbachev. I greatly admire and respect him."
Although much of Mr. Baker's briefing was given on condition it not be attributed to him, he pointedly allowed those remarks to be attributed.
His disagreement with the Soviet President seemed to reflect not only irritation with Mr. Gorbachev's criticism of the Bush Administration -- which stuck with him long after many experts advised it otherwise -- but also a mounting awareness among American officials that Mr. Gorbachev's insistence on clinging to power may be now impeding the seemingly inevitable transition here from the old Soviet Union to a commonwealth.
It was noteworthy that Mr. Baker met first with Russia's Foreign Minister, and only then did he dine privately with the Soviet Government's Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, an old friend.
 
Meeting Yeltsin First
 Mr. Baker's first meeting Monday will be with Mr. Yeltsin in St. Catherine's Hall in the Kremlin -- the room where he always met in the past with Mr. Gorbachev. He meets with Mr. Gorbachev later, in a different room.
In Washington, in the last week President Bush has spoken to Mr. Yeltsin twice on the telephone, in what White House officials described as "substantive" policy conversations. In that time, Mr. Bush has spoken only once to Mr. Gorbachev to get his "assessment" of the situation.
Mr. Kozyrev hinted that Mr. Yeltsin's military aides for the Baker meeting would be a surprise. The Russian Foreign Minister seemed to be suggesting that the lineup would make it clear that the key elements of the Soviet Army and Strategic Rocket Forces, which oversee intercontinental ballistic missiles, were now firmly with Mr. Yeltsin.
Asked if he could offer fresh assurances that nuclear weapons in the former Soviet Union are under tight control, Mr. Kozyrev said: "Follow very closely tomorrow's composition of the Russian side of the negotiating table. This will be very interesting -- like the old days with the Politburo on Lenin's masoleum. Please take notice of this thing."
Mr. Yeltsin's aides are now confident that the Russian President has won the allegiance of Defense Minister Yegeny I. Shaposhnikov, commander of the union forces. 

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Mitterand Criticizes U.S.
 PARIS, Dec. 15 (Special to The New York Times) -- President Francois Mitterrand today criticized the Bush Administration's proposal to hold an international conference in Washington next month to coordinate humanitarian aid to the fragmenting Soviet Union.
In a television interview, Mr. Mitterrand said that the meeting, proposed last week by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, would be superfluous and that Western Europe was already providing large amounts of emergency food and other aid to the Soviet republics.
"European nations now give a lot more aid than the United States does," he said. "So President Bush's request all of a sudden to meet in Washington to coordinate these efforts seems to be rather superfluous."
He also criticized Mr. Bush for not responding to his proposal that the United States, France, Britain and the Soviet Union meet to discuss ways to insure nuclear security. 

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Report on Gorbachev
 MOSCOW, Dec. 15 (AP) -- In another sign of the dramatic ebb in Mr. Gorbachev's influence, Soviet and Russian television reported that Mr. Yeltsin had met with the General Shaposhnikov to discuss matters indlucing the selection of a new commander in chief - a job that is now held by Mr. Gorbachev.
 The meeting took place late Saturday but was reported only today. The two discussed most unresolved questions about the military's future in the commonwealth, including the nuclear arsenal, the Soviet and Russian television reports said.
 It said the leaders also discussed possible candidates of the commonwealth, but gave no names.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: Two Hospitals, Two Missions -- A Special Report.;
A Health Care Quandary Over Training of Doctors

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN

 BODY:
To administrators at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center, Dr. Salvatore J. Corso is a student and his patients are his textbooks.
"I need multiple injuries, high-speed injuries, car accidents, gunshot wounds," says Dr. Corso, who is near the end of a five-year residency in orthopedic surgery. His education will not be complete, he adds, if he only sees "bread and butter" cases like "an 8-year-old with a thigh fracture." 
 To administrators at Queens Hospital Center, however, Dr. Corso is, above all, an employee. They are sympathetic to his training needs, but there are patients to be seen. Thousands of patients. And many are 8-year-olds with broken legs.
 
Troubled Marriage
 This dual view of Dr. Corso is the reason Long Island Jewish, a private hospital determined to be a major academic institution, announced this month that it would end its 26-year-old agreement to provide doctors to Queens Hospital Center, a public hospital struggling to meet its patients' basic needs.
In many ways, the troubled marriage and messy divorce of Long Island Jewish and Queens Hospital is a very specific tale. Of the 11 contracts between New York City's public hospitals and the private institutions paid to staff them, the one severed two weeks ago has long been the most troubled.
But the story of these two Queens hospitals is in many ways the story of the health care system in New York, where lack of money creates new problems and makes old ones bigger. Hospitals reflect the worst of a city, and as New York has changed over the decades so have its hospitals. The crises that Long Island Jewish find impassable are found throughout New York: AIDS, homelessness, poverty, drugs, violence and budgets grossly inadequate to the task.
And so the questions Queens Hospital and Long Island Jewish are asking each other are being asked all over New York: How can doctors be found to work in the dismay and violence of many city hospitals? What responsibility does the medical profession have for providing care despite those conditions? How can hospitals reconcile the often clashing missions of training doctors and caring for patients?
"We train doctors who go on to take care of patients and to train other doctors," said Dr. Robert K. Match, president of Long Island Jewish. "We can't continue to do that there."
Arnoline Jones, executive director of Queens Hospital, said: "Number one, I have to worry about delivering patient care. Number two, I worry about training doctors. I can't always get to number two."
The affiliation contracts, which have been under renegotiation in recent months, began in the mid 1960's. Curiously, they resulted from an economic climate that is being likened to this one. Hard times had crippled the city's health-care budget and hospitals could not find good doctors, or, often, any doctors, to staff them. The result was a relationship between New York City's public and private hospitals that is unlike any other in the country: Private institutions -- medical schools, medical corporations and, in the case of Long Island Jewish, other medical centers -- are paid to staff public hospitals.
Long Island Jewish received $40 million last year to do that from the Health and Hospitals Corporation, which runs the city's public hospitals. The money is to hire medical residents, who provide almost all the day-to-day medical care, and the senior doctors, who supervise them. The corporation pays more than $400 million a year for its staffing contracts.
In theory, each side gains. The doctors working in the public hospitals are technically private employees, and the prestige and security of those jobs means they can be filled by better doctors than the public hospitals might be able to recruit on their own. In turn, the medical residents being trained at the private institutions receive broader experience than they might otherwise have.
One medical school administrator summed up the contracts this way: "They need our doctors. We need their patients."
But in recent years that equation has become unbalanced, and nowhere are the strains more evident than at Queens Hospital and Long Island Jewish.
 
Depression Buildings Look It
 Queens Hospital has needed repair for decades but, Long Island Jewish officials say, the crumbling has accelerated in the last five years. Most of the 14 buildings on the 20-acre Jamaica campus were built during the Depression. They are drab, cramped, tired places, where every floor feels somewhat like a basement.
The 240,000 patients seen in the hospital's 80 clinics every year are more than the hospital can handle, Dr. Match said. The wait for a clinic appointment, four to six weeks a year ago, is now two to three months.
Construction of a $493 million, 589-bed building is scheduled to begin next fall and be completed in 1994. Until then, short-term renovation is under way. More than $25 million has been spent on improvements over the last five years, Mrs. Jones said, ranging from $48,000 for a walk-in refrigerator for medication to $7 million for a new surgical operating room.
Queens Hospital officials concede that the money has merely dented the problem. On one medical ward, for instance, beds are placed along an open corridor with no walls or doors for privacy. Recently, $100,000 was spent to replace the floors and put curtains between the patients.
"It's not great but at least it's not a nightmare," said Richard Langfelder, deputy executive director of operations at Queens Hospital.
A few floors away, in a unit that felt like a sauna because the thermostats were on the blink, Robert Rossdale, senior associate director of support services, pointed with some pride to the new television sets that had finally been bought to break the monotony for recuperating surgical patients. "We do what we can," he said. "It's an old hospital."
 
The Doctors
Trying to Stem White-Coat Flight
 It is also, said Dr. Match and others at Long Island Jewish, an inadequately staffed hospital. Last year for the fifth year in a row, Dr. Match said, the effective budget for staff salaries was reduced, by 3.85 percent. Last year alone, he said, 46 staff positions were eliminated. Of those, 25 were doctors and the rest were support staff like technicians, respiratory therapists and records clerks.
As a result, he said, doctors and residents are spending time on tasks that should be done by someone else, like digging through charts for X-rays and moving patients from one room to another. Earlier this year, he said, the pediatric residents at Queens Hospital complained they were being used improperly.
Mrs. Jones and others who speak for Queens Hospital argue that it is precisely because things are so bad that Long Island Jewish has an obligation to extend its contract.
"If everything was perfect we wouldn't need them the way we do," Mr. Langfelder said. Passing a group of children playing on the floor of a waiting area he shook his head and said, "What is L.I.J. thinking?"
Mrs. Jones added: "I thought they took an oath. I thought that oath went beyond any contract."
Mrs. Jones said Queens Hospital was doing its best to make things easier for the doctors. A computer system was recently installed that allows any patient's laboratory results to be found almost instantly. An "IV team" of nurses and technicians was established to insert intravenous lines so doctors do not have to.
But Dr. Match says the improvements are not enough. The poor conditions at Queens Hospital make it difficult to find doctors to work there, he said in his office five miles away at Long Island Jewish, which was built between 1954 and 1988.
 
Doctors Avoid New York City
 The goal of Long Island Jewish, he said, "is not to be a community hospital."
"Our goal is to be the best," he said. "The best occurs in an environment where teaching and learning and research can take place."
To be the "best," he said, requires the best educated residents and the best senior doctors to teach them.
Doctors, he said, do not want to work at Queens Hospital. In fact, doctors do not want to work at most New York City hospitals. A study published by The Journal of the American Medical Association last month found that while the number of residency slots in New York increased by 4 percent, the number of young doctors choosing to train in New York decreased by 28 percent, a drop the study attributed mostly to the omnipresence of AIDS but also variously to budget cuts, nursing shortages, sicker patients, addicts, "family considerations" and "life style factors."
This white-coat flight from the city is a problem for all the public hospitals. But it has several added wrinkles for Long Island Jewish.
One is that residents who choose city hospitals seem to be drawn to the prestige and academic challenge of the medical schools affiliated with them. But Long Island Jewish is the only affiliated hospital without a medical school.
Long Island Jewish straddles the border with Nassau County, hence its name. If the center's residents were not required to spend much of their time at Queens Hospital, then Long Island Jewish, with its courtyards and brand-new birthing rooms, would provide what today's doctors say they are looking for.
For the last five years, Dr. Match said, Long Island Jewish has had trouble filling its internal medicine residency, one of the most critical of the 24 residencies at Queens Hospital.
 
'Queens Track' Fills Gap
 Long Island Jewish sent questionnaires to medical students who took jobs elsewhere. Those questionnaires show, Dr. Match said, that the requirement that 40 percent of a resident's first year be spent at Queens Hospital was a major reason why the young doctors rejected the program.
In response, Long Island Jewish created what it calls the Queens track for its internal medicine residents three years ago. The regular Long Island Jewish residents in internal medicine now spend much less time at Queens. During the first year of residency, , the rotation at Queens Hospital has been reduced to two months from five months.
To fill the gaps left by this reduction, Long Island Jewish hired 30 residents in internal medicine who work only at Queens Hospital. Most, Dr. Match said, are graduates of foreign medical schools, "some of whom are very good, some of whom are not."
Mrs. Jones said Queens Hospital was willing to accept the "Queens track." Although these doctors require closer supervision, she said, at least they are available. One reason Long Island Jewish ended its contract with Queens, however, was a concern that the dual system might be rejected by the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education, which accredits residency programs. The council is scheduled to review the program early next year.
Without the dual program, Dr. Match said, Long Island Jewish would be unable to offer an internal medicine residency at either hospital.
 
The Choices
Losing a Partner Or Accreditation
 He says he is equally concerned that the Long Island Jewish orthopedic residency will lose its accreditation. Queens Hospital has applied for and been denied designation as a Level One trauma center. Such trauma centers receive the most serious injury cases, exactly the type Dr. Corso and his colleagues need to see to be certified as orthopedic surgeons.
"These are the kind of patients you want to get comfortable with because if you can handle that you can handle anything," said Dr. Corso, who is 32 years old and in the last year of his five-year residency.
Throughout Dr. Corso's residency, ambulances carrying severe trauma cases have bypassed Queens Hospital for Jamaica or Elmhurst hospitals, both of which are designated as Level One trauma centers. "In my entire time at Queens I never saw a multiple injury patient," he said.
In September, Dr. Richard Lasking, then chairman of the Long Island Jewish orthopedics department, wrote to Dr. Match predicting that the orthopedics program would be "in jeopardy" when it is reviewed next year. A short time later, Dr. Match said, he learned to his relief that Jamaica Hospital, which is private, was planning to begin an orthopedics residency program.
A result was a plan by Long Island Jewish to transfer all orthopedics patients from Queens Hospital to Elmhurst, a public hospital with extra beds. Long Island Jewish residents would then go to Jamaica Hospital, which has a trauma center. Queens Hospital would lose its orthopedics residents, but the Long Island Jewish program would be stronger.
When the Health and Hospitals Corporation was informed, they filed suit in State Supreme Court in Queens to halt the departure of the orthopedics residents from Queens Hospital.
The court ruled that Long Island Jewish's contract with the corporation forbid the orthopedics residents to leave Queens Hospital. After many meetings between the two hospitals, a compromise was reached. Long Island Jewish residents now rotate through Long Island Jewish, Queens Hospital and Jamaica Hospital.
 
Hospital's Survival Pledged
 In the month he has spent at Jamaica, Dr. Corso said he has "finally seen quite a few" multiple injury patients.
The corporation has said it will help Queens Hospital reapply for designation as a trauma center. The H.H.C. has not decided exactly how it will give Queens Hospital the doctors it needs, but it will not allow the hospital to close, said Steven J. Matthews, a spokesman for the corporation. Among the options, he said, are to eliminate the residency program and hire only senior doctors, or to create a private corporation to run the residency program at Queens.
Despite this angry prologue, the decision by Long Island Jewish not to renew its contract shocked officials at Queens Hospital and the corporation. Dr. Dumpson called it "self-serving" and "an abandonment of its commitment to the poor."
Dr. Match responded: "We're not abandoning anybody. What we're saying is we can no longer meet our responsibilities under the contract."

HEADLINE: 471 Feared Dead as Red Sea Ferry Sinks

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CAIRO, Dec. 15

 BODY:
A ferry carrying 649 people sank in the Red Sea after it was swept up by 10-foot waves and thrown against a reef, the police said today. As many as 471 people, many returning from a religious pilgrimage, were believed to have drowned.
Egypt's director of port security, Hassan al-Aghouri, said 178 people, some of whom spent nearly 12 hours in shark-infested waters, had been rescued by nightfall from off the port of Safaga. Two United States helicopters that were in the region as part of a force maintaining an economic embargo against Iraq joined in the rescue effort. 
 The deputy director of port security, Brig. Abdel-Karim el-Gazzar, said that all but 10 of the passengers were Egyptians, and that most had been returning from visits to Muslim holy places in Saudi Arabia when the ferry sank about midnight Saturday six miles off Safaga, which is 293 miles southeast of Cairo.
He said the foreign passengers were six Filipinos, two Malaysians, one Zairian and one Sudanese. Another Sudanese was in the 71-member crew, he said.
 
Owned by Egyptian Company
 Mr. Aghouri identified the ferry as the Egyptian-registered Salem Express, owned by the Egyptian Samatour Shipping Company, based in Alexandria.
The 1,105-ton ship was sailing from Jidda, Saudi Arabia, to Safaga when it was tossed about by 10-foot waves whipped by 40-mile-an-hour winds. The vessel rammed coral reefs near the Egyptian harbor and went down immediately, Mr. Aghouri said.
He said rescue teams had been unable to reach the area until dawn today because of heavy storms and high seas.
Relief crews set up tents in Safaga as reception centers for survivors, most of whom were brought in by military helicopter. Brigadier Gazzar said 118 of the survivors were hospitalized.
The American and Australian navies sent helicopters to help Egyptian sailors in the search-and-rescue operation.
 
No Distress Signal Heard
 Lieut. Rob Raine, a Navy spokesman, said American warships had not picked up a distress signal from the Salem Express, which indicated that the crew had not used the correct emergency channel or that the ferry had been out of the ships' radio range.
Some survivors said crewmembers had abandoned ship without doing enough to help. One passenger, Abdel-Aati Hassan, said crewmembers had told people to move to one side of the listing ferry to keep it afloat, then abandoned ship.
"They wore life preservers and left us and even pushed us aside to escape," Mr. Hassan said from his bed at Safaga Central Hospital. "They left us with women and kids, who died."
Brigadier Gazzar said 292 of the ferry's passengers were Egyptians returning home from performing umrah, a pilgrimage for Muslims visiting the holy city of Mecca outside the regular pilgrimage season.
The other Egyptian passengers were workers in Saudi Arabia, coming home either for a holiday because their contracts had ended or because they were being deported by the Saudis, he said.
The trip between Jidda and Safaga takes about 36 hours.
The sinking was the second major boat accident on Egypt's Red Sea coast this year. In April, 24 people died when an overloaded motor launch sank at Hurghada, north of Safaga.

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
A Forum That All but Invites the Usual Responses

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
After years of critics' laments about the sound bites that dominate a political campaign, last night's gathering of six Democrats who want to be President turned out to be more of the same.
The format compelled it. Ninety minutes for six men to talk about all manner of problems, one minute at a time, is not an invitation to reflection. What it does invite are phrases that seem to have worked before. 
 Tom Brokaw, presiding for NBC, attempted to press a point now and then only to find that the rules made evasion easy. He told Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa that NBC had added up the cost of social programs he was proposing and found that it came to several times more than the savings he was recommending. Figures were bandied about but Mr. Brokaw had to turn to another candidate and another subject. What was a viewer to make of it?
Seated at an oval table like blue-suited preppies at a seminar, the candidates offered a chorus of concern for the middle-class. There were differences -- one or two favored a tax cut, one or two did not -- but the main effort of each of these non-household names was to establish a television persona.
So viewers heard more than once from Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska that he had been wounded in Vietnam. Gov. Douglas L. Wilder called their attention to the fact that he is black. Senator Harkin let it be known that his mother was an immigrant. He also produced a $1 bill from an inside pocket to make a point about the inadequacy of a tax cut. Somebody must have told him that would fly on television.
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas seemed to be positioning himself a bit to the right of the group, but it was Paul E. Tsongas, a former senator from Massachusetts, who seemed to have his mind most focused on the issues. The camera played favorites, however, and Mr. Tsongas was not a natural.
In any gathering there has to be one group jester. Last night brought Edmund G. Brown Jr., a former governor of California. He attacked the "context of illusions," and charged that that his fellow Democrats were all in thrall to wealthy contributors. "Are you saying I'm bought and paid for?" Senator Kerrey demanded in the most dramatic encounter of the evening, which is a comment on the general quality of the debate. Mr. Brown politely avoided saying yes. And despite the injunction of Mr. Brokaw he twice announced the 800 number to which viewers could call in their modest contributions.
With six more debates to come, there is hope for something more solid, but that would mean more time on an issue. For example, Senator Kerrey alluded repeatedly to his health plan. That is surely worth a third of a 90-minute program. And so were most of the other issues raced through, from economic growth to relations with the Soviet Union to affirmative action and even Mr. Brown's favorite subject of campaign contributions.
Among the questions that can be skipped areones like why are you running and who will your vice president be? And not allowing a final word would save time and spare the viewer. Gov. Clinton said he wanted to be "an agent of change." Senator Kerrey said "as one who fought in the war in Vietnam . . ." Gov. Wilder told of being "huddled with my buddies in Korea."
The debates have begun. Maybe now they can get serious.

HEADLINE: Dual Role Is Planned for Bush's New Chief of Staff

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
White House workers anxious about the arrival of a new chief of staff on Monday received a discomfiting holiday greeting last week: a memorandum from the Office of Personnel Management outlining the proper procedure for resigning one's job.
In fact, Samuel K. Skinner, who succeeds the departing John H. Sununu, has taken pains to allay fears that he plans any White House bloodletting, and personnel officials hastily insisted that the memorandum had been sent in error. 
 As Mr. Sununu's tenure nears its end, Mr. Skinner seems unlikely to salvage much more of its legacy than the employees and the furniture -- most of it, that is, because Mr. Sununu is taking his Cabinet chair with him.
Instead, he seems likely to set about remaking his predecessor's hobbled domestic-policy operations and meshing them with the President's re-election effort. Mr. Sununu aspired to that dual role, but it was denied him by the President's political aides and by public opinion.
In interviews over the last week, White House officials and others who are following the transition offered more specific ideas of what Mr. Skinner is likely to do over the next few months. They said that his most urgent priority was to work out a clear picture of White House plans for the economy. In that regard, President Bush's own statements have been contradictory and he has been attacked on the subject by Democratic Presidential aspirants as well as by business interests.
The officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Mr. Skinner planned to use his command of Mr. Bush's office and travel schedules to expose him to experts who are neither politicians nor Washington consultants.
Mr. Skinner also will draw upon a close relationship with officials in the President's campaign organization to coordinate White House policy decisions with campaign strategy.
Mr. Skinner's status as a coordinator of domestic and political strategy raises new questions about the future duties of other top White House advisers, especially two senior aides: Richard G. Darman, the budget director, and Roger Porter, chief of the domestic-policy staff.
Officials said Mr. Darman's influence on domestic policy had expanded in recent months as Mr. Sununu's difficulties mounted. While Mr. Darman is widely regarded as a fiscal mastermind, he has few political credentials to guarantee him similar influence over domestic policy in the campaign.
Mr. Porter's office, which is central to the domestic policy-making process, is regarded by some officials as a natural target for a shakeup once Mr. Skinner is settled into his job.
But Mr. Skinner, who has not spoken on the subject, appears unlikely to make sweeping changes in Mr. Sununu's staff if only because an infusion of new and unschooled aides could hamper the ability to make quick and adept decisions in the heat of a campaign.
 
Thawing Out Relationships
 "The staff was not a problem," one official said. "The action-forcing event that got Sununu out was the campaign, which had been frozen for months" because of the corrosive relationship between Mr. Bush's political strategists and Mr. Sununu.
Since being named on Dec. 3 to succeed Mr. Sununu, Mr. Skinner has remained largely in the background and has said little in public about his plans. He has frequently talked in private with Mr. Bush's two chief re-election officials, Frederic V. Malek and Robert M. Teeter, while having informal chats with White House staff members about office operations.
Mr. Skinner is a longtime friend of Mr. Teeter, a Detroit poll taker and political strategist who was an architect of the electoral triumphs of Mr. Bush and his predecessor, Ronald Reagan. Mr. Skinner helped run Mr. Bush's primary campaign in Illinois in 1980 and managed his primary and general election campaigns there in 1988. Re-election strategists say they expect to make most significant decisions in concert with him, officials said.
Mr. Skinner's role is further elevated, one official said, because Mr. Bush's re-election staff is not run by a single person who makes most campaign decisions, as James A. Baker 3d did in Mr. Bush's 1988 race.
"For an incumbent President, the chief of staff's role is always going to be important in a campaign," the official said. "You can have someone in charge of fund raising and logistics and the rest, but for the campaign, two things are really important: Where does Bush go, and what does he say? And the chief of staff almost invariably controls those two questions."
Inside the White House, Mr. Skinner so far has kept a low profile out of deference to Mr. Sununu and also because he hopes to avoid the disruptions that major personnel shifts might cause, officials said.
In an interview last week, Mr. Skinner said he planned to adjust the White House staff and not to rebuild it from scratch. "Obviously, I'll bring in some" new staff members, he said, but "a lot of good work has been done in the White House. This is an opportunity to tune the organization and hunker down for what's going to be a very tough campaign."
 
Getting Another Opinion
 Mr. Skinner nevertheless plans an unusual review of White House operations and staffing by an outsider that could lead to far-reaching changes. It will be conducted by a New York businessman and old friend, Eugene R. Croisant, who has helped Mr. Skinner to hire staff members and to organize offices in Illinois state government and at the Transportation Department.
Mr. Croisant, an executive vice president at RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation, will take a two-month leave from his job on Monday. Officials said he carried a mandate to make recommendations about White House operations, including paper flow, the lines of decision-making authority and the abilities and effectiveness of the people who make decisions.
An Administration official said Mr. Croisant (usually pronounced KROY-sant) would look into management issues like "spans of control, the information flow between units in the White House, bottlenecks and voids -- what's dropping through the cracks." It is not clear how deeply involved he will become in hiring and firing at the White House, where all jobs are political and where friendships and loyalty are, if anything, more of an ingredient for success than in private business.
"The goal here is not to replace people, but to get the place functioning efficiently," one official said. "When you replace people, you lose continuity; you lose time because people have to come back up the learning curve."
Nevertheless, that official said, "Sam is the kind of guy who, if he senses a weakness in any of the staff areas, will move on it. So there might be some changes."
