HEADLINE: Varied Issues Delay U.S. Nominees' Confirmation

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
When the Senate adjourned last month until January, more than 150 of President Bush's nominees to various executive and judiciary positions were still awaiting confirmation, and an impatient White House complained about the slow pace of the confirmation process.
Some of the delays are merely logistical: it can take up to six weeks just to conduct the required background checks for a nominee. But some nominations, especially to judicial, foreign and economic positions, become entangled in ideological feuds or policy debates that can drag on for months. 
 Among the appointments causing the most difficulty are those to the judiciary. Distracted by the nomination of Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court this fall, the Senate Judiciary Committee had 54 nominations to consider in the fall session, only 17 of which it voted on.
 
Bush Urged Speedup
 About 50 of the 150 nominees pending have been approved by the Senate Judiciary and other committees and are awaiting a vote by the full Senate.
After the Thomas hearings, Mr. Bush urged a speedup in the confirmation process, complaining that the Senate was crippling his Administration by holding up the confirmation of several important nominees. A White House spokeswoman, Judy Smith, declined to comment on any specific vacancies.
In a speech to Federal employees in October, Mr. Bush recommended that the time between a nomination and confirmation be shortened to six weeks, from a current average of 12 weeks.
But a Senate Foreign Relations Committee aide said the average time between a nomination to the committee and a Senate vote was 60 days, 30 of which were taken up by investigations and getting the nominee to fill out the necessary papers.
 
'Usually a Reason' for Delay
 Senator Claiborne Pell, the Rhode Island Democrat who heads the Foreign Relations Committee, said that on average it took much longer than 30 days for a nomination to be processed through the executive branch.
"The Committee generally acts quickly to approve nominations, and when it does not there is usually a reason," he said. "Sometimes documents are slow in arriving from the executive branch, and when they get here are incomplete. Sometimes senators want assurances on a policy point in dispute."
Political concerns delayed several nominations to prominent posts that were vacant for months. The Administration, for instance, submitted the nomination of William C. Harrop as Ambassador to Israel to the Foreign Relations Committee on July 31, and he was not confirmed by the full Senate until Nov. 20.
In this case, however, it was the Administration that sought the delay. Committee staff members said Mr. Harrop's confirmation was held up because the State Department feared that the hearings, which coincided with the Senate's debate in September on the issue of housing loan guarantees for Israel, would become a forum for debating Israel's refusal to curtail settlements in territories it has occupied since the 1967 Mideast war.
 
White House Blamed for Delays
 Some members of Congress complain that the Administration itself has delayed sending nominations to Capitol Hill, largely for bureaucratic reasons. They point to the case of Susan M. Phillips, a governor of the Federal Reserve Board, whose name the White House sent to the Senate on Sept. 27, nine months after the departure of the governor she replaced.
Because of the Senate's procedures, a single Senator can stall a nomination. In September, Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat of California, put the brakes on two top State Department nominations until the department agreed to make public classified diplomatic cables on April Glaspie, the former United States Ambassador to Iraq.
The two nominees, Edward P. Djerejian as Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, and Thomas M. T. Niles as Assistant Secretary of State for European and Canadian Affairs, were confirmed only after a compromise had been reached for Ms. Glaspie to testify before the committee in mid-November, Mr. Djerejian on Sept. 25 and Mr. Niles on Oct. 1.
While the White House has complained that large numbers of judicial vacancies were slowing down the courts, some Senators countered that the Administration had not nominated judges expeditiously. A Senate Judiciary staff member said the Administration had submitted only 36 nominees by August, one of whom was Justice Thomas, for more than 100 positions that had been vacant since last year.
Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Delaware Democrat who heads the Judiciary Committee, complained at a Nov. 21 hearing: "We are at a point where every Federal judge, every law person in this country is talking about the need to expedite the administration of justice. The administration of justice is bogging down because of the White House."
One of the areas most affected is the Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York, which serves Manhattan, the Bronx and Westchester County. Seven of the 27 judgeships in this district are vacant. Three of the seven vacancies have not been filled for more than 18 months and for two of these there are no nominees.
 
Tremendous Burden
 "This has been tremendously burdensome," said Charles L. Brieant, the Chief Judge of the Southern District.
In the aftermath of the hearings on Justice Thomas, Mr. Bush met with Senate leaders of both parties to talk about speeding up the process, and a Senate task force was formed to study improvements.
Senator Wendell H. Ford, the Kentucky Democrat who is chairman of the Rules Committee and who will head the task force, said most of the problems with the process result from the failure of Mr. Bush and the Senate to cooperate on nominees. "Hopefully, we will return to a process that focuses on filling positions with competent individuals of unquestioned fitness to serve," Mr. Ford said.

Stunned by the growth of products making bold claims for environmental purity -- from "nuclear free" light bulbs and "environmentally safe" socks to botanically correct shampoos -- consumer advocates have begun to insist that words like "recycled" and "biodegradable" have meanings people can understand. HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: PRESS;
News or Post: Which Will Fail First?

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
Can The Daily News emerge from bankruptcy and survive? And if The News does survive, can The New York Post continue to publish?
Experts in the newspaper industry seem all but unanimous: the answer to each question is probably no. 
 Bear in mind that the experts have been predicting the death of The Daily News for a decade, and that The Post has topped the most-likely-newspaper-to-die list since the 1930's. The will to live at both papers is stunning.
But also remember that in the last year the second-ranked newspapers in Dallas; San Diego; Little Rock, Ark.; Knoxville, Tenn.; Charleston, S.C., and Richmond, Roanoke and Newport News Va., announced that they would cease publication.
 
Waiting on The News
 Clearly, it can happen, despite the defiant faith among News and Post employees that they, surely, could not have come so far and endured so much only to falter now.
Everything seems to depend upon The Daily News, which sought bankruptcy protection from its creditors 10 days ago as the Maxwell empire went into free fall. If The News ceases publication, The Post would probably thrive, at least for a time.
But The Post's owner, Peter S. Kalikow, filed for personal bankruptcy in August. While he says he will start a Sunday paper if The Daily News closes, anything he does will be subject to review by his bankers.
Should The Daily News find a savior who would invest in new presses, a lot of The Post's advertising could gravitate to The News, and The Post could slip into unprofitability, which would mean its death.
A third possibility is that both The Daily News and The Post could continue to plod precariously along on the edge of insolvency. So far, their existence has kept New York Newsday from making a profit, although Newsday, the Long Island parent newspaper, is profitable.
Maintaining the current status quo, however, seems unlikely. The Daily News is without question on the critical list.
"The News is probably a dead duck," said John Morton, a newspaper analyst at the brokerage firm of Lynch, Jones & Ryan in Washington. He views New York City as an aberration in that it has four daily papers, including The New York Times. No other American city has more than two dailies, and most have one.
Still, The Daily News has some reason for hope.
Since Robert Maxwell bought the paper in March, ending a long strike, The Daily News has demonstrated that it commands a loyalty among its readers, who have returned to the paper by the hundreds of thousands.
Advertisers want The Daily News to carry on because tabloid competition keeps ad rates low. New York Newsday has already declared it will immediately raise its ad rates if The News goes under. So advertisers have an incentive to help keep The News alive.
The Daily News seems to be within striking range of bringing its day-to-day revenues and expenses into balance, a move that will buy some time to make the big cost cuts needed if the paper is to become significantly profitable, and hence able to attract an investor who will buy new presses and give the paper a secure future.
James M. Lewis, an expert in bankruptcy law at McGuire, Woods, Battle & Boothe in Washington, said large businesses like The Daily News had a better chance of emerging from Chapter 11 bankruptcy than smaller companies. And bankruptcy gives The News advantages, including the ability to walk away from real estate and equipment lease, thus cutting costs significantly.
The Daily News is also a commodity that immediately makes its owner famous and powerful; that the owner is already rich goes without saying. Few acquisitions offer so much in prestige and instant celebrity, which could tip the balance in a buyer's mind, providing the paper's business prospects are at least mediocre.
Finally, and probably most importantly, it is life or death for The Daily News. The interests of both management and labor lie in doing whatever is necessary to keep it alive.
But there is also a negative side to the argument.
The Daily News is trying to rescue itself in the middle of a recession and a terrible environment for newspaper advertising in New York. In addition, January and February are usually poor months for newspaper advertising and promise to be worse than usual this year.
Even if The Daily News's advertisers remain loyal and buy ads, the paper may have trouble getting paid because it is in bankruptcy.
This means that the paper's revenues may dip well below what is projected, creating even more pressure to cut costs.
While The Daily News's union leaders have said that they will do whatever is necessary to save the paper, they have also said they think unions have sacrificed enough already.
Kevin Maxwell, the paper's publisher, has said The Daily News would have to earn about $40 million in annual profit to justify the $150 million for capital improvements he says are needed to save it. Assuming the paper is losing money at an annual rate of $25 million, which is probably conservative, this means $65 million in cost reductions.
Would the paper's unions make the radical concessions that such cuts would require, even in exchange for an equity stake in the paper?
While logic might say that saving some jobs, perhaps at reduced pay, is better than having no jobs at no pay, it is not that simple.
When the unions agreed in March to reduce the paper's work force by 800 jobs so that Robert Maxwell would buy The Daily News, there was $30 million available for buyouts. The News has no such pot of cash now, and it is difficult to imagine unions agreeing to waive severance.
In addition, a new owner of The Daily News could easily want changes in work rules that would be so contrary to the world the unions have known that they might rather see the paper die.
And finally, the sinking Maxwell empire in Britain may suck The Daily News under, no matter what efforts are made to save it.

HEADLINE: Consumer Optimism Improves a Bit

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Consumer spirits, which tumbled to recession levels in November, did not slip further in December and may even have improved marginally, according to the University of Michigan Survey of Consumer Sentiment.
"The consumer is pretty depressed but not yet catatonic," Robert A. Brusca, chief economist at Nikko Securities, said Friday after the survey was released. 
 Taken together with other data released Friday on retail sales and jobless claims, the report, which is preliminary and was released only to subscribers, portrayed the economy as stalled but not falling off a cliff.
"The November collapse in confidence was exaggerated," said Roger Brinner, chief economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill.
 
Return to the February Level
 The University of Michigan's index edged up to 70.4 this month, from its November level of 69.1, subscribers to the survey said.
The December level, based on responses collected in the first half of the month, is the same as February's, when confidence had started to move up from its low after the August 1990 invasion of Kuwait. In October of last year, two months after the invasion, the index stood at 63.9.
The monthly University of Michigan survey, widely watched, is included in the Commerce Department's monthly index of leading indicators.
In the most recent polling, consumers were marginally less pessimistic about the current and future conditions of their personal finances, as well as about the economy. But they were also slightly less inclined than in November to think that now was a good time to splurge on expensive items like appliances or cars; this subindex on buying conditions edged down to 118, from 119 in November.
Economists and investors track the confidence measure closely for clues to consumer spending. Adrian Throop, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco who has studied how well the University of Michigan tracks actual buying, says the survey is a fairly good guide to current spending on big-ticket items like appliances, as well as to future home buying.
Consumer sentiment has swung wildly in the last year, turning euphoric immediately after the American victory in the Persian Gulf, bobbling in a narrow range from April to September and plunging in October and November.
Consumers remain gloomy about job prospects. Nearly half expect unemployment to head higher in the next 12 months, and almost as many expect it to stay the same.
"People are seeing jobs eliminated that they don't think will come back," Mr. Brusca said. "They feel more risk, so they are saving more and spending less."
On the other hand, the survey shows that consumers are attuned to good news on interest rates and inflation.
For the fifth consecutive month, the majority of consumers said interest rates would fall further. And they expected prices to rise just 4 percent in the next year, not the 4.6 percent they had predicted a month earlier.
While economists and investors could draw comfort, if slight, from the survey, the same cannot be said for the White House or Congress. Only a handful of consumers, 4 percent of those surveyed, approved of the way Washington was handling economic matters -- the worst showing since the depths of the 1981-82 recession.

HEADLINE: SOVIET DISARRAY;
U.S. Fears Spread of Soviet Nuclear Weapons

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
With the leadership of the Soviet military in doubt, American planning is increasingly focused on preventing the spread of Soviet nuclear weapons or expertise to the Middle East, North Korea or other developing nations that want atomic weapons, Administration officials said today.
"We've watched the situation very carefully and very closely, and up till now we've been convinced that the Soviets have been able to retain control over their systems," Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said in an interview on the NBC News program "Meet the Press." 
 But both Mr. Cheney and Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger said the breakdown of the Soviet Union raises genuine concern that countries like North Korea or Iraq might be able to acquire Soviet nuclear weapons or that scientists with expertise in assembling such weapons might sell their services to other countries. It is not clear how many such experts there are.
"Given the breakup of the Soviet Union, given the disintegration of their society, given the sad state of their economy, the only realistic thing for me to do as Secretary of Defense is to anticipate that one of the byproducts of the breakup of the Soviet Union will be a proliferation of nuclear capability," Mr. Cheney said.
 
Little Margin for Error
 He added, "If the Soviets do an excellent job at retaining control over their stockpile of nuclear weapons -- let's assume they've got 25,000 to 30,000; that's a ballpark figure -- and they are 99 percent successful, that would mean you could still have as many as 250 that they were not able to control."
Administration officials have been saying for some time that the question of who controls the formidable nuclear arsenal once commanded by the Kremlin is a central force behind American policy toward the disintegration of the Soviet Union. Today's comments by Mr. Cheney and Mr. Eagleburger, who appeared on the ABC News program "This Week," provided new details about the Administration's specific concerns and goals.
Mr. Eagleburger said that apart from trying to insure that nuclear weapons remain under a central, unified command and are not seized by individual republics, the United States wants to take advantage of the uncertainty in the Soviet military to get rid of as many of its nuclear weapons as possible.
Congress has authorized the Bush Administration to take $400 million out of the Pentagon budget to help the Soviet Union destroy short-range nuclear weapons.
"We have to move as fast as we can to help them destroy as much of their nuclear stockpile as we can, and we need to do what we can to make sure what is left is not sold on the open market and make sure their technical expertise doesn't migrate," Mr. Eagleburger said.

HEADLINE: OLD ANGOLAN FOES STRUGGLE TO UNITE

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LUBANGO, Angola

 BODY:
After battling for half his life against guerrilla rebels in Angola's civil war, Alindo Ferreira has joined forces with his longtime enemies to help restore peace to this southwest African nation.
"We are all Angolans, and now have to learn to work together," said the 33-year-old Government army major based in Lubango, capital of a southern province, Huila. 
 Alongside fighters from Jonas Savimbi's insurgent movement, the National Movement for the Total Independence of Angola, known by the Portuguese acronym Unita, Major Ferreira is now preparing for a new fight: to unify the warring factions into a national army.
 
'Two Very Different Groups'
 "The process sounds simple, but it is very complex," said Col. John Longman of Britain, one of a team of British, Portuguese and French advisers assisting the Angolan Government with the formation of the new army. "We are talking about two very different groups, a guerrilla army and a conventional one and the integration of the two."
Under the cease-fire signed on May 31 by President Jose Eduardo dos Santos and Mr. Savimbi, both sides and their weapons must be secured in 45 assembly points scattered throughout the country before the actual unification process can begin.
But the assembly process has dragged behind the schedule drafted in the peace agreement, which also calls for internationally monitored elections to be held next September. The peace accord, ending the 16-year civil war that broke out soon after Angola gained independence from Portugal in 1975, called for the demobilization of troops, verified by United Nations observers, by Aug. 1. But so far, only about 65 percent of the estimated forces have been counted in the assembly areas.
 
Food Shortages Cited
 While many people acknowledge the probable inflation of projected figures, they hold acute food shortages at the assembly points largely responsible for the low turnout.
"Now thousands of idle young men without food remain near arms in the assembly points," said Ramiro da Silva, the director of the World Food Program. "Without guaranteed food, they will form banditry groups," he added. Citing "critical" food shortages as threatening the peace process, the United Nations began a $27.3 million emergency appeal in October for the demobilizing troops.
The United States has committed about one-third of this target figure, and has begun to deliver emergency relief supplies in an effort to safeguard the peace. "We want the peace process to succeed with free and multiparty elections held in the country," said Philip Davis, an Air Force captain who is one of six American military officers serving as monitors of the peace agreement. He is administering the delivery of relief supplies.
In a change from the years when Washington supplied covert and open assistance for Mr. Savimbi's South African-aided Unita forces in their fight against Cuban- and Soviet-backed Government troops, the current aid is going to both camps. But in a continued show of support for Unita, Congress has earmarked $30 million to aid its transformation from a military movement into a political party.
But even when supplies are available, they do not always reach the assembly points, many of which are inaccessible by road.
"Our biggest problem is transportation," said Daniel Machado, a United Nations observer stationed in Lubango.
A shortage of vehicles, a ravaged road system, land mines and rain have meant a logistical nightmare.
While delays have set the unification timetable back, many people agree that the peace process does not face a serious risk of collapsing. And Angolans on both sides voice a desire not to return to the fighting, which claimed about half a million lives.
"Our points of view were very different; now they have converged around peace," said Padrino Pilartes, a guerrilla colonel. "No one here is interested in war anymore."

GRAPHIC: Map of Angola showing location of Lubango.

HEADLINE: The Old Increasingly Being Bilked By the People They Must Rely On

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER

 BODY:
Investigators, prosecutors and social service agency officials say there are signs that money and property are being stolen, by trickery and coercion, from America's elderly at a disturbing rate and that a large portion of the crimes are committed not by professional criminals but by neighbors, health aides, household workers and family members.
Financial exploitation of the elderly, they say, is likely to continue growing as the number of older Americans who are most vulnerable to it, the lonely and those in poor health, rises. The recession and drug abuse are cited by law enforcement officials as the major motivation behind the rise in such crimes. 
 "There has been an alarming increase and I am afraid it is fast becoming the crime of the 1990's," said Joanne B. Marlatt, program administrator of adult protection services for Colorado.
 
Parallels to Child Abuse
 Like child abuse, many crimes against the elderly are not reported because the victims are physically or mentally unable to summon help, according to interviews with dozens of police and agency officials in New York, New Jersey, Massachusetts, Florida, Arizona, Colorado, California, Minnesota and Wisconsin.
In addition, the experts say, many cases go unreported because of a reticence on the part of the victims to publicly accuse close relatives, much like the silence that often cloaks child abuse, leaving the elderly people ashamed as well as emotionally traumatized.
And even when the abuser is not a family member, investigators say, victims may remain silent, terrified that others will suspect they are unable to care for themselves and conclude they belong in a nursing home.
There are few statistics on the subject, said Dr. Karl Pillemer, assistant professor of human development and family studies at Cornell University and an authority on abuse of the elderly. And what information exists is widely distrusted by officials, who say they believe that more than 80 percent of such cases never come to light.
"However, we do have compelling evidence there is a dramatic increase in the number of cases being reported and that conditions for the material exploitation of older Americans are expected to keep growing," said Dr. Pillemer, who is the author of "Helping Elderly Victims: The Relativity of Elder Abuse" (Columbia University Press, 1989).
The majority of the nation's 31 million men and women who are 65 or older lead active and independent lives. But it stands to reason that when crimes against the infirm or ill among the elderly are committed by people they trust, it tends to make all in the age group feel less secure.
In one such case, in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., a live-in housekeeper "controlled" an 85-year-old man and his blind, bed-ridden wife, 83, and took $500,000 of their cash and property before their children, who lived in another state, became suspicious and went to the police.
In Manchester Township, N.J., a middle-aged nurse's aide confessed that personal money problems had driven her to steal nearly $14,000 over six months from the checking account of an elderly widow. "I can't say why I did this other than to say I was under a great deal of stress," the woman told the police.
There are even cases of the old stealing from the older. In Longmont, Colo., this year, the police charged a 68-year-old man with illegally taking $67,000 from his 85-year-old mother's bank account while she was in the hospital with pneumonia.
Adult children with alcohol or drug problems are among the most likely to be abusers. So are those who were neglected, or who perceive themselves as having been neglected, as children and who feel justified in settling old scores.
"The crimes against some old people by their children and even grandchildren amount to nothing more than a mugging," said Frank Reilly, a retired New York City police officer who now works in Florida as an investigator of abuse of the elderly.
Law enforcement and social agency investigators also say that some debt-ridden family members steal from their aging relatives what they rationalize "is rightfully theirs," fearing that their inheritence might be eaten up by medical or nursing bills.
 
Abuse Out Family
 Another major source of abuse is people who are hired to provide care in the home. By using threats that they will leave, forcing the elderly person into a nursing home, or by driving a wedge between the elderly person and family members, the workers can quickly exert great influence in a household, drain assets and then disappear.
It is common for helpers to be hired at low hourly pay, without background checks for criminal activity, and to be given access to an elderly person's checkbook to pay for household expenses, officials say. In-home care for the elderly by nonprofessionals is a rapidly growing industry almost free of regulation in most states, and laws are difficult to enforce even when they do exist.
In a confidential survey in 1989 of older Canadians, 2.5 percent of those questioned said they had been financially abused by someone they knew, Dr. Pillemer said. That proportion, if applied to the United States, would translate into some 750,000 victims.
But he noted that crime rates typically run much higher in the United States, so the figure should be seen as an estimate of the lowest possible number of cases in this country. He also said it was significant that only one of 25 people in the survey said they had reported the abuse to the police.
As the ranks of the enfeebled old swell, aided by medical advances that extend life, the problem of financial abuse is likely to grow.
 
Large Nest Eggs
 In the last few decades, having the financial means to live independently has become a hallmark of older Americans, millions of whom have uprooted themselves from families and familiar communities since the 1950's to move to retirement havens in Florida, Arizona and elsewhere.
Increasing numbers of these elderly people have substantial bank and investment accounts, supplemented by benefits from Social Security and private pension plans. Many have reaped large profits, in some cases in the hundreds of thousands of dollars, from homes sold during the real estate boom of the last two decades. Those who slip into mental impairment leave such nest eggs easy prey to financial abuse.
Even less secure are people of meager means who live alone behind bolted doors in big cities.
Every metropolitan area has many cases like that of a 79-year-old widow in New York City who was made a virtual prisoner inside her home by a grandson and his girlfriend, both crack addicts, who took her Social Security checks as soon as they arrived.
Rose Herschberg, acting director of the elderly crime victims resource center of the New York City Department of Aging, said the best defense against abuse of the elderly is to educate potential victims and people who are likely to be in a position to help them, including the police, hospital workers and banks, on how to identify and address the threat.
Often, the victims are women living alone, a consequence of the longer lives among American women compared to men. Married women of middle age, on average, will become widowed before turning 70 and will die 15 years later; fewer than 1 of 10 will remarry. The United States Census Bureau has estimated that by 1995, 60 percent of women 75 and older will be living alone.
Loneliness among the elderly population and the fear of becoming a burden on families are thoughts never far from the minds of those who live alone. "Even if they know a care-provider, like a housekeeper or an adult child, is stealing their money, they won't report it because they are completely dependent, psychologically and physically, on that individual," said Fran Shaw, a paralegal investigator for the Broward County state attorney's office in Florida.
Near Asbury Park, N.J., the authorities recently were told that a man was stealing money from his mother, a woman in her 70's who lived alone and who was in the early stages of Alzheimer's disease.
"We investigated and found he had taken more than $60,000 from her," said Steven Cerretani, director of protective services for the elderly in Monmouth County. "But she wouldn't press charges because her son was her only contact with the outside world. She told us she was so lonely she'd pay the devil to visit her."
 
Who Reports Abuse
 When a case of financial abuse is reported, the source of the information is likely to be someone other than the victim: a police officer or ambulance attendant who responds to a call from the victim's residence, a bank teller who notices unusual cash withdrawals from a victim's account, a neighbor who observes strangers at a victim's home, or family members who discover that someone has been looting an elderly person's assets.
A sampling of recent police cases shows the variety of crimes against the elderly.
Near Sacramento, Calif., a 79-year-old widow described by an investigator as "sweet and charming, with some dementia and memory loss" was befriended by a younger man, who ran errands for her. Soon, he had become her "financial adviser" and talked her into giving him power of attorney over her bank accounts and stock. By the time a relative became suspicious, the man had looted the accounts of more than $150,000 and fled with jewelry and other property valued at $80,000.
A 56-year-old Pompano Beach, Fla., man who was the legal guardian for his infirm mother, was accused of pocketing $161,000 he withdrew from her bank account. Kent Neal, who heads the economic crimes unit of the Broward County prosecutor's office, said the man had used the money for a variety of expenses, including rust-proofing his car and paying traffic fines. "But at the same time he wouldn't allow doctors to replace his mother's heart pacemaker," he said.
 
Many Are Hurt
 The mentally incapacitated are not the only ones who get hurt.
In Sun City, Ariz., Ellen Lewis's eyesight was failing. Otherwise the 74-year-old widow was alert and energetic. Her one weakness, she recalled ruefully, was trust.
After her husband's death, Mrs. Lewis needed someone to drive her on errands and to do yard work. Through friends she hired "a bright clean-cut young man" and trusted him to such a degree that after a while she began routinely signing blank checks to be used by him for her household bills.
Instead, the 23-year-old man wrote four-figure sums payable to himself in a deception that was not caught for months. He confessed to the police that he had stolen thousands of dollars and he agreed to make restitution, but the episode undermined Mrs. Lewis's confidence about living alone.
In Swampscott, Mass., north of Boston, Emma Marquis also trusted "a nice young man," and it cost her $180,000, her life savings.
Mrs. Marquis, a widow, was shopping for a safe investment in 1983 when she was introduced to a Salem business leader and financial consultant. "If I had had a son, I would want one like him," Mrs. Marquis, now 79, said in a telephone interview. "He was so handsome and had a silver-tongue personality. Everything he said, you trusted."
Through the consultant, an annuity account was opened in her name with a $60,000 check she wrote. Without her knowledge, however, the man closed the account within days by forging Mrs. Marquis's name and he cashed the reimbursement check issued by the insurance company. A few years later, Mrs. Marquis gave him another $120,000 to deposit in the account.
When the consultant died last year at age 47, there were immediate rumors he had bilked dozens of clients. Mrs. Marquis learned that there was no annuity fund in her name.
Her life savings wiped out, Mrs. Marquis said she faces the future with dread. Her children send her monthly checks, "but I don't like taking things from them," she said. "I don't want to be a burden."

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Cuomo's Task: Painting a Rose-Colored New York

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
NEW York State has 13 times more cows than imprisoned criminals.
In Florida, California, Michigan and 12 other states, a larger proportion of the population is in state prison. Five states, California included, have a higher percentage of welfare recipients. New York is less urbanized than Connecticut, California or Maryland. And more American Indians live in New York than in Wyoming, Colorado and Indiana combined. 
 Mention New York to most people, though, and cows are unlikely to come to mind first. In fact, some people believe that if New York has more cows than imprisoned criminals it is only because so many criminals who ought to be in prison are roaming the streets instead.
Preconceptions and the welter of comparative statistics on spending, taxes, the economy and crime that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo marshals in rebuttal may be overshadowed by other variables, ranging from the state's fragile credit rating -- the third lowest -- to Mr. Cuomo's appealing television presence. But which stereotypes the state evokes instead may be pivotal to the Governor's appeal in a Presidential campaign.
Nobody, not even Mr. Cuomo, refers to goings-on in his home state as the New York "miracle." But do out-of-staters generally view New York as a nightmare, as Vice President Quayle suggests? Or, as Mr. Cuomo maintains, as a microcosm of America, warts and all?
If the nightmare perception prevails, Mr. Cuomo may be placed on the defensive and dismissed as part of a problem that is largely unique to the State of New York and to the city of the same name that has typically defined the state's reputation.
"Nobody wants their state to be like New York," said Roger Ailes, a Republican media consultant.
If the Governor persuasively argues that New York's social and economic problems are shared by most Americans and that New York has done more than most states to resolve them, then he stands a better chance of shifting attention, and blame, to Washington's domestic agenda.
"It would be an excellent defense and a great offense," the Governor said of the strategy he has already begun testing against the Republican White House. "There is no way they can attack New York without admitting their own abject failure."
The Cuomo administration flaunts the fact that only 10 inmates escaped from New York prisons last year -- far below the national average -- and that New York has the highest ratio of correction officers to inmates of any state with more than 40,000 inmates. Some analysts cite that very same ratio, though, as evidence that the state payroll is bloated.
Pointing out, as the Governor does, that New York has grown safer compared to the rest of the nation is also a reminder that the rest of the nation is becoming as unsafe as New York (although the facts may get in the way of Republican efforts to transform Arthur Shawcross, who murdered 10 women upstate following his parole in 1987, into Mr. Cuomo's Willie Horton.)
The economic record, according to Mr. Cuomo: New York's income-tax rate has declined from the nation's highest to 12th highest during his tenure. The average growth rate of taxpayer-supported spending has been lower than the national average; more than two-thirds of general fund spending is for local assistance. Spending on state operations grew slower than the inflation rate. The number of employees paid from tax collections has declined; state debt, swollen by the cost of road and prison construction, is still less per person than in eight other states. Federal debt, meanwhile, increased by virtually every measure -- rising, unlike New York's tax-supported debt, as a percentage of personal income, too.
The annotated record, largely according to Cynthia Green of the Citizens Budget Commission: Yes, New York's income-tax rate and state tax burden have declined, but what about the rise in local taxes caused in part by state welfare, Medicaid and other mandates? The effective income-tax rate -- income-tax revenue divided by total income -- is second only to Oregon's, which has no sales tax. Yes, state revenue increases were half the national average, but they might have been higher without budget gimmicks.
Whose record is it anyway? Republican legislative leaders share responsibility, Ms. Green said, because their priorities varied but their proclivity to spend has not.
Historically, New York has been emblematic of things that some other Americans love to hate. Mr. Cuomo, himself, would set a political precedent as an Italian-American candidate. (His middle name was anglicized to Matthew; his first and last names are often mispronounced. It is KWO-mo, not like the lake or the crooner, and MAH-ree-oh, as in Mark, not Mary). While many urban problems have become more ubiquitous, the state still ranks first in the proportion of violent crime, abortions, Jewish residents, lawyers and other categories that have tended to distinguish it from the rest of the country, the South in particular.
"I would never be running for the Senate from Mississippi," said Geraldine A. Ferraro, who hopes, instead, to run for the Senate from New York next year and who was the last New Yorker on a national ticket, for Vice President in 1984.
None has been nominated for President since 1948. None has captured the Presidency since 1932. Not since then, when America was less urbanized but just as concerned about the economy, has domestic policy been so high on the nation's agenda.

HEADLINE: Making Sense Of Labeling On Products

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER

 BODY:
Stunned by the growth of products making bold claims for environmental purity -- from "nuclear free" light bulbs and "environmentally safe" socks to botanically correct shampoos -- consumer advocates have begun to insist that trendy words like "recycled" and "biodegradable" have meanings that normal people can understand.
"The marketplace has become as polluted as the landfills," said Emma N. Byrne, director of the New Jersey Office of Consumer Protection, which today will send letters to dozens of companies asking them to prove the claims they make for their products. "How can anyone really be confident that they are getting what they are paying for?"
 
Processors Want Rules, Too
 Consumers throughout the nation have demonstrated their eagerness, even in a recession, to pay more for merchandise that promises to respect the environment, and American companies have flooded store shelves with "green" products in response. Yet, like food labels that once used the words "light," "organic" and "natural" in almost any way a manufacturer wished, few products advertising their commitment to the earth are required to prove what they mean, and few do. 
 "Recycled" paper, for example, rarely means paper from products that have already been used. Most of the time the paper is simply made from industrial scraps. And "recyclable" often means nothing at all, because with enough effort and money, every product can be broken into its component parts, and theoretically, recycled.
Neither the Federal Government nor many states have taken strong action to dissipate the emerging babel in the marketplace. Even the few states -- California, New York, Rhode Island and Indiana -- that have attempted to define consumer labels and enforce their laws have done it so differently that what is biodegradable or recycled in one state may not be so in another. And consumers are not the only group that has been overwhelmed by the conflicting claims.
"What we don't want are 50 different standards our members have to interpret and conform to," said Kathleen Grant, the environmental issues consultant to the National Food Processors Association, which would prefer a set of uniform regulations. "In a national market you can't put different labels on each product in every state. It would cost a fortune and it certainly wouldn't help shoppers much either."
Most people could hardly receive less assistance than they do now, however. For those struggling to choose ecologically sensitive products, a trip to the grocery store might as well be a forced march through the looking glass. According to the Environmental Defense Fund, which has followed the trend closely, more than 10 percent of new packaged goods in the nation carried some environmental claim last year, more than double the figure in 1989.
Are Cedar Fresh Moth Balls -- advertised on the package as "the world's first nontoxic moth ball" -- really safer and better than the others? The product carries a little "Eco-Safe" emblem, along with the words "environment friendly." But are they?
"Maybe they are and maybe not," said Mark Green, Commissioner of the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs, who has aggressively pursued what he calls "green-collar fraud" on the part of manufacturers who mislead customers with false environmental claims. "It's been left to local officials to define these terms. The Environmental Protection Agency should do it but they don't, and the Federal Trade Commission should enforce the rules. But there are none."
 
Seeking a Common Language
 E.P.A. officials say they are aware of the growing confusion and are eager to reduce it. Although it has no authority to require label changes, the agency and the Federal Trade Commission have held hearings on the issue, and each promises that within a year environmental terms will have more universal meanings. But, in the absence of Federal action, several states, including New York, have moved ahead with their own laws and definitions. Congress and many other states now appear ready to follow.
"We need a common language pretty badly," said Allen Herskowitz of the Natural Resources Defense Council. "But the terms are not exactly like health claims where fat is fat and a calorie is a calorie. Some of these terms have to vary because if a plastic cup is recyclable in California -- and often it is -- but not in Maine, we want consumers to know that. Before you have a single language you have to have a single approach to recycling. And we are very far from that day."
Acknowledging the difficulty of its task, the E.P.A. has proposed fairly broad standard definitions for the words recycled and recyclable -- the two most frequently used and (some would argue) misused environmental terms. It has suggested that the word recycled apply only to products that clearly state the percentage by weight of recycled materials they contain.
 
Educating Consumers
 That would help consumers understand the true significance of any such claim. In most cases, now, if any part of a product is recycled, its manufacturer has every right to slap the label "recycled" on the package. If, for example, a company claims that its paper towels are recycled, that can mean that a small percentage of every roll contains scraps that would in the past have been left on the factory floor. Or it could mean that the product is actually made from paper that has already been used.
"When people see the magic word recycled on their product they think they are buying something that has made from a package they threw out," said Richard Dennison, a senior scientist with the Environmental Defense Fund and a leading critic of the current system. "But usually they aren't. And if you see the word 'recyclable' at the bottom of a coffee cup you have to ask 'where can it be recycled?' It won't do you much good if the answer is half way across the country."
Often it is. Proposed E.P.A. definitions would attempt to make it clear to shoppers that their 'recyclable' merchandise cannot be recycled everywhere. Labels would also include information that would disclose how much of the product is being recycled nationwide.
In New Jersey, Ms. Byrne, the consumer affairs director, recently gave two members of her staff each $100 and sent them to local stores. Her orders were to come back with products that made claims that they were environmentally safe.
"Half of it is noise," she said in a recent interview, shaking her head at a box of "reusable lawn bags," and an "earth friendly" children's school kit. "It doesn't mean a thing. It's not fair to consumers and it's not fair to the many companies that really have tried to do something for the environment."
Today she will send a series of detailed letters to many companies selling products in New Jersey that make ecological claims. If a manufacturer calls its product biodegradable, for example, it will be asked to provide evidence.
 
'Who Sets the Rules?'
 "What will typically happen to this package or product once it is discarded by a consumer?" one letter asks a company that sells "biodegradable" bags. "How long will it take for the package to decompose? Please supply any available test data demonstrating that the package or product has the capability to decompose rapidly (within one year) through natural biological processes."
Each letter ends with a warning that failure to respond within 10 business days could result in legal action.
But many companies fear that they will be forced to comply everywhere with the strictest guidelines passed by any single state -- and that they will end up being forced to drop reasonable claims from labels that could have helped educate consumers.
"We want to be as diligent as we possible can," said Bob Murray, a spokesman for Colgate Palmolive, one of the world's largest consumer products companies. "We take the environmental aspect of our labels very seriously. But the issue of standards is not quite as simple as it seems. Whose approach should we use? Who sets the rules?
"We want it to make sense and we agree conformity is important," Mr. Murray said. "But there are so many possible approaches in so many states, cities, countries even. This is not an issue that will be easy to legislate."

HEADLINE: Industries Hoping for Relief With Tax Breaks

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
From Wall Street to Main Street, business executives are looking for changes in the tax system that will provide relief from the sluggish economy.
Many hope their businesses may be revived by restoration of some tax breaks lost in the 1986 tax reform bill, especially investment tax credits and a reduced capital gains tax. 
 President Bush's top economic advisers told Congress last week that the Administration might favor a tax credit on business investments, although they said no final decisions had been made. The Administration has long favored a lower capital gains tax.
Realtors, insurers, bankers, brokers, manufacturers, airline executives and oil producers are among those seeking changes.
 
Fear of Politics
 A notable exception is the powerful small-business lobby, the National Association of Wholesaler Distributors, which is more or less satisfied with the status quo. The group fears that tax changes would be political and lead to the unraveling of the 1986 tax reform act.
"Our people are feeling the same pain that an awful lot of other people are feeling," said Dirk Van Dongen, the group's president. "But taxes have such a propensity to be politicized that you wind up with a package that caters to constituencies and does nothing for the economy."
He added, "Our wish list is a very simple and direct one: do nothing to harm the underlying foundation of the 1986 Tax Reform Act."
On Wall Street, people believe certain tax breaks are needed to spur the economy, said Edward I. O'Brien, president of the Securities Industry Association, which represents the brokerage houses.
"Wall Street cares about the deficit," Mr. O'Brien said. "However, if you agree that there is a serious problem in moving our economy forward, the expansion of the deficit under certain circumstances is not necessarily the worst thing."
At the top of his wish list, Mr. O'Brien placed expansion of the deductibility of Individual Retirement Accounts, which he said would increase savings and make more money available for investment.
Under the 1986 tax law, millions of middle and upper income workers covered by employer pension plans -- couples with incomes above $50,000 and single individuals with incomes above $35,000 -- were no longer allowed to claim such deductions.
The group also seeks a reduction in the capital gains tax "to help get companies off the ground" and investment tax credits "to generate some jobs and verve in the American economic system." Democrats have opposed a reduction in the tax on the gains from the sale of assets, claiming that it would mainly benefit middle- and upper-income taxpayers.
 
Opinions on Investment Credit
 Investment tax credits, first enacted under President John F. Kennedy in 1961, permit businesses to subtract directly from their tax bills a percentage of the money they invest in plants and machinery. Supporters maintain that credits encourage businesses to expand and generate new jobs; opponents say they reward businesses for investments they would make anyway, help capital-intensive industries more than those that depend largely on labor, and established companies more than start-up companies.
Realtors are encouraged by the prospect of tax relief, despite the testimony Thursday of Mr. Bush's economic advisers that the Administration would oppose a reintroduction of real estate tax breaks. "I'm very optimistic," said Stephen D. Riesler, senior vice president of government affairs of the National Association of Realtors. "All the talk in Washington is that something needs to be done to stimulate the economy."
The realtors have four major proposals, each with significant Congressional support. First, they would like a modification of the passive loss restrictions in the 1986 tax bill, which prevent anyone who owns rental real estate from deducting losses against other types of income. The measure was enacted to prevent tax shelter abuses, but the realtors would like an exception made for those who participate in managing rental properties. Their proposal has 320 sponsors in the House and 50 in the Senate.
The realtors also seek the restoration of a capital gains differential for the sale of existing buildings, allowing first-time buyers of homes to make penalty-free withdrawals from I.R.A.'s or 401k savings plans, and permanent enactment of several provisions that are expiring, including tax credits for low-income people and a 25 percent deduction for self-employed people who pay their own medical insurance.
The insurance brokers, also politically influential, want to be able to amortize the acquisition of intangible assets, like the expirations of insurance policies. Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, has introduced legislation to that effect.
"We support the bill, but we want a retroactive clarification that would confirm that intangible assets have value and can be amortized," said Barbara S. Haugen, director of Federal affairs of the National Association of Insurance Brokers. "His bill is from the date of introduction. If you can show by some reasonable method that a customer-based asset has depreciating value, it should be amortized."
The nation's manufacturers seek long-term changes. Paul R. Huard, the National Association of Manufacturers' vice president for taxation and fiscal policy, said, "If they're going to do taxes at all, in terms of short-term stimulus, they ought to stay away from things that are short-term-conception oriented. Throwing money at the middle class based on the number of kids they have may be fine re-election policy, but I doubt that it's going to do much for the economy, short or long term."
The group's top priority is some kind of targeted investment tax credit to stimulate more business investment in machinery and equipment.
The manufacturers also seek a change in the alternative minimum tax, designed to insure that even those taxpayers with high tax deductions pay some tax. The group seeks either a reduction in the alternative rate, now 21 percent for corporations, or a change in the way it is calculated.
"Our big beef is primarily related to depreciation," Mr. Huard said. "Longer depreciation means higher tax liability, particularly when profits are low or non-existent."
 
Changing the Calculation
 The oil producers want a change in the calculation of the alternative minimum tax. Specifically, they do not want the minimum tax to be based on intangible drilling costs and percentage depletion. The oil producers contend that intangible drilling costs are the costs of finding oil and getting wells to the point where they become productive, while percentage depletion is similar to depreciation in other industries.
Tara Lewis, chief tax specialist of the Independent Petroleum Association of America, said, "There's no rationale for having these ordinary and necessary business expenses subject to a penalty under the alternative minimum tax."
And bankers want incentives for savings. "A broad-based incentive would be very useful -- the kind of thing bankers would be able to advertise," said Henry Ruempler, director of tax and accounting for the American Bankers Association, who added that the association had not advocated any particular incentive.
The bankers also support proposals that would improve the value of real estate, like a reduced capital gains tax and a change in the passive loss rules.
The airlines seek an investment tax credit for airline assets "to lower the cost of purchases to an industry already suffering acute capital shortages," the Air Transport Association of America said in a statement.
The airlines also seek a modification of the alternative minimum tax to eliminate air transportation assets, reductions in the 10 percent ticket tax and the 6.25 percent cargo tax, full deductibility of per diem paid to flight crews while away from home overnight, and inclusion of airline gates, routes and slots as existing intangible assets.

HEADLINE: Terrorism Strains Peru's Reforms

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HUACHO, Peru

 BODY:
A fortress of a factory stands anonymously on the Pan American Highway here. Sawhorses have been erected to block car bombers from parking areas. Guards wearing bulletproof vests and toting shotguns search visitors. A concrete watchtower, dominating a perimeter wall, is equipped with gun slits, a steel trapdoor and a battery-powered radio system.
Inside this top-security installation, lines of nimble-fingered women peel, wash and can asparagus and baby ears of corn. 
 A year ago, terrorists blew up the cannery. That was after 40 of them invaded the owner's home. "My crime," said Julio Favre Carranza, the cannery's owner, "is that I give employment to 1,000 people."
At a time when Peru's President, Alberto K. Fujimori, seeks a sweeping free-market revolution, his main obstacle is terrorism by the radical leftist Shining Path movement. Preferring Mao Zedong to Margaret Thatcher, the terrorists believe the road to revolution is through the destruction of Peru's economy.
American companies, accounting for half of the $1.2 billion in foreign investment in Peru and planning to invest more, have been the targets of several terrorist attacks. After guerrillas killed three people at an oil-drilling site, the Mobil Oil Corporation responded by housing and feeding its own detachment of the Peruvian Army.
A decade of growing terrorism by the Sendero Luminoso, or Shining Path, has led many Peruvian and foreign business executives to list security as their primary problem. In an annual survey, the percentage of Peruvian business leaders identifying terrorism as the nation's top challenge jumped to 45 percent this year from 10 percent in 1990.
In Lima, the nation's capital 80 miles south of here, factories in the industrial zone look like maximum-security prisons -- protected by concertina wire, watchtowers and dog runs. Instead of signs with company logos, there are signs ordering visitors to "Identify Yourself!"
While Peru's economy contracted sharply in the 1980's, the number of security companies registered in Lima surged -- from 64 in 1980 to 323 today.
In world rankings, Peru has had the highest number of "politically inspired" terrorist incidents, according to Pinkerton's Inc., the security and investigation organization based in Van Nuys, Calif.
"Peru has hovered around first or second place for the last few years," Gene Mastrangelo, manager of the risk assessment information service at Pinkerton's, said in a telephone interview. "The reason Peru will remain at No. 1 this year is because Shining Path operates at will virtually all over the country."
 
Freer Business Climate
 The terrorism comes just when an avalanche of decrees is giving business executives the most economic freedom in Peru's 459-year history. Seeking to end monopolies, many of which persist from the Spanish colonial era that ended in the early 19th century, the Government has allowed private-sector competition in the mail and telephone services, the railroads, road and sewer construction, electricity generation, oil and gas production and distribution, education, airport management and the production of fish meal used in animal feed and fertilizer.
Copying programs that proved successful in Chile, Peru's southern neighbor, Peru now allows its citizens to choose between state and private pension funds and between state and private health programs.
In the reversal of a socialist legacy that dates to the 1960's, employers have won greater power to hire and fire workers, landlords have won an end to rent controls, and private companies have won the right to buy, sell and mortgage farmland.
Other Government decrees have deregulated airlines, trucking and long-distance bus routes, simplified registration of small businesses and placed foreign banks on an equal footing with local banks.
 
U.S. Embassy's View
 "The Government of President Alberto Fujimori has adopted orthodox, market-oriented economic policies to an extent previously unknown in Peru," reads a new report by the United States Embassy here.
In Peru's lucrative mining and drilling sectors, decrees have allowed foreign investors to make full and free remittance of profits abroad and have encouraged Peru's three main state mining companies to establish joint ventures with private companies, local or foreign. Bidding openly for Hong Kong flight capital, Peru grants any foreigner a Peruvian passport in return for a five-year, $35,000 deposit in the state-run Banco de la Nacion.
While many Peruvians and foreigners are still trying to digest these radical changes, some pioneers have started exploring investment possibilities. Some flight capital is making the return trip home.
"One billion dollars in Peruvian capital has come back this year; if security was such a problem, it would not have come," the Minister of Labor and Social Promotion, Alfonso de los Heros, said in an interview in Lima.
While he was speaking, the lights went out -- either as the result of a terrorist attack or because of the power rationing that has resulted from past damage to transmission lines.
 
Money From Chile and the U.S.
 Investment in Lima's stock market and in southern agricultural land is reportedly coming from Chile, a country where business executives have learned over the last two decades to live with low levels of terrorism.
Peru's largest trading partner, the United States, had about 100 companies participating in a trade fair in Lima in November, the largest participation in memory.
"Assets are cheap, and inflation is headed down," said an American economist here. Inflation in October and November was 4 percent monthly -- the lowest rate in five years.
In the largest American investment seen here in more than a decade, the Southern Peru Copper Corporation, which is 52 percent owned by Asarco Inc. of New York, has announced that it will invest $300 million in new mining technology at two of its copper mines.
 
Big Investment by Occidental
 In another big new American investment, the Occidental Petroleum Corporation recently signed a contract to invest $60 million over the next four years. Occidental, which produces half of Peru's oil, plans to drill 32 new wells by 1995, double the rate of the last five years.
Mobil is drilling its first exploratory well in the Upper Huallaga Valley, the start of a six-year commitment to invest at least $107 million in exploration. Mobil's activities could grow much larger. "If production equals Mobil's expectations, total investment in the project could reach $1 billion," according to the American Embassy report.
One year ago, the Shining Path attacked Mobil's drilling site, killing three people and damaging about $1 million worth of equipment. This year, Mobil is back, protected by its Peruvian Army detachment.
 
Security First
 Indeed, all discussions of investment projects here inevitably return to hard-eyed assessments of security. In this year's survey by the Confederation of Peruvian Industrialists, half of the 400 respondents said they suspected that terrorist sympathizers had infiltrated their labor force; 47 percent said they had received telephone threats; 19 percent said their companies had endured terrorist attacks, and 4 percent said their companies had been victimized by kidnappers. One percent admitted to paying "revolutionary taxes" -- or extortion -- to guerrilla groups.
"We think it is going to be difficult for the nation to recover, if order is not restored," said Mr. Favre, the cannery owner who organized the confederation's annual conference in September under the slogan "Development and Security."
Dressed in a navy blue blazer and a designer tie on a recent morning, Mr. Favre looked like a typical Latin American company president, except for the loaded 9-millimeter Beretta pistol on his office desk.
The Beretta is the last line of defense in a private security system that eats up 9 percent of his company's operating costs and fills a vacuum left by Peru's crumbling state. At a monthly cost of $50,000, Mr. Favre protects the 11 factories of his Atahuampa Group with 80 armed guards and a 150-man Peruvian Army unit that he feeds and houses. In May, a terrorist attack on an army truck killed four of the soldiers.
"Until 1983, we had one watchman for this complex," Victor Lau Chang, Atahuampa's security director, said of a feed-grain mill where the army detachment is bivouacked. Atahuampa is Peru's third-largest canner of asparagus and the third-largest poultry hatchery.
In a region where most farmers have abandoned their land to avoid paying "revolutionary taxes," Ata huampa's security measures are warranted.
 
A Bulletproof Pickup Truck
 In 1989, a squad of guerrillas invaded Mr. Favre's hilltop residential compound here. Finding the owner absent, they killed a guard dog. Since then, he visits his factories only sporadically, driving in a bulletproof pickup truck equipped with four-wheel drive and wide tires in case a trip across the desert becomes necessary to elude kidnappers.
Last year, the Shining Path guerrillas returned. They stopped a company bus, donned the workers' uniforms and drove into the cannery. Once inside, the guerrillas gave a political harangue and then set off enough dynamite to do $1.5 million in damage.
Mr. Favre swore to rebuild his factory in a month. "The next day, I visited the factory with television stations from Lima and challenged Sendero to build its own factory in one month," Mr. Favre said.
"We worked day and night, and in 33 days, the factory was ready. I went on television again. This time, I asked the nation, 'Where is Sendero's factory?' "

HEADLINE: Market Place;
United Airlines: A Global Power

BYLINE: By Agis Salpukas

 BODY:
BY winning the bidding on Pan American's Latin American routes last week, United Airlines positioned itself as the world's leading international carrier, particularly strong in markets that are expected to grow faster than its domestic routes. There is limited entry for competitors on the routes to Brazil and Argentina because bilateral treaties restrict the market. And with the heavy business travel between those countries and the United States, those routes were money makers even for Pan Am.
"Their economies are well developed, and they have generated a lot of travel over the years," said Dan Kasper, a consultant and expert on international aviation at Harbridge House, a consulting group. "Entry and capacity have also been restricted." 
 While Brazil has taken some steps to increase competition by allowing new carriers to begin service, the two American carriers -- United and American -- will have limited competition from South American carriers for the next two years.
Although Pan Am's other markets, including the North Atlantic, lost heavily and helped drive the airline into bankruptcy, the Latin American division produced revenue of $735.1 million and a profit of $55.9 million in 1989, and revenues of $821.1 million and income of $54.2 million in 1990.
"Given the size of the revenue stream and its past earnings history, United will have very respectable and profitable operations by the end of 1992," predicted Julius Maldutis, the airline analyst for Salomon Brothers.
Kevin Murphy, the airline analyst for Morgan Stanley, said every important international route transfer had worked out well for the winning carriers. And once the recession wanes, United's stock should benefit, he said, adding: "United is now the world's best international airline franchise. No other airline in the world has United's global reach."
American Airlines, eager to expand its service to Latin America on the routes obtained from Eastern Airlines, was willing to bid $130 million just to get more frequent flights to Argentina and Brazil. American was aware that it would have had to dispose of the bulk of what it purchased because of antitrust considerations. American says its flights to Brazil and Argentina are booked solid through March.
In a fierce bidding war, United won the Pan Am routes for $135 million, seemingly a bargain since American paid $342 million for the Eastern routes. United had also offered to buy the routes from Pan Am late in August for $215 million.
"The price was quite cheap," Mr. Maldutis said.
And Mr. Kapser commented: "They wanted to fill out their portfolio. What they have done is re-create the old Pan Am -- which was the largest international carrier -- with United, which before deregulation was the largest domestic carrier.
"United has service to every major continent now," he added. The carrier bought Pan Am's Pacific routes in the mid-80's, an operation that became highly profitable after United stumbled when it first took over the service.
Because Pan Am ceased operations last week, United will in effect begin a new airline when it begins serving the routes on Jan. 15. That day, United plans to begin daily service from Kennedy International Airport in New York to Rio de Janerio, continuing to Buenos Aires, with a Boeing 747; there will also be daily service from Miami to Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo with a Boeing 747.
On the same day, United will also begin service from Kennedy to Caracas with a Boeing 757.
United will take delivery next year of 66 new airplanes, including 10 767's, wide-body aircraft that can be used on the routes.
Stephen M. Wolf, the chairman and president of United, said the airline would eventually offer more frequent flights than Pan Am did. "It will obviously take us some period to get up and running, and an additional period to utilize fully the frequencies which we have obtained," he said.
As part of its bid , United said it would offer employment to 1,000 of the 10,000 Pan Am employees who lost their jobs. The "cultural sensitivities and understanding that these individuals possess are of special importance to United," he said.
The problem is that United's unions will have to agree to integrate the new workers. The United Master Executive Council of the pilots union is expected to let in only a small number of the 880 pilots who lost their jobs at Pan Am.
