LENGTH: 1051 words

HEADLINE: Pessimism at the Fed;
For First Time, Greenspan Is Suggesting Rate Cuts Alone May Not Revive Economy

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
A new pessimism, evident in Alan Greenspan's latest speeches and in other recent comments, suggests that the chairman of the Federal Reserve now believes that new efforts by the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates will not necessarily revive the economy, as lower rates have in the past. So additional measures might have to be tried, among them Federal spending or tax cuts.
For months, the Federal Reserve confidently said that an economic upturn was just around the corner. Now, for the first time, Mr. Greenspan is suggesting that he has no clear idea when the economy's current stagnation might end: by spring, by Election Day, by early 1993 or perhaps not until later in the decade. 
 Until now, Mr. Greenspan has been adamantly opposed to tax cuts or public spending, on the ground that such fiscal measures would run up the deficit, which he still does not want to do. But his concern that the economy is dead in the water appears to be overcoming some of his aversion to Federal pump priming. Above all, he is concerned that what he has called the "utterly unprecedented" debt burden of consumers and businesses will not be resolved in some standard, easily measurable way.
 "Usually the Fed guys are optimistic as a matter of professional responsibility," said Robert Johnson, a managing director at Bankers Trust and a former Federal Reserve economist. "Mr. Greenspan's pessimism is quite candid, and it tells you how scary this recession is."
The Federal Reserve chairman is scheduled to testify tomorrow before the House Ways and Means Committee, which is seeking solutions to a recession that showed itself again yesterday with the announcement that industrial production fell four-tenths of 1 percent in November. He almost certainly will be asked about spending or tax programs that Congress and the Administration could undertake to stimulate the economy.
In none of his remarks has Mr. Greenspan given any details of the proposals he seems to be considering. He does suggest that a responsible fiscal package -- one that would not raise either the deficit or the inflation rate -- is conceivable. But the small sums involved might not be enough to help the economy.
Mr. Greenspan's views appeared to be in part an answer to critics, both in the Bush Administration and in the economics profession, who say that the economy would bounce back if the Federal Reserve would cut short-term interest rates more than the 3.75 percentage points that it has already cut since the recession started 18 months ago. The chairman, who until recently had thought that lower rates would do the job, is now in effect asking for help, and in doing so, he is putting pressure on the White House and Congress to play a role in ending the recession, said David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston, a Wall Street investment house.
 
 
'A Major Conversion'
 "Mr. Greenspan appears to have undergone a major conversion," Mr. Jones said. "What he has been saying recently is that the economy is in more difficulty than he thought it was a few months ago, and recovery requires more than just cutting interest rates. He is groping for other solutions, and one is fiscal help to jump-start the economy."
The essence of Mr. Greenspan's alarm about the economy -- the reason he seems willing to debate fiscal policy -- lies in what he calls "a heavy overhang of debt" and "the unusual degree of caution" that it has engendered among businesses, consumers and lenders. Both the debt load and the public determination to pay it down are without precedent since 1941, in the Greenspan view. As a result, Mr. Greenspan seems to imply that no method exists to measure accurately when Americans might feel sufficiently solvent to spend and invest again, thus making the economy grow and recover.
The problem, in sum, is more a psychological one than a process that can be measured with statistics, Mr. Greenspan suggests. Economists must rely more on anecdotal evidence than on such things as income-to-debt ratios or the level of mortgage rates to gauge progress toward a healthy economy. That is an unusual acknowledgement for Mr. Greenspan, whose forte is statistics. It means that the economics profession lacks the tools to forecast just when this recession might end.
Americans, in fact, might be so shaken by their experiences of the last two years -- stagnant wages, insecure jobs, falling real estate prices, the reluctance of banks to renew loans, incomes inadequate to make debt payments -- that they might not regain their confidence until they work down debt to 1950's or 1960's levels, Mr. Greenspan suggests. Car loans in the 1950's, for example, normally ran two years; today the norm is four to five years.
 
 
Recent Speeches Cited
 Mr. Greenspan had the debt burden in mind on Oct. 29 when, in a speech to business executives in Providence, R.I., he said that the economy was trying to move forward against a "50-mile-an-hour headwind." Another speech, on Dec. 6 at the annual convention of the Securities Industry Association, was devoted to the debt problem and its impact on the economy.
Mr. Greenspan's pessimism contrasts sharply with his euphoria of last summer, when he told Congress, "There are compelling signs that the recession is behind us." As recently as late September, he said that a consumption level higher than production was pushing up factory output. In past recessions, this has led to more employment, growing income, more consumption and, in sum, an expanding economy. But the incipient improvement halted in October.
Now Mr. Greenspan appears to be parting company with the prevailing White House view that consumer and business debt will be sufficiently worked down by next June to permit new activity and a recovery. David W. Mullins Jr., the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve and recently its chief public spokesman, also offers this view.
Mr. Greenspan does not reject the idea. Quite the contrary, he considers an upturn by next summer a distinct possibility. But equally possible, in the Greenspan analysis, is the possibility that the stagnant, debt-burdened economy could tip into a fresh downturn. That possibility has not been publicly expressed by the Federal Reserve and is just now being nudged forward by its chairman.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Traders Await Sign From the Fed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities and interest rates were little changed yesterday, as dealers waited to see if the Federal Reserve Board would push short-term interest rates down again.
The Fed's Open Market Committee is scheduled to meet today in Washington amid speculation that it will lower its target for the overnight Federal funds rate by a quarter of a percentage point and drop its discount rate by half a point. 
 Traders said it was unlikely that the central bank would announce any changes until tomorrow, however.
 
Supported by Numbers
 The case for another round of rate cuts to stimulate the economy was bolstered yesterday when the Fed reported that manufacturing output fell by four-tenths of 1 percent in November, a larger decline than expected. Nevertheless, the report had almost no impact on prices in the credit markets.
Some officials from the Bush Administration and the Fed, meanwhile, made optimistic statements about the economy yesterday.
John P. LaWare, a Fed governor, said in a speech in Baltimore that a recent acceleration in money-supply growth was likely to stimulate the sluggish economy. Separately, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said that the credit shortage had eased in recent weeks.
 
 
Fed Action Urged
 Those comments came even as recent speeches and remarks by the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, suggested some pessimism about the direction of the economy -- a view many analysts have asserted for some time.
Some analysts say now that the Fed needs to be more aggressive.
"The Fed has spent an awful long time doing as little as possible," said Robert A. Brusca, chief economist at Nikko Securities. "And based on what they have done in past recessions, they have more work to do."
Mr. Brusca said the Fed would likely need to push the Federal funds rate -- the rate banks charge each other for overnight loans, currently at 4 1/4 percent -- down to 3 3/4 percent or lower to get the economy moving.
Edward Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence, said, "I'm still shocked the Fed didn't lower the discount rate by a full point after the November employment report was released on Dec. 6." The discount rate is what the Government charges banks for loans.
"You are beginning to see that people are really getting scared, and I share the average consumers' concerns about the outlook," Mr. Yardeni said. "But I wonder if the Fed recognizes the magnitude of the problem."
 
Limits on New Bonds
 Bond prices did respond yesterday to remarks by Deputy Treasury Secretary John E. Robson. Speaking at the same Baltimore conference that Mr. LaWare had addressed, Mr. Robson reiterated that the Treasury was considering limiting the sale of new bonds.
Bond prices moved higher after the news, but some dealers said the idea was potentially dangerous.
"If you are going to change the rules, there is naturally going to be more uncertainty," one government bond trader said.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 102 7/8, up 6/32, to yield 7.75 percent, compared with 7.76 percent late on Friday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7.50 percent 10-year notes were offered at 102 1/4 in late trading, up 1/8 point, to yield 7.17 percent. And the 5.50 percent two-year notes were unchanged at an offered price of 100 27/ 32, to yield 5.04 percent.
 
Bills Rates Fall at Auction
 Short-term Treasury bill rates continued to fall at the weekly auction of three- and six-month securities.
Three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 4.14 percent, down from an average rate of 4.21 percent at last week's sale. The three-month bill rate was the lowest since the auction of Aug. 21, 1972, when the rate was 4.058 percent.
Bids on the new six-month bills generated an average discount rate of 4.19 percent, little changed from the 4.20 percent average rate at the sale a week ago. Nevertheless, it is the lowest rate on a six-month bill since June 12, 1972, when the rate was 4.187 percent.
 
Corporate Debt
 In the investment-grade corporate bond market, Heller Financial offered $200 million of seven-year notes through an underwriting group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The 8 percent notes, which mature Dec. 15, 1998, were priced at $99.647 to yield 8.066 percent, 1.32 percentage points more than the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 1/8 percent seven-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities were rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 
Municipal Bonds
 Trading was slow in the tax-exempt municipal bond market, as dealers prepared bids on some $1 billion of New York City securities that are expected to be priced today.
The bulk of the securities -- about $800 million, according to some estimates -- will either carry insurance or will be backed by letters of credit.
Preliminary discussions about prices in advance of the negotiated sale placed the maximum yield on uninsured securities at around 7.75 percent. The maximum yield on the insured bonds is expected to be around 6.80 percent, dealers said.

The Economy
A new pessimism on the economy is evident in Alan Greenspan's recent comments, suggesting that the chairman of the Federal Reserve now believes that new efforts to lower interest rates will not necessarily revive the economy, as they have in the past. So additional measures might have to be tried, like Federal spending or tax cuts. News Analysis. [Page A1.]

Companies
 Maxwell Communication, one of the late Robert Maxwell's two flagship public enterprises, filed for bankruptcy protection. The Chapter 11 filing was made in New York the British company said, because the bulk of its revenue and profit is from American businesses, which include Macmillan, Official Airline Guides and Collier encyclopedias. HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
A Maxwell Flagship in Bankruptcy

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
The Maxwell Communication Corporation, the publicly held corporate flagship of Robert Maxwell, tonight became the latest domino to fall in his crumbling publishing empire when it announced that it had filed for bankruptcy protection from creditors in New York.
In a statement issued late tonight, the company, which owns several American businesses -- including Macmillan Inc., the big publishing house -- said an important reason its board had decided to seek protection in the United States was because "the bulk of its revenue and operating profit is generated by businesses located in the United States." 
 Those businesses, which account for about 80 percent of the company's assets, also include Official Airline Guides, P. F. Collier encyclopedias and half of the Macmillan/McGraw-Hill School Publishing Company. Maxwell Communication said the holding company was the only concern in bankruptcy under the filing, not the operating companies.
 
$1.25 Billion in U.S. Revenues
 The American businesses have revenues of $1.25 billion and operating profits of about $225 million, the company said.
By filing for protection under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code, which gives the company time to work out a plan to pay its debt, the company is trying to put itself into a stronger position to bargain with its 40 or so lending banks, which were scheduled to meet on Wednesday.
The bankers had already been talking about breaking up the company and selling off parts of it to pay off the company's debt, which totals 1.3 billion ($2.37 billion), the company said.
 The only question in many of the bankers' minds was whether to push for the company to be liquidated immediately or to wait for an economic recovery in the United States so that the businesses might fetch a higher price. While the larger lenders seemed to prefer selling the company off piecemeal over the next two to three years, some smaller ones apparently did not want to be stuck that long.
 
 
Meeting With Banks
 The decision to seek bankruptcy protection in the United States came after a meeting this afternoon with a steering committee of the banks, where a special investigation of the company's financial health that has been conducted by Price Waterhouse, the accounting firm, was presumably discussed.
In an interview tonight, John Coyle, a Maxwell Communication spokesman, contended that there had been "no threats" from the banks at the meeting. But he said he did not know whether the banks had been informed of the Chapter 11 filing or whether they had agreed to it before the company had acted.
The Daily News in New York, which is owned by a private company that belonged to the Maxwell family, sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Dec. 5, also in New York. It did so immediately after the two private holding companies at the heart of the Maxwell empire, one of which is the paper's parent, filed for the British equivalent of bankruptcy protection.
Some analysts say they believe that one reason The Daily News filed was to insulate itself from the bankruptcy administrators appointed by an English court, who conceivably might have been less willing to keep it going. There are also suspicions that Kevin Maxwell, the son of Robert Maxwell who has been active in trying to draw up a reorganization plan for The Daily News, is hoping that he will be able to use American law to hold on to that piece of the Maxwell empire.
Even before the empire's collapse, Maxwell Communication's financial health had been fragile. It had been struggling under the burden of its debt, which it had mainly accumulated when Robert Maxwell paid $2.6 billion for Macmillan and $750 million for Official Airline Guides in 1988.
In the last couple of years, the company sold off a slew of businesses to pare its debt. In early November, the company's leaders had even thought that it would be able to meet its next big debt payment -- $750 million due next October -- without having to sell its core businesses.
But then the private Maxwell companies, which own most of the family's 68 percent stake in Maxwell Communication, collapsed under a mountain of debt and filed for the British equivalent of bankruptcy protection early this month.
 
Effect of Pension Revelation
 But it was not their bankruptcy action that forced Maxwell Communication to follow suit today. The reason was undoubtedly the revelation that Robert Maxwell had siphoned off more than $1.4 billion from employee pension funds and his two mainstay public companies: Maxwell Communication and Mirror Group Newspapers.
Maxwell Communication confirmed tonight that Mr. Maxwell and possibly others had taken about 244 million ($444.1 million) from the company, plus almost all of its 56 percent stake in Berlitz International, the language-instruction firm. The latter appears to have been pledged as collateral for loans to the private Maxwell companies.
"Over 90 percent of the Berlitz shares have been pledged wrongly," Mr. Coyle said. In addition, he said, about 60 million ($109.2 million) was missing from Maxwell Communication's pension fund.
The discovery that the Berlitz shares had been pledged as security for a loan has delayed -- and could scuttle -- a deal that Maxwell Communication struck last month to sell the Berlitz stake to Fukutake Publishing of Japan for $265 million.
 
'No More Skeletons' Seen
 Asked tonight whether the Price Waterhouse examination had found signs that even more could be missing, Mr. Coyle said, "There's no more skeletons as far as we can see."
Even so, analysts say that at best, the value of the company's assets is probably equal to that of its debts and, depending on how much of the stolen assets can be recovered, may be worth less than the debts.
Mr. Laister, the Maxwell Communication chairman, stressed that the "problems relate principally to the burden of debt in Maxwell Communication Corporation itself and do not diminish the underlying strengths of our world-class businesses." Another big question, of course, is how the banks will now fare. The banks had been estimating that they might have to write off 30 percent to 50 percent of their loans. Banks believed to have made loans to Maxwell Communication include: in France, Credit Lyonnais and Credit Agricole; in Britain, Lloyds, Barclays and Midland; Swiss Bank; Swiss Volksbank; Bank of Nova Scotia, and some Japanese banks.

HEADLINE: G.M. Woes Add to Pressure on Saturn

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN

 BODY:
Detroit's pronouncements ricochet around Spring Hill, Tenn., like bullets off a tin fence. On the other side of a knoll in the tiny town south of Nashville, the nation's No. 1 auto maker is feeling its way into the future of car manufacturing and trying -- sometimes fitfully, sometimes earnestly -- to shake off the sins of the past.
So it is not surprising that an ominous announcement from General Motors' headquarters last Wednesday raised tensions at G.M.'s Saturn factory. As the corporation braces for a major round of plant closings and layoffs at its 32 North American assembly plants, the pressure builds for Saturn to deliver on its promise to efficiently build high-quality cars and to teach G.M. the ways of the future. 
 "When I hear about G.M. layoffs it makes me that much more determined to make Saturn a great product," said Randy Sneed, a Saturn technician who teaches workers how to be more efficient and who had suffered through layoffs at other G.M. plants.
"Maybe for people who don't understand the situation, it will open their eyes," Mr. Sneed continued. "This really is our last chance. Some people who came down here haven't been laid off before. I'm not sure they were taking competition seriously."
For G.M., the competition is serious and so are the problems of the company, which has suffered from the recession and from a shrinking market share. Its plants, which can build 6.5 million to 7 million cars and light trucks a year, need to turn out only about 5 million vehicles for today's weak market -- a far cry from the corporate goal of achieving 100 percent capacity by 1993.
All that has G.M. hurtling toward a loss this year in the United States and Canada of up to $8 billion, its biggest ever.
As a consequence, a lot of people are watching the $3.5 billion Saturn experiment. When it was conceived in the early 1980's, G.M. vowed to do whatever it took to come up with the very best way to build cars.
Now, billions of dollars later and 13 months into production, Saturn is turning out nifty small coupes and sedans that draw praise from buyers, many of whom say they would otherwise have bought Japanese cars.
But the cars are not coming out of the factory as fast as G.M. had hoped. There are production problems, like the balky window cranks one day recently that trimmed output by 750 cars. There have been recalls for broken seat latches and for bad engine coolant.
All of that reflects the difficulties of a start-up manufacturing organization in which the work force and the product are new and the manufacturing rules are stricter than at other G.M. plants. In October, labor strife, which G.M. and the union had hoped to avoid in Spring Hill, flared briefly when workers realized that the number of defects in cars was ballooning. Thousands of workers, worried that quality was being sacrificed for greater output, donned armbands in a silent expression of their frustration when G.M.'s chairman, Robert C. Stempel, visited the plant.
Saturn executives do not appear panicked by the slow start-up or by any labor tension, and the fledgling division, seen as more laboratory than factory, will likely be spared in this latest G.M. retrenchment.
The bosses in Detroit have promised not to push Saturn for results too quickly. Saturn executives predict that output will improve steadily as factory-floor glitches are ironed out. With better output, the dealer network can be expanded, more cars can be sold and G.M. can inch closer to a payoff for this tremendously expensive project.
"We're always criticized for short-term thinking," said Don Hudler, Saturn's vice president of sales and dealer relations. "Profitability will come, but it's not most important right now."
 What G.M. thinks is important now is to sharpen its manufacturing skills. For years, experts said that American auto makers were neglecting manufacturing at their peril. Detroit took longer than the Japanese to build cars -- at one point 40 percent longer -- and the vehicles still turned out poorly. The American companies tried to automate parts of the assembly line with robots -- sometimes with disastrous results -- but the Japanese improved even more.
With Saturn, G.M. took a clean sheet of paper and attempted to redefine how American workers could make high-quality cars at low cost.
G.M. decided in 1985 to sink a fortune into a "different kind of car company," as Saturn advertises itself, and build a plant and a corporate culture in Tennessee.
 
'Lean' Production
 In the mid-1980's, researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology studied the Toyota Motor Corporation's production system, a profound departure from the mass-production technique of Henry Ford. Their findings, in a book entitled "The Machine That Changed the World," became gospel for Saturn engineers.
In essence, auto makers were taught to cut waste and inventory to a minimum, and to use workers' brains as well as their brawn. M.I.T. called it "lean" manufacturing. Other auto makers are superimposing "lean" principles on their current systems, while Saturn is an attempt to build an entire system around the concept.
According to the shop-floor gospel at Saturn, what is important is the nitty-gritty of machines. By training workers and honing basic skills, Toyota learned to make extremely precise parts with very little scrap, M.I.T. researchers discovered. In turn, reliability was increased and consumers were pleased.
In the case of balky car-door windows, for example, Saturn engineers could not immediately determine whether the window glass was the wrong size, the frame was built imprecisely or the handle mechanism was faulty.
 
 
Confronting Problems Quickly
 At traditional G.M. plants, workers might have concentrated on repairing individual windows, rather than on rooting out the cause of defects. An inventory of windows would be accumulated. In a "lean" system like Saturn's, every glitch is confronted instantly; until each problem is resolved, nothing further is manufactured. "When you bank parts, little problems tend to get ignored," said Robert Boruff, Saturn's vice president of manufacturing. "This way, we have no choice but to fix them." In the short run, of course, fewer cars are produced.
Longer-term, sharper skills result in swift, dependable production. Ideally, the "lean" factory comes to resemble an industrial ballet, where parts are built just as they are needed and quality is so high that inspection is virtually redundant.
To clear the way for an entirely new factory culture, G.M. thought it needed a new relationship with its hourly workers. Saturn's labor agreement with the United Automobile Workers union differs from the G.M. pacts at its other plants. At Saturn, workers receive constant training and are expected to participate in business decisions. One example: line workers who install taillights saved the company $650,000 by determining that the more costly deluxe lights were identical to the regular lights and could be dispensed with at great savings.
Saturn workers can still strike, and executives can still lay off workers, though both steps are regarded as remote possibilities.
And workers on the line tend to bridle any time they think engineers and managers are not attacking quality concerns aggressively enough. "They are very hard on their leaders," said Mike Bennett, president of the union. "They always want to know why things aren't fixed yet."
 
 
Defects Began to Rise
 Last summer, as negotiators began to bargain for the first-ever revisions to the Saturn labor contract, the number of defects per car started climbing. Workers were alarmed, Mr. Duncan said. Moreover, workers complained of increasing delays by engineers who fixed machines.
"Everyone was pushing themselves to insure quality," said Bill Betts, a Saturn spokesman. "The process wasn't working. People have to be able to assure quality, day-in and day-out, without tension and strain."
Union workers worried that bargaining over pay and benefits might have led to distractions and defects on the assembly line. "People had been excited about finally getting the chance to produce quality," said Mr. Sneed, the Saturn technician. "As time goes on, you can forget what the mission is."
Earl Ice, a Saturn assembly supervisor, who has observed Toyota's factory in Georgetown, Ky., said Saturn engineers should spend more time near the assembly line and be more available to production workers. About 500 Saturn engineers are stationed in Troy, Mich., a one-hour flight from Nashville. A spokesman said many engineers must use G.M.'s technical center and proving grounds near Detroit.
 
 
Faster Assembly Coming
 Experts point out that the faster the assembly line is moving, the harder it is to maintain quality. James Harbour, a manufacturing consultant, said, "Saturn's manufacturing processes should have been proven before the plant went into production."
Nevertheless, Mr. Ice said the current line speed of 50 cars an hour was scheduled to be increased to 68 cars an hour after the New Year. "The windows are running real slick now," he said, a week after engineers spotted and fixed several machines producing parts that differed slightly from specifications.
The final judgment on Saturn, which is probably years off, will be whether it can build cars of high quality and build them profitably. That should be decided when production finally hits its peak, and if the buyers are still attracted to the car. At that stage, G.M. may have the privilege and the headache of deciding whether to revamp all of its plants in Saturn's image.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Happy End to Tale of Mass Transit Aid

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
On the same day in November that Congress promised to almost double spending on mass transportation, the Office of Management and Budget produced a memorandum proposing that it be cut nearly in half instead.
Poorly coordinated White House staff work? A devious maneuver intended to thwart the intent of Congress? 
 The answer hardly matters, promoters of mass transportation say. They expect Samuel K. Skinner, who became White House chief of staff today, to squash the suggestion quickly because he considers it both bad management and bad politics.
In his three years as Transportation Secretary, Mr. Skinner often felt the sharp knives of the budget director, Richard G. Darman, who routinely pared the Transportation Department's requests for mass transportation in the spending requests the White House sent to Congress each winter. The lawmakers routinely restored much of the money, but mass transportation hardly thrived. After accounting for inflation, Federal aid to the states for mass transportation was cut in half in the 1980's.
In the next six fiscal years, all that is supposed to change. Not only did the transportation bill, approved by Congress before Thanksgiving, set aside $32 billion for mass transportation through the 1998 fiscal year, it gave the states the power to shift some of their highway aid to bus and subway projects if they chose.
The White House was not happy with all the bill's provisions, especially its subsidies for mass transportation systems whose fares cannot cover daily operating expenses. But the Administration has embraced the bill as a powerful economic stimulus, and President Bush is set to sign it on Wednesday.
Local transportation agencies were just uncorking the champagne to celebrate the expected signing of the bill when they learned that the White House budget office was still playing Scrooge. The office wanted the Transportation Department to scale back its mass transportation request for the 1993 fiscal year, which begins next Oct. 1, to around $2 billion. This year's budget was $3.8 billion.
Jack R. Gilstrap, executive vice president of the American Public Transit Association, complained to the President last week, "I would be extremely disappointed to think that your Administration was preparing a budget that cuts funding for the Federal transit program at the same time that you are about to sign into law an act that emphasizes the importance of transit."
Brian Clymer, the administrator of the Urban Mass Transit Administration, set out to soothe those worried about the budget office memorandum.
"I think it is very much up in the air," Mr. Clymer said in an interview. "The executive review process is a lengthy one. We begin our budget in March, and it doesn't culminate for a couple of weeks yet."
The budget office's recommendation is "only one step," he continued. "I don't think that is by any stretch of the imagination the end game."
Such talk shows how confident Mr. Clymer must be that Mr. Skinner, who is now Mr. Darman's boss, will back him in the negotiations with Mr. Darman. After all, both Mr. Skinner and Mr. Clymer once headed major transportation agencies, in Chicago and Philadelphia, respectively.
The resolution of the immediate dispute notwithstanding, it appears that mass transportation spending will not be going up quite as fast as some had hoped in any case, at least not right away.
That is because the transportation measure that passed Congress last month was an authorization bill that sets policy and establishes broad spending outlines, and it must be followed by an appropriations bill that actually allows checks to be sent to the states.
And it is the appropriations that end up figuring in the Federal deficit and must comply with Governmentwide budget agreements.
"If I were a betting man, I would say you will probably not see a jump from $3.8 billion up to $5.2 billion or $5.3 billion," Mr. Clymer said. Instead, he suggested, spending might increase by about $400 million or $500 million next year.
"Am I optimistic it is going to go up?" he asked. "The answer is, yes."
But he noted, "I can't take authorizations to the bank."

HEADLINE: 6 in Search Of an Image;
Democrats Strain To Be Presidential

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
Republicans were chortling today over Sunday night's debate, asserting that the six major Democratic Presidential contenders, as a class, seemed unpresidential. When reporters asked President Bush who won the debate, he pointed to himself.
Republican smugness aside, the first major debate of the 1992 campaign showed that the Democrats are still learning how to use a critical shot at prime time. The group portrait was contentious at best, the individual performances varied widely, and no one seemed to make a significant break from the pack, in the view of many political professionals. 
 "When they write the 'Making of the President, 1992,' this debate won't get mentioned much," said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic poll taker.
 
A Plus for Kerrey
 Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, widely seen in Democratic circles as an underachiever since he entered the race, was cited by many political professionals today as the candidate who most helped himself. Former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California was probably most successful in getting his message across, but some analysts suggested that the abrasive style of the messenger may negate the message.
In general, each of the candidates had to struggle against the limitations of the genre. "Multi-candidate debates are not a pretty sight," said Michael McCurry, an adviser to Senator Kerrey. "When you're up there with six people, trying to be distinctive and Presidential is not easy."
Kathleen Hall Jamieson, an expert on political communication at the University of Pennyslvania, said it was impossible to look Presidential on a stage with five other men, a 60-second cap on speech and a newscaster looming above the candidate. Lorraine Voles, press secretary to Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, said it "looked like a setup for the 'Newlywed Game.' "
Given that, each candidate entered the debate with his own strategic imperatives ---- some of which they achieved, some of which they did not.
Gov Bill Clinton of Arkansas was coming off a month of good reviews for speeches to Democratic audiences around the country. On Sunday, a few hours before the debate, Mr. Clinton had won a big victory in a straw poll at the Florida Democratic convention -- an event of symbolic importance only, but the kind that matters to political insiders and financial contributors.
 
Clinton Viewed as Low Key
 But the Governor's performance at the debate Sunday night was subdued, low key. His allies called it statesmanlike; his critics suggested he was trying too hard to seem Presidential.
"Somebody must have told him that he had to act Presidential and avoid the fray," said Bob Squier, a Democratic consultant. "if that's Presidential, he should go back to gubernatorial."
Still, Samuel Popkin, a political scientist at the University of California at San Diego, contended that Mr. Clinton and Mr. Harkin were much further along than their rivals in telling the public, in understandable ways, what they would do as President.
Sunday night's debate, which was sponsored by NBC News, was the first of seven nationally televised debates to be held among the major candidates for the Democratic candidates.
Mr. Kerrey has been widely viewed by political professionals as a charismatic candidate who has yet to deliver the goods in his Presidential campaign. In Sunday's debate he tried to introduce himself, and his life story, to the American public. Repeatedly, he cited his experiences as a Navy commando in Vietnam, where he lost his leg and won the Medal of Honor for heroism.
 
Sharp Exchange With Brown
 The Senator also engaged in perhaps the sharpest exchange of the night when he angrily challenged Mr. Brown on his repeated charges that America's politicains were in thrall to special interest money. "Are you saying I'm bought and paid for?" Mr. Kerrey demanded, while Mr. Brown blanched.
Like other analysts, Mr. Popkin gave Mr. Kerrey the edge in that exchange, contending that Mr. Brown "came across as a person who is lucky not to get punched out by some of the others."
Mr. Brown certainly succeeded in grabbing the mantle of the anti-establishment candidate out to rock the system, but some analysts suggested he did it a considerable cost. "He was far too intensne throughout this debate for television," Ms. Jamieson said.
Long plagued by a reputation that depicts him as "Governor Moonbeam," Mr. Brown may have only fed the image of eccentrity in Sunday night's debate, some analysts said.
Senator Harkin entered the debate with a reputation as a fire and brimstone orator with a firm control on traditional Democratic economics. Political professionals said he effectively stuck to his themes, which was not a small accomplishment in the free-wheeling atmosphere of Sunday night's debate. Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts came across as thoughtful to many political professionals, but also non-telegenic.
Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia seemed to be making a concerted appeal for black votes, delivering an unstinting defense of civil rights generally and affirmative action in particular, and assailing the White House for fostering a poor racial climate.
Ronald H. Brown, the Democratic national chairman, described the debate as "a pretty good introduction to our candidates." By Friday, which isthe filing deadline for the New Hampshire primary, Democrats should know whether the next debate will include Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York.
With or without him, Democrats are moving into prime time. And with just nine weeks before New Hampshire, they have little time to adjust.

HEADLINE: Citing Bill of Rights, Bush Praises Limits On the Government

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ORANGE, Va., Dec. 16

 BODY:
In a speech commemorating the 200th anniversary of the Bill of Rights, amid references to high principle and power, President Bush today threaded his own election-year argument: that the principles of limited Government adopted by the Founding Fathers were reflected in the policies of the Bush Administration.
Speaking at Montpelier, the majestic hunt-country estate of President James Madison, the foremost drafter of the Bill of Rights, Mr. Bush made no explicit pitch for votes or blunt attacks on his Democratic challengers. His major point was that the Bill of Rights, the first 10 amendments to the Constitution, was not so much a declaration of freedoms as "a set of legally enforceable constraints" that set out "stark" limits on government power. 
 But along the way, Mr. Bush repeatedly suggested that Madison and other founders would frown on what he described as the liberal fiscal and legislative habits of today's Government.
He never explicitly mentioned the debate over a national health-care system or complaints about excessive Federal spending and Congressional perquisites, all of which have resonated with voters in elections and political speeches this fall. But at times his remarks appeared to be a veiled response to Democratic critics who had contended that the White House was not marshaling the vast powers of Government to help citizens in distress.
 
Arguing for Limits
 "The genius of the Bill of Rights is that it limits its attention to truly important things -- and to things over which a just and limited Government can exercise some actual control," Mr. Bush said. "Today one often hears the concept of rights attached to specific social services or material standards of living. The framers, however, did not elevate acquisition of even the most vital goods and services to the status of rights."
Rather, he said, Madison and others believed that the grant of freedom empowered people to take care of themselves, and that Government "pateralism is just a sugar-coated tyranny."
Mr. Bush also enlisted a foundation of Madison's philosophy -- the idea that political factions posed the greatest threat to stability in the infant Republic -- to argue that Congress's committee system is dominated by special-interest factions and should be dismantled.
As the President spoke to an audience of about 450 at Montpelier, his new chief of staff, Samuel K. Skinner, began his first day on the job with an upbeat speech to his staff in the White House. Mr. Skinner was said by White House officials to have told the staff that they would be working "day and night" to design a new economic-recovery program.
He also said that he expected to make few changes in a staff inherited from his predecessor, John H. Sununu.
"A great burden has been lifted," one official, who refused to be identified, said of Mr. Skinner's arrival. "It's a breath of fresh air."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush signing a declaration commemorating the 200th anniversary of the Bill of Rights yesterday at Montpelier in Orange, Va., the home of James Madison, the foremost drafter of the Bill of Rights. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Nassau Board Votes Budget Of Austerity

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 16

 BODY:
The Nassau County Board of Supervisors, in a sweeping repudiation of both higher taxes and the incumbent County Executive, adopted a budget today that sharply curtailed spending and called for thousands of layoffs.
The $1.9 billion budget eliminated $122 million, three-quarters of a tax increase proposed by the County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, last month, but at the expense of programs and amenities that residents of this affluent suburb have come to take for granted. 
 Recreation programs, including the county's free concerts and its puppetmobile, are likely to be eliminated, money for senior centers has been cut, health clinic hours will be reduced and officials at the county's medical center warned that it would have to shut down wards and clinics.
 
'Deepening Economic Depression'
 Joseph N. Mondello, the board's Republican majority leader, said that the cuts were the all but inevitable product of a "deepening economic depression" that left many suburban families unable to pay ever-rising taxes and "in severe economic peril, unable to put food on the table."
"From every town and every community of this great county, a clear and unequivocal message is resonating: the people of this county must have tax relief," he said. "Many county services will undoubtedly cease to exist, and others will be scaled back significantly."
As he spoke, the County Executive looked on glumly. Both he and Mr. Mondello wore blue ribbons in their lapels, a symbol of a growing tax revolt movement in the county.
Mr. Gulotta did not speak during the meeting and did not meet with reporters afterward. He issued a two-paragraph statement saying that the budget was "in many respects better than the one that was originally proposed."
But he warned that it could produce a deficit and damage the county's credit rating, and he pledged to "implement additional and more dramatic cuts" throughout the year.
One aide to Mr. Gulotta said that this could eventually result in the layoff of as many as 4,000 of the county's 17,000 employees. In a gibe that is a staple of politics here, he added: "It is a Brooklyn budget. It will result in a quality of service comparable to that in New York City."
The new budget was put together by Mr. Mondello, who is also the Republican county leader, and other Republican members on the board over the last few weeks after Mr. Gulotta, also a Republican, proposed a budget that raised property taxes 25 percent and imposed a new sales tax on home heating oil.
The two increases proposed by Mr. Gulotta would have raised taxes on an average homeowner by about $400 a year, on top of an earlier steep increase in school taxes. The proposals caused a revolt both by Democrats, who have long complained of "bloated" spending by Republicans who have controlled the Legislature for 75 years, and by Republicans, who found themselves on the defensive.
As the board convened today before hundreds of people packed in the Board of Supervisors' room here, while county fire marshals kept others out, the Democrats presented a plan that would roll back only a third of the proposed county tax increases -- then quickly tabled their motion when they learned that the Republicans were proposing much deeper cuts in spending.
"They did a good job in cutting, but unfortunately it did not go far enough," said Gregory P. Peterson, a Republican supervisor from the Town of Hempstead.
 
Abstaining on Their Own Plan
 The two Democrats on the board, Benjamin L. Zwirn, the supervisor of the Town of North Hempstead, and Bruce Nyman, the Democratic Mayor of Long Beach, abstained on their own budget proposal, saying they needed more time to perfect it.
Instead the board adopted the Republican plan along party lines. It eliminated the tax on home heating oil and reduced the property tax increase to 9 percent, or $76 for a typical family.
To accomplish this, it cut spending by $122 million, or 6 percent. But with most of the budget going to essential services or those mandated by law, like welfare, police and corrections, the cuts fell far deeper in other areas.
But in making their reductions, the Republicans on the board deeply undermined the authority of the Republican County Executive and reduced the expensive services that have provided patronage jobs and won the loyalty of Nassau County voters.
Peter King, the Republican Nassau County Comptroller, said that personnel costs in most agencies would be cut by 22 percent under the budget. Spending on county purchases, printing, postage, consulting fees and library subsidies would be trimmed.
 
Culture and Development
 Grants to cultural groups and spending on economic development, county museums and recreation programs would be cut in half, along with county spending on senior centers and community services.
The board, using legislative prerogative, simply wrote in $65 million in personnel cuts and left it for the County Executive to fill in the details. Among the choices, the board said that the layoff of 800 part-time workers, 377 temporary full-time workers and 350 seasonal workers, along with 1,000 regular county employees, would save the $65 million.
Dr. Tracy E. Strevey Jr., executive director of Nassau County Medical Center, said the new budget would eliminate all county subsidies for the hospital, including the $15 million it provided last year to pay for the care for the poor.
"I know of no other public hospital cast loose by its government," he said. He said that it could lead to the closing of 30 to 150 patient beds.

HEADLINE: Supreme Court Roundup;
Court Rules Reservists in Training Have Unlimited Job Leave

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
The Supreme Court ruled today that military reservists and National Guard members who entered full-time military training programs were legally entitled to unlimited leaves of absence from their civilian jobs.
Voting 8 to 0, the Court overturned a ruling by a Federal appeals court that Congress had implicitly required such leaves to be of "reasonable" duration. That decision, issued in 1990 by the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit in Atlanta, held that a Birmingham, Ala., hospital could reject as "unreasonable" a Guarsdman's request for a three-year leave of absence to serve in a full-time position as Alabama's top enlisted Guardsman. 
 In an opinion today by Justice David H. Souter, the Supreme Court said the Federal law that protected the civilian jobs of those in military service was "utterly silent abut any durational limit on the protection it provides."
The law at issue, the Veterans' Re-employment Rights Act, requires employers to grant reservists and National Guard members leaves of absence "for the period required to perform active duty for training or inactive duty training in the armed forces of the United States."
The decision today does not apply to reservists who are called to active duty by Presidential order, like those men and women who were sent to the Persian Gulf. They are protected by another section of the law guaranteeing a four-year leave.
The case today applies to those who serve in special training programs that require full-time duty of six months to three years. Some 45,000 reservists and National Guard members are currently on such tours of "active duty for training."
Federal courts were split over the re-employment rights of those seeking extended leaves under these programs. Three Federal appellate circuits had concluded that the statute implicitly incorporated a "reasonableness" requirement, while another ruled last year that it did not.
The Federal Government, arguing that it was essential to enable people to serve in the special training programs "free from economic insecurity," represented the Alabama guardsman whose leave was at issue. William (Sky) King, a hospital administrator, was a 35-year veteran of the Alabama Guard when he sought appointment as command sergeant major, the top enlisted position in the state Guard.
This position requires a three-year tour of full-time duty. Mr. King's employer, St. Vincent's, went to Federal court for a ruling on whether it was obliged under law to honor his request.
Justice Clarence Thomas did not participate in the case, King v. St. Vincent's Hospital, No. 90-889, which was argued in October, before he joined the Court.
Other decisions at the Court today included these:
 
Restrictions on Aliens
 The Court unanimously upheld an Immigration and Naturalization Service regulation, adopted in 1983, that bars aliens who are facing deportation proceedings from obtaining "unauthorized employment."
As interpreted by the Court today in an opinion by Justice John Paul Stevens, the regulation means that aliens who are arrested and threatened with deportation may not hold jobs during a temporary period of release from custody if they do not have green cards or other authorization to work.
The decision, I.N.S. v. National Center for Immigrants' Rights, No. 90-1090, overturned a ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit in California. That court interpreted the regulation more broadly as applying even to aliens who had work authorization, and invalidated the regulation as unauthorized by law.
 
Safety Regulation
 Accepting an appeal by the State of Illinois, the Court agreed to decide whether states have the discretion, without prior Federal approval, to issue regulations that protect both public health and worker safety at hazardous waste sites.
The safety of workers at such locations is regulated by a Federal agency, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration. Under principles of Federal pre-emption, a state may issue more stringent job safety regulations only after first submitting its plan for the Federal agency's review.
In this case, Gade v. National Solid Wastes Management Assoc., No. 90-1676, Illinois sought to protect not only worker safety but public health in the vicinity of hazardous waste sites, a goal that is not part of the Federal agency's mandate. The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit in Chicago, ruled that "dual purpose" state regulations of this type were also pre-empted.
 
Drug Testing
 Without comment, the Court refused to hear a constitutional challenge to the Justice Department's drug-testing policy, under which lawyers tentatively accepted for employment with the department must submit to a urinalysis.
The challenge was brought by a lawyer, Carl Willner, who had tentatively been offered a job in the department's antitrust division. After the department refused to waive the rule, Mr. Willner sued on the ground that the test, in the absence of any suspicion of drug use, was an unreasonable search in violation of the Fourth Amendment.
Judge Gerhard A. Gesell of Federal District Court here agreed, declaring the test unconstitutional. But the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit overturned that ruling in a 2-to-1 decision, with Judge A. Raymond Randolph stating in the majority opinion, "If individuals view drug testing as an indignity to be avoided, they need only refrain from applying" for a job at the Justice Department.
Mr. Willner's appeal was Willner v. Barr, No. 91-448.

HEADLINE: Lawmakers' Constituents Complain About Economy, and Congress Itself

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
When Representative Rick Santorum went back to his constituents in a Pittsburgh suburb last week, he heard an angry message that politicians were indifferent to American workers and not tough enough on foreign competition.
In western Massachusetts, Representative Richard E. Neal was told that scared bankers and timid regulators were blocking the commercial loans that might give the economy a lift. 
 Representative Tim Roemer went home to northern Indiana and heard complaints that deficit spending seemed to accomplish little beyond increasing the national debt and the interest payments on it.
The greetings that members of Congress usually get these days when they go home to meet the voters are gripes about the economy. Local circumstances and political styles change the emphasis, but as they return to their districts, lawmakers are confronted with an underlying message of economic concern at least as likely to affect legislation here next year as anything said in hearings in the Senate Finance Committee or the House Ways and Means Committee.
 
Pressure for Action
 Sometimes the voters, or the lawmakers, offer specific solutions to the problems raised, like tariffs on Japanese cars, or a "Marshall Plan" to revitalize the American economy. But there is also occasional pressure for action of almost any kind from the President and Congress.
"Just doing something will give people more confidence," Greg Chase, president of a concrete company, told Mr. Neal, a Democrat, in Mr. Chases's office in East Brookfield on Thursday.
Complaints about Congress itself are frequent fare, and the complaints come from both sides. Mr. Roemer, a Democrat, insists that Congress needs change and scorns pork-barrel spending. Mr. Santorum, a Republican, attacks his colleagues, saying that "most Congressmen don't want their people to know what they're doing," especially how they vote.
Here is what these three junior members of the House have been hearing in their districts.
 
Richland Township, Pa.
Sense of Losing The Trade War
 The economic issue that angered Representative Santorum's constituents on Wednesday was trade, most of all trade with Japan and the American jobs lost in the process.
Town meetings, with residents invited by official mail, are a typical way members of Congress meet constitutents, and the freshman Republican held his 46th of the year in the municipal building here. The audience was dotted with men in windbreakers identifying the shrinking industrial giants they now or once worked for: U.S. Steel, Westinghouse, and PPG.
"Congress can't enact any legislation to balance the trade deficit with Japan," complained J. Alder Erikson, who was wearing a PPG jacket.
 
'We're in a Trade War'
 Another who attended the meeting, John Antantis, voiced this complaint: "There's no more $14- or $15-an-hour jobs for American workers."
Howard Fahnestock came with complaints and proposals. He said politicians were "cavalier about the plight of the working man" and insisted: "We're in a trade war. We've been in one for 20 years, and we're losing it."
When he demanded "immediately impose tariffs on Japanese automobiles," someone shouted "don't forget the Germans."
The only aspect of the trade issue that drew a detailed response from Mr. Santorum was criticism of his vote for expedited trade negotiations with Mexico. George Skillness asserted, "You're going to take jobs away from American workers." Mr. Santorum insisted he would vote against the free-trade treaty if the Bush Administration came back to Congress with a bad one, but said, "I don't think we can put walls around the United States and say we won't deal with Mexico."
He told them he favored an economic growth package, one that used capital gains tax cuts to expand the economy. He scorned Democrats for complaining that the benefits of such a cut went to the wealthy, saying, "This wasn't supposed to be and isn't supposed to be a fair tax program; what it's supposed to be is something to get the economy and more jobs created."
 
Blaming Bush and Congress
 Mr. Santorum is a follower of Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Republican whip who pressed the tax issue just before Congress adjourned, regardless of the White House's lack of enthusiasm.
Mr. Santorum criticized President Bush over that diffidence. He said: "I blame the President as much as I blame the Congress. The President was as indecisive as the leaders of the Congress."
But he offered the 50 constituents at the meeting little hope for wise Congressional action. He scoffed at Congress for efforts to "embarrass the President" and an "unwillingness to face the issues that people really were talking about in America, such as the economy, such as health care, such as the budget deficit."
 
Springfield, Mass.
Where Bank Failed, Tight Money Hurts
 In western Massachusetts, the economic enemy whom Representative Neal's constitutents worry about is not overseas but down at the corner: their local banker.
Tom Schmitt, an electrical contractor, told Mr. Neal today that "nobody can get any money" for construction. John Bolduc, head of the local real estate brokers group, said, "Builders today can't go out and buy land and borrow to build a subdivision."
In East Brookfield, Mr. Chase, president of Chase Precut Concrete, told the second-term Democrat, "We seem to be spending 30 to 40 percent of our management time trying to do something that will be acceptable to the bankers." And Richard Chabot, who runs an auto body shop, said, "A lot of banks are in such serious trouble they don't want to hear anything commercial whatever."
The problem is that banks here are short of money and are refusing to renew commercial loans, even to customers who have always paid on time.And as real estate values have fallen, so did the value of the collateral that borrowers once posted to back loans, and immediate payment is now being demanded of some of those loans.
Mr. Neal has argued here and in the House Banking Committee that Federal regulators have overreacted to the failure of the Bank of New England and are now too severe in their standards for classifying loans. He contends that the economy is being hurt when customers who make their payments on time are still having loans canceled.
A lot of people are out of work in Mr. Neal's district. An old friend, John Collins, business manager of Local 7 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, told him that about 200 of the local's 650 members were jobless.
In past recessions, he said, they could always find work out of state, but construction is slow "and there's no work in the whole United States," he said. The union has been collecting surplus food, but many members are too proud to take the handouts.
Wherever he went, Mr. Neal was told that besides encouraging loans from the bankers the Government had to take action to stimulate the economy.
There was no consensus on what should be done. Mr. Collins wanted a tax cut to help the middle class. Mr. Bolduc said almost any decisive action would spur confidence. So did Mr. Chase. And Mr. Neal observed, "The idea of a tax cut seems irresistible at this point."
But the attitude of banks was seen as the biggest problem. "If a viable business in the Springfield area wants to expand, they won't, because they can't get the money," said Mr. Bolduc.
And at the Quaboag Corporation, a shoe company in East Brookfield, Herbert Varnum, the chairman, said bankers' demands were forcing him to change the way he wanted to run the company. He said he was being required to keep a smaller inventory than he thought sound. " 'Friendly banker' is an oxymoron these days," he said.
 
Middlebury, Ind.
Calls for Changes In U.S. Spending
 Representative Roemer, the Democrat who won back this northern Indiana district in 1990 after it spent a decade in Republican hands, hears very little about tax cuts. But deficit spending bothers his voters.
"The budget just goes up and up," James Ebersol complained Friday at a town meeting here. "And every day that our Congress is in business the deficit goes up one billion dollars."
Mr. Roemer sympathized, said he favored a constitutional amendment to require a balanced budget and added that he had voted against popular spending measures.
At an earlier town meeting in nearby Bristol, Gunnar Erikson asked: "When you talk with your colleagues, don't they get the same story: that people want to know what they're going to do about the deficit? The 15 percent we're paying for interest would pay for so many things" if it did not have to go to service the debt.
 
Fears on Assembly Line
 But ending the budget deficit was not the only message about government spending. On the noisy assembly line at EWI Inc., an automobile stamping plant in South Bend, workers asked if he might be able to steer any Government contracts their way.
EWI is a 300-worker success story. The plant was about to be closed last spring when Mr. Roemer and state and city officials arranged its sale to an out-of-state investor and members of the United Automobile Workers took a pay cut to get a new start for the factory, whose huge stamping presses date from 1944 when Studebaker was building an amphibious vehicle called the Weasel.
The plant's immediate success is shadowed by fears for the future, and that typifies much of the economy of this district. There are victories, like a new headquarters for National Steel, and setbacks, like the closing of a Uni
royal tire plant and fears for the health insurance of retirees.
Mr. Roemer told several audiences today that the solution to long-term economic ills, not just for this district but the nation, was a domestic Marshall Plan to revive the economy. An eager supporter of the rather general proposal of Representative Ray Thornton, Democrat of Arkansas, Mr. Roemer said such a long-range development plan was vastly preferable to a "quick fix" tax cut.
Recalling the rebuilding of post-war Europe that was proposed by Secretary of State George C. Marshall in 1949, Mr. Roemer said such a plan would have three elements. One would be "education, so that we get the best trained work force."
A second element would be "transportation, rebuilding highways and bridges so we can transport our commerce and our goods and our people."
Third, the plan would help "our businesses get access to capital to modernize and retool and keep pace in an international environment" to compete with the Japanese and the Germans.
Asked later how he could both balance the budget and finance such a domestic plan, he said the balanced budget might have to wait.

HEADLINE: Damascus Journal;
Fist May Be of Iron, but Is Assad's Hand Weak?

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DAMASCUS, Syria

 BODY:
At nightfall a huge lighted sign, perched on Kassioun Mountain overlooking Damascus, blinks on with the message, "Congratulations to the People."
The newest addition to the capital's landscape celebrates the results of a recent referendum that gave President Hafez al-Assad 99.9 percent of the vote, extending his 21-year rule by seven more years. 
 Syria has been convulsed by campaign frenzy and victory celebrations for the last few weeks, although there is no legal opposition and voters were able to check only "yes" or "no" to the President's continued rule on ballots marked under the watchful eye of Government officials.
Schoolchildren have been let out of class and Government employees from offices to march through the streets. Banners and strings of carnival lights hang from the shops, and pictures of the President are plastered throughout the city.
"The whole effort is aimed at sanctifying the system and the President," said Jamal Atassi, a former Cabinet minister and one of the few critics of the Government who is willing to be quoted by name. "Those who rule this totalitarian state see the people as objects to be manipulated, and they use these spectacles to justify their hold on power."
 
Assad's Reign in Trouble
 But underneath the carefully staged euphoria the reign of President Assad is in trouble. Stripped of his old patron the Soviet Union, mired in a centralized economy that is grinding to a halt, dependent on a security apparatus that is widely hated and unable to check rampant corruption, the Government has adopted the tactics of its discredited Soviet-bloc mentors to justify its legitimacy, rather than the democratic reforms demanded by its Western critics.
The Syrians hope to mend their relations with the United States and get their name off the State Department's list of countries that sponsor terrorism, a move that would qualify them for American aid for the first time since the list was created in 1979.
The Government played a supporting role in the release of Western hostages in Lebanon, sent troops to the Persian Gulf in the war against Iraq, has taken part in the Middle East peace talks and expelled some notorious terrorists, including the man known as Carlos, who diplomats believe may have taken refuge in Baghdad. The Government does still harbor the Nazi war criminal Alois Brunner.
The country's abysmal human rights record, which includes total control of the press and the refusal to permit internal opposition, as well as continuing support for a wide variety of militant groups, including radical Palestinian factions, makes any reconciliation soon unlikely. The State Department's report on human rights says, "Syria is ruled by an authoritarian regime which does not hesitate to use force against its citizens when it feels it is threatened."
 
Constant Political Propaganda
 The Government uses everything from the army to schools to pound home its political propaganda.
The Ibn Khaldoon Boys High School is a cavernous building with 1,285 students. The students, dressed in olive green army fatigues, sit in classrooms adorned with pictures of the President and posters with his sayings.
For one hour a day they are given "political" lectures on the triumphs of the ruling Arab Baath Socialist Party and its leader, President Assad. The state-mandated curriculum includes books that teach children as young as 12 how to dismantle automatic weapons and highlights what are described as great moments in Middle East history, including the 1983 suicide bombing by pro-Iranian Shiite Muslims in Beirut that killed 241 American servicemen.
"The boys put these pictures up because of their love for the President," Mohammed Tishir Refi, the 60-year-old principal, said as he stood in a junior-year physics class adorned with over a dozen pictures of President Assad.
But his comment brought visible smirks and a few low chuckles.
"Most of us want to get out of the country," a student said. "We dream about going abroad."
The Baath Party is dominated by Mr. Assad's tiny Alawite sect, which embraces 11 percent of the population and is an offshoot of Shiite Islam. Family members, including Mr. Assad's son Basil, who has been designated the heir apparent, and other members of the sect control the military, internal security, the party and many of the trading monopolies.
 
'Free Hand' for Corruption
 Party bureaucrats travel about the capital in gleaming new Mercedes and BMW cars. They have private planes and expansive villas.
"The public has no say and no real knowledge of the inner workings of the regime," said the 69-year-old French-educated Mr. Atassi, a psychiatrist whose car was bombed and passport revoked and who lost his university post after he broke with the party in 1973. "This gives the bureaucrats a free hand to engage in corruption."
About 60 percent of the country's 12.5 million people are under 20, and few have many prospects for jobs. The Government already employs 40 percent of the workforce.
The growing number of alienated youths are often faced with only two possibilities, emigration or allegiance to the Muslim fundamentalists, who mounted an armed rebellion in Hama in 1982 that saw Syrian forces kill some 10,000 people.
"The mosques," a professor said, "are keeping their doors open for these people to file in."
 
Battle Cries Grow Wearisome
 For now the Government is tightly held in place by an extensive secret-police network that includes perhaps a dozen different intelligence agencies. The Government still spends 60 percent of the national budget on the military and state security, although it has abandoned its goal of achieving military parity with Israel.
The struggle against Israel remains the official raison d'etre for the iron-fisted control, used to explain the continued detention of some 7,000 political prisoners and even the shortages of basic goods.
But although most Syrians have little love for the Israelis, they have grown tired of the constant battle cries.
"We want to stop hearing every day about Israeli aggression," a 30-year-old professional woman said, "and start hearing about Syria."

LENGTH: 1371 words

HEADLINE: Tumult Tearing Yugoslavia Is Echoed In Serbs and Croats of Chicago Area

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Dec. 12

 BODY:
When the Rev. Mark Kozina arrived in the United States 40 years ago, he entered a Franciscan seminary "to forgive and forget" the miseries he experienced in wartime Yugoslavia, above all the execution by Serbian forces of his father, a Croatian soldier accused of complicity in atrocities committed by the Nazi collaborators who ruled Croatia in Hitler's stead.
Now, at 58 years of age, Father Kozina struggles with a bad heart and with a Roman Catholic parish in a South Chicago neighborhood where Mexican, Polish and Italian immigrants outnumber the shrinking Croatian community that settled there in the 1890's. In addition, the priest has contended for years with the social and economic fallout from the rusting steel mills, mostly silent now, that dominate the industrial wasteland running down Interstate 90 as it curls around Lake Michigan toward the Illinois-Indiana state line. 
 But for Father Kozina and others in Slag Valley, the nickname this community took in the heyday of Big Steel, the heaviest anxieties these days are rooted far away, in the renewed eruption of ethnic hatreds in Yugoslavia. By some estimates there are more than two million Americans with origins in the warring Yugoslav republics of Croatia and Serbia. One of the largest communities, perhaps as many as 300,000 people divided about equally between the two groups, lives in and around Chicago.
 
Some Mixed Reactions
 For some Americans with links to Yugoslavia, the resonance of the killing and destruction in cities and towns like Dubrovnik and Vukovar has been muted, summoning up a dimly remembered history of ethnic and religious bloodshed. For others, particularly those who still have relatives in the areas under fire, the death and destruction have brought an outpouring of recrimination.
For Father Kozina, whose widowed mother and three sisters remain in Croatia, this has meant reconciling Christian teachings on forgiveness with his, and his parishioners', more personal feelings.
"God, do you listen? Are you there?" the priest recalled asking in a sermon this month at the Sacred Heart Croatian Church, set amid the modest frame and brick homes clustered along the bleak streets of Slag Valley. "How long will it take for you to wake up and see the suffering of the Croatian people?"
The steel centers of Pittsburgh and Cleveland and Chicago drew the main wave of Croatian and Serbian immigrants before and after World War I, creating mixed communities like the one in Slag Valley, where families with roots on both sides of the current conflict live side by side and use some of the same schools and stores. Increasingly in recent years, Serbs and Croatians have intermarried.
 
A Renewal of Bitterness
 But here and elsewhere, much of the harmony has fractured. Serbian-owned stores and restaurants that relied on business from Croatians have been shunned, and vice versa. In many cases, bitterness has welled up in people who thought themselves too American to be stirred by passions that dominated earlier generations.
"I used to think my parents were a little too excited by the whole thing," said Anka Popovich, a 41-year-old American-born speech pathologist who is a spokesman for the St. Sava Cultural Club, an organization supported by many Serbians in Chicago. "When I was a kid, I used to look at my parents and think, 'What are they shouting about?' Now I'm just as excited as they ever were."
Across the Chicago area, Serbians and Croatians have established round-the-clock communications networks. They stay up late into the night monitoring shortwave radio broadcasts from Yugoslavia, and some even use backyard satellite dishes to tune in television transmissions from Zagreb, the Croatian capital, and from Belgrade, the headquarters of Yugoslav and Serb forces. Bulletins on the fighting are circulated by fax machines and debated feverishly at meetings in church halls and cultural centers.
Convinced that the United States can decisively affect the outcome, both sides have produced a blizzard of glossy pamphlets and impassioned statements aimed at persuading Washington to tilt one way or the other in the dispute. Congressmen and editorial writers have been invited to delve deep into Balkan history, a maze that runs from the Austro-Hungarian and Ottoman empires through Tito and the anti-communist Chetniks in Yugoslavia during World War II.
 
Debate Over Independence
 But the object of much of the argument has been Croatia's declaration of independence, which precipitated some of the harshest fighting after it was announced in June.
For now, the Bush Administration has refused to recognize the Croatian breakaway, signaling a preference for Yugoslavia's survival. Croatian Americans accuse Washington of a double standard for its readiness to recognize Ukraine and other breakaway Soviet republics, but not Croatia. Serbian Americans are heartened by the Administration's policy, and insist that Croatia must surrender large tracts of territory that are home to the 600,000 Serbians who live in Croatia.
"If Croatia has the democratic right to secede from Yugoslavia, surely our people have the same right to secede from Croatia," said Jelena Raskovitch, a 24-year-old economics graduate of Northwestern University who has written letters to President Bush and other political leaders urging them not to be influenced by what she regards as a pro-Croatian bias in the news media.
Militants have gone beyond the battle for American minds, injecting ugly undertones into the struggle. Earlier this month vandals daubed Croatian nationalist symbols and Nazi slogans on the walls of the Holy Resurrection Serbian Orthodox Cathedral on Chicago's North Side, the third time in months that a Serbian church in the Chicago area had been attacked. People active on both sides have reported menacing telephone calls, smashed windows and sudden, angry outbursts from strangers in subway trains, buses and banks.
Some have sought more direct involvement in the war. In August, four Croatian men from the Chicago area were arrested in Miami in what the authorities said was a conspiracy to buy $12 million of American arms, including Stinger antiaircraft missiles. Federal agents suggested that the conspiracy was part of a broader effort at illicit gun-running, but Croatians insist that picnics, banquets and church bingo games held across the country in recent months have been dedicated solely to financing shipments of humanitarian aid.
Among Serbians, the Miami arrests are cited as evidence of an endemic violence among Croatians. "Everybody knows about Auschwitz and Buchenwald," said George Bogdanich, 43, a Chicago public relations consultant, "but not about Jasenovac," a World War II death camp run by Croatia's Nazi rulers.
Croatians contend that smuggled weapons are essential in the fight against the Serbian-controlled Yugoslav Army. "Everybody is trying to get arms in there; the Serbs are trying it and so are we," said a Chicagoan with Croatian nationalist links. "You can't fight a modern army with sticks and rosary beads."
In Slag Valley the militancy is muted, perhaps because the majority of Croatian and Serbian residents are second- and third- generation Americans. But strains are evident. The principal Serbian church in the district, St. Archangel Michael's of the Eastern Orthodox rite, lies only five blocks from Father Kozina's church. But the Croatian priest has yet to meet the new pastor of the Serbian church, the Rev. Milos Vesin, who arrived from Switzerland 18 months ago. Father Vesin said he had tried several times to set up a meeting.
In some Slag Valley families such estrangements are dismissed as petty. Jack and Nadine Golich are one of the area's "mixed couples" -- he is a 38-year-old Croatian American who operates a garbage truck, she is a 30-year-old Serbian American who designs floral arrangements. Their son, Jake, 7, jokes over whether he is more Croatian or Serbian.
Over coffee in the couple's living room, Mrs. Golich shook her head at the feuding between the two communities. "We never grew up that way -- you hate the Croatians, you hate the Serbians," she said. "We consider ourselves Americans."

HEADLINE: Bit by Bit, More Gifts To Neediest

BYLINE: By J. PEDER ZANE

 BODY:
The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund recorded more than $100,000 in contributions yesterday, the first time it has reached that level since the 80th annual appeal began on Thanksgiving Day.
The $100,850 in new donations pushed the total amount of contributions to just under $1.6 million. After a slow start, collections for this year's appeal is just $59,000 behind the pace of last year, when a record $4.4 million was raised. 
 Although charitable organizations and public corporations have provided many donations, most of the money has come from private individuals, many of whom have increased their contributions despite the decline in the economy.
"I have donated far more to charities this year than ever before, despite the fact that my own income is not what it was five years ago," Shelia Maris Reilly of Middletown, R.I., wrote in a note with her $25 donation. "There are so many needy people today, and far less in the way of government-supplied resources, that it is entirely necessary and appropriate for every working person with a little to spare to contribute."
 
'I See a Greater Need'
 Lawrence B. Morris Jr. of Darien, Conn., said his $250 donation represented a 25 percent increase over last year's. In making his 45th annual contribution to the fund, David Judson of Manhattan increased his gift 50 percent over last year's, to $300, because, he said: "I see a greater need for help at a time when a lot of people who might contribute are having to cut back. I don't have to. Hope this idea can be extended to others."
Since it was founded in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, who was publisher of The Times, the Neediest Cases Fund has raised money for New York's sick, poor and disabled. What began as the Hundred Neediest Cases has expanded to meet the needs of thousands of people.
As in the past, The Times is covering all of the campaign's overhead so that every dollar collected can be passed directly to seven charities. The money provides many forms of relief, including food for the hungry, homes for the homeless and clothing for those without. The seven charities also use the money to provide job training for the disabled, counseling for drug and alcohol abusers and child abusers and services that address the problems confronted by the victims of AIDS.
As George Ginsberg of Springfield, N.J., noted in a letter with his check, the money for these services comes a dollar at a time. "Last year I contributed the small sum of $3," he wrote. "While this year gave me no windfall, I notice our economy is no better. In fact, I dare say it is worse. So it is only natural that the needy will suffer more. Therefore I felt the least I could was double my contribution. So here is $6."
He continued: "If what I have done could be duplicated by the small contributors like myself, that would help. Let us small givers take care of the small donations and the biggies will take care of themselves."
